(i) Substitutability: This refers to the ability of one input to replace another input in the production process. For example, if labour can substitute for capital to some extent, it indicates substitutability.

 

(ii) Complementarity: This signifies the degree to which inputs work together to enhance production. For instance, labour and machinery might complement each other, where increased use of machinery boosts labour productivity.

 

(iv) Specificity: Specificity refers to how specialized or dedicated an input is to a particular type of production. Highly specific inputs are tailored to a specific task or product, while less specific inputs can be used across different production processes.

Question 87
The companies having business in a large number of countries around the world at present are called:
  • A.Multinational Enterprises (MNEs)
  • B.Multinational Corporations (MNCs)
  • C.Global Corporations (GCs)
  • D.Transnational Corporations (TNCs)
Correct Answer: Global Corporations (GCs)

Global Corporation, also known as a global company, is coined from the base term ‘global’, which means all around the world. It makes sense to assume that a global company is a company that does business all over the world. There aren’t many companies in the world that can boast of having a business presence in every major country. Actually, they probably can be numbered on the fingers of both hands. To be a global company, one needs to introduce not only ones products, but also ones company to people who live in another country. People need to conduct significant research to figure out which country is there best choice for expansion and how to introduce him.

Question 88
Which of the following sources of finance has an implicit cost of capital?
  • A.Equity share capital
  • B.Retained earnings
  • C.Debentures
  • D.Preference share capital
Correct Answer: Retained earnings

Retained Earnings have an implicit cost of capital.

Question 89
Choose the correct code for the following statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:A well-chosen marketing channel must be aligned to company’s marketing strategy with respect to segmentation, targeting and positioning.Statement II:Marketing channel are set of interdependent organizations participating in the process of making the product available for the use of consumption.Codes
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are correct.
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

Marketing channels are the ways that goods and services are made available for use by the consumers. All goods go through channels of distribution, and one’s marketing will depend on the way once goods are distributed. The route that the product takes on its way from production to the consumer is important because a marketer must decide which route or channel is best for his particular product. A well-chosen marketing channel helps benefits all members of the channel, including the ultimate consumer.

 

Few benefits can be:

1. Information Provider

2. Price Stability

3. Promotion

4. Financing

5. Matching demand and supply

Question 90
Match the items of List I with the items of List II and choose the correct answer from the code given below.List I(a) Claims(b) Fringe benefits(c) PerquisitesList II(i) Company car, club membership, paid holidays, furnished house(ii) Telephone/mobile allowance, internet allowance, medical allowance(iii) Canteen, uniform, accident reliefCode:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)

The correct match is given below.

(a) Claims - Telephone/mobile allowance, internet allowance, medical allowance

(b) Fringe benefits - Canteen, uniform, accident relief

(c) Perquisites - Company car, club membership, paid holidays, furnished house

Question 91
Choose the correct code for the following statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:If the value of β2, i.e.µ4σ4, of a distribution gives the value more than 3, its curve isplatykurtic.Statement II:In a moderately asymmetrical distribution, the standard deviation is 1.25 times of mean deviation.Code:
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.
  • C.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.

Karl Pearson defined following three types of curves:

 

1. Normal Curve or Measokurtic Curve: A curve which is neither flat nor peaked is called a normal curve or meso-Kurtic curve. For such type of curve, we have β2 = 3

 

2. Leptokurtic Curve: A curve which is more peaked than the normal curve is called leptokurtic curve. For such type of curve, we have β2 > 3.

 

3. Platykurtic Curve: A curve which is flatter than the normal curve is called platykurtic curve. For such type of curve, we have β2 < 3.

Question 92
The theory suggesting that the patterns of international trade are determined by factor endowment rather than productivity was propounded by which one of the following?
  • A.Adam Smith
  • B.Michael Porter
  • C.David Ricardo
  • D.HeckscherandBertilOhlin
Correct Answer: HeckscherandBertilOhlin

The correct answer is (D) Heckscher and Bertil Ohlin.

 

Heckscher-Ohlin theory, also known as the factor proportions theory, proposes that the patterns of international trade are determined by factor endowments rather than productivity levels. Here's an explanation of each option:

 

(A) Adam Smith: Adam Smith is known for his theory of absolute advantage, which suggests that countries should specialize in producing goods where they have an absolute advantage (i.e., they can produce more efficiently) and then trade with other countries to obtain goods where they don't have an absolute advantage.

 

(B) Michael Porter: Michael Porter is known for his work on competitive advantage and the diamond model, which focuses on factors such as factor conditions, demand conditions, related and supporting industries, and firm strategy, structure, and rivalry.

 

(C) David Ricardo: David Ricardo is known for his theory of comparative advantage, which suggests that countries should specialize in producing goods where they have a comparative advantage (i.e., they have a lower opportunity cost) and then trade with other countries to benefit from the differences in opportunity costs.

 

(D) Heckscher and Bertil Ohlin: Heckscher-Ohlin theory is based on the idea that countries will export goods that require factors of production they have in abundance (factor endowment) and import goods that require factors of production they lack. For example, a country with abundant capital but scarce labour would export capital-intensive goods and import labour-intensive goods.

Question 93
Which one of the following initiatives is not the strategy for managing shortage of employees in an organization?
  • A.Offer incentives to postpone retirement
  • B.Attempt to reduce turnover
  • C.Employee training
  • D.Hire temporary employees
Correct Answer: Employee training

Except ‘Employee training’, all other initiatives mentioned at option A, B and D can be used as strategy for managing shortage of employees in an organization.

Question 94
Which of the following statements relating to the sampling theory are correct?(i) The values of the statistical measures based on the sampled units are called values of statistic.(ii) In the simple random sampling technique, the element of the population and the unit of the sample are different.(iii) Snow-ball sampling technique is a probability-based sampling technique.(iv) The ‘law of statistical regularity’ and the ‘law of large numbers’ are the main bases of the sample to become representative of the population.Choose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes
  • A.(ii) and (iii)
  • B.(i) and (iv)
  • C.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii) and (iii)
Correct Answer: (i) and (iv)

Sampling theory is a study of relationships existing between a population and samples drawn from the population. Sampling theory is applicable only to random samples. For this purpose the population or a universe may be defined as an aggregate of items possessing a common trait or traits. 

 

Following statements related to sampling theory are correct:

(a) The values of the statistical measures based on the sampled units are called values of statistic.

(b) The ‘Law of statistical regularity’ and the ‘Law of large numbers’ is the main bases of the sample to become representative of the population.

(c) Snowball sampling is a non-probability sampling technique that is used by researchers to identify potential subjects in studies where subjects are hard to locate.

Question 95
Which one among the following is the oldest form of organization?
  • A.Committee Organization
  • B.Line Organization
  • C.Project Organization
  • D.Functional Organization
Correct Answer: Line Organization

The oldest form of organization is Line Organization. Line organisation is the simplest and the oldest type of organisation. It is also known as scalar organisation or military type of organisation. In the words of J.M. Lundy, “It is characterized by direct lines of authority flowing from the top to the bottom of the organizational hierarchy and lines of responsibility flowing in an opposite but equally direct manner.”

Question 96
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion “A” and the other labelled as Reason “R”. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below.Assertion “A”:Purchase decisions are not based on how customers perceive prices but, on the marketer’s, stated price.Reason “R”:Customers may have a lower price threshold, below which prices signal inferior or unacceptable quality, and an upper price threshold where the product appears not worth the money.Codes
  • A.“A” is incorrect but “R” is correct.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the right explanation of “A”.
  • C.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is not the right explanation of “A”.
  • D.Both “A” and “R” are incorrect.
Correct Answer: “A” is incorrect but “R” is correct.

The buying decision process is the decision-making process used by consumers regarding market transactions before, during, and after the purchase of a good or service. It can be seen as a particular form of a cost–benefit analysis in the presence of multiple alternatives. Buyers purchase decisions are based on how customers perceive prices and not on marketer’s stated prices.

 

Customers may have a lower price threshold, below which prices signal inferior or unacceptable quality, and an upper price threshold where the product appears not worth the money.

Question 97
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion “A” and the other labelled as Reason “R”. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below.Assertion “A”:Consumers need to be given legal protection against certain trade practices and business methods.Reason “R”:Protection as per market forces and ‘Caveat Emptor’ is not enough as perfectly competitive market is an economist’s dream and consumer sovereignty is a myth.Code:
  • A.“A” is correct but “R” is incorrect.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the right explanation of “A”.
  • C.“A” is incorrect but “R” is correct.
  • D.Both “A” and “R” are correct but “R” is not the right explanation of “A”.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are correct but “R” is not the right explanation of “A”.

The correct answer is (D) Both "A" and "R" are correct, but "R" is not the right explanation of "A."

 

Assertion "A" states that consumers need legal protection against certain trade practices and business methods. This assertion is correct because there are various trade practices and business methods that can harm consumers, such as false advertising, deceptive pricing, unsafe products, and unfair contract terms. Legal protection in the form of consumer protection laws and regulations is necessary to safeguard consumers' rights and interests.

 

Reason "R" states that protection based solely on market forces and the principle of 'Caveat Emptor' (let the buyer beware) is insufficient. It also implies that perfectly competitive markets are idealized in economics but rarely exist in reality, and the notion of consumer sovereignty (where consumers' preferences and choices dictate market outcomes) is often challenged.

 

While Reason "R" makes valid points about the limitations of market forces and the idealized nature of perfectly competitive markets, it does not directly explain why consumers need legal protection against certain trade practices and business methods. The need for legal protection arises from various factors, including asymmetry of information, potential exploitation by businesses, and ensuring fair and ethical market practices.

Question 98
Which one of the following is the main government agency responsible for development and monitoring international trade in India?
  • A.Department of Commerce
  • B.Export Promotion Council
  • C.Indian Institute of Foreign Trade
  • D.Federation of Indian Export Organisations
Correct Answer: Department of Commerce

Department of Commerce is the main government agency responsible for development and monitoring international trade in India.

 

The long-term vision of the Department of Commerce is to make India a major player in the world trade by 2020 and assume a role of leadership in the international trade organizations commensurate with India’s growing importance. The medium-term vision is to double India’s exports of goods and services by 2017-18 over the level of 2008-09 with a long-term objective of doubling India’s share in Global trade.

Question 99
Choose the correct code for the following statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:Punctuality and team spirit among employees of an organization has great contribution in enhancing profits of the business but they do not appear as an asset in the balance sheet.Statement II:Financial statements do not reflect the correct financial position of a business.Codes
  • A.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • C.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect, but II is correct
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

Both the statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement I is correct because punctuality and team spirit are the intangibles which cannot be reflected as an asset in the balance sheet.

 

Statement II is correct as without adequate analysis it cannot be clearly said that financial statements reflect the correct financial position of the business.

Question 100
When RBI reduces CRR, it results into
  • A.Decrease in deposits
  • B.Increase in lendable resources
  • C.Decrease in lendable resources
  • D.Increase in deposits
Correct Answer: Increase in lendable resources

When the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) reduces the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR), it results in an increase in lendable resources. The correct answer is (B).

 

The Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) is the percentage of a bank's total deposit that it must hold in reserve with the central bank (RBI) in the form of cash. When the RBI reduces the CRR, it lowers the amount of reserves that banks are required to hold, freeing up more funds for lending and investment activities. This reduction in the mandatory reserve requirement increases the lendable resources of banks.

Quiz Attempt #119002

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
Michael Porter identified that competitive advantage of a nation is based on certain major attributes. Which of the following are the attributes he postulated?(i) Factor endowments(ii) Superiority of production method in host country(iii) Demand conditions(iv) Firm strategy, structure and rivalry(v) Economies of scale and synergy(vi) Related and supporting industriesSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v)
  • B.(i) (iii) (iv) (v)
  • C.(i) (ii) (iii) (vi)
  • D.(i) (iii) (iv) (vi)
Correct Answer: (i) (iii) (iv) (vi)

Theory of national competitive advantage or Porter Diamond Model or Porter's Diamond of National Advantage- attempts to analyze the reasons for a nation's success in a particular industry. Porter studied 100 industries in 10 nations. He postulated determinants of competitive advantage of a nation were based on four major attributes

(i) Factor endowments

(ii) Demand conditions

(iii) Related and supporting industries

(iv) Firm strategy, structure and rivalry

 

Success occurs where these attributes exist. More/greater the attribute, the higher chance of success. The diamond is mutually reinforcing.

Question 2
In India, the FDI is prohibited in following sectors:(i) Lottery Business including Government / private lottery, online lotteries, etc.(ii) Defence production(iii) Gambling and betting including casinos etc.(iv) Chit funds.(v) Aviation(vi) Nidhi Company.Choose the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (iii), (iv), (vi)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi)
  • C.(i), (iii), (iv), (v) (vi)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v) (vi)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (iv), (vi)

Option A is the correct answer.

 

In India, the FDI is prohibited in following sectors:

Lottery Business including Government/ Private lottery, online lotteries etc.

Chit Funds

Trading in Transferable Development Rights (TDR)

Manufacturing of Cigars, cheroots, cigarillos, and cigarettes (tobacco or tobacco substitutes)

Gambling and betting including casinos*

Nidhi Company

Real Estate Business or Construction of Farm Houses

Sectors not open to private sector investments – atomic energy, railway operations (other than permitted activities mentioned under the consolidated FDI Policy)

Foreign technology collaboration in any form including licensing for franchise, trademark, brand name, management contract is also prohibited for Lottery Business and Gambling and Betting activities

 

Note that real estate business shall not include the development of town shops, construction of residential/ commercial premises, roads or bridges and Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) registered and regulated under the SEBI (REITs) Regulations, 2014.

Question 3
Which of the following is NOT one of core ten member countries of ASEAN?
  • A.India
  • B.Cambodia
  • C.Laos
  • D.Indonesia
Correct Answer: India

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a political and economic organisation of 10 countries located in Southeast Asia, which was formed on 8th August 1967 by Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Since then, membership has expanded to include Brunei, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar (Burma) and Vietnam. Its aims include accelerating economic growth, social progress, socio-cultural evolution among its members, protection of regional peace and stability, and opportunities for member countries to discuss differences peacefully. India is one of the 4 'Summit level Dialogue Partners' of ASEAN.

 

ASEAN + 3 was the first of attempts for further integration to improve existing ties with China, Japan, and South Korea. This was followed by the even larger East Asia Summit (EAS), which included ASEAN + 3 as well as India, Australia, and New Zealand. The group became ASEAN + 6 with Australia, New Zealand and India.

Question 4
Match List-IwithList-II and select the correct answer using the codes given below the lists:List- Ia. International Bank for Reconstruction and Developmentb. International Development Associationc. International Finance Corporationd. Multilateral Investment Guarantee AgencyList- III. 1944II. 1956III. 1960IV. 1988Select the correct answer using the codes givenbelow:
  • A.a-I,b-II,c-III,d-IV
  • B.a-I,b-III,c-II,d-IV
  • C.a-II,b-I,c-IV,d-III
  • D.a-III,b-I,c-II,d-IV
Correct Answer: a-I,b-III,c-II,d-IV

The World Bank Group comprises 5 institutions managed by their member countries:

 

(1) International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1944)

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) lends to governments of middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries.

 

(2) International Development Association (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1960)

The International Development Association (IDA) provides interest-free loans — called credits — and grants to governments of the poorest countries. Together, IBRD and IDA make up the World Bank.

 

(3) International Finance Corporation (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1956)

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is the largest global development institution focused exclusively on the private sector. We help developing countries achieve sustainable growth by financing investment, mobilizing capital in international financial markets, and providing advisory services to businesses and governments.

 

(4) Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1988)

The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) was created in 1988 to promote foreign direct investment into developing countries to support economic growth, reduce poverty, and improve people’s lives. MIGA fulfills this mandate by offering political risk insurance (guarantees) to investors and lenders.

 

(5) International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1966)

The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) provides international facilities for conciliation and arbitration of investment disputes.

Question 5
The term PESTLE Analysis is used to describe a framework foranalyzing:
  • A.Competitor Environment
  • B.Macro Environment
  • C.Customer Market Environment
  • D.Micro Environment
Correct Answer: Macro Environment

The correct answer is option (B) - Macro Environment.

 

PESTLE Analysis is a framework used to analyze the macro environment surrounding a business or organization. It stands for Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Legal, and Environmental factors. These factors are external to the organization and have a significant impact on its operations, strategies, and decision-making processes.

Question 6
Quantitative measures like SLR, CRR and Qualitative measures like Direct Action, Rationing of credit comes under which type of policies of the government?
  • A.Foreign Trade Policy
  • B.Industrial Policy
  • C.Monetary Policy
  • D.Fiscal Policy
Correct Answer: Monetary Policy

Monetary Policy – These are the policy measures taken by central bank to bring stability in economy. As per C. Rangarajan, monetary policy is an arm of macroeconomic policy. Through this policy government tries to attend exchange rate stability, control inflation, pace the economic growth, etc. Various tools of monetary policy include: Bank rate, Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR), Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR), Variable Reserve Ratio etc.

Fiscal Policy – It is the means by which a government adjusts its spending levels and tax rates to monitor and influence a nation's economy. These are the budgetary policy and use instruments like – Public expenditure, taxation and public debts. Government expenditure includes – public construction, public security, Grants and government revenues include – Tax, public debt and public deficit.

Question 7
Liberalization means
  • A.Increasing disinvestment
  • B.Liberating the industry, trade and economy from unwanted restriction and licensing.
  • C.Opening up of economy to the world by attaining international competitiveness.
  • D.Free determination of interest rates
Correct Answer: Liberating the industry, trade and economy from unwanted restriction and licensing.

The basic aim of liberalization was to put an end to those restrictions which became hindrances in the development and growth of the nation. The loosening of government control in a country and when private sector companies’ start working without or with fewer restrictions and government allow private players to expand for the growth of the country depicts liberalization in a country.

 

Objectives of Liberalization Policy:

1. To increase competition amongst domestic industries.

2. To encourage foreign trade with other countries with regulated imports and exports.

3. Enhancement of foreign capital and technology.

4. To expand global market frontiers of the country.

5. To diminish the debt burden of the country.

Question 8
The National Commission shall have jurisdiction to entertain complaints where the value of the goods or services paid as consideration exceeds:1. 5 crores2. 10 crores3. 15 croresSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.1 and 2
  • B.2 and 3
  • C.1 and 3
  • D.1, 2 and 3
Correct Answer: 2 and 3

The National Commission shall have jurisdiction to entertain:

(i) complaints where the value of the goods or services paid as consideration exceeds Rs 10 Crore.

(ii) complaints against unfair contracts, where the value of goods or services paid as consideration exceeds Rs 10 Crores.

(iii) appeals against the orders of any State Commission;

(iv) appeals against the orders of the Central Authority.

Question 9
Which one of the following is true about the CSR provisions in Companies Act 2013?
  • A.The list of CSR activities that a business can undertake is mentioned Schedule VI of the 2013 Act
  • B.Eligible companies need to spend at least 5% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding three financial years on corporate social responsibility activities.
  • C.Companies cannot collaborate with other companies to jointly undertake CSR activities
  • D.The CSR Rules exempts unlisted public companies and private companies that are not required to appoint an independent director from having an independent director as a part of their CSR Committee
Correct Answer: The CSR Rules exempts unlisted public companies and private companies that are not required to appoint an independent director from having an independent director as a part of their CSR Committee

CSR Committee Applicability is given below.

Every company to which CSR provision are applicable must constitute a Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Committee.

The CSR Committee should consist of three or more directors, out of which at least one director must be an independent director.

An unlisted public company or a private company shall have its CSR Committee without any independent director if an independent director is not required.

A private company having only two directors on its Board shall constitute its CSR Committee with two directors.

In the case of a foreign company, the CSR Committee shall comprise of at least two persons of which one person shall be a person resident in India authorised to accept on behalf of the foreign company – the services of notices and other documents. Also, the other person shall be nominated by the foreign company.

A company having any amount in its Unspent Corporate Social Responsibility Account shall constitute a CSR Committee and comply with the CSR provisions.

Question 10
Which of the following is one of non-tariff barriers?
  • A.Ad Valorem duty
  • B.Specific duty
  • C.Voluntary Export Restraint
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Voluntary Export Restraint

The correct answer is option (C) - Voluntary Export Restraint.

 

Non-tariff barriers (NTBs) are restrictions on trade that do not involve the imposition of tariffs (taxes on imports or exports). Instead, they include various other measures that countries use to restrict imports or exports.

 

Voluntary Export Restraints (VERs) are a type of NTB where exporting countries agree to limit the quantity of specific goods they export to another country. This is typically done at the request or under pressure from the importing country.

 

(A) Ad Valorem duty: This is a type of tariff, not a non-tariff barrier. It is a tax based on the value of the goods being imported.

 

(B) Specific duty: Similar to Ad Valorem duty, Specific duty is also a type of tariff, not a non-tariff barrier. It is a fixed tax based on the quantity or weight of the goods being imported.

Question 11
The _______ is the acknowledgement of filing the return of income.
  • A.ITR - 4
  • B.ITR - V
  • C.Form 26AS
  • D.Form 26QB
Correct Answer: ITR - V

ITR – V is the acknowledgement of filing the return of income.

Question 12
During Balance of Payment Accounting, the payment of interest on loans and dividend payments are recorded in the
  • A.Unilateral transfer account
  • B.Reserve Account
  • C.Capital account
  • D.Current account
Correct Answer: Capital account

The Balance of Payments or BoP is a statement or record of all monetary and economic transactions made between a country and the rest of the world within a defined period (every quarter or year). These records include transactions made by individuals, companies and the government. Keeping a record of these transactions helps the country to monitor the flow of money and develop policies that would help in building a strong economy.

Components of Balance of Payments: (1) Current Account; (2) Capital Account.

 

Capital account of BOP records all those transactions, between the residents of a country and the rest of the world, which cause a change in the assets or liabilities of the residents of the country or its government. It is related to claims and liabilities of financial nature. The main components of capital account are:

(i) Borrowings and landings to and from abroad – (a) All transactions relating to borrowings from abroad by private sector, government, etc. Receipts of such loans and repayment of loans by foreigners are recorded on the positive (credit) side. (b) All transactions of lending to abroad by private sector and government. Lending abroad and repayment of loans to abroad is recorded as negative or debit item.

(ii) Investments to and from abroad – (a) Investments by rest of the world in shares of Indian companies, real estate in India, etc. Such investments from abroad are recorded on the positive (credit) side as they bring in foreign exchange. (b) Investments by Indian residents in shares of foreign companies, real estate abroad, etc. Such investments to abroad be recorded on the negative (debit) side as they lead to outflow of foreign exchange.

(iii) Change in Foreign Exchange Reserves (also called Reserve Account) - The foreign exchange reserves are the financial assets of the government held in the central bank. A change in reserves serves as the financing item in India’s BOP. So, any withdrawal from the reserves is recorded on the positive (credit) side and any addition to these reserves is recorded on the negative (debit) side. It must be noted that ‘change in reserves’ is recorded in the BOP account and not ‘reserves’.

Question 13
Which of the following Statements is true?
  • A.GATT stands for Generalised Agreement on Trade and Transfer
  • B.WTO came into being in 1948
  • C.GATT was created in 1948
  • D.Council for settlement of disputes is a subsidiary body of Generalcouncilof WTO
Correct Answer: GATT was created in 1948

GATT stands for General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It was created in 1948 with the aim of bolstering international trade by reducing trade barriers between countries through negotiations. It was replaced by World Trade Organization in 1995 after prolonged deliberations that continued for eight years in GATT.

Question 14
Dual Aspect Concept results in the following accounting equation:
  • A.Revenue = Expenses + Profit
  • B.Assets + Expenses = Capital + Profits
  • C.Assets = Capital + Liabilities
  • D.Assets = Capital
Correct Answer: Assets = Capital + Liabilities

Dual aspect concept: It is one of 13 Basic accounting concepts.

 

This concept provides the basis for recording the transaction in the books of accounts. It states that every transaction entered in the books has two aspects. For example, Man as started business with cash Rs. 50,000. In this transaction asset (cash) increases and liability (capital of owner) also increases. This principle is also known as duality principle. This principle is commonly expressed in fundamental accounting equation given below:

 

Assets = Liabilities + Capital

 

This equation states that assets of business are always equal to the claims of owners and outsiders.

Question 15
Closing Stock is an example of
  • A.Fixed Assets
  • B.Fixed Liabilities
  • C.Current Assets
  • D.Intangible Assets
Correct Answer: Current Assets

The correct answer is option (C) - Current Assets.

 

Closing Stock refers to the inventory or goods that remain unsold at the end of an accounting period. It represents the value of goods that a business still holds in its inventory at the end of the reporting period.

 

Since Closing Stock represents inventory that is expected to be sold or consumed within the normal course of business operations, it is classified as a Current Asset on the balance sheet. Current Assets are assets that are expected to be converted into cash or used up within one year or within the operating cycle of the business, whichever is longer.

Question 16
Which of the following is NOT a Liquidity Ratio?
  • A.Debt Service Coverage Ratio
  • B.Current Ratio
  • C.Acid Test Ratio
  • D.Quick Ratio
Correct Answer: Debt Service Coverage Ratio

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Liquidity Ratio: A liquidity ratio is a financial ratio that indicates whether a company's current assets will be sufficient to meet the company's obligations when they become due.

 

Debt Service Coverage Ratio: Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR), one of the coverage ratios, calculated in order to know the cash profit availability to repay the debt including interest. Essentially, DSCR is calculated when a firm takes a loan from bank / financial institution / any other loan provider. This ratio suggests the capability of cash profits to meet the repayment of the financial loan. DSCR is very important from the viewpoint of the financing authority as it indicates the repaying capability of the entity taking a loan.

DSCR = Operating IncomeDebt Services

 

Debt Service = Interest & Lease Payment + Principal Payment

Question 17
X and Y are partners in a firm sharing profits in the ratios of 2:1. Z is admitted with a13profit sharing. What will be the new profit sharing ratio of X, Y and Z?
  • A.3:2:4
  • B.4:2:3
  • C.4:2:1
  • D.2:4:3
Correct Answer: 4:2:3

At the time of admission of the new partner into the firm there is a need to calculate the new profit sharing ratio of the firm.

Let total profit = 1

‘Z’ is admitted with Share = 13

Remaining share = 1 – 13 = 23

X’s share = 23 of 23 = 49

Y’s share = 13 of 23 = 29

Z’s share = 13 = 39

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y and Z is. 4:2:3.

Question 18
The magnitude of the minority interest in the subsidiary company is
  • A.less than 50%
  • B.less than 30%
  • C.less than 20%
  • D.less than 10%
Correct Answer: less than 50%

Minority interest is the portion of a subsidiary corporation's stock that is not owned by the parent corporation. The magnitude of the minority interest in the subsidiary company is generally less than 50% of outstanding shares, or the corporation would generally cease to be a subsidiary of the parent.

Question 19
Calculate BEP in units as well as in value, by considering the figures given below:Sales 5000 unitsSales price per unitRs. 50Variable cost per unitRs. 30Fixed costRs. 35000
  • A.87500
  • B.75000
  • C.67500
  • D.90000
Correct Answer: 87500

Therefore, contribution per unit = 50 - 30 = Rs. 20

Breakeven points in units sold=3500020=1750 Units.

Breakeven sales value=1750 ×50

Breakeven sales value=Rs.87500

Or

CM Ratio=2050=0.4

Breakeven points in total sales=Fixed Expenses Contribution Margin Ratio

Breakeven points in total sales=350000.4 =Rs.87500

Question 20
Which of the following is not a Value based Monetary Model of Human Resources Accounting?
  • A.Ogan’sModel
  • B.Hermanson’sUn-Purchased Goodwill Method
  • C.Lev and Schwartz Model
  • D.Replacement Cost Model
Correct Answer: Replacement Cost Model

The correct answer is option (D) - Replacement Cost Model.

 

Human Resources Accounting (HRA) involves the quantification and measurement of human resources in monetary terms to assess their value to an organization. Various models have been developed to evaluate human resources from different perspectives.

 

(A) Ogan’s Model: Ogan’s Model is a value-based monetary model of Human Resources Accounting. It focuses on determining the value of human resources based on the present value of future earnings attributable to employees.

 

(B) Hermanson’s Un-Purchased Goodwill Method: Hermanson’s Un-Purchased Goodwill Method is another value-based monetary model of HRA. It assesses the value of human resources by estimating the goodwill generated by employees that is not reflected in the purchase price of the organization.

 

(C) Lev and Schwartz Model: The Lev and Schwartz Model is also a value-based monetary model of HRA. It evaluates the value of human resources by considering factors such as human capital investments, skills, and knowledge that contribute to the organization's performance.

 

(D) Replacement Cost Model: Unlike the other options, the Replacement Cost Model is not a value-based monetary model of HRA. Instead, it is a concept used in accounting to determine the cost of replacing an asset at its current market value. It does not specifically focus on assessing the value of human resources.

Question 21
Under ______________ bills of the facility for the past several years are analyzed to identify patterns of energy use, peak demand, and weather effects.
  • A.Utility Cost Analysis
  • B.Standard Energy Audit
  • C.Detailed Energy Audit
  • D.Preliminary Audit
Correct Answer: Utility Cost Analysis

Types of Energy Audit

There are several types of energy audits. These are listed below in order of increasing scope and, therefore, cost:

1) Preliminary Audit

2) Utility Cost Analysis

3) Standard Energy Audit

4) Detailed Energy Audit

 

Utility Cost Analysis: The purpose of this type of audit is to analyze the operating costs of the facility and determine the potential for energy efficiency retrofits. The auditor may also perform a preliminary audit to familiarize himself/herself with the facility. Utility data and the facility’s utility bills are analyzed for the past several years to identify patterns of energy use, peak demand, and weather effects. This information is used to identify energy savings potential, calculate the energy utilization index, and determine the incremental cost of each unit of energy.

Question 22
The following is the demand function;Q=120-8PWhat will be the price elasticity of demand, when price isRs. 12?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 4

Q=120-8P

When P is 12, Q is = 120 - 8 × 12 = 24

Differentiating it with respect to price, p

dQdp = -8

Elasticity of Demand is given by, Ed = dQdp × PQ

= (-8) × (12/24)

= -4 or 4

Question 23
The short run cost function of a firm is given as:TC = 100 + 2Q + Q2What will be the optimizing level of output?
  • A.5
  • B.10
  • C.12
  • D.15
Correct Answer: 10

AC= TCQ = 100Q +2 +Q

MC is given by differentiation of TC with respect to Q

 

MC= dTCdQ

 

MC= 2 + 2Q

 

Output optimization à AC = MC

100Q + 2 + Q = 2 + 2Q

Q = 10

 

Therefore, 10 units of quantity is the point where output will be optimized.

Question 24
Match the followingList-I1. Leontief Production Function2. Slope of Isoquant3. Cobb-Douglas Production Function4. Elasticity of Factor SubstitutionList-IIa. Q=A LaKβb. Q=min (Z1/a, Z2/b)c. Marginal rate of technical substitutiond. (Percentage change in K/L) / (Percentage change in MRTS)Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.1-b,2-a,3-c,4-d
  • B.1-a,2-c,3-b,4-d
  • C.1-a,2-b,3-d,4-c
  • D.1-b,2-c,3-a,4-d
Correct Answer: 1-b,2-c,3-a,4-d

a) Leontief production function uses fixed proportion of inputs having no substitutability between them. It is regarded as the limiting cases for constant elasticity of substitution. The MRTS in all such cases would, therefore, be zero. For instance, there is no substitution possible between the tyres and a battery in an automobile production process.

Q=min (Z1/a, Z2/b)

 

b) Cobb-Douglas production function refers to the production function in which one input can be substituted by other but to a limited extent. The rate at which input a can be given up in return for one more unit of input b keeping the output constant, diminishes as the amount of input b increases.

Q=A La Kβ

 

c) The marginal rate of technical substitution (MRTS) is the rate at which one input can be substituted for another input without changing the level of output. In other words, the marginal rate of technical substitution of Labour (L) for Capital (K) is the slope of an isoquant multiplied by -1. Since the slope of an isoquant is moving down, the isoquant is given by -ΔK/ΔL (change in labour/change in Capital).

 

d) The elasticity of substitution (σ) is formally defined as the percentage change in the capital labour ratio (K/L) divided by the percentage change in marginal rate of technical substitution (MRTS),

σ = (% Change in K/L) / (% Change in MRTS)

Question 25
Match the following items:List-Ia. Monopolyb. Monopolistic Competitionc. Perfect Competitiond. OligopolyList-III. Price-takerII.No Close SubstitutesIII. Differentiated productsIV. Price rigiditySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-I, b-II, c-III, d-IV
  • B.a-IV, b-III, c-II, d-I
  • C.a-II, b-III, c-I, d-IV
  • D.a-I, b-III, c-IV, d-II
Correct Answer: a-II, b-III, c-I, d-IV

Prefect Competition is a market in which there are many firms selling identical products with no firm large enough, relative to the entire market, to be able to influence market price. Hence they sell product at the prevailing price and are “price-taker”. Features of perfect competition are:

1. Large number of firms

2. Large number of buyers

3. The product is homogeneous. 

4. No barriers to entry. 

5. Complete information.  

6. Profit maximization.

 

Monopoly refers to a market situation in which there is only one seller of a commodity. Features of monopoly are:

1. One Seller and Large Number of Buyers

2. No Close Substitutes

3. Difficulty of Entry of New Firms

4. Monopoly is also an Industry

5. Price Maker

 

A Monopolistic market is a type of imperfect competition such that many producers sell products that are differentiated from one another (e.g. by branding or quality) and hence are not perfect substitutes. Features of Monopolistic Competition:

1. Large Number of Sellers

2. Product Differentiation

3. Selling costs

4. Freedom of Entry and Exit

5. Lack of Perfect Knowledge

6. Pricing Decision

7. Non-Price Competition

 

Oligopoly refers to a market situation in which there are a few firms selling homogeneous or differentiated products. Features of oligopoly are:

1. Few firms

2. Interdependence

3. Non-Price Competition

4. Barriers to Entry of Firms

5. Role of Selling Costs

6. Group Behaviours

7. Price Rigidity

Question 26
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:Total utility will be maximum when marginal utility to price of respective products are equalReason ‘R’:Deviation from this situation leads to reduction in maximum utility
  • A.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect but R is correct.
  • C.A and R both are correct but R is not right explanation of A.
  • D.A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.

Utility is the satisfaction that a person derives from the consumption of a good or service. Total utility is the total satisfaction received from consuming a given total quantity of a good or service, while marginal utility is the satisfaction gained from consuming additional quantity of a good or service. Total utility will be maximum when marginal utility to price of respective products are equal and deviation from this situation leads to reduction in marginal utility.

Question 27
If the government raises the tax on beer, this will lead to a fall in profits of the brewers is an example of ___________ Economics whereas Pollution is the most serious economic problem, is an example of­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­______________ Economics.
  • A.Positive, Normative
  • B.Normative, Positive
  • C.Micro, Macro
  • D.Macro, Micro
Correct Answer: Positive, Normative

Normative economics deals with value judgments and opinions about what ought to be, rather than what is.

 

Positive economics focuses on factual analysis and objective statements about what is, rather than what should be.

Question 28
When high price is charged during the high demand period, is called as the _________ pricing.
  • A.Price Skimming
  • B.Price Penetration
  • C.Peak load
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Peak load

The Peak Load Pricing is the pricing strategy wherein the high price is charged for the goods and services during times when their demand is at peak. In other words, the high price charged during the high demand period is called as the peak load pricing.

 

Penetration pricing is a pricing method where a firm prices its product fairly low while launching the product and then increases the price to normal levels after a period of time.

 

Price skimming is a mechanism where the seller launches the product in the market at a relatively high price and lowers the price after some period to bring it to a moderate level.

Question 29
What are the determinants of Demand?(i) Price of Commodity(ii) Price of Related Good(iii) Amount of Quantity Demanded(iv) Taste and Preferences(v) Prevailing Inflation RateSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) and (iii) only
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • D.(ii) only
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iv)

The correct answer is option (B) - (i), (ii), (iv).

 

(i) Price of Commodity: This is a fundamental principle. Generally, as the price increases, the quantity demanded decreases (assuming other factors remain constant). This is known as the law of demand.

 

(ii) Price of Related Goods: This refers to 2 categories:

Complementary Goods: When the price of a complementary good increases, the demand for the original good decreases. For example, if the price of bread rises, the demand for butter (a complementary good) might decrease.

Substitute Goods: When the price of a substitute good decreases, the demand for the original good decreases. For instance, if the price of a bus ticket falls, the demand for taxi rides (a substitute) might decline.

 

(iii) Amount of Quantity Demanded: This is not a determinant of demand itself, but rather the outcome influenced by the other determinants. Price, income, preferences, etc., affect the quantity demanded.

 

(iv) Taste and Preferences: Consumers' preferences significantly impact demand. If a new fashion trend emerges, the demand for clothing that aligns with that trend will surge.

 

(v) Prevailing Inflation Rate: Inflation generally leads to increased prices across the board. This can discourage consumption, impacting demand indirectly. However, it's not as direct an influence as the other factors mentioned.

Question 30
Indifference Curve is also known as ________.
  • A.Envelope Curve
  • B.Iso- Utility Curve
  • C.Equal utility Curve
  • D.Both (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: Both (b) and (c)

An indifference curve may be defined as the locus of points each representing a different combination of two substitute goods, which yield the same utility or level of satisfaction to the consumer. Therefore, he is indifferent between any two combinations of two goods when it comes to making a choice between them. Such a situation arises because he consumes a large number of goods and services and often finds that one commodity can be substituted for another. As shown in the Figure below, all points on the indifference curve (a, b, c, d, e) will give same level of Utility.

An indifference curve is also called Iso-utility curve or Equal utility curve.

Question 31
Which law explains thebehaviorof output in response to a proportional and simultaneous change in inputs?
  • A.Law of Returns to Scale
  • B.Law of Demand
  • C.Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility
  • D.Law of Supply
Correct Answer: Law of Returns to Scale

The laws of returns to scale explain the behavior of output in response to a proportional and simultaneous change in inputs. Increasing inputs proportionately and simultaneously is, in fact, an expansion of the scale of production.

 

When a firm expands its scale, i.e., it increases both the inputs proportionately, then there are three technical possibilities:

1. total output may increase more than proportionately;

2. total output may increase proportionately; and

3. total output may increase less than proportionately.

 

Accordingly, there are three kinds of returns to scale:

1. Increasing returns to scale;

2. Constant returns to scale, and

3. Diminishing returns to scale.

Question 32
The degree of competition is maximum under which market?
  • A.Monopolistic
  • B.Perfect
  • C.Oligopoly
  • D.Monopoly
Correct Answer: Perfect

The correct answer is option (B) - Perfect.

 

(A) Monopolistic: This market has minimal competition. A single seller (monopoly) controls the entire market, facing no direct competition and often setting higher prices.

 

(B) Perfect: A perfectly competitive market exhibits the highest degree of competition. Here's why:

Numerous Buyers and Sellers: Many small businesses operate, preventing any single entity from dominating the market.

Homogeneous Products: Sellers offer nearly identical products, making it difficult for any one firm to stand out solely on product features.

Price Takers: Individual firms have no control over prices. The market dictates the price based on supply and demand.

Free Entry and Exit: New firms can easily enter the market if they see an opportunity, and existing firms can leave without significant barriers.

 

(C) Oligopoly: A small number of large firms control the market. While there's some competition, it's limited due to the dominance of these few players. They may influence prices to a certain extent.

 

(D) Monopoly: As mentioned earlier, a monopoly has no competition. There's only one seller, eliminating any competitive pressure.

Question 33
β(Beta) is a measure of:
  • A.Systematic risk
  • B.Unsystematic risk
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.Neither A nor B
Correct Answer: Systematic risk

Systematic Risk: Also known as "market risk" or "un-diversifiable risk" or volatility or relevant risk. Systematic risk is the uncertainty inherent to the entire market or entire market segment. Interest rates, recession and wars all represent sources of systematic risk because they affect the entire market and cannot be avoided through diversification. Systematic risk can be mitigated only by being hedged. Beta is a measure of the volatility, or systematic risk, of a security or a portfolio in comparison to the market as a whole. In other words, beta gives a sense of a stock's market risk compared to the greater market. Beta is also used to compare a stock's market risk to that of other stocks.

 

Unsystematic Risk: Also known as "specific risk," "diversifiable risk" or "residual risk" this type of uncertainty comes with the company or industry you invest in and can be reduced through diversification. For example, news that is specific to a small number of stocks, such as a sudden strike by the employees of a company you have shares in, is considered to be unsystematic risk.

Question 34
Match the items of two lists, giving the correct code:List – Ia. Dividend Discount Modelb. Dividend Relevance Modelc. Dividend Irrelevance Modeld. Dividend Payout ModelList – IIi. JohnLintnerii. James E. Walteriii. Myron Gordoniv. Modigliani & Miller
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

The correct matching of items from List I to List II is as follows:

 

a. Dividend Discount Model - iii. Myron Gordon

b. Dividend Relevance Model - ii. James E. Walter

c. Dividend Irrelevance Model - iv. Modigliani & Miller

d. Dividend Payout Model - i. John Lintner

 

So, the correct code is option (C) - iii ii iv i.

Question 35
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II:List – Ia. Net Present Valueb. Payback Periodc. Internal Rate of Returnd. Accounting Rate of ReturnList – IIi. Number of years required to recover the original cash outlay invested in a project.ii. It is the rate of return which equates the present value of anticipated net cash flows with the initial outlay.iii. It is found out by dividing the average after-tax profit by the average investment.iv. It is the difference between the present value of cash inflows and present value of cash outflows.
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii

The correct code is option (D) - iv i ii iii.

 

Here’s a breakdown of the matching between project evaluation techniques and their descriptions:

 

List I - Techniques:

a. Net Present Value (NPV): (iv) This method calculates the difference between the present value of cash inflows and the present value of cash outflows associated with an investment. A positive NPV indicates profitability.

b. Payback Period: (i) This metric determines the number of years required to recover the initial investment from a project's cash inflows.

c. Internal Rate of Return (IRR): (ii) This rate represents the discount rate at which the NPV of a project becomes zero. In simpler terms, it's the investment's expected return based on its cash flows.

d. Accounting Rate of Return (ARR): (iii) This ratio calculates the average annual profit generated by an investment, divided by the average investment over a specific period.

Question 36
Which of the following is NOT considered by Miller-Orr Model?
  • A.Variability in cash requirement
  • B.Cost of transaction
  • C.Interest
  • D.Total annual requirement of cash
Correct Answer: Total annual requirement of cash

The correct answer is option (D) - Total annual requirement of cash.

 

The Miller-Orr Model is a cash management model developed by Merton H. Miller and Daniel Orr. It aims to minimize the costs associated with managing cash balances while ensuring that a company always has enough cash on hand to meet its operational needs.

 

The Miller-Orr Model considers various factors related to cash management, including variability in cash requirements, cost of transactions, and the opportunity cost of holding cash. However, it does not directly consider the total annual requirement of cash. Instead, it focuses on determining the target cash balance that minimizes the costs of holding cash and executing transactions while still meeting cash needs.

Question 37
Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) for risk measurement has been given by:
  • A.Sharpe andLintner
  • B.LintnerandTreynor
  • C.Sharpe,LintnerandTreynor
  • D.Lintner, Modigliani and Miller
Correct Answer: Sharpe,LintnerandTreynor

The CAPM was developed in the early 1960s by William Sharpe (1964), Jack Treynor (1962), John Lintner (1965a, b) and Jan Mossin (1966). The capital asset pricing model, CAPM, provides a formula that calculates the expected return on a security based on its level of risk. The cost of equity is expressed formulaically below:

 

CAPM can be summarized according to the following formula:

Ke = Rf+Rm-Rf X β

Where,

Rm = Return on market portfolio / expected market return

Ke= Cost of Equity

Rf= Risk Free Rate

Rm-Rf = Market Risk Rate

β = Beta

Question 38
When a direct quote of the home currency or any other currency is not available in the forex market, it is computed with the help of exchange quotes of other pairs of currencies, is referred to by which one of the following?
  • A.Cross rate
  • B.Arbitrage rate
  • C.Transaction rate
  • D.Translation rate
Correct Answer: Cross rate

Cross Rate: A cross rate is an exchange rate between two currencies, calculated from their common relationships with a third currency. When cross rates differ from the direct rates between two currencies, inter market arbitrage is possible.

Question 39
Determine the market price of a share using Gordon’s Model of Dividend, if total investment in asset isRs10,00,000number of shares is 50,000 with a total earning ofRs2,00,000. The cost of capital is 16% andpayoutratio is 40%.
  • A.Rs45
  • B.Rs60
  • C.Rs40
  • D.Rs38
Correct Answer: Rs40

Gordon's basic valuation formula:

P0 = E(1-b)Ke - br

Or,

Also called dividend growth model

P0 = D1Ke-g= D0(1+g)Ke-g

Where,

P0 = Price of shares

E = Earnings per share

b = Retention ratio

Ke = Cost of equity capital

br = g = Growth rate

D0 = Dividend per share

D1 = Expected dividend at the end of year 1.

 

In our example, Earning per Share, E= 200000/50000= Rs 4

Payout Ratio= 40%, thus Retention Ratio= 60%

Rate of return= 200000/1000000= 0.20 (20%)

Cost of Capital= 0.16

Growth Rate= 0.20 X 0.60= 0.12

Putting these values in formula, we get Rs 40

Question 40
Which among the following statements is NOT correct?
  • A.The NPV and IRR methods make the same accept/reject decisions for independent projects.
  • B.The payback period is defined as the number of years required to recover a projects’ cost.
  • C.The discounted payback method discounts cash flows at the rate of interest.
  • D.The NPV method assumes that cash flows will be reinvested at the firm’s cost of capital.
Correct Answer: The discounted payback method discounts cash flows at the rate of interest.

The Discounted Payback Period reflects the amount of time necessary to break even in a project based not only on what cash flows occur, but when they occur and the prevailing "rate of return in the market".

 

The "payback period" is the amount of time for a project to break even in cash collections. The discounting can be done using the given discounting rate, WACC (Weighted average cost of capital) or IRR (Internal rate of return) or bank rate company got the lending or government risk-free bond rate.

Question 41
In case of Asset Securitization, the _____________ coordinate with other parties (such as investors, rating agencies, and legal counsel) to execute the transaction successfully.
  • A.SPV
  • B.Arranger
  • C.Seller
  • D.Originator
Correct Answer: Arranger

The correct answer is option (B) - Arranger.

 

In the context of asset securitization, various parties are involved in executing the transaction successfully. Among these parties, the arranger plays a crucial role in coordinating and facilitating the process.

 

Here's an explanation of each option:

 

(A) SPV (Special Purpose Vehicle): While SPV is an essential component of asset securitization, it is not primarily responsible for coordinating the transaction. SPV is a separate legal entity created specifically to hold and manage the securitized assets.

 

(B) Arranger: The arranger, also known as the structuring agent or lead manager, is responsible for structuring the securitization transaction. They coordinate with other parties involved, such as investors, rating agencies, legal counsel, and the originator, to design the deal, determine the asset pool, set the terms, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

 

(C) Seller: The seller is the entity that transfers the assets to the SPV in exchange for cash proceeds from the sale of securities. While the seller is involved in the transaction, its primary role is to provide the underlying assets for securitization, rather than coordinating the transaction.

 

(D) Originator: The originator is the entity that originally owns or originates the assets being securitized. They may also act as the servicer, managing the assets and collecting payments from borrowers. While the originator is involved in the securitization process, their role is more focused on providing the assets and servicing them rather than coordinating the transaction.

Question 42
The Standard Deviation is _______ of Origin and is _______ of Scale.
  • A.Independent, Independent
  • B.Dependent, Dependent
  • C.Independent, Dependent
  • D.Dependent, Independent
Correct Answer: Independent, Dependent

The Standard Deviation is not affected by the value of the constant from which deviations are calculated. The value of the constant does not figure in the standard deviation formula. Thus, Standard Deviation is Independent of Origin. If a constant is added to every score in a distribution, the standard deviation will not be changed. If you visualize the scores in a frequency distribution histogram, then adding a constant will move each score so that the entire distribution is shifted to a new location. The center of the distribution (the mean) changes, but the standard deviation remains the same.

 

However, Standard Deviation is Not Independent of Scale. Thus, if the values or deviations are divided by a common factor, the value of the common factor is used in the formula to get the value of Standard Deviation. If each score is multiplied by a constant, the standard deviation will be multiplied by the same constant. Multiplying by a constant will multiply the distance between scores, and because the standard deviation is a measure of distance, it will also be multiplied.

Question 43
Consider following statements:(i) The classical approach to probability theory requires that the total number of possible outcomes be known or calculated but each of the outcomes maynotbe equally likely.(ii) A marginal probability is also known as unconditional probability.(iii) For three independent events, the joint probability of the three events, P(A∩B∩C) = P( A ) × P( B ) × P( C )(iv) Two events are mutually exclusive, exhaustive and equally likely, the probability of either event A and B occurring P (A∩B) lies between 0 and 1.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) are true.
  • B.(iii) and (iv) are true.
  • C.(ii) and (iii) are true.
  • D.only (iii) is true
Correct Answer: (ii) and (iii) are true.

Let us look at all the options in detail:

 

The classical probability theory says that the total number of possible outcomes be known or calculated and each of the outcomes may be equally likely. Hence, it's FALSE.

 

This statement is true. The marginal probability is unconditional probability. That is, it doesn’t depend on occurrence of any other event.

 

If three events are independent then P(A∩B∩C) = P( A ) × P( B ) × P( C ). This is also the multiplicative rule of probability when all events are independent.

 

If the events are mutually exclusive then P(A ∩ B) = 0. Since they are mutually exclusive, the probability of joint occurrence is 0.

Question 44
For which of the following distributions, the mean is equal to variance?
  • A.Binomial distribution
  • B.Poisson distribution
  • C.Normal distribution
  • D.Chi Square distribution
Correct Answer: Poisson distribution

Poisson distribution has mean and variance equal to λ. Below table summarizes the necessary information about all types of distributions:

 

Probability distribution

Mean

Variance

Notation

Binomial distribution

np

npq

Number of trials

P is probability of success

q is probability of failure

Poisson distribution

 λ

 λ

 λ is the mean of the random variable per unit of time

Normal distribution

 μ

 σ2

Self-explanatory

Chi Square distribution

 k

 2*k

k is degrees of freedoms

 

Question 45
To facilitate data collection of preference of subjects of students, we might use a numeric code by letting 1 denote History, 2 denote English, and 3 denote Fixed Mathematics. This is example of __________ scale of measurement.
  • A.Ordinal
  • B.Interval
  • C.Nominal
  • D.Classic
Correct Answer: Nominal

Data collection relies on four scales of measurement: nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio. These scales determine the level of detail in the data and guide appropriate summarization and statistical analysis techniques.

 

1. Nominal scale is used when data consist of labels or names to identify attributes. For instance, assigning numeric codes like 1, 2, and 3 to represent different fund categories, such as Domestic Equity, International Equity, and Fixed Income, demonstrates nominal scale.

 

2. Ordinal scale ranks data in addition to having nominal properties. For example, customer ratings like excellent, good, or poor for service quality can be ordered based on their quality level, making it an ordinal scale.

 

3. Interval scale encompasses the properties of ordinal data and also includes meaningful differences between values based on a fixed unit of measure. SAT scores, with numeric values and meaningful differences between scores, exemplify interval scale.

 

4. Ratio scale includes all features of interval data, plus a meaningful ratio between values. It requires a zero point indicating absence of the measured variable. For example, measurements like distance, height, weight, and time adhere to ratio scale, with a zero value indicating absence or nothingness for the variable. Comparing costs, such as Rs 30,000 for one automobile and Rs 15,000 for another, shows a meaningful ratio of 2:1 between their costs.

Question 46
Which of the following is a type of Non-Probability Sampling?
  • A.Simple Random Sampling
  • B.Stratified Random Sampling
  • C.Cluster Sampling
  • D.Snowball Sampling
Correct Answer: Snowball Sampling

The correct answer is option (D) - Snowball Sampling.

 

Non-probability sampling techniques rely on the researcher's judgment or convenience to select samples, rather than random selection. Simple random sampling, stratified random sampling, and cluster sampling are all types of probability sampling. In these methods, every member of the population has a known chance of being included in the sample.

 

Snowball sampling is a non-probability sampling technique where the researcher starts with a small group of individuals who meet the criteria and then asks them to identify others who also meet the criteria. This process continues like a snowball rolling down a hill, accumulating more participants through referrals.

Question 47
“Reject the hypothesis, when it is true” is:
  • A.Type-I error
  • B.Type-II error
  • C.Beta Error
  • D.Gamma Error
Correct Answer: Type-I error

The correct answer is option (A) Type-I error.

 

Type-I error: This occurs in hypothesis testing when we wrongly reject the null hypothesis (H₀), even though it's actually true. In simpler terms, we mistakenly conclude a significant difference exists when there isn't one.

Explanation for other options:

 

Type-II error: This is the opposite of a Type-I error. It occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis (H₀) when it's actually false. We miss a true effect and mistakenly believe no difference exists.

Question 48
Match the columns:List-Ia. Large sampleb. True meanc. Sample meanList-IIi. Sampleii. Populationiii. Central limit theorem
  • A.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
  • C.a-ii, b-i, c-iii
  • D.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-ii, c-i

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Large sample: The Central Limit Theorem states that the distribution of sample means approaches a normal distribution as the sample size increases. So, a large sample is a prerequisite for the Central Limit Theorem to apply.

 

True mean: This refers to the average value of the entire population. It is denoted by the Greek letter μ (mu).

 

Sample mean: This represents the average value of a sample, which is a subset of the population. It is denoted by the letter x̄ (x-bar).

Question 49
A researcher collects exam score data of a sample of 10 students Consider the null hypothesis –Ho:μ=100. Which of the following alternative hypothesis represents the right tailed test?
  • A.H1:μ<100
  • B.H1:μ>100
  • C.H1:μ≠100
  • D.H1:μ=10
Correct Answer: H1:μ>100

Remember that a null hypothesis contains a specific claim so it must have an equality sign. Option c represents two tailed test since there is an equality sign. Option d is an alternative claim and hence it is represents a point on the data. Option a represents a left tailed test since there is a less than or equal to sign. Thus, option b is the correct answer as the alternative hypothesis (Research hypothesis) represents all the points to the right of μ=100 (i.e. μ>100)

Question 50
Arithmetic mean of both regression coefficients is:
  • A.equal to coefficient of correlation
  • B.greater than coefficient of correlation
  • C.equal to or greater than coefficient of correlation
  • D.less than coefficient of correlation
Correct Answer: equal to or greater than coefficient of correlation

Regression coefficient is a statistical measure of the average functional relationship between two or more variables. In regression analysis, one variable is considered as dependent and other(s) as independent.

 

Thus, it measures the degree of dependence of one variable on the other(s).

1. It is denoted by b.

2. It is expressed in terms of original unit of data.

3. Between two variables (say x and y), two values of regression coefficient can be obtained. One will be obtained when we consider x as independent and y as dependent and the other when we consider y as independent and x as dependent. The regression coefficient of y on x is represented as byx and that of x on y as bxy.

4. Both regression coefficients must have the same sign. If byx is positive, bxy will also be positive and vice versa.

5. If one regression coefficient is greater than unity, then the other regression coefficient must be lesser than unity.

6. The geometric mean between two regression coefficients is equal to the coefficient of correlation, r = 

7. Arithmetic mean of both regression coefficients is equal to or greater than coefficient of correlation.

 

(byx + bxy)/2 = equal or greater than ‘r’.

Question 51
Which of the following is NOT one of assumptions use ANOVA?
  • A.For each population, the response variable is exponentially distributed
  • B.The variance of the response variable, is the same for all of the populations
  • C.The observations must be independent.
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: For each population, the response variable is exponentially distributed

Three assumptions are required to use ANOVA:

1. For each population, the response variable is normally distributed: The number of units produced per day must be normally distributed for each method.

2. The variance of the response variable, denoted σ2, is the same for all of the populations: The variance of the number of units produced per day must be the same for each method.

3. The observations must be independent: The number of units produced per day by any employee must be independent of the number of units produced day by any other employee.

Question 52
Which of the following principles of management was NOT given by Fayol?
  • A.Division of Work
  • B.Unity of Command
  • C.Unity of Direction
  • D.Unity of Coordination
Correct Answer: Unity of Coordination

Henry Fayol gave 14 Principles of Management:

1 Division of Work

2 Authority and Responsibility

3 Discipline

4 Unity of Command

5 Unity of Direction

6 Subordination of Individual Interest

7 Remuneration

8 The Degree of Centralization

9 Scalar Chain

10 Order

11 Equity

12 Stability of Tenure of Personnel

13 Initiative

14 Esprit de Corps

Question 53
This list of syndromes of organizational maladjustment, which can be reasons of failure of change management are:a.RigoreMartisb.Buggywhipc. Anarchyd. Smootheninge. Rat raceSelect the correct answer using thecodes given below:
  • A.a, b, c and d
  • B.a, b, c and e
  • C.b, d and e
  • D.a, d and e
Correct Answer: a, b, c and e

The correct answer is option (B) - a, b, c, and e.

 

Rigore Martis: This syndrome refers to the rigidity and resistance to change within an organization.

 

Buggywhip: This syndrome signifies investing resources in outdated or irrelevant practices or technologies.

 

Anarchy: This syndrome describes a lack of structure or control within the organization, leading to chaos and hindrance in change implementation.

 

Rat race: This syndrome refers to a competitive and stressful work environment, which can impede collaboration and change adoption.

Question 54
According to which view “there is an optimum level of organisational conflict; with too little conflict the organisation stagnates, with too much conflict the organization is disrupted”?
  • A.Unitarists
  • B.Pluralists
  • C.Interactionists
  • D.Modernists
Correct Answer: Interactionists

There are 4 approaches to Conflict Management:

1) Unitarist Perspective Assumptions - The conflict is the expression of employee dissatisfaction and differences with management is perceived as an irrational activity. Here, the conflict is regard as ' bad' for the organisation and should be suppressed through coercive means

Implications for handling conflict – eradicate conflict, either by exerting pressure on the assumed troublemakers, or appealing to everyone to pull together.

2) Pluralist Perspective Assumption - conflict is (potentially) a natural state of affairs because different individuals and groups have their own aims that they seek to achieve.

Implications for handling conflict – set up handling mechanisms so that conflict can come to the surface where it can be handled and resolved so that the organisation as a whole is not disrupted by the conflict.

3) Radical Perspective Assumption – organisational conflict merely a reflection of conflict between social classes in wider society, e.g. those who own the organisation and those who sell their labour to it; thus all conflict is between different levels in a hierarchy.

Implications for handling conflict – because the root causes (social inequalities) need to be addressed, it can’t really be handled at the level of an organisation.

4) Interactionist Perspective Assumption – there is an optimum level of organisational conflict; too little and the organisation stagnates, too much and it is disrupted (a refined form of pluralism).

Implications for handling – achieve optimum level; promote conflict if there is too little, resolve it where it is too disruptive

Question 55
Highly routine and mechanical roles produce _________.
  • A.Glow Up
  • B.End Spurt
  • C.Deprivation
  • D.Burnout
Correct Answer: Burnout

Highly routine and mechanical roles produce burnout. The amount of stress (distress) experienced as a source of irritation also contributes to burnout. Several other factors contribute to burnout phenomenon. These are stress being very low or very high, distress, stress prone personality, alienating role or job, hostile relationships, stress – prone life style, avoidance oriented role style, use of dysfunctional coping modes of styles and hostile organisational climate.

 

The opposite of these contribute to the phenomenon of Glow Up. The opposite, phenomenon of glow-up, occurs when stress is properly channelised, resulting in a feeling of challenge, job satisfaction, creativity, effectiveness and a better adjustment to work and life.

 

Deprivation: Blocking or interfering with one’s goal directed activities may also produce frustration. If an employee prepares hard for a career promotion and falls ill during the course of this process he may be forced to take rest. This leads to frustration due to deprivation factor.

Question 56
The HRD concept was first introduced by:
  • A.Leonard Nadler
  • B.RichardBeckhard
  • C.Victor Vroom
  • D.Elton Mayo
Correct Answer: Leonard Nadler

HRD concept was first introduced by Leonard Nadler in 1969 in United States. He published his book "Developing Human Resources". Leonard Nadler defined HRD as those learning experiences, which are organized, for a specific time, and designed to bring about the possibility of behavioral change. It provided a conceptual umbrella under which the field began to unity using three-fold notion of Training, Education and Development.

Question 57
Employees in countries such as Australia and the United States, expect to have a much greater say in decision making and more autonomy in their work. These cultures have been described as having:
  • A.low power distance
  • B.high power distance
  • C.equality of status
  • D.cooperative work environments
Correct Answer: low power distance

The correct answer is option (A) low power distance.

 

Geert Hofstede’s cultural dimension of power distance refers to the extent to which less powerful members of organizations or societies accept and expect that power is distributed unequally.

 

In countries such as Australia and the United States, where employees expect to have more say in decision-making and autonomy in their work, there is a lower power distance. This means that there is less acceptance of hierarchical authority and greater emphasis on equality and individual empowerment. Therefore, option (A) low power distance is the most appropriate description for these cultures.

Question 58
Which of the following methods of performance appraisal places predetermined percentages ofrateesinto several performance categories?
  • A.Alternation Ranking Method
  • B.Paired Comparison Method
  • C.Graphic Rating Scale
  • D.Forced Distribution Method
Correct Answer: Forced Distribution Method

The correct answer is option (D) - Forced Distribution Method.

 

Alternation Ranking Method: This method involves ranking employees in order of performance, but it doesn't predetermine a specific percentage of employees for each ranking category.

 

Paired Comparison Method: This method compares employees in pairs, but again, there's no pre-defined quota for each performance level.

 

Graphic Rating Scale: This method uses a scale with specific descriptions for different performance levels, but it doesn't dictate how many employees should fall under each category.

 

Forced Distribution Method: This method is specifically designed to allocate employees into pre-determined categories based on a percentage distribution. For instance, a common approach might be to categorize employees as top 20%, middle 60%, and bottom 20% based on their performance.

Question 59
Following are the probable errors committed during performance rating:(i) Leniency or severity error(ii) primacy andrecencyeffects(iii) Halo effect(iv) Spillover effect(v) Status effect(vi) Perceptual setSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Only (i), (ii), (iii) are performance rating errors.
  • B.Only (ii), (iv), (v) and (vi) are performance rating errors.
  • C.Only (i), (ii), (iii), (v) and (vi) are performance rating errors.
  • D.All are Performance rating errors.
Correct Answer: All are Performance rating errors.

The correct answer is: option (D) – All are Performance rating errors.

 

Here's a breakdown of the listed factors and why they contribute to errors in performance rating:

 

(i) Leniency or severity error: This occurs when a rater consistently overrates (leniency) or underrates (severity) all employees.
