(ii) Primacy and recency effects: This refers to the tendency to give more weight to recent events or initial impressions, potentially overlooking the overall performance.

 

(iii) Halo effect: This happens when a rater allows one positive or negative aspect of an employee's performance to influence their judgment of other areas.

 

(iv) Spillover effect: This occurs when an employee's performance in one area (e.g., teamwork) unfairly influences the rater's evaluation of their performance in another area (e.g., individual skills).

 

(v) Status effect: This refers to the tendency to rate employees with higher positions or titles more favorably, regardless of their actual performance.

 

(vi) Perceptual set: This involves pre-conceived notions or biases that can cloud the rater's judgment and lead to inaccurate evaluations.

Question 60
The concept that a subordinate should have only one superior to whom he or she is directly responsible is known as:
  • A.Span of control
  • B.Unity of command
  • C.Chain of command
  • D.Authority control
Correct Answer: Unity of command

The correct answer is option (B) – Unity of command.

 

Unity of command is a fundamental principle of management that suggests that each employee should receive orders and instructions from only one supervisor or superior. This principle helps to avoid confusion, minimize conflicts, and maintain clear lines of communication within an organization.

 

Let's briefly explore the other options:

 

(A) Span of control: Span of control refers to the number of subordinates that a manager or supervisor can effectively manage and supervise. It is not directly related to the concept of having one superior.

 

(C) Chain of command: Chain of command refers to the formal hierarchy of authority within an organization, outlining the lines of authority and communication from top management to lower levels. While related to organizational structure, it does not specifically address the principle of one superior.

 

(D) Authority control: This term does not specifically refer to the concept described in the question. Authority control typically refers to mechanisms and processes in place to manage and regulate the exercise of authority within an organization, ensuring compliance with policies and procedures.

Question 61
Which of the following is agraphical method used to help identify the relationship between a measure of business activity and staffing levels of an organization?
  • A.Managerial judgment
  • B.Trend analysis
  • C.Ratio analysis
  • D.Scatter plot
Correct Answer: Ratio analysis

Human resource departments generally use Ratio Analysis Formula to predict annual external hiring requirements. A basic ratio analysis formula can be modified in several ways to forecast different aspects of external hiring demand. Each modification uses specific historical data, such as previous staffing levels, hiring costs and sales revenues, to establish relationships relating to external hiring requirements.

Question 62
Under the Government of India’s 20-Point Economic Programmes, a new scheme for Worker’s Participation in Management, WPM was introduced in 1975. The scheme of Shop and Joint Councils was applicable to establishments employing
  • A.100 or more workers
  • B.200 or more workers
  • C.250 or more workers
  • D.500 or more workers
Correct Answer: 500 or more workers

Under the Government of India’s 20-Point Economic Programmes, a new scheme for Worker’s Participation in Management, WPM was introduced in 1975, after the emergency was declared in June 1975.

 

In the year 1975, the Government formulated a scheme of workers’ participation in industry at Shop Council and Joint Councils. The scheme was to be implemented in the first instance in enterprises in the manufacturing and mining industries, whether these were in the public, private or cooperative sector or departmentally run units irrespective of whether joint consultative machineries had been set up and were functioning in them. The scheme was applicable to such units as were employing 500 or more workers.

Question 63
According to _________________, World Bank Publication, "Corporate Governance is holding the balance between economic and social goals and between individual and community goals."
  • A.Global Compact
  • B.James D.Wolfensohn
  • C.SEBI Committee
  • D.Sir Adrian Cadbury
Correct Answer: Sir Adrian Cadbury

Sir Adrian Cadbury in ‘Global Corporate Governance Forum’, World Bank, 2000, “Corporate Governance is concerned with holding the balance between economic and social goals and between individual and communal goals. The corporate governance framework is there to encourage the efficient use of resources and equally to require accountability for the stewardship of those resources. The aim is to align as nearly as possible the interests of individuals, corporations and society”.

Question 64
The Theory Z was given by:
  • A.Douglas Murray McGregor
  • B.WilliamOuchi
  • C.John Galbraith
  • D.JerdeeandCaroll
Correct Answer: WilliamOuchi

Theory Z of Ouchi is Dr. William Ouchi’s so-called "Japanese Management" style popularized during the Asian economic boom of the 1980s. For Ouchi, Theory Z focused on increasing employee loyalty to the company by providing a job for life with a strong focus on the well-being of the employee, both on and off the job. According to Ouchi, Theory Z management tends to promote stable employment, high productivity, and high employee morale and satisfaction.

 

Theory X and Theory Y are theories of human motivation, created and developed by Douglas McGregor at the MIT Sloan School of Management in the 1960s. Theory X assumptions are that individuals dislike their careers. Theory X people have to be supervised. As for Theory Y assumptions are that individuals like their careers and are willing to take part in responsibility. Theory Y people don't need supervision and can be expected to turn good productive value in their jobs.

Question 65
As in year 2024, which of the following is NOT one of active Payment Banks?
  • A.Aditya Birla Idea Payments Bank
  • B.Tata Financial Services Payment Bank
  • C.India Post Payments Bank, Department of Posts
  • D.JioPayments Bank, Reliance Industries Limited
Correct Answer: Tata Financial Services Payment Bank

Currently India has only 6 Payment Banks as operational – Airtel Payments Bank, Fino Payments Bank, India Post Payments Bank, Jio Payments Bank, NSDL Payments Bank, and Paytm Payment Banks.

Question 66
The number of subsidiaries, under RBI, is:
  • A.1
  • B.2
  • C.3
  • D.4
Correct Answer: 4

The RBI has following Subsidiaries:

(i) Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation of India (DICGC) (set up in 1978),

(ii) Bharatiya Reserve Bank Note Mudran Private Limited (BRBNMPL) (set up in 1995),

(iii) National Housing Bank (NHB) (set up in 1987),

(iv) Reserve Bank Information Technology Private Limited (ReBIT)

Question 67
Accordingly to RBI, a Non Performing Asset (NPA) shall be a loan or an advance where, the interest and/or instalment of principal remain overdue for a period of more than ___________ in respect of a term loan.
  • A.60 days
  • B.75 days
  • C.90 days
  • D.120 days
Correct Answer: 90 days

Accordingly to RBI, a Non Performing Asset (NPA) shall be a loan or an advance where:

(i) interest and/ or instalment of principal remain overdue for a period of more than 90 days in respect of a term loan,

(ii) the account remains ‘out of order’ for a period of more than 90 days, in respect of an Overdraft/Cash Credit (OD/CC),

(iii) the bill remains overdue for a period of more than 90 days in the case of bills purchased and discounted,

(iv) interest and/or instalment of principal remains overdue for two harvest seasons but for a period not exceeding two half years in the case of an advance granted for agricultural purposes, and

(v) any amount to be received remains overdue for a period of more than 90 days in respect of other accounts.

 

Banks are required to classify nonperforming assets in one of three categories according to how long the asset has been non-performing: sub-standard assets, doubtful assets, and loss assets. A sub-standard asset is an asset classified as an NPA for less than 12 months. A doubtful asset is an asset that has been non-performing for more than 12 months. Loss assets are assets with losses identified by the bank, auditor, or inspector and have not been fully written off.

Question 68
In 2006, the Government of India constituted the “Committee on Financial Inclusion” under the chairmanship of ______________ to prepare a strategy of Financial Inclusion.
  • A.K CChakrabarty
  • B.NachiketMore
  • C.Dr.CRangarajan
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Dr.CRangarajan

In 2006, the Government of India constituted the Committee on Financial Inclusion under the chairmanship of Dr. Rangarajan to prepare a strategy of Financial Inclusion.

Question 69
Arrange the following in the order of the years, in which they were formed.(a) Industrial Development Bank of India(b) Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India(c) Small Industries Development Bank of India(d) Shipping credit and Investment Company of India LtdSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(b), (a), (d), (c)
  • B.(a), (b), (d), (c)
  • C.(b), (a), (c), (d)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (b), (a), (d), (c)

Industrial Development Bank of India (IDBI): Established in July 1964, IDBI serves as a key financial institution for industrial growth in India. It offers various forms of financial aid to medium and large-scale industries, including direct assistance like project loans and indirect support through refinancing facilities.

 

Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India (ICICI): Formed in 1955 with support from the World Bank and the Indian government, ICICI initially focused on providing project financing. Over time, it evolved into a diversified financial services group, eventually merging with ICICI Bank in 2002.

 

Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI): Established in April 1990 as a subsidiary of IDBI, SIDBI plays a vital role in promoting and financing small-scale industries. It aims to empower the MSME sector through various initiatives, including credit guarantee schemes and venture capital support.

 

Industrial Reconstruction Bank of India (IRBI) and Industrial Investment Bank of India Ltd. (IIBI): Initially set up for rehabilitating sick industrial companies, IRBI was reconstituted as IIBI in 1997 to become a full-fledged development financial institution. However, IIBI was closed down in 2012.

 

Shipping Credit and Investment Company of India Ltd. (SCICI): Established in 1986 as a public financial institution, SCICI played a crucial role in supporting shipping and related industries. It was merged with ICICI in 2013, expanding the latter's portfolio of services.

Question 70
The Non-Deposit taking NBFCs (NBFC-ND) are further classified into 2 types based on the asset size as “Systemically Important (SI)” and “Non-Systemically Important (Non-SI)”. NBFCs whose asset size are of ______________ as per last audited balance sheet are considered as “Systemically Important” NBFCs. The others are considered as “Non-Systemically Important” NBFCs.
  • A.Rs50 Crore or more
  • B.Rs100 Crore or more
  • C.Rs300 Crore or more
  • D.Rs500 Crore or more
Correct Answer: Rs500 Crore or more

For the purpose of Registration, NBFCs are classified into two categories by RBI, viz.

(i) Deposit taking NBFCs (NBFC-D) and

(ii) Non-Deposit taking NBFCs (NBFC-ND).

 

The Non-Deposit taking NBFCs (NBFC-ND) are further classified into 2 types based on source of funds and customer interface as follows:

(i) Type I - NBFC-ND not accepting public funds not having customer interface.

(ii) Type II - NBFC-ND accepting public funds and/or having customer interface.

 

The Non-Deposit taking NBFCs (NBFC-ND) are further classified into two types based on the asset size as “Systemically Important (SI)” and “Non-Systemically Important (Non-SI)”. NBFCs whose asset size are of Rs 500 Crores or more as per last audited balance sheet are considered as “Systemically Important” NBFCs, while those with asset size less than Rs 500 Crores are considered as “Non-Systemically Important” NBFCs.

Question 71
Which of the following is incorrect about BHIM mobile app?
  • A.BHIM is an acronym of Bharat Interface for Money Application
  • B.BHIM is competing with Google Pay andPhonePe.
  • C.It works on the Unified Payment Interface (UPI) technology.
  • D.It is owned by thePaytmcompany.
Correct Answer: It is owned by thePaytmcompany.

Option D is incorrect.

 

(A) BHIM is an acronym of Bharat Interface for Money Application: This statement is correct. BHIM stands for Bharat Interface for Money.

 

(B) BHIM is competing with Google Pay and PhonePe: This statement is correct. BHIM acts as a digital payment platform similar to Google Pay and PhonePe, making them competitors in the market.

 

(C) It works on the Unified Payment Interface (UPI) technology: This statement is correct. BHIM leverages UPI, a technology facilitating interbank transactions.

 

(D) It is owned by the Paytm company: This statement is incorrect. BHIM is a government-backed initiative supported by the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI). It's not affiliated with any specific private company like Paytm.

Question 72
Match the following.List-I (Types of BuyingBehaviour)(a) Complex BuyingBehaviour(b) Dissonance Reducing BuyingBehaviour(c) Habitual BuyingBehaviour(d) Variety-Seeking BuyingBehaviourList-II (Brand & Involvement)1. Few differences among brands and High Involvement2. Few differences among brands and Low Involvement3. Significant among between brands and High Involvement4. Significant among between brands and Low Involvement
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4
  • C.a-2, b-1, c-3, d-4
  • D.a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1
Correct Answer: a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4

The correct match for the types of buying behavior with their corresponding brand involvement is:

 

(a) Complex Buying Behaviour - 3. Significant among between brands and High Involvement

(b) Dissonance Reducing Buying Behaviour - 1. Few differences among brands and High Involvement

(c) Habitual Buying Behaviour - 2. Few differences among brands and Low Involvement

(d) Variety-Seeking Buying Behaviour - 4. Significant among between brands and Low Involvement

 

So, the correct answer is option (B) – 3 1 2 4.

Question 73
The ________ holds that the organization’s task is to determine the needs, wants, and interests of target markets and to deliver the desired satisfactions more effectively and efficiently than competitors in a way that preserves or enhances the consumer’s and the society’s well-being.
  • A.Customer-centeredbusiness
  • B.Focused business model
  • C.Societal marketing concept
  • D.Ethically responsible marketing
Correct Answer: Societal marketing concept

The correct answer is option (C) – Societal marketing concept.

 

The societal marketing concept emphasizes that organizations should not only focus on meeting the needs and wants of their target markets but also ensure that their actions benefit both the consumers and society as a whole. It goes beyond just satisfying customers to consider the broader implications of marketing activities on societal well-being. This concept advocates for ethical and responsible marketing practices that promote the long-term welfare of customers and society.

Question 74
Which one of the step is NOT included under the step of consumer buying process?
  • A.Evaluation of alternatives
  • B.Problem recognition
  • C.Purchase decision
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

The correct answer is option (D) – None of the Above.

 

All the steps mentioned in the options are indeed part of the consumer buying process:

 

Problem recognition: This is the first step where the consumer identifies a need or problem that can be solved through a purchase.

 

Evaluation of alternatives: After recognizing the problem, consumers typically search for information about different options available to fulfill their needs and evaluate the alternatives.

 

Purchase decision: Once consumers have evaluated the alternatives, they make a decision to purchase the product or service that best meets their needs and preferences.

Question 75
Match the following.List-I (Cost-based Pricing)(a) Mark-up pricing(b) Absorption pricing(c) Rate of return pricing(d) Marginal cost pricingList-II (Example)1. Adding a margin to the cost price2. Normal level of production3. Investment criteria4. Variable cost and proportion of fixed costSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-1, b-4, c-3, d-2
  • B.a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1
  • C.a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1
  • D.a-3, b-2, c-1, d-4
Correct Answer: a-1, b-4, c-3, d-2

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Mark-up pricing involves adding a predetermined percentage of profit (or mark-up) to the cost price to determine the selling price.

 

Absorption pricing involves setting the price based on the total cost, including both variable and fixed costs, per unit of output.

 

Rate of return pricing sets the price based on the desired rate of return on investment, considering the total investment in the product or service.

 

Marginal cost pricing involves setting the price based on the variable cost per unit of output, with no consideration for fixed costs.

Question 76
Which of the following statement is true?
  • A.Product line a group of products that are closely related either because they satisfy a class of need, are used together are sold to the same customer groups, are marketed through the same types of outlets or fall within given price ranges.
  • B.Test marketing is the stage where the entire product and marketing programming is tried out for the first time in a small number of well-chosen and authentic sales environments.
  • C.Product mix the composite of product offered for sale by a, firm or a business unit
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The correct answer is option (D) – All of the above.

 

Statement (A) defines a product line, which is indeed a group of products that are closely related in various aspects such as fulfilling similar needs, being used together, targeting the same customer segments, being sold through similar channels, or falling within certain price ranges.

 

Statement (B) accurately describes test marketing, which involves introducing a new product or marketing program on a limited scale in a real market environment to evaluate its performance and gather feedback before a full-scale launch.

 

Statement (C) defines product mix, which refers to the entire range of products offered by a company or a business unit, encompassing all the different product lines and individual products within those lines.

Question 77
In marketing 'SEM' means
  • A.Search-Engine-Marketing
  • B.Strategy-Engine-Money
  • C.Sales-Engine-Management
  • D.Sales-even-Money
Correct Answer: Search-Engine-Marketing

SEM stands for Search Engine Marketing. It is a type of internet-based marketing associated with the researching, submitting and positioning of a website within search engines to achieve maximum visibility and to increase company’s share of paid and/or organic traffic referrals from search engines. SEM involves things such as search engine optimization (SEO), keyword research, competitive analysis, paid listings and other search engine services that will increase search traffic to your site.

Question 78
Match the following –List-I (Physical Distribution Activities)(a) Order Processing(b) Packaging(c) Warehousing(d) Customer ServiceList-II (Example)1. Storage2. Repair3. Catalogue4. Protection
  • A.a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2
  • B.a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1
  • C.a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1
  • D.a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2
Correct Answer: a-3, b-4, c-1, d-2

Option A is the correct answer.

 

An order is processed once the customer selects a product from company’s catalogue.

 

Product catalogues help determine the types of products a service provider can sell, to whom they can sell, for how much and under what terms.

 

Packaging is done to ensure that the product, that is being ordered by the customer reaches his door steps without any damages. Thus it is done to protect the product from being damaged.

 

A warehouse is a place where company stores its finished products or raw material.

 

Customer service is required to look into post-purchase customer complaints, like repair, replacement or return of faulty product.

Question 79
Holistic Marketing incorporates:1. Relationship marketing and Integrated marketing2. Internal Marketing and Performance marketingSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.1 only
  • B.2 only
  • C.Both 1 and 2
  • D.Neither 1 nor 2
Correct Answer: Both 1 and 2

The Holistic marketing concept is based on the development, design, and implementation of marketing programs, processes, and activities that recognize their breadth and interdependencies. Holistic marketing recognizes that everything matters in marketing and that a broad, integrated perspective is often necessary. It has four components:

 

1. Relationship Marketing: A key goal of marketing is to develop deep, enduring relationships with people and organizations that directly or indirectly affect the success of the firm’s marketing activities. Relationship marketing aims to build mutually satisfying long-term relationships with key constituents in order to earn and retain their business. Four key constituents for relationship marketing are customers, employees, marketing partners (channels, suppliers, distributors, dealers, agencies), and members of the financial community (shareholders, investors, analysts).

 

2. Integrated Marketing: Occurs when the marketer devises marketing activities and assembles marketing programs to create, communicate, and deliver value for consumers such that “the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.” Two key themes are that (1) many different marketing activities can create, communicate, and deliver value and (2) marketers should design and implement any one marketing activity with all other activities in mind.

 

3. Internal Marketing: An element of marketing is the task of hiring, training, and motivating able employees who want to serve customers well. It ensures that everyone in the organization embraces appropriate marketing principles, especially senior management.

 

4. Performance Marketing: Requires understanding the financial and nonfinancial returns to business and society from marketing activities and programs. Smart marketers go beyond sales revenue to examine the marketing scorecard and interpret what is happening to market share, customer loss rate, customer satisfaction, product quality, and other measures. They also consider the legal, ethical, social and environmental effects of marketing activities and programs.

 

Question 80
The ________ holds that the organization’s task is to determine the needs, wants, and interests of target markets and to deliver the desired satisfactions more effectively and efficiently than competitors in a way that preserves or enhances the consumer’s and the society’s well-being.
  • A.Customer-centeredbusiness
  • B.Focused business model
  • C.Societal marketing concept
  • D.Ethically responsible marketing
Correct Answer: Societal marketing concept

The correct answer is option (C) – Societal marketing concept.

 

Customer-centered business: This approach prioritizes customer satisfaction but doesn't necessarily consider the broader societal impact.

 

Focused business model: This strategy involves concentrating resources on a specific market segment or product category, again, without explicitly addressing societal well-being.

 

Ethically responsible marketing: This concept emphasizes ethical practices throughout the marketing process, but the focus might be primarily on fair treatment of customers and avoiding harm, not necessarily extending to broader societal concerns.

 

Societal marketing concept: This concept specifically addresses the needs of both consumers and society. It emphasizes delivering desired customer satisfaction while also considering the long-term well-being of the community and environment.

Question 81
Which one of the following attributes of advertising regarding scheduling for seasonal product categories, and involves intermittent and irregular periods of advertising?
  • A.Pulsing
  • B.Continuity
  • C.Concentration
  • D.Flighting
Correct Answer: Flighting

The correct answer is option (D) – Flighting.

 

Pulsing: This strategy involves advertising throughout the year with periods of increased ad frequency during specific times. While it involves variation in intensity, there's still a presence throughout the year.

 

Continuity: This approach involves running advertisements consistently throughout the year, maintaining a constant level of brand awareness.

 

Concentration: This strategy focuses on placing a high concentration of advertising within a specific timeframe, but it doesn't necessarily involve intermittent periods.

 

Flighting: This method is characterized by intermittent and irregular periods of advertising. Ads are shown heavily during peak demand seasons for the product category and then go on hiatus during low-demand periods.

Question 82
Under Indian Contract Act, 1872, a sub-agent is a person employed by and acting under the control of
  • A.The principal only
  • B.The original agent in the business of agency only
  • C.Both the principal and original agent
  • D.Neither the Principal nor the original agent
Correct Answer: The original agent in the business of agency only

A sub-agent is a person employed by and acting under the control of the original agent in the business of agency only. The provisions of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, with respect to sub-agent is explained below:

 

Sub-Agent: As per the Indian Contract Act, “a sub-agent is a person employed by, and acting under the control of the original agent in the business of the agency.” So, the sub-agent is the agent of the original agent.

 

As between themselves, the relation of sub-agent and original agent is that of agent and the principal. A subagent is bound by all the duties of the original agent. The sub-agent is not directly responsible to the principal except for fraud and wilful wrong. The sub-agent is responsible to the original agent. The original agent is responsible to the principal for the acts of the sub-agent. As regards third persons, the principal is represented by sub-agent and he is bound and responsible for all the acts of sub-agent as if he were an agent originally appointed by the principal.

Question 83
Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to ‘Contract of Sale’ in Sale of Goods Act, 1930?
  • A.A contract of sale is made by an offer to buy or sell goods for a price and the acceptance of such offer.
  • B.Where there is a contract for the sale of specific goods, the contract is void, if the goods without the knowledge of the seller have, at the time when the contract was made, become perished or damaged.
  • C.The goods which form the subject of a contract of sale may be either existing goods, owned or possessed by the seller, but cannot be future goods.
  • D.The contract of Sale may be made in writing or by word of mouth, or partly in writing and partly by word of mouth or may be implied from the conduct of the parties.
Correct Answer: The goods which form the subject of a contract of sale may be either existing goods, owned or possessed by the seller, but cannot be future goods.

Statement C is incorrect as the goods which form the subject of a contract of sale may be either existing goods, owned or possessed by the seller, or future goods.

Question 84
Which of the following statements are correct with respect to Negotiable Instruments?(i) A promissory note or a bill of exchange payable after a fixed period, or after sight, or on specified day, or on the happening of an event which is certain to happen, is known as a time instrument.(ii) An instrument which is not an inland instrument, is deemed to be a foreign instrument.(iii) A promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque is payable to order which is expressed to be payable to a particular person, and does not contain any words prohibiting transfer or indicating an intention that it shall not be transferable.(iv) A promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque is payable to bearer when it is expressed to be so payable, or the only or last endorsement on the instrument is an endorsement in blank.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) and (ii)
  • B.(iii) and (iv)
  • C.(i) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

All the above statements are correct.

 

The negotiable instruments may be classified as under:

 

Bearer Instruments

A promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque is payable to bearer when:

(i) it is expressed to be so payable, or

(ii) the only or last endorsement on the instrument is an endorsement in blank.

 

A person who is a holder of a bearer instrument can obtain the payment of the instrument.

 

Order Instruments

A promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque is payable to order:

(i) which is expressed to be so payable; or

(ii) which is expressed to be payable to a particular person, and does not contain any words prohibiting transfer or indicating an intention that it shall not be transferable.

 

Inland Instruments

A promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque drawn or made in India, and made payable, or drawn upon any person, resident in India shall be deemed to be an inland instrument. Since a promissory note is not drawn on any person, an inland promissory note is one which is made payable in India. Subject to this exception, an inland instrument is one which is either:

(i) drawn and made payable in India, or

(ii) drawn in India upon some persons resident therein, even though it is made payable in a foreign country.

 

Foreign Instruments

An instrument which is not an inland instrument, is deemed to be a foreign instrument. The essentials of a foreign instrument include that:

(i) it must be drawn outside India and made payable outside or inside India; or

(ii) it must be drawn in India and made payable outside India and drawn on a person resident outside India.

 

Demand Instruments

A promissory note or a bill of exchange in which no time for payment is specified is an instrument payable on demand.

 

Time Instruments

Time instruments are those which are payable at some time in the future. Therefore, a promissory note or a bill of exchange payable after a fixed period, or after sight, or on specified day, or on the happening of an event which is certain to happen, is known as a time instrument.

 

In the case of bill of exchange, the expression “after sight” means after acceptance, or after noting for non-acceptance or after protest for non-acceptance.

Question 85
Under the Companies Act, 2013, the companies are generally formed with the feature of limited liability. In which of the following cases, members can be severally held liable for the payment of whole debt of the Company?
  • A.Where a company fails to repay the deposit or part thereof or any interest thereon.
  • B.If at any time number of members of a company is reduced below statutory minimum that is 7 in case of a public company and 2 in case of a private company and the company continues to carry on its business for more than six months
  • C.When the company is incorporated as an Unlimited Company.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

In all the above cases, members can be severally held liable for the payment of whole debt of the Company.

 

Limited Liability as a characteristic of a Company:

“The privilege of limited liability for business debts is one of the principal advantages of doing business under the corporate form of organisation.” The company, being a separate person, is the owner of its assets and bound by its liabilities. The liability of a member as shareholder, extends to the contribution to the capital of the company up to the nominal value of the shares held and not paid by him. Members, even as a whole, are neither the owners of the company’s undertakings, nor liable for its debts.

 

However, members can be severally held liable for the payment of whole debts of the company in following cases:

If at any time number of members of a company is reduced below statutory minimum that is 7 in case of a public company and 2 in case of a private company and the company continues to carry on its business for more than six months, while the number of members is so reduced (Sec. 3A inserted vide The Companies Amendment Act, 2017).

When the company is incorporated as an Unlimited Company.

When the Tribunal is satisfied that the company got incorporated by furnishing any false or incorrect information during incorporation.

Where in the course of its winding up it appears that the business of the company has been carried on with an intent to defraud its creditors or any other person.

Where it is proved that a prospectus has been issued for any fraudulent purpose.

Where a company fails to repay the deposit or part thereof or any interest thereon.

Question 86
Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to registration of Limited Liability Partnerships?
  • A.The applicants can place 3 choices for names in the form which should be unique.
  • B.Once the name approval application is accepted by the MCA, an LLP name approval letter will be issued to the proposed Partners. The Partners then have 90 days to file the required incorporation documents and register the LLP.
  • C.After receiving the Name approval Letter from ROC (Registrar of Companies), the incorporation document shall be filed with the ROC along with the fee within 60 days from the date of name approval.
  • D.After incorporation of LLP, LLP agreement has to be filed with ROC within 30 days of incorporation of LLP.
Correct Answer: The applicants can place 3 choices for names in the form which should be unique.

Statement A is incorrect as the applicants can place 6 choices for names in the form which should be unique.

Question 87
Under the Competition Act, 2002, the revised threshold limits for ‘Individual combination’ effective March 2016 are:
  • A.Either the combined assets of the enterprises would value more than (INR) 1,500 crores in India or the combined turnover of the enterprise is more than (INR) 4,500 crores in India. In case either or both of the enterprises have assets/turnover outside India also, then the combined assets of the enterprises value more than US$ 750 million, including at least (INR) 750 crores in India, or turnover is more than US$ 2,250 million including at least (INR) 2,250 crores in India.
  • B.Either the combined assets of the enterprises would value more than (INR) 2,000 crores in India or the combined turnover of the enterprise is more than (INR) 6,000 crores in India. In case either or both of the enterprises have assets/turnover outside India also, then the combined assets of the enterprises value more than US$ 1 billion, including at least (INR) 1000 crores in India, or turnover is more than US$ 3 billion, including at least (INR) 3,000 crores in India.
  • C.Either the combined assets of the enterprises would value more than (INR) 1,000 crores in India or the combined turnover of the enterprise is more than (INR) 3,000 crores in India. In case either or both of the enterprises have assets/turnover outside India also, then the combined assets of the enterprises value more than US$ 500 million, including at least (INR) 500 crores in India, or turnover is more than US$ 1,500 million, including at least (INR) 1,500 crores in India.
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Either the combined assets of the enterprises would value more than (INR) 2,000 crores in India or the combined turnover of the enterprise is more than (INR) 6,000 crores in India. In case either or both of the enterprises have assets/turnover outside India also, then the combined assets of the enterprises value more than US$ 1 billion, including at least (INR) 1000 crores in India, or turnover is more than US$ 3 billion, including at least (INR) 3,000 crores in India.

Option B is the correct answer.

Question 88
Match the following schedules with their content as attached to the Information Technology Act, 2000.List I(a) First Schedule(b) Second Schedule(c) Third ScheduleList II(i)Omitted by the Information Technology (Amendment) Act, 2008.(ii)Documents or transactions to which the act shall not apply.(iii)Technique and process of Electronic Signature or electronic Authentication.
  • A.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
  • B.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-i
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iii, c-i

List of Schedules under Information Technology Act, 2000

 

First Schedule- Documents or transactions to which the act shall not apply

 

Second Schedule- Technique and process of Electronic Signature or electronic Authentication.

 

Third Schedule- Omitted by the Information Technology (Amendment) Act, 2008.

 

Fourth Schedule- Omitted by the Information Technology (Amendment) Act, 2008.

Question 89
Who are covered under Competent Authority under the Right to Information Act, 2005?
  • A.Chief Justice of India in the case of the Supreme Court;
  • B.Chair­man in the case of the Council of States of a Legislative Council of States
  • C.Chief Justice of the High Court in the case of a High Court
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Competent authority under Right to Information Act means:

(a) Speaker in the case of the House of the People or the Legislative Assembly of a State or a Union territory having such Assembly;

(b) Chair­man in the case of the Council of States of a Legislative Council of States;

(c) Chief Justice of India in the case of the Supreme Court;

(d) Chief Justice of the High Court in the case of a High Court;

(e) President or the Governor, as the case may be, in the case of other authorities established or constituted by or under the Constitution;

(f) Administrator appointed under article 239 of the Constitution.

Question 90
The term of copyright for an author lasts how long?
  • A.The life of the author
  • B.The life of the author plus 60 years
  • C.95 years
  • D.75 years
Correct Answer: The life of the author plus 60 years

The term of copyright for an author lasts for the life of the author plus 60 years.

 

Term of Copyright

Literary, dramatic, musical or artistic works enjoy copyright protection for the life time of the author plus 60 years beyond i.e. 60 years after his death. In the case of copyright in posthumous, anonymous and pseudonymous works, photographs, cinematograph films, sound recordings, works of Government, public undertaking and international organisations, the term of protection is 60 years from the beginning of the calendar year next following the year in which the work has been first published.

 

This right is to be enjoyed by every broadcasting organisation for a period of 25 years from the beginning of the calendar year next following the year in which the broadcast is made.

Question 91
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to administration of Goods and Service Tax?
  • A.Central Goods and Service Tax is a revenue source to the Central Government of India, on intra-state supplies of taxable goods or services or both.
  • B.No cross utilization of credit would be permitted except in case of IGST.
  • C.The revenue of inter-state sales will not accrue to the exporting state and the exporting state will be required to transfer to the Centre the credit of SGST/UTGST used in payment of IGST.
  • D.None of the above.
Correct Answer: None of the above.

As all the above statements are correct, hence option D is the answer.

Question 92
Income of a person leaving India who has no present intention of returning to India is charged to tax in the previous year itself. In this case, the total income of such individual up to _______________ shall be charged to tax in that assessment year.
  • A.The probable date of his departure from India
  • B.The end of the assessment year
  • C.The end of the previous year
  • D.The end of the previous year in which he leaves India
Correct Answer: The probable date of his departure from India

If following conditions are satisfied, then income of a person leaving India is charged to tax in previous year itself:

It appears to the Assessing Officer that any individual may leave India during the current assessment year or shortly after its expiry.

Such a person has no present intention of returning to India.

 

In above case, the total income of such individual up to the probable date of his departure from India shall be charged to tax in that assessment year

Question 93
State which combination of statements is correct with respect to exempted allowances under the head Salaries in Income Act, 1961?(a) Children Education allowance exempted up toRs. 300 per month per child up to a maximum of 2 children.(b) Hostel Expenditure allowance exempted up toRs. 100 per month per child up to a maximum of 2 children.(c) Transport Allowance granted to an employee to (who is a blind and handicap) to meet expenditure on commuting between place of residence and place of duty is exempted up toRs. 3,200 per month for blind and handicapped employees(d) Underground Allowance to employees working in uncongenial, unnatural climate in underground mines is exempted up toRs. 800 per month.(e) Tribal area allowance exempted up toRs. 200 per month.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (c)
  • B.(b), (c), (d)
  • C.(a), (b), (d)
  • D.(c), (d), (e)
Correct Answer: (c), (d), (e)

The Children Education is exempt up to Rs. 100 per month per child up to a maximum of 2 children and Hostel Expenditure Allowance is exempt up to Rs. 300 per month per child up to a maximum of 2 children. Hence, the options (c), (d) and (e) are correct.

Question 94
Mr.Rajatsold his old house in April, 2018 forRs. 25,20,000. Long-term capital gain arising on transfer of old house amounted toRs. 8,40,000. In December, 2018 he purchased another residential house worthRs. 10,00,000. The new house was however, sold in April, 2019 forRs. 12,00,000(stamp duty value of the new house wasRs. 10,00,000). What will be amount of taxable capital gains in the hands of Mr.Rajatfor the financial years 2018-19 and amount of exemption under section 54 of the Income Tax Act?
  • A.Rs.8,40,000 andRs. 10,00,000
  • B.Rs. 10,00,000 andRs. 8,40,000
  • C.Nil andRs. 8,40,000
  • D.Rs. 8,40,000 and Nil
Correct Answer: Nil andRs. 8,40,000

Computation of capital gains for the financial year 2018-19:

 

Particulars

Amount in (Rs.)

Long-term capital gain arising on transfer of old house

8,40,000

Less: Exemption under section 54 (*)

8,40,000

Taxable long-term capital gains

Nil

 

(*) Exemption under section 54 will be lower of following:

(a) Amount of capital gains arising on transfer of residential house; or

(b) Investment in new residential house property

Considering the above provisions, the exemption in this case will be lower of the following amount:

(a) Amount of capital gain, i.e., Rs. 8,40,000.

(b) Amount of investment in new house, i.e,. Rs. 10,00,000

 

Thus, the taxable LTCG shall be Nil and the exemption will be Rs. 8,40,000.

Question 95
Which of the following incomes of Mrs. A can be clubbed with her spouse’s income under the provisions of Income Tax Act, 1961?(i)Mrs. Areceiving a salaryfrom a company or a firm in which Mr. A is having substantial interest.(ii) Mrs. A receiving a salary in the same company in professional capacity.(iii)Mr. Atransfers an assetto his spouse directly or indirectly without receiving adequate consideration.(iv)Mr. Atransfers an assetto an association of persons, directly or indirectly, without adequate consideration, so that the benefit arises to Mrs. A on a deferred basis from such transfer.Select the correct answer using the codes given below
  • A.(i), (iii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii) only
  • C.(i) only
  • D.(iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii) and (iv)

Incomes mentioned in (i), (iii) and (iv) can be clubbed with the income of Mr. A.

 

Clubbing of income

As the term suggests, clubbing of income means adding or including the income of another person (mostly family members) to one’s own income. This is allowed under Section 64 of the IT Act. However, certain restrictions pertaining to specified person(s) and specified scenarios are mandated to discourage this practice.

 

Clubbing of Spouse's Income:

 

When it comes to taxation, there are situations where your spouse's income may be considered as part of your income, and you'll be liable to pay tax on it.

 

(i) If your spouse earns a salary from a company or firm where you have a significant stake, that income will be added to your income. A significant stake means you or your relatives (like husband, wife, siblings, or parents) own 20% or more equity in a company or are entitled to 20% or more profits in a firm. However, if your spouse earns income due to their technical or professional skills, it will be taxed separately.

 

(ii) If you transfer an asset to your spouse without adequate payment (except in divorce settlements), any income from that asset will be added to your income. For example, if you transfer an asset worth Rs 1,00,000 to your wife for Rs 25,000 to lower your taxes, 3/4th of the income from that asset will be taxed in your hands. Even if you transfer a house property to your wife without adequate payment, you'll still be considered the owner for tax purposes.

 

(iii) If you transfer an asset to someone without adequate payment, and the benefit goes to your spouse, the income from that asset will be considered part of your income.

 

(iv) If you give money to your non-working spouse, and they invest it to generate income, that income will be added to your income. However, if your spouse reinvests the income and earns further income, it may not be added to your taxable income.

Question 96
Dividend received from a foreign company is charged to tax under the head______.
  • A.Profits and gains of business or profession
  • B.Capital gains
  • C.Income from other sources
  • D.Income from salaries
Correct Answer: Income from other sources

Dividend received from a foreign company is charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”. Thus, option C is the correct option.

Question 97
Which of the following incomes will be taxed under the head ‘Income from other sources’.(i) Lease rent of vacant plot of land ofRs. 52,200 received by Mr. Kumar.(ii)Rs. 8,400 won by Mr. Shan from a crossword puzzle.(iii)Rs. 2,52,000received by Mr. Kumar from his friends on his wedding anniversary.(iv) Interest ofRs. 8,252 received by Mr.Sahilon a bank deposit.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii)
  • B.(i), (iii), (iv)
  • C.(iii) and (iv)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

 

Sl. No.

Nature of income

Head of Taxability

(i)

Lease rent of vacant plot of land of Rs. 52,200 received by Mr. Kumar.

Lease rent from vacant land is always charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”.

(ii)

Rs. 8,400 won by Mr. Shan from a crossword puzzle.

Income by way of winnings from lotteries, crossword puzzles, races including horse races, card games and other game of any sort, gambling or betting of any form whatsoever, are always charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”. Hence, Rs. 8,400 won from a crossword puzzle will be charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”.

(iii)

Rs. 2,52,000 received by Mr. Kumar from his friends on his wedding anniversary.

Gifts received by an individual or HUF (which are charged to tax) are taxed under the head “Income from other sources”. In this case, gift is received from friends and it exceeds Rs. 50,000. Hence, entire amount will be charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”.

(iv)

Interest of Rs. 8,252 received by Mr. Sahil on a bank deposit.

Interest on bank deposits is charged to tax under the head “Income from other sources”.

 

Question 98
Which of the following factors need to be considered while taking ‘Make or Buy’ Decisions?
  • A.labour problem in the factory
  • B.dependence upon supplier
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Make or Buy - Many costing or non-costing considerations guide the decision relating to ‘make or buy’. Some of these considerations are – (a) utilisation of capacity, (b) inadequacy of funds, (c) latest technology, (d) variable cost of manufacturing vis-à-vis purchase price, (e) dependence upon supplier, (f) labour problem in the factory, etc.

 

The following tax consideration one has to keep in mind while taking ‘make or buy’ decision:

(a) Establishing a new unit – If the decision to manufacture a part or component involves setting up a separate industrial unit, then tax incentives available under section 10A, 10B, 32, 80-IA, 80-IB and 80-IC one has to keep in mind.

(b) Sale of plant and machinery – If buying a cheaper than manufacturing and the assessee decides to ‘buy’ parts or components for a long period of time, he may like to sell all the existing plant and machinery. Tax implications, as specified by section 50, one has to consider for taking the decision.

Question 99
Which Goods and Transactions are not classified under Tax Collected at Source?
  • A.Scrap
  • B.Toll Plaza, Parking lot ticket, Quarrying, and Mining
  • C.Bullion that exceeds overRs. 2 lakhs/ Jewellery that exceeds overRs. 5 lakhs
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

Tax Collected at Source (TCS) is income tax collected in India payable by the seller who collects in turn from the buyer and it is provided under section 206C of Income Tax Act, 1961 at the sale of some goods which are specified. The TCS Rate is different for each category of goods.

 

Goods and Transactions Classified under TCS: The following are considered for collecting tax at source:

Liquor of alcoholic nature for human consumption including IMFL (Indian Made Foreign Liquor),

Timber wood obtained from a forest that has been leased,

Tendu Leaves,

Timber wood by any other mode than leased,

A forest produces other than Tendu leaves and timber,

Scrap,

Toll Plaza, Parking lot ticket, Quarrying, and Mining,

Minerals that include lignite or coal or iron ore,

Bullion (gold or silver in bulk) that exceeds over Rs. 2 lakhs/ Jewellery that exceeds over Rs. 5 lakhs.

Question 100
As per section 208 of the Income Tax Act, every person whose estimated tax liability for the year exceeds ___________, shall pay his tax in advance in the form of “advance tax”.
  • A.Rs. 5,000
  • B.Rs. 10,000
  • C.Rs. 25,000
  • D.Rs. 50,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 10,000

As per section 208, every person whose estimated tax liability for the year exceeds Rs.

10,000, shall pay his tax in advance in the form of “advance tax”.

Quiz Attempt #119003

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
Which of the following is NOT a pillar of the Foreign Trade Policy 2023?
  • A.Incentive to Remission
  • B.Export promotion through collaboration
  • C.Import Reduction
  • D.Ease of Doing Business
Correct Answer: Import Reduction

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The pillars of the Foreign Trade Policy 2023 include Incentive to Remission, Export promotion through collaboration, Ease of doing business, reduction in transaction cost and e-initiatives, and Emerging Areas – E-Commerce Developing Districts. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Increase in transaction costs.

 

The Union Ministry of Commerce and Industry notified the Foreign Trade Policy 2023. It is notified by the Central Government, in the exercise of powers conferred under Section 5 of the Foreign Trade (Development & Regulation) Act, 1992.

 

The Key Approach to the policy is based on these 4 pillars:

(i) Incentive to Remission,

(ii) Export promotion through collaboration - Exporters, States, Districts, Indian Missions,

(iii) Ease of doing business, reduction in transaction cost and e-initiatives, and

(iv) Emerging Areas – E-Commerce Developing Districts as Export Hubs and streamlining SCOMET policy.

Question 2
The District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum shall have jurisdiction to entertain complaints where the value of the goods or services and the compensation:
  • A.does not exceedRs20 lakhs
  • B.Rs20 lakhs to 50 lakhs
  • C.Rs50 lakhs to 100 lakhs
  • D.does not exceedRs50 lakhs
Correct Answer: does not exceedRs20 lakhs

Three-Tier Grievance Redressal Machinery

The Consumer Protection Act 1986 provides for a three-tier redressal mechanism at the District, State and National levels for redressal of consumer disputes and grievances.

 

1. District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum

The State Government shall, establish a District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum (to be known as the District Forum). The District Forum shall have jurisdiction to entertain complaints where the value of the goods or services and the compensation, does not exceed Rs 20 lakhs.

 

2. State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission

The State Government shall, establish a State Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (to be known as the State Commission). The State Commission shall have jurisdiction to entertain complaints:

(a) Where the value of the goods or services and the compensation, exceeds Rs 20 lakhs but does not exceed Rs 100 lakhs,

(b) Appeals against the orders of any District Forum within the State.

 

3. National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission

The State Government shall, establish a National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission (to be known as the National Commission). The National Commission shall have jurisdiction to entertain complaints:

(a) Where the value of the goods or services and the compensation, exceeds Rs 100 lakhs,

(b) Appeals against the orders of any State Commission.

Question 3
Which of the following factors does NOTconstitute the social environment?
  • A.Life Expectancy
  • B.Population shifts
  • C.Composition of family
  • D.Level of political morality
Correct Answer: Level of political morality

Some of the elements of Social Environment are:

Attitudes towards product innovations, lifestyles, occupational distribution and consumer preferences

Concern with quality of life

Life expectancy

Expectations from the workforce

Shifts in the presence of women in the workforce

Birth and death rates

Population shifts

Educational system and literacy rates

Consumption habits

Composition of family

 

Level of Political Morality is a factor of political environment.

Question 4
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II and select the correct answer.List – I(i) Micro Environment(ii) Macro Environment(iii) Internal Environment(iv) External EnvironmentList – II(a) PESTLE Analysis(b) Micro and Macro environment comes under this(c) Quality of Human Resource(d) Task environment/ Companies immediate environment
  • A.i-(d), ii-(b), iii-(a), iv-(c)
  • B.i-(b), ii-(a), iii-(c), iv-(d)
  • C.i-(d), ii-(a), iii-(c), iv-(b)
  • D.i-(c), ii-(d), iii-(a), iv-(b)
Correct Answer: i-(d), ii-(a), iii-(c), iv-(b)

The correct match is provided in option C.

 

Micro Environment (i) is matched with (d) Task environment/ Companies immediate environment. The micro-environment involves factors that are in close proximity to the company and directly impact its operations. This includes elements like customers, suppliers, competitors, and other stakeholders that are part of the immediate business environment.

 

Macro Environment (ii) is matched with (a) PESTLE Analysis. The macro-environment encompasses broader external factors that affect the industry or market as a whole. PESTLE Analysis is a tool used to analyze these factors, including political, economic, social, technological, legal, and environmental influences.

 

Internal Environment (iii) is matched with (c) Quality of Human Resource. The internal environment refers to factors within the organization itself that can influence its operations and performance. The quality of human resources is an internal factor that can significantly impact an organization's success.

 

External Environment (iv) is matched with (b) Micro and Macro environment comes under this. The external environment includes both micro and macro elements. It comprises factors that are outside the immediate control of the company but can still influence its performance and strategy.

Question 5
The _________ is a condition of slow economic growth and relatively high unemployment, or economic stagnation, accompanied by rising prices.
  • A.Stagflation
  • B.Deflation
  • C.Recession
  • D.Inflation
Correct Answer: Stagflation

The correct answer is (A) Stagflation.

 

Stagflation is a term used to describe a situation characterized by a combination of stagnant economic growth, high unemployment, and inflation. It is an unusual and challenging economic scenario because inflation and unemployment typically have an inverse relationship (i.e., when one goes up, the other tends to go down).

 

(B) Deflation: This refers to a general decrease in the price level of goods and services, resulting in an increase in the purchasing power of money. It is the opposite of inflation.

 

(C) Recession: A recession is a period of economic decline characterized by a decrease in gross domestic product (GDP) for two consecutive quarters or more. It often involves a decline in economic activity, increased unemployment, and decreased consumer spending.

 

(D) Inflation: Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, leading to a decrease in the purchasing power of a currency.

Question 6
Which of the following is NOTone of the components of New Economic Policy adopted in 1991?
  • A.Liberalisation
  • B.Privatisation
  • C.Globalisation
  • D.Decentralization
Correct Answer: Decentralization

The correct answer is (D) Decentralization.

 

The New Economic Policy (NEP) adopted in 1991 in India aimed at liberalizing and opening up the economy to global influences. The key components of the NEP are commonly known as the LPG reforms, which stand for Liberalization, Privatization, and Globalization. Here's a brief explanation of each:

 

(A) Liberalization: This involved reducing government intervention and restrictions on economic activities. It aimed at promoting competition, efficiency, and flexibility in various sectors.

 

(B) Privatization: The NEP emphasized the need to reduce the role of the public sector in the economy. This included the sale of state-owned enterprises to private entities and encouraging private investment.

 

(C) Globalization: The policy sought to integrate the Indian economy with the global economy by promoting international trade, liberalizing foreign investment, and opening up markets to foreign competition.

 

(D) Decentralization: While decentralization is an important concept in governance and administration, it was not explicitly a component of the New Economic Policy of 1991. The primary focus of the NEP was on liberalization, privatization, and globalization to revitalize the Indian economy.

Question 7
Indicate the right sequence of the stages of internationalization:(i) Multinational Company(ii) Global Company(iii) Transnational Company(iv) International CompanySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) (iv) (ii) (iii)
  • B.(iv) (i) (iii) (ii)
  • C.(i) (iv) (iii) (ii)
  • D.(iv) (i) (ii) (iii)
Correct Answer: (iv) (i) (ii) (iii)

The correct sequence of the stages of internationalization is given by option (D) (iv) (i) (ii) (iii).

 

International Company (iv): This is the initial stage where a company engages in international business by exporting products or services to foreign markets. At this stage, the company's operations are primarily domestic, with limited international involvement.

 

Multinational Company (i): As the company expands its international activities, it may become a multinational company. This involves establishing subsidiaries or branches in different countries. Each subsidiary operates independently, and there is limited coordination or integration among them.

 

Global Company (ii): The next stage involves increased coordination and integration of operations across different countries. A global company operates as a single, unified entity with standardized products, marketing, and management practices. It seeks to achieve economies of scale and scope on a global level.

 

Transnational Company (iii): The highest stage of internationalization is represented by transnational companies. In this stage, companies strive to achieve a balance between global integration and local responsiveness. They aim to be globally competitive while adapting their strategies to local markets. Transnational companies have a highly interconnected and interdependent network of operations worldwide.

Question 8
The comparative cost theory of International trade was developed by:
  • A.David Ricardo
  • B.Haberlar
  • C.J S Mill
  • D.Hecksher-Ohlin
Correct Answer: David Ricardo

The comparative cost theory of international trade, also known as the theory of comparative advantage, was developed by David Ricardo.

 

David Ricardo, a British economist, introduced the theory of comparative advantage in his work "Principles of Political Economy and Taxation," published in 1817. The theory suggests that countries should specialize in the production of goods and services in which they have a comparative cost advantage, even if they are not absolutely more efficient in the production of all goods.

Question 9
The Ministry of Commerce & Industry set up a committee under chairmanship of _____________to study the existing SEZ policy of India. The committee submitted its report in Nov 2018.
  • A.NandanNilekani
  • B.BabaKalyani
  • C.NachiketMore
  • D.Urjitpatel
Correct Answer: BabaKalyani

The Baba Kalyani led committee (constituted by the Ministry of Commerce & Industry) to study the existing SEZ policy of India submitted its report in Nov 2018.

 

The objectives of the committee were to evaluate the SEZ policy and make it WTO compatible, suggest measures for maximizing utilisation of vacant land in SEZs, suggest changes in the SEZ policy based on international experience and merge the SEZ policy with other Government schemes like coastal economic zones, Delhi-Mumbai industrial corridor, national industrial manufacturing zones and food and textiles parks.

Question 10
Consider following two statements:Statement I:The Trade diversion refers to the increase in economic welfare from joining a free trade area, such as a customs union.Statement II:The Trade creation occurs when tariff agreements cause imports to shift from low-cost countries to higher cost countries.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect

The Trade creation refers to the increase in economic welfare from joining a free trade area, such as a customs union. Trade creation will occur when there is a reduction in tariff barriers, leading to lower prices. This switch to lower cost producers will lead to an increase in consumer surplus and economic welfare.

 

The Trade diversion occurs when tariff agreements cause imports to shift from low-cost countries to higher cost countries. Trade diversion is considered undesirable because it concentrates production in countries with a higher opportunity cost and lower comparative advantage. Trade diversion may occur when a country joins a free trade area with a common external tariff.

Question 11
The form ITR-1 SAHAJ cannot be used by ordinarily resident individual whose total income includes:
  • A.Income from salary/pension;
  • B.Income from one house property (excluding cases where loss is brought forward from previous years) or loss to be carried forward;
  • C.Whose total income for the assessment year 2024-25 exceedRs. 50 lakh.
  • D.Income from other sources (excluding winnings from lottery, income from race horses and income taxable under section 115BBDA or Income of the nature referred to in section 115BBE).
Correct Answer: Whose total income for the assessment year 2024-25 exceedRs. 50 lakh.

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Non-Applicability of ITR-1 for AY 2024-25 is given below:

  • An individual with an income above Rs 50 lakh.
  • An individual who is either a director of a company or has held any unlisted equity shares at any time during the financial year.
  • Residents not ordinarily resident (RNOR) and non-residents.

 

Individuals who have earned income through the following means:

  • More than one house property
  • Lottery, racehorses, legal gambling, etc.
  • Taxable capital gains (short-term and long-term)
  • Agricultural income exceeding Rs 5,000
  • Business and profession
  • A resident that has assets (including financial interest in any entity) outside India or is a signing authority in any account located outside India.
  • Individuals claiming relief of foreign tax paid or double taxation relief under section 90/90A/91.
  • Deferred income tax on ESOP received from an eligible start-up.
Question 12
In the Dispute Settlement Mechanism of WTO how much maximum time is allowed for Appellate Review?
  • A.Upto60 days
  • B.Upto120 days
  • C.Upto90 days
  • D.Upto30 days
Correct Answer: Upto90 days

Dispute Settlement Mechanism of WTO

 

Settling disputes is the responsibility of the Dispute Settlement Body (the General Council in another guise), which consists of all WTO members. The Dispute Settlement Body has the sole authority to establish “panels” of experts to consider the case, and to accept or reject the panels’ findings or the results of an appeal. It monitors the implementation of the rulings and recommendations, and has the power to authorize retaliation when a country does not comply with a ruling.

 

After a panel issues a ruling in a dispute, either side can appeal it, but only on legal grounds, not re-examining existing evidence or introducing new issues. The appeal is heard by three members of a 7-member Appellate Body, chosen from the WTO membership. Appellate Body members serve four-year terms and must be experts in law and international trade without government affiliation.

 

The appeal can confirm, modify, or overturn the panel's legal findings. Appeals generally last up to 60 days, with a maximum of 90 days. The Dispute Settlement Body must decide to accept or reject the appeal's report within 30 days, and rejection requires a consensus.

Question 13
The European Central Bank (ECB) is the central bank for the euro-zone (the states which have adopted the euro) and thus controls monetary policy in that area with an agenda to maintain price stability. It is located at:
  • A.London
  • B.Paris
  • C.Frankfurt
  • D.Rome
Correct Answer: Frankfurt

The European Central Bank (ECB) is the central bank for the euro-zone (the states which have adopted the Euro) and thus controls monetary policy in that area with an agenda to maintain price stability. It is at the centre of the European System of Central Banks which comprises all EU national banks. The bank is governed by a board of national bank governors and a President. The ECB is located in Frankfurt.

Question 14
Match the items of List – IwithList – II:List – I(a) Cash Flow Statements(b) Valuation of Inventories(c) Net Profit or Loss for the Period(d) Depreciation AccountingList – II(i)IndAS 5(ii)IndAS 6(iii)IndAS 2(iv)IndAS 3Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)

The ICAI has issued the following Accounting Standards:

AS 19 Leases

AS 25 Interim Financial Reporting

AS 26 Intangible Assets

AS 28 Impairment of Assets

AS 29 Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets

Question 15
Which of the following best represents Income in accounting?
  • A.Income means the amount realized or receivable from the sale of goods.
  • B.Income results from something other than the day to day earnings of the business.
  • C.Income is the excess of revenues over expenses.
  • D.Income is excess of expenses over revenues.
Correct Answer: Income is the excess of revenues over expenses.

In accounting, income is generally defined as the excess of revenues over expenses. Let's break down the options:

 

(A) "Income means the amount realized or receivable from the sale of goods" refers more specifically to revenue generated from sales, not the overall concept of income.

 

(B) "Income results from something other than the day-to-day earnings of the business" is a vague definition and does not accurately represent the accounting concept of income.

 

(C) "Income is the excess of revenues over expenses" is the correct definition. In accounting terms, revenues are the inflows or earnings, and expenses are the outflows or costs. The difference between these, when revenues exceed expenses, represents income.

 

(D) "Income is the excess of expenses over revenues" is not the standard accounting definition. Income is typically calculated as revenues minus expenses.

Question 16
Identify the incorrect statement.
  • A.Trial Balance is prepared after General Ledger
  • B.Financial statement generally consists of two statements- Income statement and position statement.
  • C.Final account of a ‘not-for-profit organization’ consists of Receipt and Payment Account, Income and Expenditure Account and Balance Sheet.
  • D.As per accounting cycle ‘adjusting entries’ are passed at the beginning of the year before ‘journal entries’.
Correct Answer: As per accounting cycle ‘adjusting entries’ are passed at the beginning of the year before ‘journal entries’.

(A) Trial Balance is prepared after the General Ledger: This statement is correct. A trial balance is prepared after posting all transactions to the general ledger to ensure that debits equal credits.

 

(B) Financial statements generally consist of two statements - Income statement and position statement: This statement is generally correct. Financial statements typically include an income statement (or profit and loss statement) and a position statement (or balance sheet), among others.

 

(C) Final account of a ‘not-for-profit organization’ consists of Receipt and Payment Account, Income and Expenditure Account, and Balance Sheet: This statement is correct. In the context of not-for-profit organizations, these accounts are used to summarize financial activities and present the financial position.

 

(D) As per the accounting cycle, 'adjusting entries' are passed at the beginning of the year before 'journal entries': This statement is incorrect. In the accounting cycle, adjusting entries are typically made at the end of an accounting period, not at the beginning of the year. Adjusting entries are made to ensure that the financial statements reflect the true financial position and are made after the trial balance and before the preparation of financial statements.

 

Therefore, the incorrect statement is (D).

Question 17
X and Y sharing profits in the ratio of 7:3, admit Z for37share in the new firm in which he takes27thfrom X and17thfrom Y. What will be the new profit sharing ratio of X, Y and Z?
  • A.29:11:30
  • B.27:11:35
  • C.21:11:15
  • D.17:19:31
Correct Answer: 29:11:30

X’s old share = 710

X’s sacrifice for Z = 27

X’s new share = 710 − 27 = 2970

Y’s old share = 310

Y’s sacrifice for Z = 17

Y’s new share =310 − 17 = 1170

Z’s share = 37 = 3070

New Profit sharing Ratio among X, Y and Z is 29:11:30.

Question 18
Arrange the process of company formation in correct order.(a) Commencement of Business(b) Promotion(c) Capital Subscription(d) Incorporation or RegistrationSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(b), (d), (c), (a)
  • B.(b), (c), (a), (d)
  • C.(c), (d), (b), (a)
  • D.(c), (b), (a), (d)
Correct Answer: (b), (d), (c), (a)

The correct order for the process of company formation is: (b) Promotion, (d) Incorporation or Registration, (c) Capital Subscription, (a) Commencement of Business.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) (b), (d), (c), (a).

 

Promotion (b): This is the initial stage where individuals conceive the idea of forming a company, gather resources, and make plans for its establishment.

 

Incorporation or Registration (d): Once the promotion activities are completed, the next step is to formally incorporate or register the company with the relevant authorities. This involves preparing and filing the necessary legal documents to establish the company's legal existence.

 

Capital Subscription (c): After incorporation, the company seeks to raise capital by offering shares to the public or private investors. This step involves attracting shareholders who subscribe to the company's shares, contributing the initial capital needed for its operations.

 

Commencement of Business (a): Once the company has been formed, registered, and has received sufficient capital, it can commence its business operations.

Question 19
Prime cost equals to:
  • A.Direct material + Direct Wages + Indirect expenses
  • B.Indirect material + Direct Wages + Direct expenses
  • C.Direct material + Direct Wages + Direct expenses
  • D.Direct material + Indirect Wages + Direct expenses
Correct Answer: Direct material + Direct Wages + Direct expenses

Components of Total Cost

 

The Components of cost are shown in the classified and analytical form in the cost sheet. Components of total cost are as follows:

 

Prime Cost: It consists of direct material, direct wages and direct expenses. In other words, “Prime cost represents the aggregate of cost of material consumed, productive wages, and direct expenses”. It is also known as basic, first, flat or direct cost of a product.

 

Prime Cost = Direct material + Direct Wages + Direct expenses

 

Direct material means cost of raw material used or consumed in production.

Question 20
Which of the following is a Non-Monetary HRA Model?
  • A.Hermanson’sUn-Purchased Goodwill Method
  • B.Likert’s Model
  • C.Historical Cost Model
  • D.Ogan’sModel
Correct Answer: Likert’s Model

The correct answer is option (B) – Likert’s Model.

 

Likert’s Model is a non-monetary Human Resource Accounting (HRA) Model. Human Resource Accounting involves the measurement of the cost and value of human resources in an organization. Unlike monetary models that focus on quantifying the financial value of human resources, non-monetary models consider qualitative aspects and attempt to measure the non-monetary contributions of employees to the organization.

 

Likert’s Model, developed by Rensis Likert, emphasizes the qualitative aspects of human resources. It focuses on assessing the effectiveness and performance of employees based on their behavior, skills, attitudes, and other non-monetary factors. This model is particularly concerned with the impact of human resources on organizational success and aims to capture the intangible contributions of employees that may not be easily expressed in monetary terms.

Question 21
Target Costing equals to:
  • A.Selling Price plus Profit Margin
  • B.Cost Price minus Profit Margin
  • C.Cost Price plus Selling Price
  • D.Selling Price minus Profit Margin
Correct Answer: Selling Price minus Profit Margin

The correct answer is option (D) - Selling Price minus Profit Margin.

 

Target costing is a cost management strategy used in business to manage costs during the product development and production phases. The goal of target costing is to determine the desired profit margin and then set a target cost that allows the company to achieve that profit margin. The formula for target costing is as follows:

 

Target Cost = Selling Price − Profit Margin

Question 22
Consider the following.Statement I:Demand curve moves downward, when demand of the commodity falls as a rise in the price of the commodity.Statement II:Demand curve shifts rightward, when demand of the commodity increases because of any other factor, which affects demand, other than its prices.
  • A.Statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • C.Statements I and II are incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is not correct, but II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is not correct, but II is correct.

CHANGE IN QUANTITY DEMAND – It means change in demand of a commodity when its price changes, ceteris paribus.

i. Extension in demand- Increase in demand of a commodity when its price falls, ceteris paribus. In this case demand curve moves downward.

ii. Contraction in demand – Fall in demand of a commodity when its price rises, ceteris paribus. In this case demand curve moves upward.

 

CHANGE IN DEMAND – Change in demand due to change in other factors which affect demand, prices remain same.

a. Increase in demand – Increase in demand due to change in other factors which affect demand, price remains same, In this case demand curve shifts rightward.

b. Decrease in demand – Decrease in demand due to change in other factors which affects demand, price remains same, In this case demand curve shifts leftward.

Question 23
Which of the following statement is true?
  • A.Explicit cost refers to the loss of earnings due to opportunities forgone due to scarcity of resources.
  • B.Business cost includes all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business but does not include contractual obligation.
  • C.Full costs include all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business as well as opportunity cost and normal profit.
  • D.The payment of wages & salaries, materials,etcto outsiders are the examples of implicit cost.
Correct Answer: Full costs include all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business as well as opportunity cost and normal profit.

The correct answer is option (C) - Full costs include all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business as well as opportunity cost and normal profit.

 

(A) Explicit cost refers to the loss of earnings due to opportunities forgone due to scarcity of resources.

This statement is incorrect. Explicit costs are the direct, observable, and quantifiable costs that a firm pays for inputs such as wages, rent, and materials. Opportunity cost, on the other hand, is related to the value of the next best alternative foregone when a decision is made. The definition in statement (A) is more aligned with opportunity cost than explicit cost.

 

(B) Business cost includes all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business but does not include contractual obligation.

This statement is incorrect. Business costs typically include all expenses incurred to carry out business operations, and contractual obligations, such as wages and rent, are usually part of these costs.
