(C) Full costs include all the expenses which are incurred to carry out business as well as opportunity cost and normal profit.

This statement is correct. Full costs encompass both explicit costs (like wages, rent, and materials) and implicit costs, including opportunity costs and normal profit. It provides a more comprehensive view of the total cost of doing business.

 

(D) The payment of wages & salaries, materials, etc to outsiders are examples of implicit cost.

This statement is incorrect. Wages, salaries, and materials are examples of explicit costs, not implicit costs. Implicit costs are non-monetary costs associated with the use of self-owned resources, such as the opportunity cost of using one's time or capital for a specific business activity.

Question 24
Consider the following:Assertions: A:A monopoly firm’s revenue curve is upward sloping from left to right.Reason: R:The monopoly firm does not simultaneously enjoy the freedom to determine both price and quantity to be sold according to its whims and fancy.
  • A.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect but R is correct.
  • C.A and R both are correct but R is not right explanation of A.
  • D.A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A is incorrect but R is correct.

Under monopoly revenue curves (AR and MR) is downward sloping from left to right. It indicates that to sell more units of a commodity, the monopolist will have to lower the price. The monopoly firm does not simultaneously enjoy the freedom to determine both price and quantity to be sold according to its whims and fancy. Monopolists have the power over the prices but for selling more units he has to lower the prices and as a result demand curve (AR) is downward sloping.

Question 25
Other things being equal an increase in income lead to a decrease in demand for which types of goods?
  • A.Superior Goods
  • B.Inferior Goods
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.Normal Good
Correct Answer: Inferior Goods

Inferior goods: A commodity is deemed to be inferior if its demand decreases with the increase in consumer’s income beyond a certain level of income. Demand for such goods rises only upto a certain level of income and declines as income increases beyond this level. It should also be noted that the income effect is negative in case of inferior goods.

 

Examples include- Inter-city bus service, this form of transportation is cheaper than air or rail travel, but is more time-consuming. When money is constricted, traveling by bus becomes more acceptable, but when money is more abundant than time, more rapid transport is preferred.

 

Whereas normal goods are the one for which the opposite is observed. Normal goods are those for which demand rises as consumer income rises. Superior goods are a type of normal goods whose demand increases when consumer’s income improves.

Question 26
Match the following:List I(a) Marginal Utility(b) Average Utility(c) Total UtilityList II(i) Defined as the utility derived from the use of one unit of commodity.(ii) Defined as the addition to the total utility resulting from the consumption (or accumulation) of one additional unit.(iii) Defined as the sum of the utility derived by a consumer from the various units of a good or service he consumes at a point or over a period of time.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.i-(a), ii-(b), iii-(c)
  • B.i-(b), ii-(a), iii-(c)
  • C.i-(c), ii-(b), iii-(a)
  • D.i-(b), ii-(c), iii-(a)
Correct Answer: i-(b), ii-(a), iii-(c)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Total utility may be defined as the sum of the utility derived by a consumer from the various units of a good or service he consumes at a point or over a period of time. Suppose a consumer consumes four units of a commodity, X, at a time and derives utility from the successive units of consumption as U1, U2, U3 and U4. His total utility (Ux) from commodity X can be then measured as:

 

Ux = U1+U2+U3+U4

 

Marginal utility is another very important concept used in economic analysis. It is defined as the utility derived from the marginal or one additional unit consumed. It may also be defined as the addition to the total utility resulting from the consumption (or accumulation) of one additional unit. Marginal Utility (MU) thus refers to the change in the Total Utility (i.e., ΔTU) obtained from the consumption of an additional unit of a commodity, say X. It may be expressed as:

 

MUn =  TUn - TUn-1

Or, MUx =∆TUx∆Qx

Where

TUx = total utility,

TUn = total utility of the nth unit

TUn-1= total utility of the (n -1) unit

ΔQx = change in quantity consumed by one unit.

 

Average Utility is defined as the utility derived from the use of one unit of commodity. It is calculated by dividing total number of utils by the number of units commodity is used by the consumer.

Question 27
A demand function may be expressed as follows:Dx= f (Px, M,Py, Pc T, F)What do we mean by T in this equation?
  • A.Technology
  • B.Time Period
  • C.Total Cost
  • D.Consumer Tastes and Preferences
Correct Answer: Consumer Tastes and Preferences

The demand function states the relationship between the demand for a product (the dependent variable) and its determinants (the independent or explanatory variables). A demand function may be expressed as follows:

 

Dx = f (Px, M, Py, Pc T, F)

 

Where,

Dx is the quantity demanded of product X

Px is the price of the commodity

M is the money income of the consumer

Py is the price of its substitutes

Pc is the price of its complementary goods

T is consumer tastes, and preferences

F is future expectations

Question 28
Ordinal Utilityconcept was given by _________ modern economist(s).
  • A.Leon Walrus
  • B.J R Hicks and R G D Allen
  • C.Alfred Marshall
  • D.Jeremy Bentham
Correct Answer: J R Hicks and R G D Allen

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Modern economists, most notably J R Hicks and R G D Allen, hold the view that utility is not quantitatively measurable—it is not measurable in absolute terms. Utility can be expressed only ordinally or in terms of ‘less than’ or ‘more than’. It is, therefore, possible to list the goods and services in order of their preferability or desirability. It is ordinal utility theory which forms the basis for Indifference Curve. For example, suppose a person prefers chocolate to ice cream and ice cream to cold drink. He can express his preference as chocolate > ice cream > cold drink. But he cannot express his preference in quantitative terms. This is known as the ordinal concept of utility.

Question 29
Which economics particularly focus on Price Analysis?
  • A.Macro Economics
  • B.Micro Economics
  • C.Positive Economics
  • D.Normative Economics
Correct Answer: Micro Economics

Microeconomics is the branch of economics that focuses on the behavior and decisions of individual agents, such as consumers, firms, and industries. It deals with the study of specific economic units and the relationships between them. One of the key areas within microeconomics is price analysis, where the focus is on the determination of prices in individual markets, factors influencing price changes, and the allocation of resources at the micro level.

Question 30
Overall efficiencycan be measured by which of the following formula?
  • A.Overall efficiency = Technical efficiency + Allocative efficiency
  • B.Overall efficiency =(Technicalefficiency×Allocativeefficiency)100
  • C.Overall efficiency =(Technicalefficiency-Allocativeefficiency)100
  • D.Overall efficiency = Technical efficiency × Allocative efficiency
Correct Answer: Overall efficiency =(Technicalefficiency×Allocativeefficiency)100

Efficiency is often measured as the ratio of useful output to total input, which can be expressed with the mathematical formula r = P/C, where P is the amount of useful output ("product") produced per the amount C (cost) of resources consumed.

 

But when we have to calculate an Overall efficiency we use the formula:

 

Overall efficiency = (Technical efficiency × Allocative efficiency)100

Question 31
Which of thefollowing are Factors of Production?(i) Land(ii)Labour(iii) Capital(iv) EntrepreneurSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(iii) only
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • C.(ii) and (iv)
  • D.(i) and (iii)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Factors of production refer to inputs. An input is a good or service which a ¬firm buys for use in its production process. Production process requires a wide variety of inputs, depending on the nature of output. The process of producing goods in a modern economy is very complex. Land, labour, capital and entrepreneurial ability are the four factors or resources which make it possible to produce goods and services.

Question 32
Price elasticity of demand for a product is measured by:(Where Ed = elasticity of demand, Q = Quantity, P = Price andΔ= represents change)
  • A.Ed = (ΔQ/ Q)× (ΔP/ P)
  • B.Ed = (ΔQ/ Q)÷ (ΔP/ P)
  • C.Ed = (ΔP/ΔQ)× (Q/P)
  • D.Ed = (ΔP/P)÷ (ΔQ/Q)
Correct Answer: Ed = (ΔQ/ Q)÷ (ΔP/ P)

Price elasticity

 

Price elasticity of demand is generally defined as the responsiveness or sensitiveness of demand for a commodity to the changes in its price. More precisely, elasticity of demand is the percentage change in demand as a result of one per cent change in the price of the commodity.

 

ed= Percentage change in quanmtity demandedPercentage change in price

ed= ∆Q∆P× PQ

Question 33
Consider the following.Statement - I: In general, the NPV and IRR methods lead to the same acceptance or rejection decision when a single project is involved.Statement - II: The inconsistency in ranking of competing projects as per the NPV and IRR methods lies in the implicit assumptions with regard to different rates of returns on re-investment of intermediate cash flows.
  • A.Both statements are correct
  • B.Both statements are incorrect
  • C.Statement - I is correct, Statement - II is incorrect
  • D.Statement - I is incorrect, Statement - II is correct
Correct Answer: Both statements are correct

The correct answer is option (A) – Both statements are correct.

 

Statement I: "In general, the NPV and IRR methods lead to the same acceptance or rejection decision when a single project is involved."

This statement is generally true. For a single, independent project, the NPV (Net Present Value) and IRR (Internal Rate of Return) methods usually result in the same decision. If the NPV is positive or the IRR is greater than the required rate of return, the project is typically accepted, and if the NPV is negative or the IRR is less than the required rate of return, the project is usually rejected.

 

Statement II: "The inconsistency in ranking of competing projects as per the NPV and IRR methods lies in the implicit assumptions with regard to different rates of returns on re-investment of intermediate cash flows."

This statement is also correct. Inconsistencies in ranking can arise when evaluating mutually exclusive projects with different cash flow patterns. The IRR method assumes reinvestment at the project's internal rate of return, while the NPV method assumes reinvestment at the project's cost of capital. This difference in reinvestment assumptions can lead to conflicting rankings for competing projects.

Question 34
DividendPayoutRatio can be expressed as:
  • A.Dividend per Share/Earnings per Share
  • B.Earnings per Share /Dividend per Share
  • C.Dividend per Share /Current Share Price
  • D.Current Share Price/ Earnings per Share
Correct Answer: Dividend per Share/Earnings per Share

Dividend Payout Ratio: Dividend payout ratio is the percentage of a company’s earnings that it pays out to investors in the form of dividends. It is calculated by dividing dividends paid during a period by net earnings for that period.

 

Dividend payout ratio is reciprocal of retention ratio (or plowback period) which measures the percentage of earnings a company reinvests in projects to generate future growth. It is an important indicator of a company’s performance from an investor’s point of view.

Question 35
Participating preference shares are those which participate in the:
  • A.General meeting of the company
  • B.Voting during general meeting
  • C.Profits over and above their fixed dividend
  • D.Management of the company
Correct Answer: Profits over and above their fixed dividend

The correct answer is (C) Profits over and above their fixed dividend.

 

Participating preference shares are a type of preference shares that have the right to participate in the surplus profits of the company, in addition to receiving a fixed rate of dividend. This means that if the company distributes dividends to common shareholders after paying the fixed dividend to preference shareholders, participating preference shareholders also get a share of the remaining profits.

 

Here's a breakdown of the options:

 

(A) General meeting of the company: This does not describe the characteristic of participating preference shares. Shareholders in general, including preference shareholders, may attend general meetings, but it's not a defining feature of participating preference shares.

 

(B) Voting during general meeting: Voting rights are typically associated with common shares, not preference shares. Participating preference shareholders may not necessarily have additional voting rights.

 

(D) Management of the company: Preference shareholders, including participating preference shareholders, generally do not have a role in the day-to-day management of the company. Management is typically associated with common shareholders.

Question 36
Interest Rate Risk arises due to variability in the interest rates from time to time. It is type of:
  • A.Un-diversifiable Risk
  • B.Unsystematic Risk
  • C.Both A & B
  • D.Diversifiable Risk
Correct Answer: Un-diversifiable Risk

The correct answer is (A) Un-diversifiable Risk.

 

Interest Rate Risk is a type of risk associated with the potential changes in interest rates. This risk affects the value of financial instruments, such as bonds, and can impact the returns on investments. Interest Rate Risk is considered a systematic or un-diversifiable risk because it is not specific to a particular company or industry. It affects the entire market and cannot be eliminated through diversification.

Question 37
The cost of equity (Ke) can be correctly expressed by which among the following?Here,D1= Expected Dividend per Share at the end of the year,NP= Net Proceeds per equity share,g= Rate of Growth in dividends andD0= Previous year’s dividend
  • A.Ke=D0NP– g
  • B.Ke=D1NP– g
  • C.Ke=D0NP+ g
  • D.Ke=D1NP+ g
Correct Answer: Ke=D1NP+ g

Dividend Price Plus Growth Approach

The cost of equity is calculated on the basis of the expected dividend rate per share plus growth in dividend. It can be measured with the help of the following formula:

 

Ke = D1NP + g = D0(1+g)NP + g

 

Where,

Ke = Cost of Equity Capital

D1 = Expected Dividend per Share at the end of the year

NP = Net Proceeds per equity share

g = Rate of Growth in dividends

D0 = Previous year’s dividend

Question 38
A company has sales ofRs. 5,00,000, Variable cost ofRs. 3,00,000, fixed cost ofRs. 1,00,000 and long term loans ofRs. 4,00,000 at 10% rate of interest. Calculate the Operating Leverage.
  • A.2
  • B.5/3
  • C.10/3
  • D.1/2
Correct Answer: 2

Operating Leverage = Contribution EBIT  = 500000-300000(500000-300000)-100000 = 200000100000 = 2

Question 39
Which among the following are assumptions ofMM Hypothesis ofIrrelevance Concept of dividend:(1)Investors behave rationally(2)No investor is large enough to affect the market price of shares(3) Perfect capital markets(4)No floatation and transaction costsSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.I, IV only
  • B.II, III, IV only
  • C.I, III, IV only
  • D.I, II, III, IV
Correct Answer: I, II, III, IV

Assumptions of MM Hypothesis are:

There are perfect capital markets.

Investors behave rationally.

Information about the company is available to all without any cost.

There are no floatation and transaction costs.

No investor is large enough to affect the market price of shares.

There are no taxes or there are no differences in the tax rates applicable to dividends and capital gains.

The firm has a rigid investment policy.

Question 40
A firm earns return on investment at the rate of 20% , earning per share isRs15,payoutratio is 50%, cost of equity is 12%; the market price per share as per Walter’s model is:
  • A.Rs300
  • B.Rs240
  • C.Rs75
  • D.Rs166.67
Correct Answer: Rs166.67

Walter’s formula for determining the value of a share:

P0 = D+ rKe(E-D)Ke = 15/2+ .2.12(15-7.5).12 = 166.66666 = 166.67.

 

Where,

P0 = Price of Equity Share

D = Initial dividend per share

Ke = Cost of Equity capital

r = Internal rate of return

E = Earnings per share

Question 41
Gross working capitalis:
  • A.Total current Assets
  • B.Total Current Assets – Total Current Liabilities
  • C.Total Current Assets + Total Current Liabilities
  • D.Total Assets + Total Current Liabilities
Correct Answer: Total current Assets

Types of working capital are:

Gross working capital concept: According to this concept, working capital means total of all current assets of business.

Gross working capital = Total current assets.

 

Net working capital concept: According to this concept, working capital means excess of current assets over current liabilities.

Net Working capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

Question 42
The First coefficient ofSkewness is also known as ________.
  • A.Bowley’scoefficient of Skewness
  • B.Karl Pearson‘s coefficient of Skewness
  • C.Kelly's coefficient of Skewness
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Bowley’scoefficient of Skewness

The coefficient of skewness is a measure of the asymmetry or skewness of a probability distribution of a real-valued random variable. It indicates whether the data distribution is skewed to the left (negatively skewed) or to the right (positively skewed).

 

The first coefficient of skewness is also known as Bowley’s coefficient of skewness. It is named after the economist and statistician Arthur Bowley.

Question 43
The following are the two statements relating to the theory of probability. Indicate the statements being correct or incorrect.Statement I:The probability of the joint occurrence of independent events A and B is equal to the sum of probability of A and the probability of B.Statement II:The probability of the joint occurrence of independent event A and dependent event B is equal to the probability of event A multiplied by the conditional probability of B when A has occurred or vice versa.
  • A.Both the statements are correct.
  • B.Both the statements are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct while Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.

Statement I is incorrect. The probability of joint occurrence of two independent events is product of probability of A and the probability of B.

 

That is, PA∩B=P A ×P( B )

 

Statement (II) is correct. Let us see the expression of the conditional probability –

PBA=PA∩BP( A )

PBA×P( A )=PA∩B

Thus, the probability of the joint occurrence of independent event A and dependent event B is equal to the probability of event A multiplied by the conditional probability of B when A has occurred The reason why we call event B as dependent because its occurrence depends on the occurrence of A.

Question 44
The Binomial Distribution is a _________ probability distribution. The Poisson Distribution is a _________ probability distribution.
  • A.Continuous, Continuous
  • B.Discrete, Discrete
  • C.Continuous, Discrete
  • D.Discrete, Continuous
Correct Answer: Discrete, Discrete

The Binomial Distribution is discrete probability distribution.

 

The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of events occurring within a given time interval. It is based on discrete random variable and thus is Discrete probability distribution.

 

The Normal Probability distribution is Continuous Probability distribution.

 

The Exponential distribution is a Continuous random distribution.

Question 45
For the purposes of research analysis,the________ are data collected at the same or approximately the same point in time.The___________ are data collected over several time periods.
  • A.Categorical data, Quantitative data
  • B.Quantitative data, Categorical data
  • C.Time series data, Cross-sectional data
  • D.Cross-sectional data, Time series data
Correct Answer: Cross-sectional data, Time series data

The correct answer is option (C) – Time series data, Cross-sectional data.

 

Time series data: This refers to data collected over several time periods. It involves observing and recording data points at regular intervals over time. Time series data is often used to analyze trends, patterns, and variations in a particular variable over time.

 

Cross-sectional data: This refers to data collected at the same or approximately the same point in time. Cross-sectional data is collected from different subjects or units at a specific point in time, allowing for comparisons and analysis of different variables at that particular point.

 

So, the correct pairing is:

 

Time series data for data collected over several time periods.

Cross-sectional data for data collected at the same or approximately the same point in time.

Question 46
The characteristic of a population is referred to as a ___________ of the population. The characteristic of a sample is called a ______
  • A.census, statistic
  • B.parameter, census
  • C.parameter, statistic
  • D.statistic, parameter
Correct Answer: parameter, statistic

The correct answer is (C) parameter, statistic.

 

Parameter: A parameter is a characteristic of a population. It is a numerical measure that describes some aspect of the entire population. For example, the population mean, population standard deviation, and population proportion are parameters.

 

Statistic: A statistic is a characteristic of a sample. It is a numerical measure calculated from the data of a sample, providing information about the sample itself. Examples include the sample mean, sample standard deviation, and sample proportion.

Question 47
Which of the following is a non-probability sampling technique?i. Cluster Samplingii. Systematic Samplingiii. Quota Samplingiv. Convenience samplingSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Optioni, ii
  • B.Optioni, iii
  • C.Optioni, iv
  • D.Option iii, iv
Correct Answer: Option iii, iv

The correct answer is (D) Option iii, iv.

 

Cluster Sampling (i): Cluster sampling is a probability sampling technique. In this method, the population is divided into clusters, and then a random sample of clusters is selected. All individuals within the selected clusters are included in the sample.

 

Systematic Sampling (ii): Systematic sampling is also a probability sampling technique. It involves selecting every kth individual from a list after randomly selecting a starting point. The key here is that each individual has a known and equal chance of being selected.

 

Quota Sampling (iii): Quota sampling is a non-probability sampling technique. In quota sampling, the researcher selects individuals based on pre-defined quotas that ensure the sample reflects certain characteristics such as age, gender, or socioeconomic status. It doesn't involve random selection, and participants are chosen based on meeting specific criteria until the quota is filled.

 

Convenience Sampling (iv): Convenience sampling is a non-probability sampling technique. In this method, the sample is drawn from individuals who are easiest to reach or most readily available. It lacks random selection, and participants are chosen for their convenience rather than being representative of the entire population.

Question 48
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II (test statistic) and denote the code of correct matching:List – I(i) Comparison of difference between variances of two independent population by drawing two independent sample(ii) Testing data presented by the two categorical variables are independent of each other(iii) A researcher wants to test whether mean of more than 2 groups is equal. But, none of the standard ANOVA assumptions are met.List – II1. F-test2. Chi Square3.Kruskal-Wallis testSelect the correct answer using the codes givenbelow:
  • A.i-3, ii-2, iii-1
  • B.i-1, ii-2, iii-3
  • C.i-3, ii-1, iii-2
  • D.i-2, ii-1, iii-3
Correct Answer: i-1, ii-2, iii-3

Option B is the correct answer.

 

To test whether the variance across two populations varies from each other we use the F-test statistic under the null hypothesis H0:σ_12=σ_22

 

To test if two categorical variables are independent of each other, we use Chi-Square test under the null hypothesis H0:Observed values, Oi=Expected values, Ei.

 

The Kruskal-Wallis test is a non-parametric test which is used to test if we want to test if mean across more than 2 samples significantly differs from each other when the standard ANOVA assumptions are not met.

Question 49
If a hypothesis is statistically significant, then it is concluded that
  • A.It is a claim that is generated by data and is likely to happen due to a chance.
  • B.It is a claim that is generated by data and is not likely to happen due to a chance.
  • C.The null hypothesis may or may not be rejected depending on test involved
  • D.thenull hypothesis of no relationship is probably true.
Correct Answer: It is a claim that is generated by data and is not likely to happen due to a chance.

Statistical significance is basically a claim that is understood with the help of data and a test statistic. Also, it is a claim not likely to happen due to chance and is likely to be attributable to a specific cause.

Question 50
How many degrees of freedom should be used to apply chi-square test statistic on a contingency table that has 7 rows and 3 columns?
  • A.21
  • B.14
  • C.12
  • D.20
Correct Answer: 12

Let us assume that the contingency table contains n rows and r columns, then the computed test statistic will follow chi square distribution with (n-1) × (r-1). For the above question, degrees of freedom = (7-1) × (3-1) = 6 × 2 = 12

Question 51
Which of the following is statement is true in context of simple linear regression?
  • A.The slope coefficient of regression of Y on X and X on Y can have opposite signs
  • B.The geometric mean of slope coefficients in statement 1 will yield correlation coefficient.
  • C.If the R-square of a simple linear regression is really high then it necessarily implies that X causes Y.
  • D.Regression coefficients are independent of scale and origin.
Correct Answer: The geometric mean of slope coefficients in statement 1 will yield correlation coefficient.

Statement A is false. Remember that numerator term in the formula slope coefficient of both regressions will be covariance of X and Y. If it is negative, then the slope coefficient of both the regressions will have negative sign and vice-versa.

 

Thus, both regression coefficients must have the same sign. If byx is positive, bxy will also be positive and vice versa.

 

If one regression coefficient is greater than unity, then the other regression coefficient must be lesser than unity.


Statement B is TRUE.


Statement C is FALSE. High R-square only tells us about model fit but nothing about X causing Y.

Statement D is FALSE. Regression coefficients are independent of origin but not of scale. It means that the measurement scale of either of X or Y will change then it will affect the estimated values of regression coefficients.

Question 52
Match the following activities (List-I) with the degree of delegation (List-II).List – I (Activities)a. Critical Activityb. Needed Activityc. Peripheral ActivityList – II (Degree of Delegation)i. Moderateii. Highiii. LowSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-i
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii

Delegation of authority is the process that transfers authority from supervisor to subordinate and allows a subordinate to exercise discretion in making certain decisions. Since the chief executive cannot make all the decisions, especially the day-to- day ones, it is necessary to delegate some decision-making authority to subordinates. The process of delegation involves the assignment of tasks, the determination of expected results, and the granting of authority to accomplish the talks.

 

Supervisor can give an employee various degree of freedom. The more experienced and reliable the other person is, the more freedom you can give. The more critical the task, the more cautious supervisor needs to be. Critical Activity will need "low" degree of delegation but supervisor needs closer monitoring. On the other hand for "Peripheral Activity" degree of delegation may be "High".

Question 53
MBTI is generally used instrument for Personality Assessment during Recruitment Process. Which of the following statements about MBTI is/are true/false?a. MBTI has 108 itemsb. Sixteen personality types are generated by the instrumentc. MBTI has 100 itemsd. Sixteen personality types are based on a combination of four basic elements of psyche.e. MBTI was developed by a father-daughter team.f. MBTI was developed by a mother-daughter team.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a, d and e are true
  • B.b, c, d and f are true
  • C.c, d and e are true
  • D.a, b, e and f are true
Correct Answer: b, c, d and f are true

The correct answer is option (B) – b, c, d and f are true.

 

a. MBTI has 108 items: This statement is false. The MBTI (Myers-Briggs Type Indicator) typically has typically 100 items.

 

b. 16 personality types are generated by the instrument: This statement is true. The MBTI categorizes individuals into 16 personality types based on their preferences in four dichotomies: Extraversion/Introversion, Sensing/Intuition, Thinking/Feeling, and Judging/Perceiving.

 

c. MBTI has 100 items: This statement is true. While the total number of items can vary, the standard MBTI assessment usually consists of around 100 items.

 

d. Sixteen personality types are based on a combination of four basic elements of psyche: This statement is true. The 16 personality types in the MBTI are determined by the combination of preferences in the four dichotomies mentioned above.

 

e. MBTI was developed by a father-daughter team: This statement is false. The MBTI was developed by Katharine Cook Briggs and her daughter Isabel Briggs Myers.

 

f. MBTI was developed by a mother-daughter team: This statement is true. The correct relationship is that the MBTI was developed by a mother-daughter team.

Question 54
Consider following theories of Motivation:(a) Maslow’s needs hierarchy(b)Alderfer’sERG theory(c) McClelland’s achievement motivation(d) Herzberg’s two-factor theory(e) Skinner’s reinforcement theory(f) Victor Vroom's expectancy theorySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b) are Content Theories and (c), (d), (e), (f) are Process Theories
  • B.(a), (b), (c) are Content Theories and (d), (e), (f) are Process Theories
  • C.(a), (b), (c), (d) are Content Theories and (e), (f) are Process Theories
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c), (d) are Content Theories and (e), (f) are Process Theories

We can distinguish between content and process motivation theories. Content theories focus on WHAT, while Process theories focus on HOW human behavior is motivated. Content theories are the earliest theories of motivation. Within the work environment they have had the greatest impact on management practice and policy, whilst within academic circles they are the least accepted. Content theories are also called needs theories: they try to identify what our needs are and relate motivation to the fulfilling of these needs. The content theories cannot entirely explain what motivate or demotivate us. Process theories are concerned with “how” motivation occurs, and what kind of process can influence our motivation.

 

Content theories are Maslow’s needs hierarchy, Alderfer’s ERG theory, McClelland’s achievement motivation and Herzberg’s two-factor theory.

Process theories are: Skinner’s reinforcement theory, Victor Vroom's expectancy theory, Adam’s equity theory and Locke’s goal setting theory

Question 55
Who gave theformula “C = (ABD) > X” foranalyzingChange Management?
  • A.NoelTichyand MaryanneDevanna.
  • B.RichardBeckhardand Reuben Harris.
  • C.David Nadler and MichaelTushman.
  • D.RosabethMossKanterand ToddJick.
Correct Answer: RichardBeckhardand Reuben Harris.

Beckhard and Harris designed a formula for companies to make decisions if change is needed.

The formula is: C = [ABD] > X

 

Where

A = Level of dissatisfaction with the status quo (dissatisfied with present state)

B = Desirability of the prose change or end state (eager to achieve the end state)

C = Change

D = Practicality of the change (minimal risk and disruption)

X = ’Cost’ of changing (perceived cost)

 

Beckard and Harris states, in order for change ‘C’ to occur, A, B, D must be greater than X. If the cost ‘X’ is less for completing A, B, D then change can occur.

Question 56
Which job evaluation method rates jobs bycomparing them and makes analysis by breaking jobs into compensable factors?
  • A.Factor Comparison Method
  • B.Points Rating Method
  • C.Ranking Method
  • D.Grading Method
Correct Answer: Factor Comparison Method

Factor Comparison Method: This method is a combination of both ranking and point methods. It rates jobs by comparing them and makes analysis by breaking jobs into compensable factors. This system is usually used to evaluate white collar, professional and managerial positions.

Question 57
Who distinguished between the ‘soft’ and ‘hard’ aspects of HRM?
  • A.John Storey
  • B.David McClelland
  • C.Peter Drucker
  • D.Douglas McGregor
Correct Answer: John Storey

A distinction was made by John Storey (1989) between the ‘hard’ and ‘soft’ versions of HRM. The hard version of HRM emphasizes that people are important resources through which organizations achieve competitive advantage. These resources have therefore to be acquired, developed and deployed in ways that will benefit the organization. The focus is on the quantitative, calculative and business-strategic aspects of managing human resources in as ‘rational’ a way as for any other economic factor.

 

The soft version of HRM traces its roots to the human-relations school. It emphasizes communication, motivation and leadership. It involves ‘treating employees as valued assets, a source of competitive advantage through their commitment, adaptability and high quality (of skills, performance and so on)’. It therefore views employees as means rather than objects. The soft approach to HRM stresses the need to gain the commitment – the ‘hearts and minds’ – of employees through involvement, communications and other methods of developing a high-commitment, high-trust organization. Attention is also drawn to the key role of organizational culture.

Question 58
Which of the following is the process for identifying and developing new leaders who can replace old leaders when they leave or retire?
  • A.Succession Planning
  • B.Career Development
  • C.Executive Development Program
  • D.Manpower Forecasting
Correct Answer: Succession Planning

Succession planning is a process for identifying and developing internal people with the potential to fill key business leadership positions in the company. Succession planning increases the availability of experienced and capable employees that are prepared to assume these roles as they become available.

Question 59
The interview which attempts to examine extensively the core areas of knowledge and skills of the job is called
  • A.Stress Interview
  • B.Structured Interview
  • C.Depth Interview
  • D.Panel Interview
Correct Answer: Depth Interview

The correct answer is (C) Depth Interview.

 

Stress Interview (A): A stress interview is designed to put the candidate in a challenging or stressful situation to observe how they handle pressure. It aims to assess how well a candidate can cope with difficult or uncomfortable circumstances.

 

Structured Interview (B): A structured interview is a standardized interview format where the interviewer asks a set of predetermined questions. The questions are typically related to the specific job requirements, and each candidate is evaluated based on their responses to the same set of questions.

 

Depth Interview (C): A depth interview is an interview technique that attempts to examine extensively the core areas of knowledge and skills relevant to the job. It involves exploring in-depth the candidate's qualifications, experiences, and abilities related to the job. The focus is on gaining a comprehensive understanding of the candidate's capabilities.

 

Panel Interview (D): A panel interview involves a candidate being interviewed by a group of interviewers. Each member of the panel may ask questions, and the candidate has to respond to the panel collectively.

Question 60
Which one of the following isNOTa performance appraisal method?
  • A.Forced Choice Method
  • B.Critical Incident Method
  • C.Assessment Centre
  • D.Position Analysis Questionnaire
Correct Answer: Position Analysis Questionnaire

The correct answer is (D) Position Analysis Questionnaire.

 

Forced Choice Method (A): The Forced Choice Method is a performance appraisal method where the evaluator must choose between two or more statements that are equally plausible. This method helps reduce biases and encourages a more objective evaluation.

 

Critical Incident Method (B): The Critical Incident Method involves recording specific behaviors that are observed and deemed critical for job performance. This method focuses on real-life examples of employee behavior.

 

Assessment Centre (C): Assessment Centre is a method in which individuals participate in a series of simulations, exercises, and assessments to evaluate their skills, competencies, and potential. It is often used for managerial and leadership positions.

 

Position Analysis Questionnaire (D): The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is not a performance appraisal method. Instead, it is a job analysis tool used to collect detailed information about various aspects of a job, such as responsibilities, duties, and required qualifications.

Question 61
In India,Identify the schemes/provisions for Workers’ Participation in Management is available?a) Shop Level Councilsb) Joint Level Councilsc) Industry Level Councilsd) Employee Participation Committeee) Works Councilf) Board Level ParticipationSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a, b, c, d, e
  • B.c, d, e
  • C.a, c, d, e
  • D.a, b, f
Correct Answer: a, b, f

Schemes of workers’ participation in management are:

 

(1) Works committee (1947)

(2) Joint management councils (1958)

(3) Board level participation (1970)

(4) Shop council and joint council under old 20- point programme (1975)

(5) Unit and joint councils in commercial and service organizations in the public (1977).

(6) Scheme of Employees' participation in Public Sector Undertakings (1983)

Question 62
The Managerial Theory of Collective Bargaining was developed by
  • A.Richard Walton and RobertMcKersie
  • B.N.W. Chamberlain and J.W. Kuhn
  • C.John T. Dunlop
  • D.John Henry Richardson
Correct Answer: N.W. Chamberlain and J.W. Kuhn

N.W. Chamberlain and J.W. Kuhn analyzed Collective bargaining in terms of three theories:

(a) the marketing theory- Collective bargaining as a means of contracting for the sale of labour

(b) the governmental theory- Collective bargaining as a form of industrial government

(c) the managerial theory - Collective bargaining as a method of management

Question 63
Five bases of power – reward, coercion, legitimate, expert, and referent, were given by:
  • A.French and Raven
  • B.Ian Clegg
  • C.Neil W. Chamberlain
  • D.E. Durkheim
Correct Answer: French and Raven

The original French and Raven (1959) model included 5 bases of power – reward, coercion, legitimate, expert, and referent – however, informational power was added by Raven in 1965, bringing the total to six.

1. Coercive power uses the threat of force to gain compliance from another. Force may include physical, social, emotional, political, or economic means.

2. Reward power is based on the right of some to offer or deny tangible, social, emotional, or spiritual rewards to others for doing what is wanted or expected of them. Some examples of reward power (positive reward) are: (a) a child is given a dollar for earning better grades; (b) a student is admitted into an honor society for excellent effort.

3. Legitimate power comes from an elected, selected, or appointed position of authority.

4. Referent power is rooted in the affiliations we make and/or the groups and organizations we belong to. Our affiliation with a group and the beliefs of the group are shared to some degree.

5. Expert power is based on what one knows, experience, and special skills or talents.

6. Informational power is the ability of an agent of influence to bring about change through the resource of information.

Question 64
The __________ Phenomenon in which the norm for consensus overrides the realistic appraisal of alternative course of action. Group members rationalize any resistance to the assumptions they have made. The __________ is a change in decision risk between the group’s decision and the individual decision that member within the group would make; can be either toward conservatism or greater risk.
  • A.Social Loafing,Ringelmanneffect
  • B.Ringelmanneffect, Social Loafing
  • C.Groupthink, Group shift
  • D.Group shift, Groupthink
Correct Answer: Groupthink, Group shift

The correct answer is option (C) – Groupthink, Group shift.

 

Groupthink: Groupthink is the phenomenon in which the norm for consensus overrides the realistic appraisal of alternative courses of action. In groupthink, members of a group prioritize conformity and consensus over critical evaluation of information or alternative viewpoints. The desire for harmony and agreement within the group can lead to flawed decision-making, as dissenting opinions are suppressed.

 

Group shift: Group shift is the change in decision risk between the group's decision and the individual decision that a member within the group would make. This shift can be either toward conservatism (greater caution and risk aversion) or greater risk (more willingness to take risks). It represents the change in the group's decision-making tendencies compared to the individual tendencies of its members.

Question 65
As per RBI guidelines, the foreign banks can operate in India through following modes:(a) through branch presence(b) set up a wholly owned subsidiary (WOS) with near national treatment(c) with joint venture with a PSU bankSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a) only
  • B.(b) only
  • C.either (a) or (b)
  • D.either (a), (b) or (c)
Correct Answer: either (a) or (b)

In the aftermath of the crisis and building on the lessons from the crisis, the RBI issued a Discussion Paper in January 2011 on the mode of presence of foreign banks in India. Taking into account the feedback received on the Discussion Paper, the Scheme for setting up of wholly owned subsidiary WOS by foreign banks in India has now been finalised. It has been decided, as hitherto to, allow foreign banks to operate in India either (a) through branch presence or (b) they can set up a wholly owned subsidiary (WOS) with near national treatment. The foreign banks have to choose one of the above two modes of presence and shall be governed by the principle of single mode of presence.

Question 66
The Governing Board of RBI is assisted by number of committees and sub-committees. Which one of the following is not one of them?
  • A.Committee on National Payment Corporation of India (CNPCI)
  • B.Committee of the Central Board (CCB)
  • C.Board for Financial Supervision (BFS)
  • D.Board for Regulation and Supervision of Payment and Settlement Systems (BPSS)
Correct Answer: Committee on National Payment Corporation of India (CNPCI)

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Central Board is assisted by 3 committees:

1. the Committee of the Central Board (CCB)

2. the Board for Financial Supervision (BFS)

3. the Board for Regulation and Supervision of Payment and Settlement Systems (BPSS)

These Committees are chaired by the Governor.

 

In addition, the Central Board has 4 sub-committees:

1. Audit and Risk Management Sub-Committee (ARMS)

2. Human Resource Management Sub-Committee (HRM-SC)

3. Building Sub- Committee (BSC)

4. Information Technology Sub-Committee (IT-SC)

 

These sub-committees are headed by an External Director.

Question 67
What is the minimum period of non-payment required for a loan to be classified as Non-Performing Asset (NPA)?
  • A.30 days
  • B.60 days
  • C.90 days
  • D.120 days
Correct Answer: 90 days

Debt is classified as non-performing when the loan payments have not been made for a minimum period of 90 days.

Question 68
The________ are used by the Central Government tofulfillits short-term liquidity requirementuptothe period of 364 days.
  • A.Non-Convertible Debentures (NCDs) of original maturity up to one year
  • B.Treasury Bills
  • C.Certificate of Deposits (CD)
  • D.Commercial Bill (CB)
Correct Answer: Treasury Bills

The Treasury Bills (TBs) are used by the Central Government to fulfill its short-term liquidity requirement upto the period of 364 days. At present 91-day TBs, 182-day TBs and the 364-day TBs are issued by the Government.

 

A Treasury bill is basically an instrument of short-term borrowing by the Government of India maturing in less than one year. They are also known as Zero Coupon Bonds issued by the Reserve Bank of India on behalf of the Central Government to meet its short-term requirement of funds. Treasury bills are issued in the form of a promissory note. They are highly liquid and have assured yield and negligible risk of default. They are issued at a price which is lower than their face value and repaid at par. The difference between the price at which the treasury bills are issued and their redemption value is the interest receivable on them and is called discount. Treasury bills are available for a minimum amount of Rs 25,000 and in multiples thereof.

Question 69
Which of the following isNOTcorrect?
  • A.State Industrial Development Corporations (SIDCs) were established under the erstwhile Companies Act, 1956.
  • B.State Financial Corporations (SFCs) were formed after enactment of the State Financial Corporations Act, 1951.
  • C.At present, there are 18 SFCs, all of which were set up under the SFC Act, 1951.
  • D.NEDFiprovides financial assistance to micro, small, medium and large enterprises for setting up industrial, infrastructure andagri-allied projects in the North Eastern Region of India.
Correct Answer: At present, there are 18 SFCs, all of which were set up under the SFC Act, 1951.

State Financial Corporations (SFCs): State Financial Corporations Act, 1951 was enacted by the Parliament to provide institutional framework for financing medium and small-scale industries, which fell outside the operational scope of IFCI. After enactment of the Act, SFCs were set up in the various States over a period of time. The Act provides special role for the State Governments in the promotion and management of the affairs of the SFCs.

 

At present, there are 18 SFCs of which 17 were set up under the SFC Act, 1951 while the Tamil Nadu Industrial Investment Corporation Ltd. was incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956 but still functions as SFC. Their main objectives are to finance and promote small and medium enterprise in the States concerned for achieving balanced regional growth, catalyse investment, generate employment and widen the ownership base of industries by way of providing term loans, direct subscription to equity / debentures, extending guarantees, discounting of bills and providing special / seed capital, etc.

 

The first State Finance Corporation was set up in Punjab in 1953.

Question 70
Which financial regulator is responsible for regulation of the commodities like MCX, NCDEX, NMCE, UCX etc., of the Indian futures market?
  • A.RBI
  • B.Forward Markets Commission
  • C.Ministry of Corporate Affairs
  • D.None of Above
Correct Answer: None of Above

The Forward Markets Commission WAS chief regulator of the commodity (MCX, NCDEX, NMCE, UCX etc) of the Indian futures market. The main aim of this body was to advise the Central Government on matters of the Forwards Contracts Act, 1952. The FMC was merged with SEBI in 2016. The SEBI regulates these Financial Instruments.

Question 71
Which of the following is not correct about USSD banking?
  • A.USSD stands for "Unstructured Secure Service Data".
  • B.It is also called *99# Banking.
  • C.You do not need to have a smartphone or internet connection to use USSD banking.
  • D.It uses your registered mobile number to connect with your bank account.
Correct Answer: USSD stands for "Unstructured Secure Service Data".

USSD stands for Unstructured Supplementary Service Data.

 

USSD banking or *99# Banking is a mobile banking based digital payment mode. You do not need to have a smartphone or internet connection to use USSD banking. You can easily use it with any normal feature phone. USSD banking is as easy as checking your mobile balance. You can use this service for many financial and non-financial operations such as checking balance, sending money, changing MPIN and getting MMID.

 

The *99# code works as a bridge between your telecom operator’s server and your bank’s server. It uses your registered mobile number to connect with your bank account. Hence, dial *99# with your registered number only.

Question 72
The concept of marketing mix was developed by________.
  • A.N.H. Borden
  • B.Philip Kotler
  • C.Stanton
  • D.W. Anderson
Correct Answer: N.H. Borden

In 1964, Neil H. Borden published an article whose title was “The Concept of the Marketing Mix”, from which the marketing mix concept started gaining popularity. In the 1940s, James Culliton portrayed the marketing manager as a mixer of ingredients.

 

In his article, Borden outlined these ingredients among many others as product, distribution, planning, price, branding, advertising, packaging, promotions display, and personal selling. E. Jerome McCarthy later grouped these multiple items into 4 top level categories that are currently referred to as the marketing mix 4 Ps. A combination of these four classes is helpful in creating marketing strategies and tactics.

Question 73
What is the last stage of the consumer decision process?
  • A.Problem recognition
  • B.Post purchasebehavior
  • C.Alternative evaluation
  • D.Purchase
Correct Answer: Post purchasebehavior

The correct answer is (B) Post purchase behavior.

 

The stages of the consumer decision process are typically considered as follows:

 

Problem recognition: This is the first stage where the consumer recognizes a need or problem that can be satisfied by purchasing a product or service.

 

Information search: After recognizing a problem, the consumer seeks information about possible solutions. This can involve internal or external searches for information.

 

Alternative evaluation: The consumer evaluates different options or alternatives available in the market. Factors such as features, benefits, and pricing are considered during this stage.

 

Purchase: Once the consumer has evaluated the alternatives, they make a decision to purchase the chosen product or service.

 

Post-purchase behaviour: This is the last stage of the consumer decision process. It involves the consumer's reactions and feelings after making the purchase. It includes satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the product, whether expectations were met, and the likelihood of repeat purchases.

Question 74
Process of managing upstream and downstream of final goods, flow of raw materials and information about resellers and final consumers is classified as
  • A.Marketing Logistics Network
  • B.Supply Chain Management
  • C.Value Delivery Network
  • D.Physical Distribution Management
Correct Answer: Supply Chain Management

Supply Chain Management (SCM) is the management of the flow of goods and services and includes all processes that transform raw materials into final products. It involves the active streamlining of a business's supply-side activities to maximize customer value and gain a competitive advantage in the marketplace. SCM represents an effort by suppliers to develop and implement supply chains that are as efficient and economical as possible. Supply chains cover everything from production to product development to the information systems needed to direct these undertakings.

Question 75
The _________ holds that consumersfavorthose products that offer the most quality, performance, or innovative features.
  • A.Production Concept
  • B.Marketing Concept
  • C.Selling Concept
  • D.Product Concept
Correct Answer: Product Concept

The correct answer is (D) Product Concept.

 

Production Concept (A): This concept focuses on producing large quantities of goods at the lowest possible cost. The assumption is that consumers will favor products that are widely available and inexpensive.

 

Marketing Concept (B): The marketing concept emphasizes understanding and meeting the needs and wants of customers. It centers on delivering customer value and satisfaction.

 

Selling Concept (C): The selling concept is based on the idea that consumers will not buy enough of the firm's products unless it undertakes a substantial selling and promotional effort.

 

Product Concept (D): The product concept holds that consumers favor products with the most quality, performance, or innovative features. The focus is on continuous product improvement and innovation.

Question 76
Which of the following isNOTan extension 4Ps of marketing mix?
  • A.People
  • B.Physical evidence
  • C.Process
  • D.Product
Correct Answer: Product

Marketing mix is the set of marketing tools that the firm uses to pursue its marketing objectives in the target market. As shown in figure, McCarthy classified these tools into four broad groups that he called the “four Ps of marketing”: Product, Price, Place, and Promotion. For marketing of services, 3 additional P’s have been identified, People, Process and Physical evidence.

Question 77
Segmentation of customer market on the basis of “compulsive, ambitious and outgoing customers” will be termed as
  • A.Geographic segmentation
  • B.Demographic segmentation
  • C.Psychographic segmentation
  • D.Behavioralsegmentation
Correct Answer: Psychographic segmentation

The correct answer is (C) Psychographic segmentation.

 

Geographic Segmentation (A): Dividing the market based on geographical location is known as geographic segmentation. For example, grouping customers based on their region, city, climate, etc.

 

Demographic Segmentation (B): Demographic segmentation involves dividing the market based on demographic factors such as age, gender, income, education, occupation, etc.

 

Psychographic Segmentation (C): Psychographic segmentation considers the psychological and lifestyle characteristics of consumers. This includes factors like personality traits, values, attitudes, interests, and behaviors. The mentioned segmentation of "compulsive, ambitious, and outgoing customers" falls under psychographic segmentation as it delves into their personality traits and behaviors.

 

Behavioral Segmentation (D): Behavioral segmentation categorizes consumers based on their behavior towards a product or service. This could include their usage patterns, brand loyalty, decision-making process, etc.

Question 78
Which of the following is NOTa market oriented pricing technique?
  • A.Auction Pricing
  • B.Going Rate pricing
  • C.Perceived Value pricing
  • D.Early-cash recovery pricing
Correct Answer: Early-cash recovery pricing

The correct answer is (D) Early-cash recovery pricing.

 

Auction Pricing (A): Auction pricing involves setting prices through a bidding process where buyers compete to purchase the product or service. This method is market-oriented as it reflects the willingness of buyers to pay.

 

Going Rate Pricing (B): Going Rate pricing is a market-oriented technique where prices are set based on the prevailing market rates. Organizations adjust their prices to align with competitors and market conditions.

 

Perceived Value Pricing (C): Perceived Value pricing is market-oriented and involves setting prices based on the perceived value of the product or service in the eyes of the customer. It focuses on what the customer is willing to pay for the perceived benefits.

 

Early-cash recovery pricing (D): Early-cash recovery pricing is not a market-oriented pricing technique. It suggests recovering the cash invested in a product or service quickly, which is more focused on financial considerations rather than responding to market dynamics.

Question 79
Arrange the process of personal selling in correct order:1. Sales presentation2. Pre-approach3. Handling Objects4. Follow-up5. Closing the sale6. Approach7. Prospecting & qualifying8. Trial CloseSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • B.7, 2, 6, 1, 8, 3, 5, 4
  • C.2, 4, 5, 7, 3, 1, 8, 6
  • D.8, 6, 5, 2, 3, 1, 4, 7
Correct Answer: 7, 2, 6, 1, 8, 3, 5, 4

The personal selling process is a consecutive series of activities conducted by the salesperson, the lead to a prospect taking the desired action of buying a product or service and finish with a follow-up contact to ensure purchase satisfaction.

 

Step 1 – Prospecting & Qualifying

The process of looking for and checking leads is called prospecting or determining which firms or individuals could become customers. Qualifying a prospect lead is a name on a list. It only becomes a prospect if it is determined that the person or company can benefit from the service or product offered. A qualified prospect has a need, can benefit from the product and has the authority to make the decision.

 

Step 2 - The Pre-approach

This stage involves the collecting of as much relevant information as possible prior to the sales presentation. The pre-approach investigation is carried out on new customers but also on regular customers. Systematic collection of information requires a decision about applicability, usefulness and how to organize the information for easy access and effective use.

 

Step 3 - The Approach

The salesperson should always focus on the benefits for the customer. This is done by using the product's features and advantages. This is known as the FAB technique (Features, Advantages and Benefits).

Features: Refers to the physical characteristics such as size, taste etc.

Advantages: Refers to the performance provided by the physical characteristics eg it does not stain.

Benefits: Refers to the benefits for the prospect. Eg. Saves you 20% on replacement cost.

 

Step 4 - The Sales Presentation

After the prospects interest has been grasped, the sales presentation is delivered. This involves a "persuasive vocal and visual explanation of a business proposition". It should be done in a relaxed atmosphere to encourage the prospect to share information in order to establish requirements. Some small talk may be necessary to reduce tension but the purpose always remains business.

 

Step 5 - The Trial Close

The trial close is a part of the presentation and is an important step in the selling process. Known as a temperature question - technique to establish the attitude of the prospect towards the presentation and the product.

 

Step 6 - Handling Objections

Objections are often indications of interest by the prospect and should not be viewed with misgiving by salespeople. The prospect is in fact requesting additional information to help him to justify a decision to buy. The prospect may not be fully convinced and the issues raised are thus very important. It also assists the salesperson to establish exactly what is on the prospect's mind.

 

Step 7 - Closing the Sale

This is the last part of the presentation. Many salespeople fear the closing of a sale. Closing a sale is only the confirmation of an understanding. Fear will disappear if the salesperson truly believes that the prospect will enjoy benefits after the purchase of the product.

 

Step 8 - The Follow-up

The sale does not complete the selling process. Follow-up activities are very important and are useful for the establishment of long-term business relationships. It is important to check if the products have been received in good condition, to establish the customer is satisfied etc.

Question 80
A/An _________ displays before a user can access requested content, sometimes while the user is waiting for the content to load. They are a form of interruption marketing.
  • A.frame ad
  • B.interstitial ad
  • C.expanding ad
  • D.floating ad
Correct Answer: interstitial ad

The correct answer is (B) Interstitial ad.

 

Frame Ad (A): A frame ad typically appears within a designated space on a webpage, and it doesn't cover the entire screen. It's a form of online advertising.

 

Interstitial Ad (B): An interstitial ad is an ad that displays before a user can access requested content, sometimes appearing while the user is waiting for the content to load. It covers the entire screen or a significant portion of it and is a form of interruption marketing.

 

Expanding Ad (C): An expanding ad starts as a standard-sized ad and expands or changes its dimensions when the user interacts with it or hovers over it. It is a dynamic ad format.

 

Floating Ad (D): A floating ad moves around the screen as the user scrolls. It is designed to catch the user's attention but may not necessarily display before accessing content.

Question 81
We usually see the bell-shaped curve for typical Product Life Cycles. However, there can be many different alternate patterns, like given below, EXCEPT:
  • A.Growth-slump-maturity pattern
  • B.Cycle-recycle pattern
  • C.Scalloped pattern
  • D.Exponential pattern
Correct Answer: Exponential pattern

While the bell-shaped curve is typical, Product Life Cycles can exhibit many different alternate patterns. For example:

1. Growth-slump-maturity pattern: After a period of strong growth, sales decline dramatically only to stabilize at a certain level. An example of a product that exemplifies this is the electric kitchen knife. The sales of electric kitchen knives grew rapidly when first introduced and then fell to a much lower level. This lower level has been sustained by late adopters buying the product for the first time and early adopters replacing the product.

 

2. Cycle-recycle pattern: The period of growth and subsequent decline is followed by another period of growth and decline. A good example here are drugs. The pharmaceutical company aggressively promotes its new drug resulting in the first growth cycle. When sales start declining the company gives the drug another push, which produces a second cycle. The subsequent cycles are usually off smaller magnitude and duration.

 

3. Scalloped pattern: Here sales pass through a succession of growth periods based on the discovery of new product characteristics, uses, or users. Nylon sales, for example, display a scalloped pattern because, over time, new and a new uses have been discovered—parachutes, hosiery, shirts, carpeting, etc.

Question 82
What is the meaning of novation, under the Indian Contract Act, 1872?
  • A.Rescinding of a contract
  • B.Alteration of a contract
  • C.Change in provisions of a contract
  • D.Substituting an old contract for a new one
Correct Answer: Substituting an old contract for a new one

Novation means substituting an old contract for a new one.

 

The methods stipulated under the Indian Contract Act for discharging a contract by mutual consent are:

(i) Novation - The parties to a contract may substitute a new contract for the old. If they do so, it will be a case of novation. On novation, the old contract is discharged and consequently, it need not be performed.

(ii) Alteration – It refers to change in one or more of the material terms of a contract.

(iii) Rescission - A contract is also discharged by rescission. When the parties to a contract agree to rescind it, the contract need not be performed. In the case of rescission, only the old contract is cancelled and no new contract comes to exist in its place.

(iv) Remission – It is the acceptance of a lesser sum than what was contracted for or a lesser fulfilment of the promise made.

(v) Waiver – It is the deliberate abandonment or giving up of a right which a party is entitled to under a contract, where upon the other party to the contract is released from his obligation.

Question 83
The price in the contract of sale may be:
  • A.fi­xed by the contract
  • B.agreed to be fi­xed in a manner provided by the contract, e.g., by avaluer
  • C.determined by the course of dealings between the parties
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

‘Price’ means the monetary consideration for sale of goods. The price in the contract of sale may be:

(1) fi­xed by the contract, or

(2) agreed to be fi­xed in a manner provided by the contract, e.g., by a valuer, or

(3) determined by the course of dealings between the parties.

Question 84
In which of the following situations, a bill is not said to be dishonoured by non-acceptance?
  • A.When the drawee does not accept it within 48 hours from the time of presentment for acceptance.
  • B.When presentment for acceptance is excused and the bill remains unaccepted.
  • C.When the drawee is a fictitious person or after reasonable search cannot be found.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

In all the options A, B and C as mentioned above, a bill is said to be dishonoured by non-acceptance, hence option D is correct.

 

A bill is said to be dishonoured by non-acceptance:

(a) When the drawee does not accept it within 48 hours from the time of presentment for acceptance.

(b) When presentment for acceptance is excused and the bill remains unaccepted.

(c) When the drawee is incompetent to contract.

(d) When the drawee is a fictitious person or after reasonable search cannot be found.

(e) Where the acceptance is a qualified one.

Question 85
Under the provisions of Companies Act, 2013, while incorporating a company, which set of statements is incorrect during filing of documents with the Registrar of Companieswithin whose jurisdiction the location of the registered office of the proposed company falls?(i) Memorandum of Association and Articles of Association, duly signed by all subscribers must be filed.(ii) A declaration by First Directors regarding compliance with all the requirements of the Act with respect to registration must be filed.(iii) A declaration by First Directors that the documents filed with the registrar are complete and true to the best of his knowledge must be filed.(iv) Consent of the First Directors to act as such is not mandatory to file.(v) The particulars of interests in other firms or bodies corporate of the First directors of the company must also be filed.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(ii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii) and (iii)
  • C.(i) and (v)
  • D.(iv) and (v)
Correct Answer: (ii) and (iv)

Statement (ii) above is incorrect, as the declaration regarding compliance with the requirements of the Act must be duly signed by person or professional engaged in the formation of the Company but not by First Directors and Statement (iv) is incorrect, as it is mandatory to file consent of First Directors to act as such.

Question 86
Under the Companies Act, 2013, a Small Company means:
  • A.paid-upshare capital of which does not exceedRs. 50 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 10 crore and turnover of which does not exceedRs. 2 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 100 crore.
  • B.paid-upshare capital of which does not exceedRs. 50 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 5 crore and turnover of which does not exceedRs. 2 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 50 crore.
  • C.paid-upshare capital of which does not exceedRs. 25 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 5 crore and turnover of which does not exceedRs. 1 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 50 crore.
  • D.paid-upshare capital of which does not exceedRs. 25 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 10 crore and turnover of which does not exceedRs. 1 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 100 crore.
Correct Answer: paid-upshare capital of which does not exceedRs. 50 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 10 crore and turnover of which does not exceedRs. 2 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum ofRs. 100 crore.

Under the Companies Act, 2013, Small company means a company, other than a public company:

(i) paid-up share capital of which does not exceed Rs. 50 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum of Rs. 10 crore; and

(ii) turnover of which does not exceed Rs. 2 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum of Rs. 100 crore.

Question 87
Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to Competition Commission of India?
  • A.No Chairperson or other Member shall hold office as such after he has attained the age of 65 years.
  • B.The Chairperson and other Members are restricted for a period of 2 years from the date on which they cease to hold office, to accept any employment in, or be connected with the management or administration of, any enterprise which has been a party to a proceeding before the Commission.
  • C.The Chairperson and other Members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Central Government from a panel of names recommended by a Selection Committee.
  • D.The Chairperson and every other Member shall hold office for a term of 3 years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall be eligible for re-appointment.
Correct Answer: The Chairperson and every other Member shall hold office for a term of 3 years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall be eligible for re-appointment.

Statement D is incorrect as the Chairperson and every other Member shall hold office for a term of 5 years from the date on which he enters upon his office and shall be eligible for re-appointment.

Question 88
The name of the Committee for the purpose of advising under the Information Technology Act, 2000 is:
  • A.Cyber Crime Control Regulations Committee
  • B.Cyber Regulations Committee
  • C.Cyber Crime Regulations Advisory Committee
  • D.Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee
Correct Answer: Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee

Constitution of Advisory Committee

The Central Government shall constitute a Committee called the Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee.

 

The Cyber Regulations Advisory Committee shall advise:

(a) the Central Government either generally as regards to rules or for any other purpose connected with this Act;

(b) the Controller in framing the regulations under this Act.

Question 89
Which pair of the following statements is incorrect under the provisions of Right to Information Act, 2005?(a) An applicant making request for information shall be required to give reason for requesting the information.(b) Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer (CPIO / SPIO) willdispose of the information seeking request within 30 days.(c) The information shall be provided free of charge where a public authority fails to comply with the time limits.(d) Where a request for information has been rejected, CPIO/SPIO is not bound to communicate reasons for such rejection.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(a) and (d)
  • C.(c) and (d)
  • D.(b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a) and (d)

The related provisions of the Right to Information Act, 2005 are as follows:

 

SECTION 5: DESIGNATION OF PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICERS

Every public authority shall, designate CPIO/SPIO, in all administrative units or offices within 100 days of the enactment of this Act.

 

Every CPIO/SPIO, shall deal with requests from persons seeking information and render reasonable assistance to the persons seeking such information.

 

SECTION 6: REQUEST FOR OBTAINING INFORMATION

A person, who desires to obtain any information, shall make a request in writing or through electronic means in English or Hindi or in the official language of the area to the CPIO/SPIO (or Central Assistant Public Information Officer or State Assistant Public Information Officer).

 

An applicant making request for information shall not be required to give any reason for requesting the information.

 

If the information is held by another public authority, then he shall transfer the application to that other public authority and also inform the applicant immediately (within 5 days from date of receipt).

 

SECTION 7: DISPOSAL OF REQUEST

CPIO/SPIO will provide information within 30 days.

If the information sought concerns the life or liberty of a person, the same shall be provided within 48 hours of the receipt of the request.

 

Where a decision is taken to provide the information on payment of any further fee representing the cost of providing the information, the CPIO/SPIO shall send an intimation to the person making the request, giving the details of further fees. The period intervening between the despatch of the said intimation and payment of fees shall be excluded for the purpose of calculating the period of 30 days.

 

The information shall be provided free of charge where a public authority fails to comply with the time limits.

 

Where a request for information has been rejected, CPIO/SPIO shall communicate:

reasons for such rejection;

period within which an appeal against such rejection may be preferred; and

particulars of the appellate authority.

Question 90
The term “WIPO” stands for
  • A.World Investment policy organization
  • B.World Intellectual Property organization
  • C.Wildlife Investigation and Policing organization
  • D.World institute for Prevention of organized crime
Correct Answer: World Intellectual Property organization

WIPO stands for World Intellectual Property Organization.

 

The World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations. It is dedicated to developing a balanced and accessible international intellectual property (IP) system, which rewards creativity, stimulates innovation and contributes to economic development while safeguarding the public interest.

 

The WIPO was established by the WIPO Convention in 1967 with a mandate from its Member States to promote the protection of IP throughout the world through co-operation among states and in collaboration with other international organizations. Its headquarters are in Geneva, Switzerland.

Question 91
Which of the following is NOTthe part of procedure of GST implementation?(i) Audits(ii) Assessment(iii) Demand and Recovery(iv) Advance RulingSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) and (ii)
  • B.(iii) and (iv)
  • C.(i) and (iv)
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

All the options mentioned above are the parts of procedure of GST implementation. Hence, option D is correct.

Question 92
Income from shipping business of a non-resident is charged to tax in the previous year itself; in such a case, ________% of the amount paid or payable on account of such carriage to the non-resident shall be deemed to be income accruing in India to the non-resident.
  • A.5
  • B.5.5
  • C.7
  • D.7.5
Correct Answer: 7.5

Income from shipping business of a non-resident is charged to tax in the previous year itself. In such a case, 7.5% of the amount paid or payable on account of such carriage to the non-resident shall be deemed to be income accruing in India to the non-resident. Thus, option D giving correct rate is correct.

Question 93
State which set of the following allowances are exempt to the extent of expenditure incurred for official purposes?(i) Conveyance Allowance(ii) Transport Allowance to blind employee(iii) Tribal Area Allowance(iv) Uniform Allowance(v) Travelling Allowance to meet the cost of travel on transfer(vi) Underground Allowance(vii) Helper/ Assistance Allowance(viii) Research AllowanceSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (iv), (v), (vii), (viii)
  • B.(ii), (iv), (v), (vi), (vii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv), (v), (vii)
  • D.(i), (iv), (vi), (vii), (viii)
Correct Answer: (i), (iv), (v), (vii), (viii)

Option A is the correct answer.

Question 94
Mr. Raja purchased a piece of land in May, 2004 forRs. 84,000 and sold the same in April, 2017 forRs. 10,10,000 (brokerageRs. 10,000). What will be the taxable capital gain in the hands of Mr. Raja?
  • A.9,16,000
  • B.9,17,000
  • C.7,97,805
  • D.7,02,295
Correct Answer: 7,97,805

Computation of capital gain will be as follows :

 

Particulars

Amt in Rs.

Full value of consideration (i.e., Sales consideration of asset)

10,10,000

Less: Expenditure incurred wholly and exclusively in connection with transfer of capital asset (brokerage)

10,000

Net sale consideration

10,00,000

Less: Indexed cost of acquisition (*)

2,02,195

Less: Indexed cost of improvement, if any

Nil

Long-Term Capital Gains

7,97,805

 

(*) The cost inflation index notified for the year 2004-05 is 113 and for the year 2017-18 is 272. Hence, the indexed cost of acquisition, i.e., the inflated cost of acquisition will be computed as follows:

 

= Cost of acquisition × Cost inflation index of the year of transfer of capital asset Cost inflation index of the year of acquisition

 

 

= 84,000 × 272 113 = 2,02,195

Question 95
Mr. Raja (age 40 years) has made the following payments during the financial year 2018- 19:Which of thebelowdoes not qualify for admissible deduction under section 80D?
  • A.Payment of medical insurance premium on his policy ofRs. 15,000 and Payment of medical insurance premium on policy of his parents (resident and aged 68 years),Rs. 18,000 on policy of his father andRs. 18,000 on policy of his mother.
  • B.Payment of medical insurance premium on policy of his spouseRs. 4,000 and Payment ofRs. 3,000 towards expenditure on preventive health check-up (for his own check-up and check-up of his wife).
  • C.Payment of medical insurance premium on policy of his younger daughter who is dependent on himRs. 3,000.
  • D.Payment of medical insurance premium on policy of his elder daughter who is self-employed and not dependent on himRs. 5,000.
Correct Answer: Payment of medical insurance premium on policy of his elder daughter who is self-employed and not dependent on himRs. 5,000.

The deduction in case of Mr. Raja will be as follows:

1) Medical insurance premium on his policy of Rs. 15,000 will qualify for deduction.
