2) Medical insurance premium on policy of his spouse of Rs. 4,000 will qualify for deduction.

3) Medical insurance premium on policy of Rs. 3,000 of his younger daughter who is dependent on him will qualify for deduction.

4) Premium of Rs. 5,000 on policy of elder daughter who is not dependent on him will not qualify for deduction.

5) Medical insurance premium on policy of his parents of Rs. 36,000 will qualify for deduction (being Senior Citizens).

6) Expenditure on preventive health check-up will also qualify for deduction, but, it will be restricted to Rs. 3,000 only (as the overall limit of deduction under section 80D in respect of assessee and his family cannot exceed Rs. 25,000).

Question 96
Dividend received from foreign company will be included in the total income of the tax payer and will be charged to tax at___________.
  • A.15%
  • B.20%
  • C.30%
  • D.Normal rate of tax applicable to theassessee
Correct Answer: Normal rate of tax applicable to theassessee

Dividend received from foreign company will be included in the total income of the tax payer and will be charged to tax at the rates applicable to the taxpayer. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Question 97
Which set of statements among the following are true with respect to Minimum Alternate Tax (MAT)?(i) As per section 115JB, every taxpayer being a company is liable to pay MAT, if the Income tax(including surcharge and cess) payable on the total income, computed as per the provisions of the Income-tax Act in respect of any year is less than 18.50% of its book-profit + surcharge (SC) + health & education cess.(ii) Both MAT (Minimum Alternate Tax) and AMT (Alternate Minimum Tax) are same and there is no difference between them.(iii) Both MAT and AMT are basically different, so far MAT applies to companies and AMT applies to a person other than a company.(iv) As per section115JB(5A) MAT shall not apply to any income accruing or arising to a company from life insurance business referred to in section 115B.
  • A.(i), (ii), (iv)
  • B.(i) and (ii) only
  • C.(i) and (iv) only
  • D.(i), (iii), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (iv)

Statement (i), (iii) and (iv) are true.

 

Minimum Alternative Tax is payable under the Income Tax Act. The concept of MAT was introduced to target those companies that make huge profits and pay the dividend to their shareholders but pay no/minimal tax under the normal provisions of the Income Tax Act, by taking advantage of the various deductions, and exemptions allowed under the Act. But with the introduction of MAT, the companies have to pay a fixed percentage of their profits as Minimum Alternate Tax. MAT is applicable to all companies including foreign companies.

 

MAT is calculated under Section 115JB of the Income-tax Act. Every company should pay higher of the tax calculated under the following two provisions:

(i) Tax liability as per the Normal provisions of income tax act (tax rate 30% plus 4% Edu cess plus surcharge (if applicable)

(ii) Tax liability as per the MAT provisions are given in Sec 115JB (18.5 % of Book Profits Plus 4 % education cess plus a surcharge if applicable)

 

The provisions of MAT are applicable to a corporate taxpayer only. The provisions relating to AMT are applicable to non-corporate taxpayers in a modified pattern in the form of Alternate Minimum Tax, i.e., AMT. Thus, it can be said that MAT applies to companies and AMT applies to a person other than a company. The provisions relating to AMT are given in sections 115JC to 115JF.

 

The provisions of MAT are applicable to every company whether public or private and whether Indian or foreign. However, as per section 115JB (5A) MAT shall not apply to any income accruing or arising to a company from life insurance business referred to in section 115B. Further, as per provisions of Section 115V-O the provisions of MAT will not apply to a shipping income liable to tonnage taxation, i.e., tonnage taxation scheme as provided in section 115V to 115VZC.

Question 98
Which set of statements from given below are considered incorrect while taking decision regarding shut down or continue operations?(i) If the business or profession has been discontinued, unabsorbed depreciation can be set off against income from business or profession or income under any other head and can be carried forward and set off for indefinite period, whether business is carried on or discontinued.(ii) Where a partner leaves a firm (on retirement or death), his share of loss can be carried forward and set off by the reconstituted firm.(iii) Where succession takes place by inheritance, the loss incurred by the father in the course of carrying on his business can be carried forward and set off by his son, if he succeeds to the business of his father on account of his death.(iv) Where there has been a demerger of an undertaking, the accumulated loss and the unabsorbed depreciation directly relatable to the undertaking transferred by the demerged company to the resulting company shall be allowed to be carried forward and set off in the hands of demerged company.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) and (iv)
  • B.(i) and (iii)
  • C.(iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i) and (ii)
Correct Answer: (i) and (iv)

Statement (i) and (iv) are incorrect. The provisions related to Shut down or continue decisions of the Income Tax Act are as follows:

 

Shut down or continue operations - Loss co- exist with profit in a business. A business may suffer loss due to fall in demand, financial problems, change in technology, high rate of taxes, mismanagement etc. When a business suffers losses continuously, whatever the reason of loss may be, the management has to decide whether the business should be shut down or continue. While taking this decision, the impact of income tax provisions should not be overlooked.

 

Treatment of losses and unabsorbed depreciation in some specific cases;

(a) Business loss - If the business or profession has been discontinued, loss can be carried forward and set off against profits and gains of business and profession.

(b) Unabsorbed depreciation - If the business or profession has been discontinued, unabsorbed depreciation can be set off against income from business or profession or income under any other head and can be carried forward and set off for indefinite period, whether business is carried on or discontinued.

 

Where a part of business (unit, department, or activity) is discontinued or the business is continued with the reduced level of activity it is not a discontinuation of business. Where the business of an industrial undertaking carried on in India is discontinued in the previous year by reason of extensive damage to, or destruction of any building , plant , machinery or furniture owned by the assessee and used for the purpose of such business is re- established, re constructed or revived by the assessee within 3 years from the end of previous year in which the business was discontinued, the losses of such a business shall be carried forward or set off against the profits and gains of business or any other business carried on by him.

 

Where succession takes place by inheritance, the loss incurred by the father in the course of carrying on his business can be carried forward and set off by his son, if he succeeds to the business of his father on account of his death.

 

Where an assessee transfers his business to his spouse and / or minor child and the income from such business is to be included in his total income, the assessee is entitled to set off of his loss carried forward from the previous year against the income of the wife and minor child included in his income. The loss can be set off by the same person who has suffered the loss but where two or more companies amalgamate and form a new company, the assessee (amalgamating companies and amalgamated companies) and the business are not the same and losses sustained by amalgamating companies cannot be carried forward and set off by the amalgamated company.

 

Where there has been a demerger of an undertaking, the accumulated loss and the unabsorbed depreciation directly relatable to the undertaking transferred by the demerged company to the resulting company shall be allowed to be carried forward and set off in the hands of resulting company. If the accumulated loss or unabsorbed depreciation is not directly relatable to the undertaking, the same will be apportioned between the demerged company and the resulting company in the same proportion in which the value of the assets have been transferred.

 

Where the business carried on by a HUF is transferred to the members of the family on partition there is a change in the persons carrying on the business. Hence, the losses suffered by the family in its business cannot be set off by the members after partition of the family.

 

Where a partner leaves a firm (on retirement or death), his share of loss cannot be carried forward and set off by the reconstituted firm.

Question 99
No penalty will be levied under section 271H for the failure to file the TDS/TCS return, if the person proves that after paying tax deducted/collected by him, along with the fee and interest (if any), to the credit of the Central Government, he had filed the TDS/TCS return before the expiry of a period of __________ from the due date of filing the TDS/TCS return.
  • A.6 months
  • B.1 year
  • C.2 years
  • D.5 years
Correct Answer: 1 year

No penalty will be levied under section 271H for the failure to file the TDS/TCS return, if the person proves that after paying tax deducted/collected by him, along with the fee and interest (if any), to the credit of the Central Government, he had filed the TDS/TCS return before the expiry of a period of one year from the due date of filing the TDS/TCS return. Thus, option B is the correct option.

Question 100
Mr. Rana is an engineer. Although MR. Rana is in profession specified under Section44AA(1) but he doesn’t opt for the presumptive taxation scheme of Section 44ADA. His estimated tax liability for the year amounts toRs. 2,00,000. He has paid advance tax ofRs. 30,000 by 15th June. In the month of August he got a contract from a multinational company. After incorporating the receipts of the new contract, his revised tax liability for the year amounts toRs. 3,00,000. In this case, how much advance tax he is required to pay in each instalment?List I(a) 1stInstalment(b) 2ndInstalment(c) 3rdInstalment(d) 4thInstalmentList II(i) 75,000(ii) 30,000(iii) 90,000(iv) 1,05,000Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(i)

If the estimated tax liability of the taxpayer is Rs. 10,000 or more, then he has to discharge his tax liability in the form of advance tax. Advance tax is to be paid in different instalments. The due dates for payment of different instalments of advance tax in case of all assesses (other than the eligible assesses as referred to in section 44AD or section 44ADA) are as follows:

 

FY 2018-19 For both individual and corporate taxpayers

Due Date

Advance Tax Payable

Advance tax liability

Already paid (in Total)

Amount left to be paid

On or before 15th June

15% of advance tax less advance tax already paid

15% of Rs. 2,00,000

-

30,000

On or before 15th September

45% of advance tax less advance tax already paid

45% of Rs. 3,00,000 (revised income) = 135,000

30,000

1,05,000

On or before 15th December

75% of advance tax less advance tax already paid

75% of Rs. 3,00,000 = 2,25,000

1,35,000

90,000

On or before 15th March

100% of advance tax less advance tax already paid

100% that is Rs. 3,00,000

2,25,000

75,000

 

Quiz Attempt #119004

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
The objective of the Central Consumer Protection Council is to promote and protect the rights of the consumers,which includes following EXCEPT:a) The right to be protected against the marketing of goods and services which are hazardous to life and property;b) The right to be informed about the quality, quantity, potency, purity, standard and price of goods or services, as the case may be so as to protect the consumer against unfair trade practices;c) The right to be assured, wherever possible, access to a variety of goods and services at competitive prices;d) The right to be heard and to be assured that consumer's interests will receive due consideration at appropriate forums;e) The right to get compensation from the Central Government for the damage.f) The right to seek redressal against unfair trade practices or restrictive trade practices or unscrupulous exploitation of consumers; andg) The right to consumer education;Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(b) only
  • B.(e) only
  • C.(e) and (g)
  • D.(g) only
Correct Answer: (e) only

As per the Consumer Protection Act 2019,

 

The Central Government shall establish the Central Consumer Protection Council (to be known as the Central Council), which shall be on advisory council and consist of the following:

(a) the Minister-in-charge of the Department of Consumer Affairs in the Central Government, who shall be the Chairperson

(b) Number of official or non-official members, as prescribed by the Centre Government.

The Central Council shall meet at least once every year.

 

The objective of the Central Council is to promote and protect the rights of the consumers such as:

The right to be protected against the marketing of goods and services which are hazardous to life and property;

The right to be informed about the quality, quantity, potency, purity, standard and price of goods or services, as the case may be so as to protect the consumer against unfair trade practices;

The right to be assured, wherever possible, access to a variety of goods and services at competitive prices;

The right to be heard and to be assured that consumer's interests will receive due consideration at appropriate forums;

The right to seek redressal against unfair trade practices or restrictive trade practices or unscrupulous exploitation of con­sumers; and

The right to consumer education

Question 2
Laissez Faire policy is adopted in:
  • A.Capitalist Economic System
  • B.Socialist Economic System
  • C.Communist Economic System
  • D.Mixed Economic System
Correct Answer: Capitalist Economic System

Laissez faire is the belief that economies and businesses function best when there is no interference by the government. It comes from the French, meaning to “leave alone or to allow to do”. It is one of the guiding principles of capitalism and a free market economy. It is the policy of minimum governmental interference in the economic affairs of individuals and society.

Question 3
Difference between the government’s total expenditure and its total receipts excluding borrowing is referred to as:
  • A.Primary Deficit
  • B.Fiscal Deficit
  • C.Budget Deficit
  • D.Revenue Deficit
Correct Answer: Fiscal Deficit

Budget Deficit- A budget deficit occurs when expenses exceed revenue and indicate the financial health of a country. The government generally uses the term budget deficit when referring to spending rather than businesses or individuals. Accrued deficits form national debt. Budget deficits, reflected as a percentage of GDP, may decrease in times of economic prosperity, as increased tax revenue, lower unemployment rates, and increased economic growth reduce the need for government-funded programs such as unemployment insurance and Head Start.

 

Budget deficit = total expenditure – total receipts.

 

Revenue Deficit is excess of total revenue expenditure of the government over its total revenue receipts. It is related to only revenue expenditure and revenue receipts of the government. Revenue deficit signifies that government’s own earning is insufficient to meet normal functioning of government departments and provision of services. 

 

Revenue deficit = Total revenue expenditure – Total revenue receipts.

 

Fiscal Deficit is defined as excess of total budget expenditure over total budget receipts excluding borrowings during a fiscal year. In simple words, it is amount of borrowing the government has to resort to meet its expenses. A large deficit means a large amount of borrowing so it measure; how much the government needs to borrow from the market to meet its expenditure when its resources are inadequate.

 

Fiscal Deficit = total expenditure – total receipts except borrowings.

 

Primary Deficit is defined as fiscal deficit of current year minus interest payments on previous borrowings. It indicates borrowing requirement exclusive of interest payment (i.e., amount of loan). It shows how much government borrowing is going to meet expenses other than Interest payments. Thus, zero primary deficits means that government has to resort to borrowing only to make interest payments.

 

Primary deficit = Fiscal deficit – Interest payments

Question 4
Which one isNOTan element of internal environment?
  • A.Marketing Team
  • B.Operational efficiency
  • C.Human Resources Planning
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The internal environment of an organization includes factors and elements within the organization's boundaries that have a direct impact on its operations and performance. Let's break down the options:

 

(A) Marketing Team: This is an element of the internal environment. The marketing team is part of the organization and contributes to its internal dynamics.

 

(B) Operational efficiency: This is also an element of the internal environment. Operational efficiency relates to how well the organization's processes and activities are managed internally.

 

(C) Human Resources Planning: Human Resources Planning is an integral part of the internal environment. It involves managing and planning for the organization's workforce.

Question 5
Which of the following is not one of models of CSR?
  • A.Stakeholder Model
  • B.Pyramid Model of CSR
  • C.Expectancy Model of CSR
  • D.Ackerman’s Model
Correct Answer: Expectancy Model of CSR

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Ackerman’s Model

Ackerman proposed 3 phases model on CSR (Ackerman & Bauer, 1976). More than a model, it was a strategy that guided the implementation of CSR activities, but not their formulation. The first phase was about the top managers recognizing a social problem, the second phase was an intensive study of the problem and finding out solutions by hiring experts and the third phase was implementation of the proposed solutions. It is obvious that this model, rather a plan, merely provides strategies to deal with problems having social implications. Other parameters and constraints of CSR activities did not come under the purview of this model.

 

Pyramid Model of CSR

It was Carroll who had stated that individual responsibilities and obligations in different fields are finally summarized into the totality of CSR The pyramid model, which is based on such totality of CSR, comprises four very different aspects.

 

 

The pyramid is arranged according to decreasing order of priorities, Economic responsibilities being the most important one. In this context, Carroll points out that ‘all other business responsibilities are predicated upon the economic responsibility of the firm, because without it the others become moot considerations’. Legal responsibility is the second priority. Ethical responsibility, that is, the responsibilities and obligations that are not legally codified but should be performed for the greater good, comes as the third priority. Philanthropic responsibilities, which are actually supposed to be discretionary in nature, are assigned the least priority.

 

Stakeholder Model

The stakeholder model is often associated with R. Edward Freeman, whose seminal analysis of the stakeholder approach to strategic management in 1984 brought stake holding into the mainstream of management literature (Freeman, 1984). The rise of globalization has brought with it a growing consensus that with increasing economic rights, the range of social obligations of businesses is also growing. This, as a consequence, gave rise to the stakeholder model of corporate responsibility.

Question 6
Which one of the following isNOTthe advantage of MNCs to the host country?
  • A.Access to new markets
  • B.Increase in economic activities
  • C.Utilisation of natural resource
  • D.R&D efforts enhanced.
Correct Answer: Access to new markets

The merits of a multinational corporation may be enumerated as follows:

(1) Research and development activities

(2) Far-reaching effects on the economic, social and political conditions of the host country

(3) Product innovation (R&D Activities)

(4) Marketing superiority

(5) Financial superiority

(6) Technological superiority

(7) Potential source of capital and advanced technology

(8) Expansion of market territory

(9) Creating employment opportunities

(10) Lower cost of production

 

“Access to new market” is advantage to the “home country” and not to the “host country”.

Question 7
The “Income Terms of Trade”, ITT indicates a nation’s capacity to:
  • A.import
  • B.export
  • C.improve its trade deficit
  • D.enhance GDP income through foreign trade
Correct Answer: import

The Income Terms of Trade (ITT) is an index of the value of exports divided by the unit value (price) of imports—the value of exports measured in terms of import goods. It corresponds to the commodity terms of trade multiplied by the volume of exports. ITT measures the purchasing power of exports—the amount of imports that can be financed by the total exports.

 

The use of ITT is often recommended in order to correct shifts in the commodity terms of trade for changes in the volume of exports. A fall in the terms of trade may be desirable if it leads to a significant expansion in export volumes so that the value of exports rises. As a result the capacity to import rises. The income terms of trade index is designed to measure the net effect of a change in the commodity terms of trade on the capacity to import or on the purchasing power of exports.

Question 8
Vernon’s international product life cycle theory:
  • A.helpsexplain the movement from absolute advantage to comparative advantage.
  • B.extendsthe concept of comparative advantage by bringing into consideration the endowment and cost of factors of production.
  • C.showswhy the United States, surprisingly, exports relatively morelabor-intensivegoods and imports capital-intensive goods.
  • D.helpsexplain why a product that begins as a nation export often ends up becoming an import.
Correct Answer: helpsexplain why a product that begins as a nation export often ends up becoming an import.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Vernon's international product life cycle theory is closely associated with the dynamics of how products evolve in the global market. According to this theory:

 

In the early stages of a product's life cycle, it is often developed and introduced in the home country (innovation stage).

 

As the product gains market acceptance and matures, the production tends to shift to other countries where costs, including labor, may be lower (growth and maturity stages).

 

Finally, the home country may become a net importer of the product as production continues to move to countries with lower costs (decline stage).

Question 9
The Foreign Trade Policy is governed by the Foreign Trade Act, which was passed in the year
  • A.1986
  • B.1989
  • C.1992
  • D.1995
Correct Answer: 1992

Option C is the correct answer.

 

In India, the main legislation concerning foreign trade is the Foreign Trade (Development and Regulation) Act, 1992. The Act provides for the development and regulation of foreign trade by facilitating imports into, and augmenting exports from, India and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto.

 

As per the provisions of the Act, the Government:

(i) may make provisions for facilitating and controlling foreign trade;

(ii) may prohibit, restrict and regulate exports and imports, in all or specified cases as well as subject them to exemptions;

(iii) is authorised to formulate and announce an export and import policy and also amend the same from time to time, by notification in the Official Gazette;

(iv) is also authorised to appoint a ‘Director General of Foreign Trade’, DGFT for the purpose of the Act, including formulation and implementation of the export-import policy.

Question 10
The General Agreement on Trade in Services, GATS entered into force in:
  • A.January 1992
  • B.January 1993
  • C.January 1994
  • D.January 1995
Correct Answer: January 1995

The General Agreement on Trade in Services, GATS was created to extend the multilateral trading system to service sector, in the same way as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade () provided such a system for merchandise trade. The agreement entered into force in January 1995.

Question 11
Which of the following statements are correct with respect to TAN?(a) It stands for Tax Deduction Account Number or Tax Collection Account Number.(b) It is 12-digit alpha-numeric number issued by the Income-Tax Department.(c) It is not mandatory to quote TAN on statement of financial transactions or reportable accounts.(d) The provisions relating to obtaining of TAN will not apply to a person deducting tax under section 194-IA (i.e. from sale consideration of land/building).(e) The penalty for quoting incorrect TAN isRs. 20,000.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a) and (d) only
  • B.(d) and (e) only
  • C.(a) and (b) only
  • D.(c) and (e) only
Correct Answer: (a) and (d) only

Only statement (a) and (d) are correct.

 

Meaning of TAN

Tax Deduction Account Number or Tax Collection Account Number is a 10-digit alphanumeric number issued by the Income-tax Department (we will refer to it as TAN). TAN is to be obtained by all persons who are responsible for deducting tax at source (TDS) or who are required to collect tax at source (TCS). First 4 digits of TAN are alphabets, the next 5 digits of TAN are numeric and last digit is an alphabet.

 

Relevance of TAN

As per section 203A of the Income-tax Act, 1961, every person who deducts or collects tax at source has to apply for the allotment of TAN. Section 203A also makes it mandatory to quote TAN in following documents:

(a) TDS statements i.e. return

(b) TCS statements i.e. return

(c) Statement of financial transactions or reportable accounts

(d) Challans for payment of TDS/TCS

(e) TDS/TCS certificates

(f) Other documents as may be prescribed

 

The provisions relating to obtaining of TAN will not apply to a person deducting tax under section 194-IA (i.e. from sale consideration of land/building) and to such person, as may be notified by the Central Government in this behalf.

 

Consequences of not quoting TAN

Section 272BB(1) provides for penalty for failure to obtain TAN and section 272BB(1A) provides for penalty for quoting incorrect TAN. Penalty imposable under section 272BB is Rs. 10,000.

Question 12
Which of the following isNOTone of the components of Governance Structure of IMF?
  • A.Executive Board
  • B.International Monetary and Financial Committee
  • C.Development Committee
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Governance Structure of IMF

The Board of Governors consists of one governor and one alternate governor for each member country. Each member country appoints its two governors. The Board normally meets once a year and is responsible for electing or appointing executive directors to the Executive Board. While the Board of Governors is officially responsible for approving quota increases, Special Drawing Right allocations, the admittance of new members, compulsory withdrawal of members, and amendments to the Articles of Agreement and By-Laws, in practice it has delegated most of its powers to the IMF's Executive Board.

 

Of the IMF's current 24 Executive Directors, five are appointed (US, Japan, Germany, France, and the United Kingdom), and a further three represent a single country (Saudi Arabia, Russia, and the People's Republic of China). The remaining 16 are elected by groups of countries (known as Constituencies) for 2 years.

 

The Board of Governors is advised by the International Monetary and Financial Committee and the Development Committee. The International Monetary and Financial Committee has 24 members and monitors developments in global liquidity and the transfer of resources to developing countries. The Development Committee has 25 members and advises on critical development issues and on financial resources required to promote economic development in developing countries. They also advise on trade and environmental issues.

 

The IMF has a Managing Director, who is head of the staff and Chairperson of the Executive Board. The Managing Director is appointed by the Executive Board for a renewable term of five years and is assisted by a First Deputy Managing Director and three Deputy Managing Directors. The Board of Governors reports directly to the Managing Director of the IMF (Christine Lagarde as on April 2019).

 

From India, the Finance Minister is the ex-officio Governor on the Board of Governors of the IMF. RBI Governor is the Alternate Governor at the IMF. India is represented at the IMF by an Executive Director.

Question 13
What are the principles of WTO (Trading Systems)?(i) Non-discrimination(ii) Reciprocity(iii) Binding and enforceable commitments(iv) Transparency(v) Safety valvesSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) only
  • B.(i) (ii) (iv) (v) only
  • C.(i) (ii) (iii) only
  • D.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v)
Correct Answer: (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The WTO (World Trade Organization) provides a framework for trade policies without specifying outcomes. It focuses on setting rules for trade policy games, and five key principles are crucial:

 

1. Non-discrimination: This principle involves the most favoured nation (MFN) rule, requiring equal trade conditions with all WTO members, and the national treatment policy, ensuring that imported goods are treated as favourably as domestically produced ones.

 

2. Reciprocity: This principle aims to limit free-riding and enhance access to foreign markets. Nations negotiate to ensure that the gains from reciprocal concessions exceed those from unilateral liberalization.

 

3. Binding and enforceable commitments: WTO members make tariff commitments in negotiations, recorded in schedules of concessions. These commitments are binding and can be changed only through negotiation with trading partners.

 

4. Transparency: Members must publish trade regulations, maintain institutions for reviewing administrative decisions, respond to information requests from other members, and notify the WTO of changes in trade policies. Trade policy reviews contribute to improved adherence to WTO agreements.

 

5. Safety valves: Governments can, under specific circumstances, restrict trade to protect the environment, public health, animal health, and plant health, as permitted by the WTO's agreements.

Question 14
IFRS stands for:
  • A.Indian Financial Reporting Standard
  • B.International Forex Rate Standard
  • C.International Financial reporting Statement
  • D.International Financial reporting Standard
Correct Answer: International Financial reporting Standard

International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs)

International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRSs) are globally accepted accounting standards developed by International Accounting Standard Board (IASB). IFRS is a set of accounting standards for reporting different types of business transactions and events in the financial statements. The objective is to facilitate international comparisons for true and fair valuation of a business enterprise. The qualitative characteristics associated with the preparation of financial statements are useful to the users of accounting information in making financial decisions.

Question 15
Which of the following is incorrect as per the Golden Rules of Accounting?
  • A.Real Account: Debit – What comes in
  • B.Personal Account: Credit – The Giver
  • C.Nominal Account: Debit – The Income or Gain of the business
  • D.Real Account: Credit–What goes out
Correct Answer: Nominal Account: Debit – The Income or Gain of the business

Option C is the correct answer.

 

A Real Account is a general ledger account relating to Assets and Liabilities other than people accounts. These are accounts that don’t close at year end and are carried forward.

 

A Personal Account is a general ledger account connected to all those accounts which are either directly or indirectly related to individuals, companies, firms or organizations are known as Personal Account. For example, Kumar Account, XVZ Pvt. Ltd., etc.

 

A Nominal Account is an account relating to all income, expenses, losses and gains.

 

Golden Rules of Accounting

For each account there is a set of Golden Rules and hence there are three Golden Rules of Accounting.  

 

Real Account

Debit – What comes In

Credit – What goes Out

Personal Account

Debit – The Receiver

Credit – The Giver

Nominal Account

Debit – The Expenses or Loss of the business

Credit – The Income or Gain of the business

 

Question 16
In the context of Cash Flow Statement, “Cash generated from the sale of land” is an example of ____________ activities.
  • A.Financing Activities
  • B.Investing Activities
  • C.Operating Activities
  • D.Cash Activities
Correct Answer: Investing Activities

Cash generated from the sale of land falls under the category of Investing Activities in the Cash Flow Statement. Investing activities involve transactions related to the acquisition and disposal of long-term assets, such as property, equipment, and investments.

 

In this case, the sale of land is a cash inflow, but it is associated with the disposal of a long-term asset. Therefore, it is classified as an Investing Activity, as it reflects the cash impact of the company's investment or divestment in capital assets.

Question 17
Ram, Mahesh and Tina are partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 5:3:2. Mahesh retires from the firm and his share was gained by Ram and Tina in the ratio 2:1. Find the new profit sharing ratio?
  • A.4:3
  • B.5:3
  • C.6:3
  • D.7:3
Correct Answer: 7:3

Gaining Ratio is 2:1.

Share gained by Ram = 23×310 = 210

Share gained by Tina = 13×310 = 110

 

New share of Ram = 510+210=710

 

New share of Tina = 210+110=310

 

Thus, the new profit sharing ratio of Ram and Tina will be = 7:3.

Question 18
When a company forfeits 200 shares ofRs. 10 each on whichRs. 600 had been received, it can allow a maximum discount ofRs. 600 on their reissue. Assuming that the company reissues these shares forRs. 1,800 as fully paid, then the Share Forfeiture A/c will be:
  • A.Debited withRs. 600
  • B.Credited withRs. 600
  • C.Debited withRs. 200
  • D.Credited withRs. 200
Correct Answer: Debited withRs. 200

When a company forfeits shares, it usually debits the Share Forfeiture Account. In this case, the company forfeits 200 shares on which Rs. 600 had been received. The company then reissues these shares for Rs. 1,800 as fully paid.

The maximum discount allowed on reissue is limited to the amount already received. In this scenario, the company can allow a maximum discount of Rs. 600. Since the reissue is for Rs. 1,800, and the maximum discount allowed is Rs. 600, the remaining amount to be received is Rs. 1,200 (1,800 - 600).

 

Therefore, the Share Forfeiture Account will be debited with Rs. 200 (the amount to be recovered from the original shareholder). The debiting of the Share Forfeiture Account reflects the recovery of the forfeited amount from the original shareholder.

Question 19
In case a product’s selling price (per unit) isRs20, the variable cost (per unit) isRs14, fixed factory overheads, (per year) isRs5,40,000 and fixed selling overheads isRs2,52,000, the break-even in terms of sales volume and the number of units to be sold to earn a profit ofRs60,000 will be?
  • A.45%
  • B.55%
  • C.65%
  • D.75%
Correct Answer: 65%

Unit sales to attain the target profit= Total Fixed Cost + ProfitSelling Price – Variable Cost

 

Unit sales to attain the target profit= 252000+540000+6000020-14

 

Unit sales to attain the target profit= 142000 units.

 

Total Sales to attain the target profit = BEP Units×Selling Price

Total Sales to attain the target profit = 142000×20

Total Sales to attain the target profit= Rs.284000

 

The Margin of Safety

The margin of safety is the excess of budgeted (or actual) sales over the break-even volume of sales.

 

Margin of safety = Total Sales - Break-even Sales

Margin of safety %= (Sales - BEP)Sales×100

Taking figures from previous illustration:

Margin of safety %= (5000 - 1750)5000×100=65%

Question 20
Likert’s Model of HRA is developed by which of the following?
  • A.M.Dasgupta
  • B.RensisLikert and David G. Bowers
  • C.David Watson
  • D.Hekimian& Johns
Correct Answer: RensisLikert and David G. Bowers

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Likert’s Model of Human Resource Accounting (HRA) was developed by Rensis Likert and David G. Bowers. Rensis Likert, an American social psychologist, and David G. Bowers, a management consultant, worked together to conceptualize and present a model for evaluating the value of human resources within an organization.

 

Likert's Model of HRA focuses on the recognition of the importance of human resources as assets and emphasizes the need to account for the value contributed by employees to the organization. The model considers various factors, including skills, knowledge, experience, and commitment, in assessing the overall worth of human capital.

Question 21
Arrange the EIA (Environmental Impact Assessment) cycle in correct order, as per the 2006 amendment.(a) Screening(b) Scoping(c) Public Hearing(d) AppraisalSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (d), (c)
  • B.(c), (b), (a), (d)
  • C.(b), (a), (c), (d)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c), (d)

Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is a process of evaluating the likely environmental impacts of a proposed project or development, taking into account inter-related socio-economic, cultural and human-health impacts, both beneficial and adverse. Environment Impact Assessment in India is statutorily backed by the Environment Protection Act, 1986 which contains various provisions on EIA methodology and process.

 

After 2006 Amendment the EIA cycle comprises of 4 stages:

(i) Screening

(ii) Scoping

(iii) Public hearing

(iv) Appraisal

Question 22
Consider the following.Statement I– A homogenous production function is a function such that if each of the inputs is multiplied by k, then k can be completely factored out of the function.Statement II- The power of k is called the degree of homogeneity.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Statements I and II are both correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • C.Statements I and II are both incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is not correct, but II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statements I and II are both correct.

A homogenous production function is a function such that if each of the inputs is multiplied by k, then k can be completely factored out of the function.

X* = Kvf (L, K)

The power of k is called the degree of homogeneity of the function and is a measure of the returns to scale. If,

V=1, constant returns to scale

V>1, increasing returns to scale

V<1, diminishing returns to scale

Question 23
Consider the following.Statement I: MC curve intersects AC curve at its minimum.Statement II: When MC curve intersects AC curve, AC is constant.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Statements I and II are both correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • C.Statements I and II are incorrect.
  • D.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Statements I and II are both correct.

AC and MC are related in following ways:

 

1) When MC falls, AC follows, over a certain range of output. When MC is falling, the rate of fall in MC is greater than that of AC, because while MC is attributed to a single marginal unit, AC is distributed over the entire output. Therefore, AC decreases at a lower rate than MC.

 

2) Similarly, when MC increases, AC also increases but at a lower rate. There is, however, a range of output over which the relationship does not exist.

 

3) MC curve intersects AC curve at its minimum. The reason is, while AC continues to decrease, MC begins to rise. Therefore, they are bound to intersect. Also, when AC is at its minimum, it is neither increasing nor decreasing: it is constant. When AC is constant, AC= MC.

Question 24
Consider the following.Assertion–‘A’: Cross elasticity of demand for substitutes good is positive.Reasoning–‘R’:In case of substitutes good, if price of one commodity increases then demand for another commodity also increases, vice-versa.
  • A.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect but R is correct.
  • C.A and R both are correct but R is not right explanation of A.
  • D.A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.

The Cross-price elasticity of Demand shows the relationship between two goods or services. More specifically, it captures the responsiveness of the quantity demanded of one good to a change in price of another good.

 

The cross-price elasticity may be a positive or negative value, depending on whether the goods are complements or substitutes.

 

If two products are complements, an increase in demand for one is accompanied by an increase in the quantity demanded of the other. For example, an increase in demand for cars will lead to an increase in demand for fuel.

 

If the price of the complement falls, the quantity demanded of the other good will increase. The value of the cross-price elasticity for complementary goods will thus be negative.

 

A positive cross-price elasticity value indicates that the two goods are substitutes. For substitute goods, as the price of one good rises, the demand for the substitute good increases. For example, if the price of coffee increases, consumers may purchase less coffee and more tea. Conversely, the demand for a substitute good falls when the price of another good is decreased.

Question 25
Match the following items:List-Ii. Dumpingii. Kinked demand curveiii. Horizontal straight-line revenue curveiv. Large number of buyers and sellers with differentiated productsList-IIa. Monopolistic competitive firmb. Oligopoly firmc. Perfectively competitive firmd. Discriminatory monopolySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.i-d, ii-b, iii-c, iv-a
  • B.i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
  • C.i-d, ii-b, iii-a, iv-c
  • D.i-a, ii-d, iii-b, iv-c
Correct Answer: i-d, ii-b, iii-c, iv-a

An oligopoly is a market form in which a market or industry is dominated by a small number of sellers. In oligopoly, oligopolistic faces a kinked‐demand curve because of competition from other oligopolists in the market.

 

Dumping is a kind of predatory pricing, especially in the context of international trade. It occurs when manufacturers export a product to another country at a price either below the price charged in its home market or below its cost of production. It is a kind of discriminatory monopoly.

 

In monopolistic competitive market there is large number of buyers and sellers with differentiated products.

 

In perfectly competitive firm price remains constant in the market as a result it encounters a horizontal straight-line revenue curve.

Question 26
Isoquant curve isalso referred to as __________.
  • A.Budget Lines
  • B.Utility Curve
  • C.Equal Product Curve
  • D.Production Possibility Curve
Correct Answer: Equal Product Curve

The term ‘isoquant’ has been derived from the Greek word iso meaning ‘equal’ and Latin word quantus meaning ‘quantity’. The ‘isoquant curve’ is, therefore, also known as ‘Equal Product Curve’ or ‘Production Indifference Curve’. An isoquant curve is locus of points representing various combinations of two inputs—capital and labour— yielding the same output.

 

An ‘isoquant curve’ is analogous to an ‘indifference curve’, with two points of distinction:

(a) an indifference curve is made of two consumer goods while an isoquant curve is constructed of two producer goods (labour and capital) and

(b) an indifference curve measures ‘utility’ whereas an isoquant measures output.

Question 27
Which of the following are the assumptions of Law of diminishing Marginal Utility?(i) Heterogeneous Unit(ii) Standard Unit of Consumption(iii) Continuous Consumption(iv) Case of related goods(v) Based on realistic assumptions(vi) Failed in case of prestigious goodsSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (iii), (v)
  • B.(ii), (iv), (vi)
  • C.(ii), (iii), (iv), (vi)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (v)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi)

The law of diminishing marginal utility holds only under certain conditions. These conditions are referred to as the assumptions of the law which are given below:

 

(i) Homogenous units: The different units consumed should be identical in all respects. The habit, taste, temperament and income of the consumer also should remain unchanged.

(ii) Standard units of Consumption: The different units consumed should consist of standard units. If a thirsty man is given water by successive spoonfuls, the utility of the second spoonful of water may conceivably be greater than the utility of the first.

(iii) Continuous Consumption: There should be no time gap or interval between the consumption of one unit and another unit i.e. there should be continuous consumption.

(iv) The Law fails in the case of prestigious goods: The law may not apply to articles like gold, cash, diamonds etc. where a greater quantity may increase the utility rather than diminish it. It also fails to apply in the case of hobbies, alcohol, cigarettes, rare collections etc.

(v) Case of related goods: Utility is not in fact independent. The shape of the utility curve may be affected by the presence or absence of articles which are substitutes or complements. The utility obtained from tea may be seriously affected if no sugar is available and the utility of bottled soft drinks will be affected by the availability of fresh juice.

(vi) Based on unrealistic assumptions: The assumptions of cardinal measurability of utility, constancy of marginal utility of money, continuous consumption and consumer rationality are unrealistic

 

Given these conditions, the law of diminishing marginal utility holds universally.

Question 28
Arc Elasticity and Point Elasticity are the calculating methods used under which type of elasticity?
  • A.Price Elasticity
  • B.Income Elasticity
  • C.Cross Elasticity
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Price Elasticity

Both Arc Elasticity and Point Elasticity are methods used for calculating Price Elasticity of Demand.

 

Arc Elasticity: This method calculates elasticity over a range or arc of the demand curve. It involves taking the average elasticity between two points.

 

Point Elasticity: This method calculates elasticity at a specific point on the demand curve. It involves finding the elasticity at a single point. The formula for point elasticity is (dq/dp) × (p/q), where dq/dp is the derivative of the demand function with respect to price, and p/q is the ratio of price to quantity.

 

Both methods are applicable to the measurement of how sensitive the quantity demanded of a good is to a change in its price, which falls under the category of Price Elasticity. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Price Elasticity.

Question 29
Which of the following is not the properties of Indifference Curve?
  • A.Indifference Curves are upward slopping
  • B.Indifference Curve cannot intersect
  • C.Indifference Curves are convex
  • D.Indifference curve may or may not be parallel to each other.
Correct Answer: Indifference Curves are upward slopping

Option A is the correct answer. Indifference Curves are Downward Sloping.

 

Virtually all indifference curves have a negative slope. That is, they slope downward from left to right. The slope of an indifference curve shows the rate of substitution between two goods, i.e. the rate at which an individual is willing to give up some quantity of good A to get more of good B.

Question 30
Product differentiation refers to:
  • A.Features that make one product appear different from competing products in the same market.
  • B.Different prices for the same product in a certain market.
  • C.The selling of identical products in different markets.
  • D.The charging of different prices for the same product in different markets.
Correct Answer: Features that make one product appear different from competing products in the same market.

Product differentiation is a marketing process that strives to identify and communicate the unique benefits or qualities of a product compared to its competitors. It has features that make one product appear different from competing products in the same market.

Question 31
Market Equilibrium relates to ________.
  • A.Demand & Supply
  • B.Production and Raw Material
  • C.Demand and Price
  • D.Supply and Production
Correct Answer: Demand & Supply

Market Equilibrium is the state in which market supply and demand balance each other, and as a result, prices become stable. Generally, an over-supply for goods or services causes prices to go down, which results in higher demand. The balancing effect of supply and demand results in a state of equilibrium.

Question 32
α + β = 1 referred to as ____________ degree of returns to scale.
  • A.Constant Return to Scale
  • B.Increasing Return to Scale
  • C.Decreasing Return to Scale
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Constant Return to Scale

Cobb-Douglas production function refers to the production function in which one input can be substituted by other but to a limited extent. The rate at which input a can be given up in return for one more unit of input b keeping the output constant diminishes as the amount of input b increases. It is shown in panel III. For example, capital and labour can be used as a substitute of each other, but to a limited extent only.

Q= AkαLb

 

 

Degree of return to scale:

1. Constant Return to Scale → α + β = 1

2. Increasing Return to Scale → α+ β > 1

3. Decreasing Return to Scale → α + β < 1

Question 33
The firm’s average rate of return is 15%, its cost of capital is 10% and earnings per share isRs10. If thepayoutratio is 40%, 60% and 90%, the value of share according to Gordon’s model will be
  • A.Rs440,Rs120 andRs90, respectively
  • B.Rs400,Rs120 andRs105, respectively
  • C.Rs400,Rs150 andRs105.88, respectively
  • D.Rs440,Rs160 andRs120, respectively
Correct Answer: Rs400,Rs150 andRs105.88, respectively

Gordon's basic valuation formula is given as:

P0 = E(1-b)Ke - br

Or,

Also called dividend growth model

P0 = D1Ke-g= D0(1+g)Ke-g

Where,

P0 = Price of shares, E = Earnings per share , b = Retention ratio , Ke = Cost of equity capital , br = g = Growth rate , D0 = Dividend per share , D1 = Expected dividend at the end of year 1.

As per the question, P0 = E(1-b)Ke - br = P0 = 10(1-0.6)0.1 -(0.6*0.15) = 400 (solving for payout ratio = 40%)

Now, solving for payout ratio 60%

 

P0 = E(1-b)Ke - br = 10(1-0.4)0.1 -(0.4*0.15) = 150

Question 34
Match the following expressions:List – Ia. Venture capitalb. Private equityc. Private placementList – IIi. Emphasizes on Corporate governanceii. Issue of securities to a select group of persons not exceeding 49iii. Emphasizes on Management capabilitySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-i
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii

Venture capital is financing that investors provide to startup companies and small businesses that are believed to have long-term growth potential. Venture capital generally comes from well-off investors, investment banks and any other financial institutions. However, it does not always take just a monetary form; it can be provided in the form of technical or managerial expertise.

Private placement is a capital raising event that involves the sale of securities to a relatively small number of select investors. Investors involved in private placements can include large banks, mutual funds, insurance companies and pension funds.

 

Private equity is an alternative investment class and consists of capital that is not listed on a public exchange. Private equity is composed of funds and investors that directly invest in private companies, or that engage in buyouts of public companies, resulting in the delisting of public equity

Question 35
For the following items in List – I and List – II, indicate the correct code after matching them:List – Ii. Net income approach for capital structureii. Irrelevance of capital structure for the value of the firm.iii. FRICT analysis for capital structureList – IIa. Modigliani, M. and Miller M.H.b. Robert Brunerc. David DurandSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.i-a, ii-b, iii-c
  • B.i-c, ii-a, iii-b
  • C.i-b, ii-a, iii-c
  • D.i-a, ii-c, iii-b
Correct Answer: i-c, ii-a, iii-b

Option B is the correct answer.

 

i. Net income approach for capital structure - (c) David Durand

 

The Net Income Approach, which suggests that the capital structure decision does affect the value of the firm, is associated with David Durand.

 

ii. Irrelevance of capital structure for the value of the firm - (a) Modigliani, M. and Miller M.H.

 

The Modigliani-Miller Propositions argue that, under certain assumptions, the capital structure is irrelevant to the value of the firm.

 

iii. FRICT analysis for capital structure - (a) Robert Bruner

 

The FRICT analysis, which considers factors like flexibility, risk, income, control, and timing in capital structure decisions, is associated with Robert Bruner.

Question 36
If risk free rate of return is 5%, market return is 10% and the cost of equity is 13%, the value of beta (β) is:
  • A.1.2
  • B.1.5
  • C.1.8
  • D.1.6
Correct Answer: 1.6

According to CAPM MODEL

Ke = Rf+Rm-Rf X β

Where,

Rm = Return on market portfolio / expected market return

Ke= Cost of Equity

Rf= Risk Free Rate

Rm-Rf = Market Risk Rate

β = Beta

As per the question

0.13 = 0.05 + (0.10- 0.05) β

β= 0.13-0.050.10-0.05

β = 1.6

Question 37
According toLintnerModel, factors affecting dividend of current year are:
  • A.DPS of previous year, EPS, target pay-out ratio and adjustment rate.
  • B.EBIT, interest rate and retention ratio.
  • C.P/E ratio, retention ratio and pay-out ratio.
  • D.E/P ratio, pay-out ratio and rate of interest on it.
Correct Answer: DPS of previous year, EPS, target pay-out ratio and adjustment rate.

The Lintner Model, developed by John Lintner, is a model of dividend policy that takes into account the factors influencing dividend decisions. According to the Lintner Model, the factors affecting the dividend of the current year include:

 

DPS of previous year: The dividend per share paid in the previous year serves as a reference point for determining the current year's dividend.

 

EPS (Earnings Per Share): The company's earnings per share are a crucial factor influencing the dividend decision. Higher earnings often support the ability to pay dividends.

 

Target pay-out ratio: The proportion of earnings that the company aims to distribute as dividends. This ratio guides the dividend decision-making process.

 

Adjustment rate: The adjustment rate is used to gradually bring the actual dividend payout closer to the target pay-out ratio. It helps smooth out drastic changes in dividends.

 

Option (A) accurately captures the factors considered in the Lintner Model for determining the dividend of the current year.

Question 38
The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) is determined where:
  • A.Net Present Value is positive
  • B.Net Present Value is negative
  • C.Net Present Value is zero
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Net Present Value is zero

Internal Rate of Return: Internal rate of return is that rate at which NPV of the project is Zero (0). It is also called the discounted cash flow rate of return. 

Question 39
The _______________ account means ‘our account with you’. It is an account maintained by a bank with its branch or another bank at overseas centre and the account is maintained in foreign currency.
  • A.VOSTRO Account
  • B.NOSTRO Account
  • C.LORO Account
  • D.Mirror Account
Correct Answer: NOSTRO Account

The term described is "NOSTRO Account." The options are related to different types of accounts used in international banking:

 

VOSTRO Account: "Your account with us." It refers to an account maintained by a local bank on behalf of a foreign bank. For example, if a foreign bank has an account with a local bank, it is called a VOSTRO Account for the local bank.

 

NOSTRO Account: "Our account with you." It is an account maintained by a bank in a foreign country with another bank or its own branch in the home country. It is held in a foreign currency.

 

LORO Account: "Their account with you." It is an intermediary account used by a correspondent bank. For example, if Bank A in Country A holds an account with Bank B in Country B, and Bank B holds an account with Bank C in Country C, then Bank B's account with Bank C is a LORO Account.

 

Mirror Account: This term is not commonly used in the context described.

Question 40
In case the profitability index of an investment is equal to one (=1), the net present value of the investment will be:
  • A.More than one (>1).
  • B.Equal to one (=1).
  • C.Less than one (<1).
  • D.Equal to zero (=0).
Correct Answer: Equal to zero (=0).

The Profitability Index (PI) is calculated as the ratio of the present value of cash inflows to the present value of cash outflows for a particular investment project. Mathematically, it is expressed as:

 

Profitability Index (PI) = Present Value of Cash Inflows/ Present Value of Cash Outflows

​

If the Profitability Index is equal to one (PI = 1), it means that the present value of cash inflows is exactly equal to the present value of cash outflows. In other words, the project is expected to break even – the net present value (NPV) is zero.

 

The NPV is calculated as the difference between the present value of cash inflows and the present value of cash outflows:

 

NPV = Present Value of Cash Inflows − Present Value of Cash Outflows

 

If PI is equal to one, then NPV is indeed equal to zero. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Equal to zero (=0).

Question 41
The company has been buying an item in lots of 2,400 units which is six months' supply, the cost per unit isRs12, order cost isRs8 per order and the carrying cost is 25%. The Economic Order Quantity is:
  • A.392
  • B.39
  • C.160
  • D.200
Correct Answer: 160

The Economic Order Quantity, EOQ is defined by the formula: EOQ = 2 ×Total Demand ×Ordering CostHolding Cost.

= 2 X 4800 X 80.25 X 12 (where 4800 is total demand for 12 months)

= 160

Question 42
The Third Quartile (denotedbyQ3) or upper Quartile has ______ of the items of the distribution below it and ______ of the items above it.
  • A.33.33%, 66.67%
  • B.66.67%, 33.33%
  • C.25%, 75%
  • D.75%, 25%
Correct Answer: 75%, 25%

If the values of the variate are arranged in ascending or descending order of magnitudes then we have seen above that median is that value of the variate which divides the total frequencies in two equal parts.

 

Similarly the given series can be divided into 4, 10 and 100 equal pars. The values of the variate dividing into 4 equal parts are called Quartile, into 10 equal parts are called Decile and into 100 equal parts are called Percentile.

Quartiles

The values of the variate which divide the total frequency into 4 equal parts, are called quartiles.

 

There are three quartiles.

(i) The first Quartile (denoted by Q1) or lower quartile has 25% of the items of the distribution below it and 75% of the items are greater than it.

(ii) The second Quartile (denoted by Q2) or median has 50% of items below it and 50% of the observations above it.

(iii) The third Quartile (denoted by Q3) or upper Quartile has 75% of the items of the distribution below it and 25% of the items above it. Thus, Q1 and Q3 denote the two limits within which central 50% of the data lies.

Question 43
In an experiment, a coin is tossed 3 times. The researcher records the data on a piece of paper but is not willing to share it with you. He claims that he got 4 heads. What is the probability of 4 heads?
  • A.0.50
  • B.1
  • C.0
  • D.0.125
Correct Answer: 0

A coin is tossed 3 times. Let us define the event as number of heads.

 

The sample space, S = {HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, TTH, THT, HTT, TTT}

 

In the sample space, the maximum number of heads, it can get is 3. Hence, the probability of 4 heads is 0.

Question 44
The number of trials (n) and probability of success (p) is the parameter for which of the following distributions?
  • A.Normal distribution
  • B.Binomial distribution
  • C.Exponential distribution
  • D.Poisson distribution
Correct Answer: Binomial distribution

The two parameters by which binomial distribution are represented by the probability of success and number of trials.

 

Normal distribution is represented by the mean and the variance of the random variable.

The Poisson distribution provides an appropriate description of the number of occurrences per interval of time, then the exponential distribution will provide a description of the length of time between occurrences.

Question 45
For which of the following distributions would you come across the concept of degrees of freedoms?
  • A.Uniform distribution
  • B.Chi-Square distribution
  • C.Normal distribution
  • D.Exponential distribution
Correct Answer: Chi-Square distribution

To calculate probabilities values of a Chi-square distribution, we need to know the degrees of freedom that the test statistics follows. Another distribution which is defined for certain degrees of freedom is F distribution. However, we do not need to know degrees of freedom for random variable that follows Normal distribution and exponential distribution.

Question 46
The standard deviation of population of 2500 managers isσ=4000. The Population size, N = 2500. The sample size, n = 25. The Standard Error of Mean will be:
  • A.600
  • B.800
  • C.200
  • D.400
Correct Answer: 800

The standard deviation of population of 2500 managers is σ= 4000. The Population size, N = 2500. The sample size, n = 25.

 

We calculate n/N = 25/2500 = 0.010, which is less than 0.05.

 

So, the Formula for calculating Standard Deviation of x- (also called Standard Error of Mean) is:

σx- = σn 

 

= 400025

 

= 800

Question 47
Which of the following statements are correct?Statement I:A parameter is a characteristic of sample.Statement II:A statistic a characteristic of population.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Both statements are correct
  • B.Statement I is correct while Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Both Statements are incorrect
  • D.Statement II is correct while Statement I is incorrect
Correct Answer: Both Statements are incorrect

Both statements are incorrect. A population is characterized by a “parameter”. We want to draw inferences about population, so we draw a sample and construct a test “statistic” around it.

Question 48
A manager wants to understand whether there is significant difference in the productivity of three group of workers. It is assumed that these samples are drawn from normal distribution. Which is the following is FALSE about the hypothesis procedure of this exercise:
  • A.H0:μ1=μ2=μ3H1:H0isfalse
  • B.The manager will use the ANOVA test to test the difference across three groups of workers
  • C.The manager should use t-test for difference of means across 3 groups
  • D.The calculated test statistic will follow F-distribution
Correct Answer: The manager should use t-test for difference of means across 3 groups

The manager wants to test if there is a difference in means across the three groups. This is a case of One-way ANOVA. The null hypothesis- H0: μ1=μ2=μ3will describe the same while the alternative hypothesis will say that null hypothesis is false. Option A is true.
The calculated test statistic for the above exercise = between group variance/within group variance. Hence option D is correct


The test statistic in option D will follow F-distribution with k-1 and n-k degrees of freedoms. The k here is number of groups and n is the total number of observations across all groups.

Question 49
It is given to us thatα=0.10andβ=0.15, calculate the power of test.
  • A.0.90
  • B.0.10
  • C.0.85
  • D.0.15
Correct Answer: 0.85

The alpha, α refers to the probability of rejecting null hypothesis when it was in fact true. For that reason, it is also called type I error.


The beta, β refers to the probability of not rejecting null hypothesis when null hypothesis indeed was false. It wrongly concludes no statistical significance.

 

The power of the test refers to the probability that a test correctly rejects null hypothesis when alternate is indeed true.


Power of test = 1 – β = 1- 0.15 = 0.85

Question 50
Consider the regression equation Y = A + BX + u. Match the columns on the left with the ones on right:List-Ia. Yb. Xc. Bd. AList-IIi. Interceptii. Slopeiii. Dependent Variableiv. Independent Variablev. Residual term
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • B.a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i

In a regression equation, Y is the dependent variable, X is independent variable, B is slope coefficient while A is the intercept term. The u is the residual term.

 

Y = A + BX + u

Question 51
Calculation of Mean of Population, when Standard Deviation of Population is notknown, is done with the help of:
  • A.z test
  • B.ANOVA
  • C.t test
  • D.F test
Correct Answer: t test

(i) Calculation of Mean of Population, when Standard Deviation of Population (σ) is Known – using z test

 

(ii) Calculation of Mean of Population, when Standard Deviation of Population (σ) is NOT Known- using t test

Question 52
Which of the following are known as ‘Big Five’ dimensions of personality?Dimensions:a. Extraversionb. Dominancec. Sensitivityd. Agreeablenesse. Conscientiousnessf. Rule-consciousnessg. Self-relianceh. Emotional Stabilityi. Openness to experiencej. PerfectionismSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a, d, e, h andi
  • B.a, e, h, b and j
  • C.d, e, f, g and h
  • D.a, d, g,iand j
Correct Answer: a, d, e, h andi

Big Five Model: Big Five factors of personality are five broad domains which define human personality and account for individual differences. Human resources professionals often use the Big Five personality dimensions to help place employees. That is because these dimensions are considered to be the underlying traits that make up an individual’s overall personality. The Big Five traits are:

I. Openness - People who like to learn new things and enjoy new experiences usually score high in openness. Openness includes traits like being insightful and imaginative and having a wide variety of interests.

II. Conscientiousness - People that have a high degree of conscientiousness are reliable and prompt. Traits include being organized, methodic, and thorough.

III. Extraversion - Extraverts get their energy from interacting with others, while introverts get their energy from within themselves. Extraversion includes the traits of energetic, talkative, and assertive.

IV. Agreeableness - These individuals are friendly, cooperative, and compassionate. People with low agreeableness may be more distant. Traits include being kind, affectionate, and sympathetic.

V. Neuroticism - Neuroticism is also sometimes called Emotional Stability. This dimension relates to one’s emotional stability and degree of negative emotions. People that score high on neuroticism often experience emotional instability and negative emotions. Traits include being moody and tense.

Question 53
Which of the following is NOT one of leadership style suggested byRensisLikert?
  • A.Consultative
  • B.Benevolent Authoritative
  • C.Exploitative Authoritative
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Rensis Likert identified four main styles of leadership, in particular around decision-making and the degree to which people are involved in the decision.

 

1) Exploitive authoritative: In this style, the leader has a low concern for people and uses such methods as threats and other fear-based methods to achieve conformance.

2) Benevolent authoritative: When the leader adds concern for people to an authoritative position, a 'benevolent dictatorship' is formed. The leader now uses rewards to encourage appropriate performance and listens more to concerns lower down the organization.

3) Consultative: The upward flow of information here is still cautious and rose-tinted to some degree, although the leader is making genuine efforts to listen carefully to ideas. Nevertheless, major decisions are still largely centrally made.

4) Participative: At this level, the leader makes maximum use of participative methods, engaging people lower down the organization in decision-making. People across the organization are psychologically closer together and work well together at all levels.

Question 54
Which of the following is not one of stages of Change Management?
  • A.Changing
  • B.Adjusting
  • C.Unfreezing
  • D.Refreezing
Correct Answer: Adjusting

The correct answer is (B) Adjusting.

 

Change Management typically involves a structured process with various stages. The three classic stages of Change Management, often attributed to psychologist Kurt Lewin, are:

 

Unfreezing: This stage involves preparing the organization or individuals for the change by creating awareness and understanding of the need for change.

 

Changing: This is the stage where the actual change or transformation occurs. New processes, systems, or ways of working are introduced and implemented.

 

Refreezing: In this stage, the changes are reinforced, and new behaviors or practices become the norm. Stability is re-established, and the organization or individuals adapt to the new state.

Question 55
Who is/are the profounder of the People Capability Maturity Model (PCMM) approach to Human Resource Development?
  • A.Ulrishand Lake
  • B.Yeung and Berman
  • C.Friedman et. al
  • D.Curtis et. al
Correct Answer: Curtis et. al

The People Capability Maturity Model (PCMM) approach to Human Resource Development was developed by a team led by Bill Curtis. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Curtis et. al.

 

The PCMM is a framework that focuses on the continuous improvement of the capability of an organization's workforce. It provides guidelines for organizations to enhance their human resource practices and processes to achieve higher levels of maturity in managing and developing their people. The model consists of five maturity levels, each representing a different stage of organizational capability in managing and developing its workforce.

Question 56
Which of the following is NOT a method of Job Analysis?
  • A.Job Elements Approach
  • B.Factor Comparison Method
  • C.Position Analysis Questionnaire
  • D.Task Inventory Approach
Correct Answer: Factor Comparison Method

Factor Comparison Method is a method of Job Evaluation and not job analysis.

Question 57
A_________is a systematic way of determining the value/worth of a job in relation to other jobs in an organization. It tries to make a systematic comparison between jobs to assess their relative worth for the purpose of establishing a rational pay structure.
  • A.Job Determination
  • B.Job Analysis
  • C.Job Evaluation
  • D.Job Grading
Correct Answer: Job Evaluation

Job Evaluation is a systematic process used by organizations to determine the relative value of different jobs within the company. It involves assessing and comparing various jobs based on specific criteria such as skill requirements, responsibilities, and complexity. The goal of job evaluation is to establish a fair and rational pay structure, ensuring that employees are compensated appropriately for their contributions to the organization.

Question 58
Arrange the following steps ofBehaviourallyAnchored Rating Scales (BARS) in sequence:a. Generate critical incidentsb. Develop performance dimensionsc. Develop final instrumentd. Scale the incidentse. Reallocate incidents
  • A.a, b, e, d, c
  • B.a, b, c, d, e
  • C.b, a, c, d, e
  • D.c, d, a, e, b
Correct Answer: a, b, e, d, c

Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scales (BARS)

A BARS combines the benefits of narratives critical incidents and quantified ratings by anchoring a quantified scale with specific behavioral examples of a good or poor performance. BARS was proposed by Charles L Hulin and Milton R Blood.

 

Developing BARS typically requires the following 5 steps:

1. Generate critical incidents: Person who knows the job being appraised is asked to describe specific illustrations of effective and ineffective performance.

2. Develop performance dimensions: These people then cluster the incidents into a smaller set of performance dimensions. Each cluster is then defined.

3. Reallocate incidents: Another group of people who also know the job then reallocate the original critical incidents. They are given the clusters’ definitions and the critical incidents and are asked to reassign each incident to they think it fits best.

4. Scale the incidents: This second group is generally asked to rate the behavior described in the incident as to how effectively or ineffectively it represents performance on the appropriate dimension.

5. Develop final instrument: A subset of the incidents is used as behavioral anchors for each dimension.

Question 59
Arrange the following phases of group formation in their right sequence:(a) forming(b) norming(c) performing(d) storming(e) adjourning
  • A.(a), (d), (c), (b), (e)
  • B.(a), (d), (b), (c), (e)
  • C.(a), (b), (d), (c), (e)
  • D.(a), (c), (d), (b), (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (d), (b), (c), (e)

In 1965, psychologist Bruce Tuckman proposed model of group development. This model suggests that groups and teams move through a series of stages in order to achieve their peak level of performance. Four stages of the model are: Forming – Storming – Norming – Performing. In the first stage of team building, the forming of the team takes place. In the storming stage, enough initial trust has been developed between team members that they start to feel comfortable expressing discontent and challenging others' opinions. In the norming stage the team manages to have one goal and come to a mutual plan for the team at this stage. It is possible for some teams to reach the performing stage. Tuckman, along with his colleague Mary Ann Jensen, proposed a fifth stage of group development in 1977 called adjourning. If a group has fulfilled its goals and objectives, it will move into the Adjourning stage.

Question 60
Match the following techniques of training listed in Column – A, with their descriptions listed in Column – B:Column – A (Techniques of Training)a. Ice Breakersb. Strategic Plannerc. Role Reversald. Mirroringe. Monodramaf. Structured Role PlayingColumn – B (Description)i. Role-play with pre-determined objectivesii. Exercise to teach plurality of viewsiii. Insight into a given interactioniv. Games to test ability to plan aheadv. Training with an external perspectivevi. Games to get team members know each otherSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv, e-v, f-vi
  • B.a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-vi, e-v, f-iv
  • C.a-iv, b-v, c-ii, d-i, e-iii, f-vi
  • D.a-vi, b-iv, c-ii, d-v, e-iii, f-i
Correct Answer: a-vi, b-iv, c-ii, d-v, e-iii, f-i

Few important terminologies, used in training (especially Sensitivity Training), are:

 

Ice Breakers: Games to get team members know each other

Strategic planners: Games to test ability to plan ahead

Role reversal: Exercise to teach plurality of view

Mirroring: Training with external perspective

Monodrama: Insight into a given interaction

Structured role playing: Role play with predetermined objective

Question 61
Which of this is a second stage of Kohlberg’s model of moral development?
  • A.Obedience and Punishment
  • B.Individualism and Exchange
  • C.Maintaining Social Order
  • D.Social Contract and Individual Rights
Correct Answer: Individualism and Exchange

Kohlberg identified three distinct levels of moral reasoning each with two sub-stages. People can only pass through these levels in the order listed. Each new stage replaces the reasoning typical of the earlier stage. Not everyone achieves all the stages.

 

Level 1 - Pre-conventional morality

At the pre-conventional level (most nine-year-old and younger, some over nine), we don’t have a personal code of morality. Instead, our moral code is shaped by the standards of adults and the consequences of following or breaking their rules. Authority is outside the individual and reasoning is based on the physical consequences of actions.

 

Stage 1: Obedience and Punishment Orientation. The child/individual is good in order to avoid being punished. If a person is punished, they must have done wrong.

Stage 2: Individualism and Exchange. At this stage, children recognize that there is not just one right view that is handed down by the authorities. Different individuals have different viewpoints.

 

Level 2 - Conventional morality

At the conventional level (most adolescents and adults), we begin to internalize the moral standards of valued adult role models. Authority is internalized but not questioned, and reasoning is based on the norms of the group to which the person belongs.

 

Stage 3: Good Interpersonal Relationships. The child/individual is good in order to be seen as being a good person by others. Therefore, answers relate to the approval of others.

Stage 4: Maintaining the Social Order. The child/individual becomes aware of the wider rules of society, so judgments concern obeying the rules in order to uphold the law and to avoid guilt.

 

Level 3 - Post-conventional morality

Individual judgment is based on self-chosen principles, and moral reasoning is based on individual rights and justice. According to Kohlberg this level of moral reasoning is as far as most people get. Only 10-15% are capable of the kind of abstract thinking necessary for stage 5 or 6 (post-conventional morality). That is to say, most people take their moral views from those around them and only a minority think through ethical principles for themselves.

 

Stage 5: Social Contract and Individual Rights. The child/individual becomes aware that while rules/laws might exist for the good of the greatest number, there are times when they will work against the interest of particular individuals.
