The issues are not always clear-cut. For example, in Heinz’s dilemma, the protection of life is more important than breaking the law against stealing.

Stage 6: Universal Principles. People at this stage have developed their own set of moral guidelines which may or may not fit the law. The principles apply to everyone. E.g., human rights, justice, and equality. The person will be prepared to act to defend these principles even if it means going against the rest of society in the process and having to pay the consequences of disapproval and or imprisonment. Kohlberg doubted few people reached this stage.

Question 62
Which among the following is NOT correct with regards to Clause 49 of SEBI Act?
  • A.It mandates appointment of at least one woman director
  • B.Clause 49 is related to the Listing Agreement to the Indian Stock Exchange.
  • C.In the case of a company with an executive Chairman, one-third directors should be independent directors.
  • D.It is applicable to companies with equity share capital of more than Rs.10 Crore
Correct Answer: In the case of a company with an executive Chairman, one-third directors should be independent directors.

After the enactment of the new Companies Act, 2013, the SEBI through an official circular has amended Clause 49 of the Listing Agreement, mandating, that the Board of Directors of listed entities shall have an optimum combination of executive and non-executive directors with at least one woman director.

 

As per Clause 49, for a company with an Executive Chairman, at least 50 per cent of the board should comprise independent directors. In the case of a company with a non-executive Chairman, at least one-third of the board should be independent directors.

 

Clause VI (ii) of Clause 49 requires all companies to submit a quarterly compliance report to stock exchange in the prescribed form. The clause also requires that there be a separate section on corporate governance in the annual report with a detailed compliance report.

 

Applicability of Clause 49 Extends to all listed companies except:

Companies with equity share capital of less than Rs 10 crore

Companies having a net worth not exceeding of Rs 25 crore and

Companies listed on SME and SME-ITP platforms of the stock exchanges

Question 63
Robert Katz identified 3 managerial skills essential to successful management. They can be arranged from top to bottom as:(a) technical(b) human(c) conceptualSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.c, b, a
  • B.a, b, c
  • C.c, a, b
  • D.b, c, a
Correct Answer: c, b, a

To perform management functions and assume multiple roles, managers must be skilled. Robert Katz identified three managerial skills essential to successful management: Technical, Human, and Conceptual.

 

Technical skill involves process or technique knowledge and proficiency. Managers use the processes, techniques and tools of a specific area. Human skill involves the ability to interact effectively with people. Managers interact and cooperate with employees. Conceptual skill involves the formulation of ideas. Managers understand abstract relationships, develop ideas, and solve problems creatively. Thus, technical skill deals with things, human skill concerns people, and conceptual skill has to do with ideas.

 

Lower management deals with technical skills, middle management with human skills and top management with conceptual skills.

Question 64
Which of the followingdenotes the tendency of humans to see familiar objects as having standard shape, size, colour or location regardless of changes in the angle of perspective, distance or lighting?
  • A.Figure Ground Principle
  • B.Perceptual Grouping
  • C.Perceptual Constancy
  • D.Halo Effect
Correct Answer: Perceptual Constancy

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Perceptual constancy denotes the tendency of humans to see familiar objects as having standard shape, size, colour or location regardless of changes in the angle of perspective, distance or lighting. Without perceptual constancy we cannot identify different objects, things or person.

Question 65
A scheduled bank is a bank that is listed under the ______ Schedule of the RBI Act, 1934.
  • A.First
  • B.Second
  • C.Third
  • D.Fourth
Correct Answer: Second

A scheduled bank is a bank that is listed under the Second Schedule of the RBI Act, 1934.

 

In order to be included under this schedule of the RBI Act, banks have to fulfill certain conditions such as having a paid up capital and reserves of at least Rs 5 lakh and satisfying the Reserve Bank that its affairs are not being conducted in a manner prejudicial to the interests of its depositors. Non­scheduled banks are those which are not included in the second schedule of the RBI Act, 1934.

 

The scheduled banks comprise (a) scheduled commercial banks and (b) scheduled cooperative banks.

Question 66
The Central Government, in September 2016, constituted the Monetary Policy Committee MPC. The Chairman of MPC is:
  • A.Finance Minister of the Government of India
  • B.Governor of the Reserve Bank of India
  • C.Secretary of Department of Financial Services
  • D.Deputy Governor of RBI, to be nominated by the Governor of RBI.
Correct Answer: Governor of the Reserve Bank of India

Under Section 45ZB of the amended (in 2016) RBI Act, 1934, the central government is empowered to constitute a six-member Monetary Policy Committee (MPC).

 

The MPC shall consist of 6 members:

(i) RBI Governor as its ex officio chairperson,

(ii) Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy,

(iii) An officer of the Bank to be nominated by the Central Board,

(iv) 3 persons to be appointed by the central government. This category of appointments must be from “persons of ability, integrity and standing, having knowledge and experience in the field of economics or banking or finance or monetary policy”.

Question 67
Basel III guidelines, which were released in 2010, in response to the financial crisis of 2008, aims to promote a more resilient banking system by focusing on four vital banking parameters. Which of the following is NOT one of the parameters?
  • A.Capital
  • B.Leverage
  • C.Funding
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: None of the Above

In 2010, Basel III guidelines were released. These guidelines were introduced in response to the financial crisis of 2008. The guidelines aim to promote a more resilient banking system by focusing on 4 vital banking parameters viz. capital, leverage, funding and liquidity.

 

(i) Capital: The capital adequacy ratio is to be maintained at 12.9%. The minimum Tier 1 capital ratio and the minimum Tier 2 capital ratio have to be maintained at 10.5% and 2% of risk-weighted assets respectively. In addition, banks have to maintain a capital conservation buffer of 2.5%. Counter-cyclical buffer is also to be maintained at 0-2.5%.

 

(ii) Leverage: The leverage rate has to be at least 3 %. The leverage rate is the ratio of a bank’s tier-1 capital to average total consolidated assets.

 

(iii) Funding and Liquidity: Basel-III created two liquidity ratios: LCR and NSFR. The liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) will require banks to hold a buffer of high-quality liquid assets sufficient to deal with the cash outflows encountered in an acute short term stress scenario as specified by supervisors. This is to prevent situations like “Bank Run”. The goal is to ensure that banks have enough liquidity for a 30-days stress scenario if it were to happen.

 

The Net Stable Funds Rate (NSFR) requires banks to maintain a stable funding profile in relation to their off-balance-sheet assets and activities. NSFR requires banks to fund their activities with stable sources of finance (reliable over the one-year horizon).

Question 68
A Government Security (G-Sec) is a tradeable instrument issued by the _____________. It acknowledges the Government’s debt obligation. Such securities are short term (usually called treasury bills, with original maturities of less than 1 year) or long term (usually called Government bonds or dated securities with original maturity of 1 year or more).
  • A.RBI
  • B.Central Government
  • C.Central Government or State Governments
  • D.RBI or Central Government or State Governments
Correct Answer: Central Government or State Governments

A Government Security (G-Sec) is a tradeable instrument issued by the Central Government or the State Governments. It acknowledges the Government’s debt obligation. Such securities are short term (usually called treasury bills, with original maturities of less than 1 year) or long term (usually called Government bonds or dated securities with original maturity of 1 year or more).

 

In India, the Central Government issues both, treasury bills and bonds or dated securities while the State Governments issue only bonds or dated securities, which are called the State Development Loans (SDLs). G-Secs carry practically no risk of default and, hence, are called risk-free gilt-edged instruments.

Question 69
Which of the following bank is appointed as the Trustee bank under NPS by the PFRDA?
  • A.State Bank of India
  • B.Punjab National Bank
  • C.ICICI Bank
  • D.Axis Bank
Correct Answer: Axis Bank

The function of the Trustee bank is to manage the banking operations for NPS. Trustee Bank as an intermediary is responsible for the day-to-day flow of funds and banking facilities in accordance with the guidelines/ directions issued by the Authority under NPS. It receives NPS funds from all Nodal Offices and transfers the same to the Pension Funds / Annuity Service Providers/other intermediaries as per the operational guidelines.

 

Axis Bank Ltd. has been appointed as Trustee Bank under NPS by PFRDA w.e.f. 1st July, 2015. The appointment of Trustee Bank is valid for five (5) years subject to annual review by PFRDA.

Question 70
Which of the following is NOT correct, about SEBI?
  • A.The chairman of SEBI is appointed by Central Government.
  • B.The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) was first established in the year 1984 as a non-statutory body for regulating the securities market.
  • C.It became an autonomous body on 12 May 1992 and given statutory powers in 1992 after the SEBI Act 1992 was passed by the Indian Parliament.
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) was first established in the year 1984 as a non-statutory body for regulating the securities market.

The Securities and exchange Board of India (SEBI) was first established in the year 1988 as a non-statutory body for regulating the securities market. It became an autonomous body on 12 May 1992 and given statutory powers in 1992 after the SEBI Act 1992 was passed by the Indian Parliament.

Question 71
Which of the following is NOT correct about Insurance?
  • A.An individual agent can work for 1 Life Insurance Company, 1 Non-life insurance company and 1 Stand-alone health insurance company at a time.
  • B.Corporate Agents are allowed to work for up to 3 Life, 3 Non-life and 3 Stand-alone Health insurance companies at a time.
  • C.Insurance Brokers are authorized to sell the insurance products of any number of insurance companies, Life, Non-life and Stand-alone Health insurance companies.
  • D.Point of Sale Person (POS) is a type of the Web Aggregator.
Correct Answer: Point of Sale Person (POS) is a type of the Web Aggregator.

Point of Sale Person (POS) and Web Aggregator are distinct entities in the insurance sector. The correct relationship is as follows:

 

Point of Sale Person (POS): POS is an individual who is appointed by an insurance company or its intermediary to solicit and service insurance products. POS persons can only represent one life insurer, one non-life insurer, and one standalone health insurer at a time.

 

Web Aggregator: A Web Aggregator is an online platform that provides information about various insurance products from different insurance companies. It facilitates the comparison of policies, allowing users to make informed decisions. Web Aggregators are not POS persons; they operate in the online space to aggregate and present information.

 

Therefore, option (D) is not correct.

Question 72
The_______ are somewhatskepticalconsumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace.
  • A.Innovators
  • B.Late Majority
  • C.Laggard
  • D.Early Adopter
Correct Answer: Late Majority

Consumers can be grouped according to how quickly they adopt a new product. On the one extreme, some consumers adopt the product as soon as it becomes available. On the other extreme, some consumers are among the last to purchase a new product. As a whole, the new product adoption process can be modeled in the form of a bell-shaped diffusion curve.

 

Innovators: Well-informed risk-takers who are willing to try an unproven product. Innovators represent the first 2.5% to adopt the product.

 

Early adopters: Based on the positive response of innovators, early adopters then begin to purchase the product. Early adopters tend to be educated opinion leaders and represent about 13.5% of consumers.

 

Early majority: Careful consumers who tend to avoid risk, the early majority adopts the product once it has been proven by the early adopters. They rely on recommendations from others who have experience with the product. The early majority represents 34% of consumers.

 

Late majority - somewhat skeptical consumers who acquire a product only after it has become commonplace. The late majority represents about 34% of consumers.

 

Laggards - those who avoid change and may not adopt a new product until traditional alternatives no longer are available. Laggards represent about 16% of consumers.

Question 73
A firm have its own shop in one area, and in the same area, it is distributing the product through recognized intermediaries. The former is direct distribution and the latter is indirect. This may lead to _________.
  • A.Vertical Channel conflict
  • B.Horizontal Channel conflict
  • C.Intra-Channel Conflict
  • D.Multi-Channel Conflict
Correct Answer: Multi-Channel Conflict

The Channel Conflict arises when the channel partners such as manufacturer, wholesaler, distributor, retailer, etc. compete against each other for the common sale with the same brand. There can be three types of channel conflict among channel members:

 

Vertical Level Conflict is the conflict between the higher and lower level channels i.e. between the wholesaler and manufacturer. Another example of the vertical conflict is the non-cooperation and boycott of pharmaceutical companies by their wholesalers and chemists.

 

Horizontal Level Conflict is the conflict between the same level of channel members i.e. between the same retailers on the issue of price and territory jumping.

 

Multi-channel Level Conflict is when the intermediary comes in conflict with the manufacturer using both direct and indirect means of distribution. For example, the firm may have its own shop in the area, and in the same area, it may be distributing the product through recognized intermediaries. The former is direct distribution and the latter is indirect. The conflict occurs when the shop prices are lower than that of the intermediaries or dealers.

Question 74
Match the followingList-I(a) Coupons(b) Tie-in Promotions(c) Cross PromotionList-II(i) Using one brand to advertise another non-competing brand.(ii) Offers to consumers of savings off the regular price of a product.(iii) Certificates entitling the bearer to a stated saving on the purchase of a specific product.(iv) Two or more brands or companies team up on coupons, refunds, and contests to increase pulling power.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(iv)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i)

Coupons - A promotional tool in the form of a document or electronic graphic that can be redeemed for a discount when purchasing goods or services. Coupons are generally issued by manufacturers or retailers to the consumer and may be distributed through direct mail, apps, social media or other marketing means. A coupon will feature a specific savings amount or other special offers to persuade consumers to purchase specific goods or services or to purchase from specific retailers.

 

Tie-in Promotions - Special marketing displays and gimmicks that relate to an ongoing advertising campaign. In such marketing arrangement seller sells an in-demand product to a buyer on one-stated condition that he would have to buy a lesser popular brand along with it.

 

Cross Promotion - A marketing technique which involves promotion of other product(s) targeted to the customers of a related product. It usually involves two or more parties, as it is seen in the inclusion of Visa and Mastercard in the promotion of Credit, Debit, and Reward cards.

Question 75
New product pricing strategy through which companies set lower prices to gain large market share is classified as:
  • A.Optional Product Pricing
  • B.Skimming Pricing
  • C.Penetration Pricing
  • D.Captive Product Pricing
Correct Answer: Penetration Pricing

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Market Penetration Pricing sets an initial low price in order to penetrate the market quickly and deeply—to attract a large number of buyers quickly and win a large market share. The high sales volume results in falling costs, allowing the company to cut its price even further. The market must be highly price sensitive so that a low price produces more market growth. Production and distribution costs must fall as sales volume increases. The low price must help keep out competition, and the company that uses penetration pricing must maintain its low-price position.

Question 76
Which of the following is a form of online ad which appears between two content pages while visiting a website?
  • A.Viral Marketing
  • B.Micro-sites
  • C.Interstitials
  • D.Contextual placements
Correct Answer: Interstitials

Interstitial Ad – It is an ad, which appears between two content pages while visiting a website or by extension an ad displayed before accessing the homepage. An interstitial takes up the full extent of the browser window and disappears after a few seconds to allow access to the intended page.

 

Micro-sites - A micro-site is an individual web page or small cluster of web pages that act as a separate entity for a brand. A micro-site typically lives on its own domain, but some exist as a sub-domain.

 

Viral Marketing - Viral marketing seeks to spread information about a product or service from person to person by word of mouth or sharing via the internet or email. The goal of viral marketing is to inspire individuals to share a marketing message to friends, family and other individuals to create exponential growth in the number of its recipients.

 

Contextual placements - Advertising on a website that is targeted to the specific individual who is visiting the Web site. A contextual ad system scans the text of a Web site for keywords and returns ads to the Web page based on what the user is viewing, either through ads placed on the page or pop-up ads.

Question 77
The _________ establishes relationships between profitability, customer loyalty, and employee satisfaction, loyalty, and productivity.
  • A.Internal Marketing
  • B.Service-Profit Chains
  • C.Interactive Marketing
  • D.Service Differentiation
Correct Answer: Service-Profit Chains

Service-Profit Chains emphasize the interconnectedness of various factors within a service-oriented business. It establishes relationships between profitability, customer loyalty, and employee satisfaction, loyalty, and productivity. The idea is that satisfied and engaged employees lead to satisfied customers, which, in turn, contribute to higher profitability.

Question 78
The _____________ recognizes that "Everything Matters" with marketing and that a broad, integrated perspective is often necessary.
  • A.The production concept
  • B.The product concept
  • C.The holistic marketing concept
  • D.The selling concept
Correct Answer: The holistic marketing concept

The Holistic marketing concept is based on the development, design, and implementation of marketing programs, processes, and activities that recognize their breadth and interdependencies. Holistic marketing recognizes that everything matters in marketing and that a broad, integrated perspective is often necessary. It has 4 components:

 

Relationship Marketing: A key goal of marketing is to develop deep, enduring relationships with people and organizations that directly or indirectly affect the success of the firm’s marketing activities. Relationship marketing aims to build mutually satisfying long-term relationships with key constituents in order to earn and retain their business. Four key constituents for relationship marketing are customers, employees, marketing partners (channels, suppliers, distributors, dealers, agencies), and members of the financial community (shareholders, investors, analysts).

 

Integrated Marketing: Occurs when the marketer devises marketing activities and assembles marketing programs to create, communicate, and deliver value for consumers such that “the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.” Two key themes are that (1) many different marketing activities can create, communicate, and deliver value and (2) marketers should design and implement any one marketing activity with all other activities in mind.

 

Internal Marketing: An element of marketing, is the task of hiring, training, and motivating able employees who want to serve customers well. It ensures that everyone in the organization embraces appropriate marketing principles, especially senior management.

 

Performance Marketing: Requires understanding the financial and nonfinancial returns to business and society from marketing activities and programs. Smart marketers go beyond sales revenue to examine the marketing scorecard and interpret what is happening to market share, customer loss rate, customer satisfaction, product quality, and other measures. They also consider the legal, ethical, social and environmental effects of marketing activities and programs.

Question 79
Which one of the following is a research method that is used to identify how an organization is perceived by consumers of an organization and their competitors?
  • A.Competitor value analysis
  • B.Customer value analysis
  • C.Customer profitability analysis
  • D.Customer perceived value
Correct Answer: Customer value analysis

Customer Value Analysis (CVA) refers to a research method that is used to identify how an organization is perceived by consumers of an organization and their competitors. The analysis is conducted to determine what benefits target customers’ value and how they rate the relative value of various competitors’ efforts.

Question 80
Under the ___________, the buyer is required to bear the entire cost of transport and is responsible for the risks occurring during transport except those, which are assumed by the carrier.
  • A.Postage Stamp Pricing
  • B.Zone Pricing
  • C.FOB Pricing
  • D.Basic Point Pricing
Correct Answer: FOB Pricing

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Under the FOB (Free On Board) pricing term, the buyer is required to bear the entire cost of transport and is responsible for the risks occurring during transport, except those assumed by the carrier. The term specifies the point at which the responsibility and costs associated with the shipment transfer from the seller to the buyer.

 

The other options refer to different pricing or shipping terms:

 

(i) Postage Stamp Pricing (option A): This term is not a standard shipping or pricing term. It seems to be a concept unrelated to the shipping of goods.

 

(ii) Zone Pricing (option B): Zone pricing typically relates to pricing based on geographical zones or regions and is not specifically associated with the transfer of risks and costs during transport.

 

(iii) Basic Point Pricing (option D): This term is not a recognized shipping or pricing term in the context of international trade or transportation.

Question 81
The _________ is the number of different product lines the company carries. For example, Colgate has 3 product lines (toothbrush, toothpaste and mouthwash).
  • A.product mix width
  • B.product mix depth
  • C.product mix length
  • D.product consistency
Correct Answer: product mix width

The term "product mix width" refers to the number of different product lines a company offers. In the example given, Colgate has three product lines: toothbrush, toothpaste, and mouthwash. Each of these represents a different category within Colgate's product mix.

 

The other options represent different dimensions of a product mix:

 

Product Mix Depth (option B): This refers to the number of variants or different products within a specific product line. For example, within the toothpaste product line, Colgate may have multiple variants such as different flavors or formulations.

 

Product Mix Length (option C): This refers to the total number of products a company offers across all its product lines.

 

Product Consistency (option D): This refers to how closely related the various product lines are in terms of their use, production, or distribution.

Question 82
Contingent contract to do or not to do anything on the happening of an uncertain future event:
  • A.is never enforceable
  • B.is enforceable since the time of making it
  • C.becomes enforceable in the immediate possibility of happening of that event
  • D.becomes enforceable only on the happening of that event
Correct Answer: becomes enforceable only on the happening of that event

Contingent contract to do or not to do anything on the happening of an uncertain future event becomes enforceable only on the happening of that event. The provisions related to Contingent Contracts are as follows:

 

Contingent Contracts

A contingent contract is a contract to do or not to do something, if some event collateral to such contract, does or does not happen. For example, X contracts to sell Y 20 bales of cotton for Rs. 20,000, if the ship by which they are coming returns safely. This is a contingent contract. Contract of insurance and contracts of indemnity and guarantee are popular instances of contingent contracts.

 

Rules governing enforcement of Contingent contracts

(a) Contracts contingent upon the happening of a future uncertain event cannot be enforced by law unless and until that event has happened. If the event becomes impossible, the contract becomes void. For example, (i) A makes a contract to buy B’s house if A survives C. This contract cannot be enforced by law unless and until C dies in A’s lifetime. (ii) A contracts to pay B a sum of money when B marries C, C dies without being married to B. The contract becomes void.

(b) Contracts contingent upon the non-happening of an uncertain future event can be enforced when the happening of that event becomes impossible and not before. For example, A contracts to pay B a certain sum of money if a certain ship does not return. The ship is sunk. The contract can be enforced when the ship sinks.

(c) If a contract is contingent upon how a person will act at an unspecified time, the event shall be considered to become impossible when such person does anything which renders it impossible that he should so act within any definite time or otherwise than under further contingencies. For example, A agrees to pay B Rs. 1,000 if B marries C. C marries D. The marriage of B to C must now be considered impossible although it is possible that D may die and C may afterwards marry B.

(d) Contracts contingent on the happening of an event within a fixed time become void if, at the expiration of the time, such event has not happened, or if, before the time fixed, such event becomes impossible. For example, A promises to pay B a sum of money if a certain ship returns with in a year. The contract may be enforced if the ship returns within the year, and becomes void if the ship is burnt within the year.

(e) Contracts contingent upon the non-happening of an event within a fixed time may be enforced by law when the time fixed has expired and such event has not happened or before the time fixed has expired, if it becomes certain that such event will not happen. For example, A promises to pay B a sum of money if a certain ship does not return within the year. The contract may be enforced if the ship does not return within the year or is burnt within the year.

(f) Contingent agreements to do or not to do anything if an impossible event happens, are void, whether the impossibility of the event is known or not known to the parties to the agreement at the time when it is made. For example, A agrees to pay Rs. 1,000 to B if two straight lines should enclose a space. The agreement is void.

Question 83
Under Sale of Goods Act, 1930, when unpaid seller has parted with goods to a carrier & buyer has become insolvent, he can exercise right of _________ in transit.
  • A.Lien
  • B.Resale
  • C.Stoppage goods
  • D.Cannot exercise any right
Correct Answer: Stoppage goods

When unpaid seller has parted with goods to a carrier & buyer has become insolvent, he can exercise right of stoppage goods in transit.

Question 84
Under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, which of the following alterations will be considered as Material Alteration?(i) Alteration of the date(ii) in the time of payment(iii) of the place of payment(iv) by addition of a new party(v) correction of a mistake(vi)additionof the words “on demand” in an instrument where no time of payment is stated.
  • A.(i), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • B.(i), (ii), (v), (vii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv), (vi)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, the following alterations will be rendered as Material Alteration:

(i) Alteration of the date

(ii) in the time of payment

(iii) of the place of payment

(iv) by addition of a new party

 

Material Alteration

An alteration is material which in any way alters the operation of the instrument and the liabilities of the parties thereto. Therefore, any change in an instrument which causes it to speak a different language in legal effect from that which it originally spoke, or which changes legal character of the instrument is a material alteration.

 

A material alteration renders the instrument void, but it affects only those persons who have already become parties at the date of the alteration. Those who take the altered instrument cannot complain. Section 88 provides that an acceptor or endorser of a negotiable instrument is bound by his acceptance or endorsement notwithstanding any previous alteration of the instrument.

 

Examples of material alteration are:-

Alteration (i) of the date of the instrument (ii) of the sum payable, (iii) in the time of payment, (iv) of the place of payment, (v) of the rate of interest, (vi) by addition of a new party, (vii) tearing the instrument in a material part.

 

There is no material alteration and the instrument is not vitiated in the following cases:

(i) correction of a mistake, (ii) to carry out the common intention of the parties, (iii) an alteration made before the instrument is issued and made with the consent of the parties, (iv) crossing a cheque, (v) addition of the words “on demand” in an instrument where no time of payment is stated.

Question 85
Match the following Doctrines with their Objectives:List 1 – Doctrines(a) Doctrine of Constructive Notice(b) Doctrine of Ultra Vires(c) Doctrine of Indoor Management(d) Doctrine of piercing the Corporate VeilList 2 – Objective(i) The Act which is beyond the powers of the Company as stated in its Memorandum of Association, are null and voidab initio.(ii) Where a fraudulent and dishonest use is made of the legal entity, the individuals concerned will not be allowed to take shelter behind the corporate personality.(iii) Persons dealing with the company need not inquire whether internal proceedings relating to the contract are followed correctly, once they are satisfied that the transaction is in accordance with the memorandum and articles of association.(iv) It is the duty of every person dealing with a company to inspect its public documents and make sure that his contract is in conformity with their provisions.
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(ii)

The correct matching of Doctrines with their Objectives is option (B) – (iv) (i) (iii) (ii).

 

(a) Doctrine of Constructive Notice - (iv) It is the duty of every person dealing with a company to inspect its public documents and make sure that his contract is in conformity with their provisions.

 

(b) Doctrine of Ultra Vires - (i) The Act which is beyond the powers of the Company as stated in its Memorandum of Association are null and void ab initio.

 

(c) Doctrine of Indoor Management - (iii) Persons dealing with the company need not inquire whether internal proceedings relating to the contract are followed correctly, once they are satisfied that the transaction is in accordance with the memorandum and articles of association.

 

(d) Doctrine of piercing the Corporate Veil - (ii) Where a fraudulent and dishonest use is made of the legal entity, the individuals concerned will not be allowed to take shelter behind the corporate personality.

Question 86
Which statement is incorrect with respect to e-form ACTIVE under Companies Act, 2013?
  • A.Every company incorporated on or before the 31st December, 2016 shall file the particulars of the company and its registered office, in e-Form ACTIVE.
  • B.In case a company does not intimate said particulars with in prescribed due date, the Company shall be marked as “ACTIVE-non-compliant” and shall be liable for action.
  • C.The Registrar shall not update its records for any further event based change with respect to a Company which is marked as “ACTIVE-non-compliant”.
  • D.Where a company files “e-Form ACTIVE”, on or after the due date, the company shall be marked as “ACTIVE Compliant”, on payment of fee ofRs. 10,000.
Correct Answer: Every company incorporated on or before the 31st December, 2016 shall file the particulars of the company and its registered office, in e-Form ACTIVE.

Statement A is incorrect, as every company incorporated on or before the 31st December, 2017 shall file the particulars of the company and its registered office, in e-Form ACTIVE.

 

Active Company Tagging Identities and Verification (ACTIVE)

(Inserted by the Companies (Incorporation) Amendment Rules, 2019 dated 21.02.2019)

Every company incorporated on or before the 31st December, 2017 shall file the particulars of the company and its registered office, in e-Form ACTIVE (Active Company Tagging Identities and Verification) on or before 25.04.2019.

 

In case a company does not intimate said particulars, the Company shall be marked as “ACTIVE-non-compliant” on or after 26th April, 2019 and shall be liable for action.

 

The Registrar shall not update its records for any further event based change with respect to a Company which is marked as “ACTIVE-non-compliant”.

 

Where a company files “e-Form ACTIVE”, on or after 26th April, 2019, the company shall be marked as “ACTIVE Compliant”, on payment of fee of Rs. 10,000.

Question 87
Match the following penalties and fines with the offences under the Competition Act, 2002.List I – Offences(a) Failure to comply with directions of Commission and Director General(b) Non-furnishing of information on combination within 30 days(c) Making false statement or omission to furnish material informationList II – Penalties and Fines(i) Penalty which shall not be less than ₹ 50 lakhs but which may extend to ₹ 1 crores, as may be determined by the Commission.(ii) Fine which may extend to ₹ 1 lakh for each day during which such failure continues subject to a maximum of ₹ 1 crores.(iii) Penalty which may extend to 1% of the total turnover or the assets, whichever is higher, of such a combination.
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i)

The correct match as per Competition Act 2002 is given below.

 

(a) For failure to comply with directions of Commission and Director General – (ii) fine which may extend to ₹ 1 lakh for each day during which such failure continues subject to a maximum of ₹ 1 crores.

(b) For non-furnishing of information on combination within 30 days – (iii) penalty which may extend to 1% of the total turnover or the assets, whichever is higher, of such a combination.

(c) For making false statement or omission to furnish material information – (i) penalty which shall not be less than ₹ 50 lakhs but which may extend to ₹ 1 crores, as may be determined by the Commission.

Question 88
Match the following offences with their respective penalties and fines under the Information Technology Act, 2000.List I(i)Tampering with computer source documents(ii)Punishment for identity theft(iii)Punishment for cyber terrorism(iv)Punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic formList II(a)Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with fine up toRs5 lakh rupees, or both.(b)Imprisonment for life.(c)Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with fine up toRs1 lakh rupees.(d)Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with fine up toRs2 lakh rupees, or both.
  • A.i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(b), iv-(a)
  • B.i-(c), ii-(d), iii-(a), iv-(b)
  • C.i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(a), iv-(b)
  • D.i-(a), ii-(b), iii-(c), iv-(d)
Correct Answer: i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(b), iv-(a)

The correct matching of offences with their respective penalties and fines under the Information Technology Act, 2000 is option (d) (c) (b) (a).

 

(i) Tampering with computer source documents - (d) Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with a fine up to Rs 2 lakh rupees, or both.

 

(ii) Punishment for identity theft - (c) Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with a fine up to Rs 1 lakh rupees.

 

(iii) Punishment for cyber terrorism - (b) Imprisonment for life.

 

(iv) Punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form - (a) Imprisonment up to 3 years, or with a fine up to Rs 5 lakh rupees, or both.

Question 89
In which of the following situations under the Right to Information Act, 2005, it is NOT obligatory on an officer to provide information to citizen seeking information?
  • A.information available to a person in his fiduciary relationship
  • B.information which would impede the process of investigation or apprehension or prosecution of offenders
  • C.disclosure of information which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual
  • D.All of the Above.
Correct Answer: All of the Above.

Option D is the correct answer.

Question 90
Match the following:List I – Patent Applications(i)Convention Application(ii)Application for Patent of Addition(iii)Divisional Application(iv)PCT International ApplicationList II - Purpose(a) it paves the way for a streamlined patent application process in many countries at one go(b) filed if a particular application claims for more than one invention(c) filed or granted only after the grant of the parent patent(d) entitles the applicant to claim priority in all the convention countries
  • A.i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(b), iv-(a)
  • B.i-(a), ii-(b), iii-(c), iv-(d)
  • C.i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(a), iv-(b)
  • D.i-(c), ii-(d), iii-(b), iv-(a)
Correct Answer: i-(d), ii-(c), iii-(b), iv-(a)

(i) Convention Application - entitles the applicant to claim priority in all the convention countries

(ii) Application for Patent of Addition - filed or granted only after the grant of the parent patent

(iii) Divisional Application - filed if a particular application claims for more than one invention

(iv) PCT International Application - it paves the way for a streamlined patent application process in many countries at one go

 

Following are types of Patent Applications:

1. Ordinary Application: An ordinary application for a patent can filed in the patent office, without claiming any priority made in the convention country or without any other reference to an application. An ordinary application can be approached by two ways or only one way i.e. by filling provisional application or complete specification.

2. Convention Application: If the request for a patent is claiming the priority date of the same or a large extent similar patent application filed in one or more of the Convention countries, then it is called Convention application. To claim convention status, an applicant has to file the application within twelve months from the basic application in Indian Patent Office (IPO).

3. PCT International Application: PCT stands for Patent Cooperation Treaty which is an international patent law treaty that provides a unified patent application filing platform that protects the invention in all contracting states. Under PCT filing an applicant can file a single international application for a patent in a receiving office to seek protection at the same time in all the contracting member countries.

4. PCT National Phase Application: PCT National Phase Application must follow International Application. A PCT National Phase Application has to file in each designating country where applicant sought for protection within 31 months.

5. Application for Patent of Addition: An applicant can file a patent of addition for the improvement or modification of the invention for which he has already applied or has a granted patent. No need to pay the extra renewal fee for the patent of addition. It expires along with the main patent. Also, it will not be granted before the grant of a patent for the main invention.

6. Divisional Application: When an application is made for more than one invention, then an applicant can divide the application at any time before the grant of a patent and can file a further application(s) for the invention(s) already applied.

 

In order to obtain a patent, an applicant must fully and particularly describe the invention therein claimed in a complete specification. The disclosure of the invention in a complete specification must be such that a person skilled in the art may be able to perform the invention. This is possible only when an applicant discloses the invention fully and particularly including the best method of performing the invention.

Question 91
Which of the following statement is not correct with respect to GST?
  • A.Late filing of GST return will have a cascading effect leading to heavy fines and penalty.
  • B.To avoid the long process of appeal and litigation, a taxpayer may request for the advance ruling under GST.
  • C.The Joint Commissioner does not have the power to inspect places of business of the suspected evader.
  • D.Demand and recovery provisions are applicable when a registered dealer has paid tax incorrectly or not paid tax at all.
Correct Answer: The Joint Commissioner does not have the power to inspect places of business of the suspected evader.

Inspection under GST

The Joint Commissioner of SGST/CGST (or a higher officer) may have reasons to believe that in order to evade tax, a person has suppressed any transaction or claimed excess input tax credit etc. Then the Joint Commissioner can authorize any other officer of CGST/SGST (in writing) to inspect places of business of the suspected evader.

Question 92
Mrs. Kapoor is a housewife. During the year 2012-13, she receivedRs. 1,84,000from her husband for household expenses. Out ofRs. 1,84,000she utilisedRs. 1,50,000 for household expenses and savedRs. 34,000. In this case, ________ will be treated as taxable income of Mrs. Kapoor out ofRs. 1,84,000.
  • A.Rs. 1,84,000
  • B.Rs. 1,50,000
  • C.Rs. 34,000
  • D.Nil
Correct Answer: Nil

Pin money received by a housewife for her personal expenses is not regarded as income of the housewife. Further, any savings made by housewife from money received from her husband for household expenses is also not regarded as income of the housewife. Considering above provision, nothing will be charged to tax in the hands of Mrs. Kapoor out of Rs. 1,84,000. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Question 93
In which type of Provident Fund, exemption under Section 80C is not available for employee’s own contribution?
  • A.Recognized Provident Fund
  • B.Unrecognized Provident Fund
  • C.Statutory Provident Fund
  • D.Public Provident Fund
Correct Answer: Unrecognized Provident Fund

Unrecognized Provident Fund: If a provident fund is not recognized by the Commissioner of Income Tax, it is known as unrecognized PF.

Taxability as per the Income Tax Act, 1961:

Employer’s contribution to provident fund – Exempt from tax

Deduction under Section 80C – Not Available

Interest credited to provident fund – Exempt

Payment at retirement – Employee’s own contribution is exempt but interest on his own contribution is taxable under the head “income from other sources”. Payment received towards the employer’s contribution and interest thereon is taxable under the head “Salaries”.

Question 94
In March, 2018, Mr. Kumar received advance salary ofRs. 84,000 pertaining to the month of April, 2018. In which year advance salary will be charged to tax?
  • A.2017-18
  • B.2018-19
  • C.As per the choice of theassessee
  • D.None of the above, because of the separate tax treatment
Correct Answer: 2017-18

Salary is taxed on due or receipt basis, whichever is earlier. Thus, advance salary of April, 2018 received in the year 2017-18, i.e., in March, 2018 will be taxed in the year 2017-18.

 

Advance salary received by an employee is taxed in the year of receipt. The rule behind this is the basis of taxability of salary, i.e., salary is taxed on due or receipt basis, whichever is earlier.

Question 95
What is the minimum holding period in respect of life insurance policy whose premium is claimed as deduction under section 80C?
  • A.2 years
  • B.3 years
  • C.4 years
  • D.5 years
Correct Answer: 2 years

Following is the minimum holding period in respect of certain investments, deposits, etc., prescribed under section 80C which should be kept in mind while claiming deduction under section 80C:

 

Nature of Investments/Deposits

Minimum Holding Period

ULIP of UTI or LIC

5 years

Life Insurance Policy

2 years

Senior Citizens Saving Scheme and Post Office Time Deposit

5 years

 

Question 96
Which of the following statements is incorrect about Transfer Pricing?
  • A."Transfer pricing" generally refers to prices of transactions between associated enterprises which may take place under conditions differing from those taking place between independent enterprises.
  • B.The implication of Transfer Pricing Manipulation is moving of one nation’s tax revenue to another.
  • C.Transfer Price and Arm’s Length Price are always same.
  • D.The Indian Transfer Pricing regulations are broadly based on Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) TP guidelines. They were first published in 1981.
Correct Answer: Transfer Price and Arm’s Length Price are always same.

Option C is incorrect.

 

Transaction at Arm’s length price means a transaction in which the buyers and sellers of a product act independently and have no relationship to each other. The concept of an arm’s length transaction is to ensure that both parties in the deal are acting in their own self-interest and are not subject to any pressure or duress from the other party.

 

Transfer price is the price charged in a transaction. The term ‘transfer price’ is used to describe the actual price charged between the associated enterprises in an international transaction. Transfer pricing issues arise when entities of multinational corporations resident in different jurisdictions transfer property or provide services to one another. These entities do not deal at arm’s length and, thus, transactions between these entities may not be subject to ordinary market forces. Where the transfer price is different from the price which would have been charged if the enterprises were not associated and the difference gives rise the tax advantage, the tax is calculated on the basis of arm’s length price.

Question 97
Under the Income Tax Act, 1961, the basic exemption limit (for the Assessment Year 2024-25) in case of a resident individual of the age of below 60 years isRs. ___________.
  • A.Rs. 2,00,000
  • B.Rs. 2,50,000
  • C.Rs. 3,00,000
  • D.Rs. 5,00,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 2,50,000

The basic exemption limit (for the assessment year 2024-25) in case of a resident individual of the age of below 60 years is Rs. 2,50,000.

Question 98
With respect to amortization of preliminary expenses, under Section 35D of the Income Tax Act, the limit prescribed on the aggregate amount of qualifying amount cannot exceed, in case of a corporateassesseeis:
  • A.5% of cost of project; or 5% of capital employed, whichever is more
  • B.5% of cost of project
  • C.10% of cost of project; or 10% of capital employed, whichever is more
  • D.10% of cost of project
Correct Answer: 5% of cost of project; or 5% of capital employed, whichever is more

Amortisation of preliminary expenses: Certain preliminary expenses are deductible under section 35D. Deduction under section 35D is available in case of an Indian company or a resident non-corporate assessee. A foreign company even if it is resident in India, cannot claim any deduction under section 35D. The heads of qualifying expenditure are the following:

(i) Expenditure in connection with preparation of feasibility report, preparation of project report, conducting a market survey (or any other survey necessary for the business of the assessee), etc.

(ii) Legal charges for drafting any agreement.

(iii) Legal charges for drafting the memorandum and articles of association.

(iv) Printing expenses of the memorandum and articles of association.

(v) Registration fees of a company under the provisions of the Companies Act.

(vi) Expenses in connection with the public issue of shares or debentures of a company, underwriting commission, brokerage and charges for drafting, typing, printing and advertisement of the prospectus.

(vii) Any other expenditure, which is prescribed.

 

The aggregate expenditure cannot exceed the following:

 

In the case of a corporate assessee:

(a) 5 % of cost of project; or

(b) 5 % of capital employed, whichever is more

 

In the case of a non-corporate assessee – 5 % of cost of project.

 

1/5th of the qualifying expenditure is allowable as deduction in each of the 5 successive years beginning with the year in which the business commences, or as the case may be, the previous year in which extension of the industrial undertaking is completed or the new industrial unit commences production or operation.

Question 99
Mr. Kapoor (Age 54 Years) has made a fixed deposit with ABC Bank. The annual interest on deposit will amount toRs. 55,000. Whether TDS should be deducted and if yes, what should be the total amount of Interest on which TDS should be deducted?
  • A.Yes, onRs. 15,000
  • B.Yes, onRs. 40,000
  • C.Yes, onRs. 55,000
  • D.No tax should be deducted on interest income on FD.
Correct Answer: Yes, onRs. 55,000

As per section 194A, no tax is to be deducted if the aggregate amount of interest during the financial year does not exceed Rs. 5,000. However, the limit of Rs. 5,000 is increased to Rs. 40,000 in case of interest paid/payable by banking company on time deposit or a co-operative society carrying on banking business on time deposit and in case of interest paid/payable by post office on deposit made under Senior Citizens Saving Scheme Rules, 2004. Once the interest exceeds the above limit, tax is to be deducted on the entire amount of interest. The annual interest in this case exceeds Rs. 40,000 and hence, bank has to deduct tax on the total interest of Rs. 55,000.

Question 100
Taxpayers opting for presumptive taxation scheme of Section 44AD are required to pay up to of advance tax by 15thJune?
  • A.15%
  • B.45%
  • C.75%
  • D.Nil
Correct Answer: Nil

Option D is the correct answer.

Quiz Attempt #119006

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
B.Nanusproposed a 4 step model that uses scenario writing for environmental scanning. The steps of model are:(i) Strategy planners first observe the events and trends of the organization.(ii) Then, from that observation they broadly consider important issues, which may affect the organization, using environment appraisal.(iii) Summarizing these issues, their effects and different scenarios to show the implementation of these strategies, creates a report.(iv) In the last step, the planners who decide the feasibility of the suggested strategy that is beneficial for the organization review reports and scenarios.The name of model is:
  • A.PESTLE Analysis
  • B.SWOT Analysis
  • C.QUEST Analysis
  • D.ETOP Analysis
Correct Answer: QUEST Analysis

The model described in the question aligns with the QUEST Analysis proposed by B. Nanus. The acronym QUEST stands for:

 

Q: Questioning ongoing expectations

U: Understanding the present

E: Exploring the future

S: Searching for solutions

T: Transforming the vision into reality

 

The 4 steps mentioned in the question correspond to the steps in the QUEST Analysis model:

 

(i) Observing events and trends: This aligns with the "Understanding the present" phase of QUEST.

 

(ii) Considering important issues through environment appraisal: This corresponds to the "Questioning ongoing expectations" phase.

 

(iii) Summarizing issues and creating scenarios: This step aligns with the "Exploring the future" phase.

 

(iv) Reviewing reports and deciding feasibility: This corresponds to the "Searching for solutions" and "Transforming the vision into reality" phases.

Question 2
Reserve Money (M0) (also known as High-Powered Money/Monetary Base/ Base Moneyetc) can be expressed as:
  • A.Currency with public + Demand deposits with the Banking system (current account, saving account) + Other deposits with RBI
  • B.M3 + All deposits with post office savings banks
  • C.Currency in Circulation + Bankers’ Deposits with RBI + Other deposits with RBI
  • D.M1 + Savings deposits of post office savings banks
Correct Answer: Currency in Circulation + Bankers’ Deposits with RBI + Other deposits with RBI

Money Supply

The measures of money supply in India are classified into four categories M1, M2, M3 and M4 along with M0.  

 

Reserve Money (M0)

It is also known as High-Powered Money, Monetary Base, Base Money etc.

 

M0 = Currency in Circulation + Bankers’ Deposits with RBI + Other deposits with RBI
It is the monetary base of economy.

 

Narrow Money (M1 and M2)

M1 = Currency with public + Demand deposits with the Banking system (current account, saving account) + Other deposits with RBI

 

M2 = M1 + Savings deposits of post office savings banks

 

Broad Money (M3 and M4)

M3 = M1 + Time deposits with the banking system

M4 = M3 + All deposits with post office savings banks

Question 3
Which of the following is not one of factors of the political environment?
  • A.Constitution of the country
  • B.Level of political morality
  • C.Monetary policies of RBI
  • D.Prevailing Political System
Correct Answer: Monetary policies of RBI

The correct answer is option (C) - Monetary policies of RBI.

 

The political environment refers to the factors and conditions related to government institutions, political stability, and the overall political system of a country.

 

(A) Constitution of the country: The constitution is a fundamental factor in the political environment, as it defines the framework for governance and establishes the principles and rights of the citizens.

 

(B) Level of political morality: The level of political morality is an important aspect of the political environment. It reflects the ethical standards and values within the political system, influencing decision-making and governance.

 

(C) Monetary policies of RBI: Monetary policies are part of the economic environment rather than the political environment. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is a financial institution that formulates and implements monetary policies to regulate the money supply and achieve economic goals. While there may be some interaction between monetary and political factors, monetary policies primarily fall under the economic domain.

 

(D) Prevailing Political System: The prevailing political system, such as democracy, socialism, or authoritarianism, significantly influences the political environment. It shapes the distribution of power, decision-making processes, and governance structures within a country.

Question 4
Which among these is NOT one of the Industrial Policy Resolutions released by the government?
  • A.Industrial Policy 1948
  • B.Industrial Policy 1950
  • C.Industrial Policy 1956
  • D.Industrial Policy 1991
Correct Answer: Industrial Policy 1950

The correct answer is option (B) - Industrial Policy 1950.

 

The Industrial Policy Resolutions released by the government of India are significant documents outlining the economic policies and strategies related to industrial development. Let's examine each option:

 

(A) Industrial Policy 1948: This was the first Industrial Policy Resolution released by the government of India, which aimed to lay the foundation for industrial development in the country.

 

(B) Industrial Policy 1950: There was no specific Industrial Policy released in 1950. The policy resolutions during this time were primarily extensions or modifications of the 1948 policy. Therefore option (B) is the correct answer.

 

(C) Industrial Policy 1956: The Industrial Policy Resolution of 1956 marked a major shift in India's economic approach, emphasizing a mixed economy with a significant role for the public sector in industrial development.

 

(D) Industrial Policy 1991: The Industrial Policy of 1991 was a landmark policy that introduced economic reforms, liberalization, and globalization, moving away from the earlier era of a more controlled and regulated economy.

Question 5
Which schedule of the Companies Act 2013, mentions the list of CSR activities?
  • A.Schedule I
  • B.Schedule VIII
  • C.Schedule VII
  • D.Schedule II
Correct Answer: Schedule VII

Option C is the correct answer.

 

In India, the concept of CSR is governed by clause 135 of the Companies Act, 2013. India is the first country in the world to mandate CSR spending along with a framework to identify potential CSR activities.

 

The CSR provisions within the Act is applicable to companies with an annual turnover of 1,000 crores and more, or a net worth of Rs. 500 crores and more, or a net profit of Rs. 5 crores and more.

 

The Act requires companies to set up a CSR committee which shall recommend a Corporate Social Responsibility Policy to the Board of Directors and also monitor the same from time to time. The Act encourages companies to spend 2% of their average net profit in the previous three years on CSR activities.

 

The indicative activities, which can be undertaken by a company under CSR, have been specified under Schedule VII of the Act. The activities include:

Eradicating extreme hunger and poverty,

Promotion of education, gender equality and empowering women,

Combating Human Immunodeficiency Virus, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and other diseases,

Ensuring environmental sustainability;

Contribution to the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund or any other fund set up by the Central Government for socio-economic development and relief and funds for the welfare of the Scheduled Castes, the Scheduled Tribes, other backward classes, minorities and women etc.

Question 6
Which among the following is NOT one of the reasons, why countries trade with each other?
  • A.Increased Competition
  • B.Diversity of Choice
  • C.Corporate Social Responsibility
  • D.Increased Welfare
Correct Answer: Corporate Social Responsibility

Option C is the correct answer.

 

While individual companies may engage in Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), it is not a primary reason for countries to trade. Countries typically trade to enhance economic growth, create jobs, and improve overall welfare.

Question 7
In this approach, a company gives equal importance to every country’s domestic market. Every participating country is treated solely and individual strategies are carried out. This approach is especially suitable for countries with certain financial, political and cultural constraints. Which approach is the statement referring to?
  • A.RegiocentricOrientation
  • B.Polycentric Orientation
  • C.Ethnocentric Orientation
  • D.Geocentric Orientation
Correct Answer: Polycentric Orientation

The correct answer based on the given description is (B) Polycentric Orientation.

 

In a Polycentric Orientation, a company gives equal importance to every country's domestic market. Individual strategies are carried out for each participating country, and the emphasis is on adapting products and marketing strategies to suit the specific preferences and conditions of each local market. This approach is especially suitable for countries with certain financial, political, and cultural constraints.

 

Let's briefly review the other options for clarity:

 

(A) Regiocentric Orientation: This approach involves grouping countries into regions and developing strategies specific to each region, acknowledging similarities and differences within those regions.

 

(C) Ethnocentric Orientation: In an ethnocentric orientation, there is a tendency to view the home country's practices and products as superior, and strategies are applied universally across all markets.

 

(D) Geocentric Orientation: A geocentric orientation involves adopting a standardized approach to marketing and operations across countries, focusing on global integration.

Question 8
The _______________ theory explains that a country should produce and export that commodity which involves those factors of production that are abundantly available with the country. The model essentially says that countries will export products that use their abundant and cheap factor(s) of production and import products that use the countries’ scarce factor(s).
  • A.Heckcher-Ohlin Model
  • B.Comparative Advantage
  • C.Absolute Advantage
  • D.Mercantilism
Correct Answer: Heckcher-Ohlin Model

The correct answer is option (A) - Heckscher-Ohlin Model.

 

The Heckscher-Ohlin Model, also known as the factor proportions theory, explains that a country should produce and export goods that use factors of production that are abundantly available in the country. Conversely, it should import goods that use factors of production that are relatively scarce.

 

In the context of the question, the theory suggests that countries will export products that utilize their abundant and cheap factors of production and import products that use factors of production that are scarce in their own country. This model is based on the factors of production, such as land, labor, and capital, and how their abundance or scarcity influences a country's comparative advantage in producing certain goods.

 

Let's briefly discuss the other options for clarity:

 

(B) Comparative Advantage: The comparative advantage theory, developed by David Ricardo, states that countries should specialize in the production of goods in which they have a lower opportunity cost compared to other countries.

 

(C) Absolute Advantage: The absolute advantage theory, also proposed by David Ricardo, suggests that countries should specialize in the production of goods in which they have an absolute advantage over other countries in terms of productivity.

 

(D) Mercantilism: Mercantilism is an economic theory that emphasizes the importance of accumulating wealth, especially through a positive balance of trade, by exporting more than importing.

Question 9
A _______________ investment is when a parent company chooses to begin operations in a foreign country establishing the construction of new production facilities “from scratch”, including all the necessary offices, living quarters and distribution hubs.
  • A.Brown-field
  • B.White-field
  • C.Yellow-field
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Greenfield investment is a type of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) where a company establishes new operations in a foreign country by constructing new facilities and infrastructure from the ground up. In essence, it involves building or developing a new project on a "green field" or an undeveloped site.

Question 10
The UNCTAD members are divided into 4 lists, the division being based on United Nations Regional Groups. The India is a member of:
  • A.List A
  • B.List B
  • C.List C
  • D.List D
Correct Answer: List A

The UNCTAD members are divided into four lists, the division being based on United Nations Regional Groups. List A consists mostly of countries in the African and Asia-Pacific Groups of the UN. List B consists of countries of the Western European and Others Group. List C consists of countries of the Group of Latin American and Caribbean States (GRULAC). List D consists of countries of the Eastern European Group. India is member of List A.

 

The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was established in 1964 as a permanent intergovernmental body. Its headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland.

 

UNCTAD is the part of the United Nations Secretariat dealing with trade, investment, and development issues. The organization's goals are to: "maximize the trade, investment and development opportunities of developing countries and assist them in their efforts to integrate into the world economy on an equitable basis.

Question 11
If theassesseefails to furnish return of income within due date as prescribed under Section 139(1) then, he is liable to pay a sum by way of penalty:
  • A.Rs. 5000 if return is furnished on or before 31stDecember of Previous year andRs. 10,000 in any other case.
  • B.Rs. 10,000 if return is furnished on or before 31stDecember of Previous year andRs. 5,000 in any other case.
  • C.Rs. 5000 if return is furnished on or after 31stDecember of Previous year andRs. 10,000 in any other case.
  • D.Rs. 5000 if return is furnished on or before 31stDecember of Assessment year andRs. 10,000 in any other case.
Correct Answer: Rs. 5000 if return is furnished on or before 31stDecember of Assessment year andRs. 10,000 in any other case.

With effect from assessment year 2018-19, if assessee failed to furnish return of income within due date as prescribed under section 139(1) then as per section 234F, he will be required to pay fee of:

a) Rs. 5000 if return is furnished on or before 31 December of assessment year.

b) Rs. 10,000 in any other case.

 

However, if total income of the person does not exceeds Rs. 5 lakh then fee payable shall be Rs. 1000.

Question 12
The _________ isthe temporary sale of a commodity at below cost or at a lower price abroad in order to drive foreign producers out of business, after which prices are raised to take advantage of the newly acquired monopoly power abroad.
  • A.Persistent dumping
  • B.Predatory dumping
  • C.Sporadic dumping
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Predatory dumping

The correct answer is option (B) - Predatory dumping.

 

Predatory dumping refers to the practice of temporarily selling a commodity at a price below its cost or at a lower price in the international market. The intention behind predatory dumping is to drive foreign competitors out of business. Once competitors are forced out and a degree of monopoly power is achieved, the company engaging in predatory dumping may then raise prices to take advantage of the reduced competition.

 

Persistent dumping: This term is not a commonly used economic concept. The term "persistent" does not specifically describe a type of dumping strategy.

 

Sporadic dumping: Sporadic dumping refers to occasional instances of selling goods at lower prices in the international market, but it doesn't necessarily imply the same strategic intent as predatory dumping.

Question 13
ASEAN + 3 includes following countries EXCEPT?
  • A.India
  • B.Japan
  • C.China
  • D.Cambodia
Correct Answer: India

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a political and economic organisation of 10 countries located in Southeast Asia, which was formed on 8 August 1967 by Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Since then, membership has expanded to include Brunei, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar (Burma) and Vietnam. Its aims include accelerating economic growth, social progress, socio-cultural evolution among its members, protection of regional peace and stability, and opportunities for member countries to discuss differences peacefully.

 

ASEAN + 3 was the first of attempts for further integration to improve existing ties with China, Japan, and South Korea. This was followed by the even larger East Asia Summit (EAS), which included ASEAN + 3 as well as India, Australia, and New Zealand. The group became ASEAN + 6 with Australia, New Zealand and India.

Question 14
Which of the following is NOT a Qualitative Characteristics of Accounting Information?
  • A.Reliability
  • B.Relevance
  • C.Accuracy
  • D.Comparability
Correct Answer: Accuracy

The correct answer is option (C) - Accuracy.

 

Qualitative characteristics of accounting information are attributes that make financial information useful for decision-making purposes. Let's discuss each of the options:

 

(A) Reliability: This refers to the dependability and trustworthiness of the financial information. Reliable information is free from bias and can be used with confidence.

 

(B) Relevance: Relevant information is capable of making a difference in the decision-making process. It is timely and has the potential to influence the decisions of users.

 

(C) Accuracy: While accuracy is generally desirable, it is not considered one of the primary qualitative characteristics of accounting information. Accuracy is more of a sub-characteristic that contributes to reliability. Reliable information must be accurate, but accuracy alone does not capture the full scope of usefulness in decision-making.

 

(D) Comparability: Comparability enables users to identify and understand similarities and differences in financial information over different periods or among different entities. It allows for meaningful analysis and interpretation.

Question 15
Consider the following.Statement I:Accounting is mainly related to identifying, measuring and recording financial transactions.Statement II:Bookkeeping is the process of summarizing, interpreting and communicating financial transactions which were classified in the ledger account.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • D.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.

Both Statements are incorrect.

 

Bookkeeping is mainly related to identifying, measuring and recording financial transactions.

 

Accounting is the process of summarizing, interpreting and communicating financial transactions which were classified in the ledger account.

Question 16
What best represents the Retention Ratio?
  • A.1 ÷PayoutRatio
  • B.1 +PayoutRatio
  • C.1 –PayoutRatio
  • D.1 ×PayoutRatio
Correct Answer: 1 –PayoutRatio

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Retention ratio (also known as plough back ratio) is the percentage of a company's earnings retained and reinvested by the company. Retention ratio is the opposite of payout ratio.

 

Retention Ratio = 1 – Payout Ratio

Question 17
Which of the following is not a ‘Model of Dissolution without the intervention of the court’?
  • A.Dissolution by Notice
  • B.Dissolution by Agreement
  • C.Permanent Incapacity
  • D.Compulsory Dissolution
Correct Answer: Permanent Incapacity

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Dissolution of Partnership Firm

We have learnt about the reconstitution of a partnership firm which takes place on account of admission, retirement or death of a partner. In such a situation while the existing partnership is dissolved, the firm may continue under the same name if the partners so decide. In other words, it results in the dissolution of a partnership but not that of the firm.

 

According to Section 39 of the partnership Act 1932, the dissolution of partnership between all the partners of a firm is called the dissolution of the firm. That means the Act recognizes the difference in the breaking of relationship between all the partners of a firm and between some of the partners; and it is the breaking or discontinuance of relationship between all the partners which is termed as the dissolution of partnership firm. This brings an end to the existence of firm, and no business is transacted after dissolution except the activities related to closing of the firm as the affairs of the firm are to be wound up by selling firm’s assets and paying its liabilities and discharging the claims of the partners.

 

Model of dissolution of firm-

 

Dissolution without the intervention of the court

Dissolution by agreement

Compulsory dissolution

Dissolution on the happening of certain contingencies

Dissolution by notice

 

Dissolution by the court

Insanity

Permanent incapacity

Misconduct

Breach of agreement

Transfer of interest

Loss in business

Just and equitable

Question 18
Arrange the ‘Steps for Merger Transaction’ in the correct order:(a) Screening Merger Proposal(b) Negotiation(c) Approval by Stakeholders(d) Tribunal’s Approval(e) Approval of Central Govt.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (d), (c), (e)
  • B.(c), (b), (a), (d), (e)
  • C.(b), (a), (c), (e), (d)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d), (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c), (d), (e)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The correct order for the ‘Steps for Merger Transaction’ is Option (D) – (a), (b), (c), (d), (e).

 

(a) Screening Merger Proposal: This is the initial step where companies evaluate the feasibility and desirability of a merger.

 

(b) Negotiation: Once the decision to pursue a merger is made, negotiations between the involved parties take place to determine the terms and conditions of the merger.

 

(c) Approval by Stakeholders: After negotiations, the proposed merger must be approved by the stakeholders of the companies involved. This includes obtaining approval from shareholders, creditors, and other relevant parties.

 

(d) Tribunal’s Approval: In some jurisdictions, mergers may require approval from regulatory authorities or tribunals to ensure compliance with antitrust laws and regulations.

 

(e) Approval of Central Govt.: Depending on the nature and scale of the merger, approval from the Central Government may be necessary, especially in sectors that are subject to specific regulations.

Question 19
Which of the following is NOT a classification of Budget?
  • A.Effort
  • B.Time
  • C.Function
  • D.Flexibility
Correct Answer: Effort

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Budgets can be classified into different categories on the basis of Time, Function, or Flexibility. The different budgets covered under each category are shown in the following chart:

 

Question 20
Under _________, financial statements are adjusted according to price indexes, rather than relying solely on a cost accounting basis.
  • A.Human Resource Accounting
  • B.Social Accounting
  • C.Inflation Accounting
  • D.Environmental Accounting
Correct Answer: Inflation Accounting

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Inflation Accounting adjusts financial statements during periods of high inflation by using price indexes instead of relying solely on a cost accounting basis.

 

Human Resource Accounting (HRA) measures the cost and value of people (employees and managers) in an organization. It calculates recruitment, hiring, training, and development costs and determines the present economic value of employees and managers. The organization creates an HRA Report, shared with top-level management, employees, managers, and external investors.

 

Environmental Accounting incorporates environmental management principles into reporting and cost/benefit analyses. It helps businesses understand the impact of sustainable practices on their supply chain and expansion, allowing accountants to report the economic impact to stakeholders for informed decision-making.

 

Social Accounting measures and reports information about an entity's impact on society. It recognizes that evaluating business units should consider social costs and benefits, not just commercial aspects, to justify fund allocation to a business unit.

Question 21
Consider the following.Statement I:Vouching means auditors inspect that the transaction is supported by a documentary evidence or not.Statement II:Precise note of all facts discovered by auditor in the course of audit is called Audit Notes.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • D.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

The correct answer is option (A) - Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I: "Vouching means auditors inspect that the transaction is supported by documentary evidence or not." This statement is correct. Vouching is a verification technique used by auditors to check the authenticity of transactions by examining supporting documents like invoices, receipts, contracts, etc.

 

Statement II: "Precise note of all facts discovered by the auditor in the course of audit is called Audit Notes." This statement is also correct. Audit notes are records that auditors maintain to document the facts, findings, and observations made during the audit process. These notes help in providing evidence and support for the auditor's conclusions and opinions.

Question 22
Which of the following statement is not correct about long-run cost curve (LAC)?
  • A.LAC is derived by combining the short run average cost curves.
  • B.LAC is also known as planning or envelope curve.
  • C.LAC is U-shaped.
  • D.LMC intersects LAC curve where LAC curve is increasing.
Correct Answer: LMC intersects LAC curve where LAC curve is increasing.

Long-run average cost curve (LAC) is derived by combining the short-run average cost curves (SACs). The LAC curve is also known as the Envelope Curve or Planning Curve as it serves as a guide to the entrepreneur in his plans to expand production. LAC is U-shaped curve. LMC intersects LAC when the LAC is at its minimum.

Question 23
The __________ refers to the demand for goods meant for final consumption.
  • A.Induced Demand
  • B.Direct Demand
  • C.Derived Demand
  • D.Autonomous Demand
Correct Answer: Direct Demand

Direct demand refers to the demand for goods meant for final consumption. It is the demand for consumer goods such as sugar, milk, tea, food items etc. On the contrary to it, derived demand refers to the demand for those goods which are needed for further production of a particular good.
