For instance, the demand for cotton for producing cotton textiles is a case of derived demand. Indeed, derived demand is the demand for producer’s goods.

 

Autonomous and induced demand: Goods whose demand is not tied with the demand of some other good is autonomous demand. For ex- demand for food, shelter, cloth. Whereas, goods whose demand depends on the demand of some other good is derived demand. For ex- demand for steel leads to demand for steel worker.

Question 24
Consider the following.Statement I:Economies of scope refers to reduced costs per unit that arise from increased total output of a product.Statement II:Economies of Scale are economic factors that make the simultaneous manufacturing of different products more cost-effective than manufacturing them on their own.
  • A.Statement I and II both are Correct
  • B.Statement I and II both are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and II is incorrect
  • D.Statement II is correct and I is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I and II both are incorrect

Economies of scale: refers to reduced costs per unit that arise from increased total output of a product. For example, a larger factory will produce power hand tools at a lower unit price, and a larger medical system will reduce cost per medical procedure. (Internal Economies of Scale- are the one which is unique to firm, ex- patent over machine. whereas external economies of scale are the one faced by entire industry)

 

Economies of Scope are economic factors that make the simultaneous manufacturing of different products more cost-effective than manufacturing them on their own.

Question 25
Which of the following are the assumptions of Law of Demand?(i) The money income of consumer should remain the same.(ii) There should be no change in the scale of preference (taste, habit & fashion) of the consumer.(iii) There should be no change in the price of substitute goods.(iv) There should be no expectation of price changes of the commodity in near future.(v) The commodity under question should not be prestigious or of snob appeal.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii)
  • B.(iii) and (v) only
  • C.All of the Above
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

Assumptions of the law of demand are given below:

The money income of consumer should remain the same.

There should be no change in the scale of preference (taste, habit & fashion) of the consumer.

There should be no change in the price of substitute goods.

There should be no expectation of price changes of the commodity in near future.

The commodity under question should not be prestigious or of snob appeal.

Question 26
When Elasticity Co-efficient is equal to zero, then increase in price will________ the total revenue and a decrease in price will _________ the total revenue.
  • A.increase, increase
  • B.Not change, not change
  • C.increase, decrease
  • D.decrease, increase
Correct Answer: increase, decrease

A firm aiming at enhancing its total revenue would like to know whether increasing or decreasing the price would achieve its goal. The price-elasticity coefficient of demand for its product at different levels of its price provides the answer to this question. The simple answer is that if ep>1, then decreasing the price will increase the total revenue and if ep<1, then increasing the price will increase the total revenue.

 

The relationship between Price-elasticity, Price Change and Change in Total Revenue, TR is summed up in Table below.

If the demand for a product is unit elastic (ep=1) quantity demanded increases (or decreases) in the proportion of decrease (or increase) in the price. Therefore, total revenue remains unaffected.

If demand for a commodity has ep>1, change in quantity demanded is greater than the proportionate change in price. Therefore, the total revenue increases when price falls and vice versa.

Question 27
The _____________costs are those which cannot be altered- increased or decreased, by varying the rate of output.
  • A.Sunk
  • B.Historical
  • C.Incremental
  • D.Replacement
Correct Answer: Sunk

The correct answer is option (A) - Sunk costs.

 

Sunk costs are costs that have already been incurred and cannot be recovered or changed by any future decision. These costs are independent of the rate of output or production. Regardless of the level of production or the decision taken, sunk costs remain the same.

 

Let's briefly discuss the other options for clarity:

 

(B) Historical costs: Historical costs refer to the costs incurred in the past for acquiring assets or resources. While historical costs are related to the past, they may or may not be sunk costs, as some historical costs can still be relevant to future decisions.

 

(C) Incremental costs: Incremental costs are the additional costs incurred by producing one more unit of output. Unlike sunk costs, incremental costs can vary based on the level of production.

 

(D) Replacement costs: Replacement costs refer to the cost of replacing an asset at its current market value. Like historical costs, replacement costs may or may not be sunk costs, depending on the context.

Question 28
Match the Following:List I(a) First Degree Price Discrimination(b) Second Degree Price Discrimination(c) Third Degree Price DiscriminationList II(i) Under this method of pricing, firm separates the market into each individual consumer & charge price which they are able & willing to pay.(ii) Under this method of pricing, firm separates the market as per the volume (quantity) of consumer purchase.(iii) Under this method of pricing, products are priced according to the characteristics of buyer.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-(ii),b-(iii),c-(i)
  • B.a-(i),b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii),b-(ii),c-(i)
  • D.a-(i),b-(iii),c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(i),b-(ii), c-(iii)

Price discrimination is when a company sells the same product in different markets at different prices simultaneously. The variation in prices is not linked to differences in production and distribution costs.

 

First-degree price discrimination involves making each consumer pay the maximum amount they are willing to pay. Auctions are an example of this, helping sellers identify those willing to pay the highest price.

 

Second-degree price discrimination is based on the volume of consumer purchases, like quantity discounts or two-tier pricing.

 

Third-degree price discrimination involves charging different prices for the same product in different market segments, such as student concessions. This practice provides specific groups with better deals.

Question 29
Under which pricing method the seller launches the product in the market at a relatively high price and lowers the price after some period?
  • A.Price Skimming
  • B.Cost-plus Pricing
  • C.Going Rate Pricing
  • D.Rate of return
Correct Answer: Price Skimming

Price skimming is a mechanism where the seller launches the product in the market at a relatively high price and lowers the price after some period to bring it to a moderate level. It is akin to skimming the cream from milk.

 

Rate of return pricing is a pricing method where the prices are marked according to a defined rate of return. This rate of return could be on any parameter that the firm may wish to consider, such as return on investment, return on equity, return on sales, i.e. profit margin and so on. The pricing process initiates with the determination of the desired rate of return. Once that is identified, then the price is evolved such that the firm accomplishes this return.

 

Pricing strategy which is guided by the going rate of a product in the market is known as going-rate pricing. This method of pricing, as one would observe is diametrically opposite to cost-plus pricing, in terms of profitability assessment of the firm.

 

Cost-plus Pricing is the method which involves ascertaining the cost of the product. To this cost, the amount of profit that a firm desires to earn is added to yield the selling price of the product. It is also known as full-cost pricing.

Question 30
The following is the demand function in the small market:Q = 50 – 5PWhere ‘Q’ denotes quantity in physical units and ‘P’ denotes price of the commodity. At priceRs5, the point price elasticity of demand would be:
  • A.Zero
  • B.Equal to unity
  • C.Highly elastic
  • D.Highly inelastic
Correct Answer: Equal to unity

Elasticity of demand is the measure of change in quantity demanded in response to the change in the price of the commodity. Elasticity of demand is denoted by Ed. Where,

Q = 50 – 5P

= 50 – 5 × 5

= 25

Ed= dQdP × PQ

dQdP= -5

Ed = (-) (-5) ×525

Ed= 1

Question 31
Which law states that as the quantity consumed of a commodity goes on increasing, the utility derived from each successive unit goes on decreasing, consumption of all other commodities remaining the same?
  • A.Law of Returns to Scale
  • B.Law of Demand
  • C.Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility
  • D.None of The Above
Correct Answer: Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility

The correct answer is option (C) - Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility.

 

The Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility states that as the quantity consumed of a commodity goes on increasing, the additional satisfaction or utility derived from each successive unit goes on decreasing, assuming the consumption of all other commodities remains constant.

 

In other words, as a person consumes more units of a particular good or service, the additional satisfaction gained from each additional unit tends to decrease. This concept is fundamental to understanding consumer behavior and is a key element in the theory of demand in economics.

 

The other options are discussed below:

 

(A) Law of Returns to Scale: This law is related to the production process and examines how increasing all inputs in production affects the output.

 

(B) Law of Demand: The Law of Demand states that, all other factors being equal, as the price of a good or service decreases, the quantity demanded increases, and vice versa.

Question 32
In the short run, when the output of a firm increases, its average fixed cost:
  • A.Remains constant
  • B.Decreases
  • C.Increases
  • D.First decreases and then rises
Correct Answer: Decreases

Average Fixed Cost (AFC), AFC is obtained by dividing the total ­fixed cost by the number of units of output produced. i.e.,

 

AFC = TFCQ

 

Where, Q is the number of units produced.

 

Since total fi­xed cost is a constant amount, average ­fixed cost will steadily fall as output increases. Therefore, if we draw an average fi­xed cost curve, it will slope downwards throughout its length but will not touch the X-axis as AFC cannot be zero.

Question 33
Production Possibility Frontier curve is __________ to origin in shape.
  • A.Concave
  • B.Convex
  • C.Vertical
  • D.Horizontal
Correct Answer: Concave

The correct answer is option (A) – Concave.

 

The Production Possibility Frontier (PPF) curve illustrates the maximum output combinations of two goods that an economy can produce with its available resources and technology. The shape of the PPF is typically concave to the origin.

 

The reason why the PPF is concave is discussed below:

 

Law of Increasing Opportunity Cost: As an economy moves along the PPF and increases the production of one good, the opportunity cost of producing the other good tends to increase. This is due to the fact that resources are not perfectly adaptable to the production of different goods.

 

Diminishing Marginal Returns: In many cases, as more resources are allocated to one specific good, the marginal returns diminish. This means that additional units of resources contribute less to the increase in output.

 

Due to these factors, the PPF tends to slope outward and be concave to the origin, reflecting the trade-offs and opportunity costs involved in production. The concave shape signifies that the economy faces increasing opportunity costs as it moves along the PPF.

Question 34
A major difference between monopoly and monopolistic competition is:
  • A.One maximizes profits by setting MR equal to MC, and the other does not.
  • B.The number of firms in the market.
  • C.One type of firm has market power, and the other does not.
  • D.One has a downward-sloping demand curve, and the other does not.
Correct Answer: The number of firms in the market.

The correct answer is option (B) - The number of firms in the market.

 

Monopoly and monopolistic competition are two distinct market structures with significant differences:

 

(A) "One maximizes profits by setting MR equal to MC, and the other does not." This statement is not a major difference between monopoly and monopolistic competition. Both types of firms aim to maximize profits by producing at the quantity where marginal revenue (MR) equals marginal cost (MC).

 

(B) "The number of firms in the market." This is a major difference. Monopoly refers to a market structure with a single seller or producer, giving the firm substantial market power. Monopolistic competition, on the other hand, involves many sellers, and each firm has a relatively small market share.

 

(C) "One type of firm has market power, and the other does not." This is generally true. In monopoly, the single firm has significant market power due to its control over the entire market. In monopolistic competition, while firms have some degree of market power, it is limited by the presence of other competing firms.

 

(D) "One has a downward-sloping demand curve, and the other does not." This is not a major difference. Both monopoly and monopolistic competition firms typically face downward-sloping demand curves. However, the extent of the slope and the elasticity may differ.

Question 35
Which of the following is NOT the factor behind Law of Demand?
  • A.Substitution Effect
  • B.Income Effect
  • C.Utility- MaximizingBehavior
  • D.Inflation Effect
Correct Answer: Inflation Effect

The correct answer is (D) Inflation Effect.

 

The Law of Demand states that, all else being equal, as the price of a good or service decreases, the quantity demanded increases, and vice versa. The factors behind the Law of Demand include:

 

(A) Substitution Effect: When the price of a good decreases, it becomes more attractive relative to other goods, leading consumers to substitute it for more expensive alternatives.

 

(B) Income Effect: A change in the price of a good can affect a consumer's real income. When the price decreases, the consumer effectively has more purchasing power, leading to an increase in the quantity demanded.

 

(C) Utility-Maximizing Behavior: Consumers aim to maximize their satisfaction or utility given their budget constraints. As prices decrease, consumers can afford to buy more of a good, contributing to the Law of Demand.

Question 36
Arrange the following in the proper order for decision under capital budgeting.(i) Estimating the cost and benefits of proposals.(ii) Deciding the investment objective.(iii) Selecting the best investment proposal.(iv) Applying the capital budgeting decision technique.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(ii),(iv),(i),(iii)
  • B.(ii), (iv),(iii),(i)
  • C.(ii),(i),(iv),(iii)
  • D.(ii),(i),(iii),(iv)
Correct Answer: (ii),(i),(iv),(iii)

The correct answer is option (C) – (ii) (i) (iv) (iii).

 

Deciding the investment objective (ii): The capital budgeting process typically begins with clearly defining the investment objectives. This involves determining the goals and criteria that an investment must meet to be considered viable.

 

Estimating the cost and benefits of proposals (i): Once the investment objectives are established, the next step is to estimate the costs and benefits associated with different investment proposals. This involves projecting cash flows, considering the time value of money, and assessing the risks involved.

 

Applying the capital budgeting decision technique (iv): Various capital budgeting techniques, such as Net Present Value (NPV), Internal Rate of Return (IRR), and Payback Period, are applied to evaluate the investment proposals. These techniques help in assessing the financial viability of each proposal.

 

Selecting the best investment proposal (iii): Based on the results obtained from the capital budgeting decision techniques, the management can then choose the best investment proposal that aligns with the established objectives and provides the highest value or return on investment.

Question 37
Match items of List – I with the items of List – II.List – I(a) Working capital(b) Cash conversion cycle(c) Just-in-time system(d) OutsourcingList – II(i) Used to hold down inventory costs(ii) The practice of purchasing components(iii) Current assets(iv) Inventory conversion period + receivables collection period – payables deferral periodSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(iii),(i), (ii),(iv)
  • B.(iii),(iv), (i),(ii)
  • C.(iv),(i), (iii),(ii)
  • D.(iii),(i),(iv),(ii)
Correct Answer: (iii),(iv), (i),(ii)

The correct matching is option (B) - (iii) (iv) (i) (ii).

 

(a) Working capital: Working capital represents the difference between a company's current assets and current liabilities. In this context, it corresponds to current assets, so it matches with (iii).

 

(b) Cash conversion cycle: The cash conversion cycle is calculated as the inventory conversion period plus the receivables collection period minus the payables deferral period. Therefore, it matches with (iv).

 

(c) Just-in-time system: The just-in-time system is a practice of purchasing components as they are needed in the production process to minimize inventory holding costs. It matches with (i).

 

(d) Outsourcing: Outsourcing involves obtaining goods or services from an external supplier rather than producing them in-house. It matches with (ii).

Question 38
If YTM is less than Coupon rate then:
  • A.Price < Face value
  • B.Price = Face value
  • C.Price > Face value
  • D.Cannot be determined
Correct Answer: Price > Face value

Yield to Maturity (YTM): The discount rate used in the bond pricing formula is also known as the bond’s yield to maturity (YTM) or yield.  This equals the rate of return earned by a bond holder (known as the holding period return) if: the bond is held to maturity the coupon payments are reinvested at the yield to maturity.

 

A bond’s YTM is the unique discount rate at which the market price of the bond equals the present value of the bond’s cash flows:

 

Market Price = PV (Cash Flows)

 

A bond's price equals the Present value of its expected future cash flows. The rate of interest used to discount the bond's cash flows is known as the Yield to Maturity (YTM).

 

These results show the following important relationship:

If YTM > Coupon rate, Price < Face value

If YTM = Coupon rate, Price = Face value

If YTM < Coupon rate, Price > Face value

Question 39
While calculating the weighted average cost of capital, the weights can be assigned in which of the ways?
  • A.Historical or existing weights
  • B.Book Value Weights
  • C.Market Value Weights
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

The correct answer is option (D) - All the above.

 

When calculating the Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC), the weights refer to the proportionate importance of each component in the capital structure. The weights can be assigned in the following ways:

(A) Historical or existing weights: This involves using the historical values or existing values of the components in the capital structure. For example, historical debt and equity values can be used.

 

(B) Book Value Weights: Book value weights are based on the accounting values of the components in the capital structure, such as the book value of debt and the book value of equity.

 

(C) Market Value Weights: Market value weights are based on the market values of the components, such as the market value of equity and the market value of debt. Market value weights are generally considered more relevant as they reflect the current market conditions.

 

Using different weightings can lead to variations in the calculated WACC. The choice of weights depends on the specific context and the information available. In practice, market value weights are often preferred for a more accurate representation of the current financial structure and costs.

Question 40
The market value of a national currency is permitted to fluctuate within a range specified by a band of fluctuation. This band is determined by international agreements or by unilateral decision by a central bank. The bands are adjusted periodically by the country’s central bank. Which Exchange rate system is the statement referring to?
  • A.Crawling bands
  • B.Crawling Pegs
  • C.Pegged with horizontal bands
  • D.Floating Exchange Rate
Correct Answer: Crawling bands

Crawling Bands: In a crawling bands exchange rate system, the market value of a national currency is allowed to fluctuate within a specified range or band. This range is set by either international agreements or unilateral decisions by the country's central bank. The bands are periodically adjusted by the central bank to accommodate changes in economic conditions.

 

Crawling Pegs: Crawling pegs, on the other hand, involve a fixed exchange rate system where the currency's value is adjusted periodically in small increments.

 

Pegged with Horizontal Bands: This term is not commonly used in the context of exchange rate systems.

 

Floating Exchange Rate: In a floating exchange rate system, the currency's value is determined by market forces, and there are no fixed or predetermined ranges or bands.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Crawling Bands.

Question 41
The LIBOR is the average interest rate at which major global banks borrow from one another. It is based on _____ currencies.
  • A.5
  • B.6
  • C.7
  • D.8
Correct Answer: 5

The LIBOR is the average interest rate at which major global banks borrow from one another. It is based on 5 currencies including the US dollar, the euro, the British pound, the Japanese yen, and the Swiss franc, and serves seven different maturities—overnight/spot next, one week, and one, two, three, six, and 12 months. The combination of five currencies and seven maturities leads to a total of 35 different LIBOR rates calculated and reported each business day. The most commonly quoted rate is the three-month U.S. dollar rate, usually referred to as the current LIBOR rate.

Question 42
The ____________ is a curve which is more peaked than the normal curve. For such type of curve, we haveβ2> 3.
  • A.Leptokurtic Curve
  • B.MeasokurticCurve
  • C.PlatykurticCurve
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Leptokurtic Curve

Karl Pearson defined following three types of curves:

 

1. Normal Curve or Measokurtic Curve: A curve which is neither flat nor peaked is called a normal curve or meso-kurtic curve. For such type of curve we have β2 = 3

 

2. Leptokurtic Curve: A curve which is more peaked than the normal curve is called leptokurtic curve. For such type of curve, we have β2 > 3.

 

3. Platykurtic Curve: A curve which is more flatter than the normal curve is called platykurtic curve. For such type of curve, we have β2 < 3.

Question 43
If an experiment has n simple outcomes, thenthe_______________ would assign a probability of 1/n to each outcome. In other words, each outcome is assumed to have an equal probability of occurrence. This method is also called the axiomatic approach.
  • A.Subjective Approach
  • B.Relative-Frequency Approach
  • C.Classical Approach
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Classical Approach

The correct answer is (C) Classical Approach.

 

Classical Approach: In the classical approach to probability, if an experiment has "n" simple outcomes (equally likely outcomes), the probability of each outcome is calculated as 1/n. This approach assumes that all outcomes are equally likely, making it applicable when each outcome is presumed to have the same chance of occurring. It is also known as the axiomatic approach.

 

Subjective Approach: The subjective approach to probability involves assigning probabilities based on an individual's personal judgment or belief about the likelihood of events.

 

Relative-Frequency Approach: The relative-frequency approach determines probabilities based on observed frequencies in past occurrences of an event. It involves calculating the proportion of times an event occurs relative to the total number of trials.

Question 44
If probability of success for a particular Bernoulli process is 0.55, then which of the following options describe probability of exactly 5 successes in 7 trials:
  • A.7C5(0.55)5(0.45)2
  • B.7C5(0.55)3(0.45)4
  • C.1-7C5(0.55)5(0.45)2
  • D.7C30.5530.454
Correct Answer: 7C5(0.55)5(0.45)2

7C5 (0.55)5(0.45)2

Assume that X follows Bernoulli process. Then if this experiment is repeated again, then it will lead to Xi following Binomial distribution. In such a case, the probability of r successes when the trial is conducted n times will be –

PX=r= nCrpr1-pn-r

PX=5= 7C5p51-p2

Since p = 0.55, PX=5= 7C50.5551-0.552= = 7C50.5550.452

Question 45
onsiderfollowing two statements.Statement I:The Interview, Observation, Action research and Case studies are methods of Secondary data collection.Statement II:The Questionnaires and Ethnographic research are methods of Primary data collection.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
  • D.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect

Primary data is the data collected by the researcher themselves, i.e.

Interview

Observation

Action research

Case studies

Life histories

Questionnaires

Ethnographic research

Longitudinal studies

 

Secondary sources are data that already exists and is sourced from some place that has originally collected it.

Previous research

Official statistics

Mass media products

Diaries

Letters

Government reports

Web information

Historical data and information

Question 46
The Central Limit Theorem states that “in selecting random samples of size n from a population, the sampling distribution of the sample meanx-can be approximated by a ______________ as the sample size becomes large”.
  • A.normal distribution
  • B.binomial distribution
  • C.exponential distribution
  • D.Poisson distribution
Correct Answer: normal distribution

The Central Limit Theorem states that “In selecting random samples of size n from a population, the sampling distribution of the sample mean x-  can be approximated by a normal distribution as the sample size becomes large”. For most applications, the sampling distribution of x- can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever the sample is size 30 or more. In cases where the population is highly skewed or outliers are present, samples of size 50 may be needed.

Question 47
While determining the form or shape of the sampling distribution of proportions, a binomial distribution of proportions can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever the sample size is large enough to satisfy the following condition:
  • A.np ≥ 5 only
  • B.n(1-p) ≥ 5 only
  • C.Both np ≥ 5 and n(1-p) ≥ 5
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Both np ≥ 5 and n(1-p) ≥ 5

Let us determine the form or shape of the sampling distribution of p-.

 

For a simple random sample from a large population, the value of x is a binomial random variable indicating the number of elements in the sample with the characteristic of interest. Because n is a constant, the probability of x/n is the same as the binomial probability of x, which means that the sampling distribution of p- is also a discrete probability distribution and that the probability for each value of x/n is the same as the probability of x.

 

A binomial distribution can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever the sample size is large enough to satisfy the following two conditions: (i) np ≥ 5 and (ii) n(1-p) ≥ 5.

 

Hence, the sampling distribution of p- can be approximated by a normal distribution whenever np ≥ 5 and n(1-p) ≥ 5.

Question 48
A manager wants to understand whether there is significant difference in the productivity of three of group of workers. However, he has forgotten the steps of hypothesis testing and needs your help. Arrange the below options in the order in which they should be conducted.1. Set up the null and alternative hypothesis, i.e.H0:μ1=μ2=μ32. State the significance level of the test (i.e.α-alpha) and calculate critical value of the test statistic3. Set up alternative hypothesis-H1:H0isfalse4. Calculate the test statistic and reject theHoif the value of test statistic exceeds critical t-value. Else do not reject Ho.
  • A.1,2,3,4
  • B.1,3,2,4
  • C.4,2,1,3
  • D.1,3,4,2
Correct Answer: 1,3,2,4

To conduct hypothesis testing, we first set the null hypothesis which must be a specific claim. Then we must also state the alternative hypothesis. In the third step, we must also specify the level of significance. Lastly, calculate the test statistic.

 

Additional information: Since the null hypothesis tests the equality of means across multiple samples, we will the ANOVA subject to standard ANOVA assumptions. The test statistic will follow F distribution.

Question 49
Type I errors are also called:(a) Producer’s risk(b) Misdetection(c) False alarm(d) False positive(e) False negative(f) αerrorSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (c)
  • B.(a), (c), (e), (f)
  • C.(a), (b), (e), (f)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (c), (e), (f)

Type I and Type II errors

A Type I error (α) is the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis.

A Type II error (β) is the probability of failing to reject a false null hypothesis.

Or simply:

A Type I error (α) is the probability of telling you things are wrong, given that things are correct.

A Type II error (β) is the probability of telling you things are correct, given that things are wrong.

 

Power of test = 1-β

 

Type I errors are also called: 1) Producer’s risk 2) False alarm 3) False negative 4) α error

Type II errors are also called: 1) Consumer’s risk 2) Misdetection 3) False positive 4) β error

Question 50
TheKruskal-Wallis test is always expressed as:
  • A.an upper tail test
  • B.a lower tail test
  • C.parametric test
  • D.Both B and C
Correct Answer: an upper tail test

Kruskal and Wallis were able to show that, under the null hypothesis assumption of identical populations, the sampling distribution of H can be approximated by a chi-square distribution with (k-1) degrees of freedom. This approximation is generally acceptable if the sample sizes for each of the k populations are all greater than or equal to 5. The null hypothesis of identical populations will be rejected if the test statistic H is large. As a result, the Kruskal-Wallis test is always expressed as an upper tail test.

Question 51
Which of the following statistical concepts is used to measure the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables?
  • A.Karl Pearson Coefficient of correlation
  • B.R-Square of a regression model
  • C.Spearman's Rank-Order Correlation
  • D.Standard error of the ranked variables
Correct Answer: Spearman's Rank-Order Correlation

Spearman's rank-order correlation is used to measure the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables.

Question 52
When one individual or group wins at the expense of another individual or group, it is termed as
  • A.Zero-sum conflict
  • B.Non-zero sum conflict
  • C.Line-staff conflict
  • D.Formal-informal conflict
Correct Answer: Zero-sum conflict

The correct answer is (A) Zero-sum conflict.

 

Zero-sum conflict: In a zero-sum conflict, the gains or losses of one participant or group are exactly balanced by the losses or gains of other participants or groups. It implies that one side's benefit or success comes at the direct expense of the other side. The total amount of resources or value involved remains constant, and any gain for one party results in an equivalent loss for the other.

 

Non-zero sum conflict: In a non-zero sum conflict, the total amount of resources or value can be increased, and both parties can benefit or lose without a direct one-to-one correlation.

 

Line-staff conflict: Line-staff conflict typically refers to conflicts between the line departments (involved in core business activities) and staff departments (providing support services).

 

Formal-informal conflict: This term is not commonly used in the context of conflicts. Formal and informal typically refer to the structure of organizations or communication channels.

Question 53
Motivation Potential Score, MPS is given by following characteristics of given "Job":
  • A.[One third of (Variety + Identity + Significance)] + Autonomy + Feedback
  • B.[One third of (Variety + Identity + Significance)] × Autonomy × Feedback
  • C.[One third of (Variety + Identity + Significance)] + Autonomy × Feedback
  • D.[One third of (Variety + Identity + Significance)] × Autonomy + Feedback
Correct Answer: [One third of (Variety + Identity + Significance)] × Autonomy × Feedback

Job Characteristics Model, given by Hackman and Oldham's, identifies 5 job characteristics and their relationship to personal and work outcomes. The five characteristics are:

 

Skill Variety: The degree to which a job requires a variety of different activities.

 

Task Identity: The degree to which the job requires completion of a whole and identifiable piece of work.

 

Task Significance: The degree to which the job has a substantial impact on the lives or work of other people.

 

Autonomy: The degree to which the job provides substantial freedom and discretion to the individual in scheduling the work and in determining the procedures to be used in carrying it out.

 

Feedback: The degree to which carrying out the work activities required by a job results in the individual obtaining direct and clear information about the effectiveness of his or her performance.

 

Jobs with these five characteristics directly affect three psychological states of employees: Knowledge of results, Meaningfulness of work, Personal feelings of responsibility for results. Increase in these psychological states results in increased motivation, performance, and job satisfaction.

 

Motivation Potential Score (), is the summary of Hackman and Oldham's Job Characteristics Model. measures the overall motivating potential of a job, or job satisfaction. identifies the dimensions most in need of redesign. It is calculated by taking the AVERAGE of skill variety plus task identity plus task significance and then multiplying that AVERAGE by autonomy and feedback.

Question 54
The Leadership theory of Contingency with 3 factors as Leader-Member Relations, Task Structure and Leader's Position Power, was given by:
  • A.Blake and Mouton
  • B.Fred Fiedler
  • C.Blake and Mouton
  • D.Stodgilland Barnard
Correct Answer: Fred Fiedler

The correct answer is (B) Fred Fiedler.

 

Fred Fiedler proposed the Contingency Theory of Leadership, which focuses on the idea that the effectiveness of a leader is contingent upon various situational factors. One of his most well-known models, known as the "Contingency Model," considers three key situational factors:

 

(i) Leader-Member Relations: Refers to the degree of confidence, trust, and respect that exists between the leader and the group members.

 

(ii) Task Structure: Relates to the degree to which tasks are defined, structured, and clear within the group.

 

(iii) Leader’s Position Power: Refers to the amount of formal authority, influence, and control possessed by the leader.

 

Fiedler's model suggests that different leadership styles are more effective in different situations. For example, a leader with a task-oriented style might be more effective in situations with high or low favourability, while a leader with a relationship-oriented style might be more effective in situations with moderate favourability.

Question 55
Which of the following is correct?
  • A.OD Cube was given by Blake & Mouton, Consul Cube was given by Schmuck & Miles
  • B.OD Cube was given by Schmuck & Miles, Consul Cube was given by Blake & Mouton
  • C.OD Cube was given by Reddy, Consul Cube was given by French and Bell
  • D.OD Cube was given by French and Bell, Consul Cube was given by Reddy
Correct Answer: OD Cube was given by Schmuck & Miles, Consul Cube was given by Blake & Mouton

Miles and Schmuck (1971) presented a cube of characteristics for classifying OD interventions in which the 3 dimensions of the cube were – (1) the mode of intervention, (2) the focus of attention, and (3) diagnosed problems.

Question 56
The employees are considered as a means of production just like land, materials, machinery. Identify the underlying concept.
  • A.The Commodity Concept
  • B.The Factor of Production Concept
  • C.The Paternalistic Concept
  • D.The Humanitarian Concept
Correct Answer: The Factor of Production Concept

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The Factor of Production Concept: The statement suggests that employees are considered as one of the factors of production, alongside land, materials, and machinery. This aligns with the Factor of Production Concept, which views various inputs, including labor (employees), as essential factors in the production process. The factors of production are traditionally categorized into land, labor, capital, and entrepreneurship. In this case, the statement highlights the perspective that employees are treated as a factor of production, emphasizing their role in the production of goods and services.

Question 57
Consider the following statements(a) Job analysis determines worth of a job.(b) Job specification sets out the purpose, scope and duties of a job.(c) Job description is a statement of the skills and knowledge required to carry out a job.(d) Job design is the process of deciding on the content of a job in terms of its duties and responsibilities.Select the correct code:
  • A.Only a and b are true
  • B.Only c is true
  • C.Only d is true
  • D.All of the above are true
Correct Answer: Only d is true

Job specification describes the key qualifications necessary for satisfactory completion of the job. It is a written record of the physical, mental, social and psychological and behavioral characteristics which a person should possess in order to perform the job effectively. Physical characteristics include height, weight, chest, vision, hearing, health, age, voice, poise, hand and foot coordination etc. Mental characteristic consists of general intelligence, memory, judgement, ability to concentrate, foresight etc. Social and psychological characteristics comprise emotional stability, flexibility, personal appearance, pleasing manners, initiative, drive, conversational ability etc. Other personal characteristics include sex, education, family background, job experience, extra- curricular activities, hobbies, etc.

 

A job description is a written statement of the appropriate and authorized contents of a job. It is descriptive in nature and provides job related information in terms of its title, location, duties and activities to be performed, authority & responsibility, working conditions, tools and equipment used, hazards of the job etc. It tells us what is the job that needs to be done, why it will be done, how it will be done, and under what conditions. Thus, job description differentiates one job from other and describes duties and responsibilities of a specific job.

 

Job Analysis is a systematic exploration, study and recording the responsibilities, duties, skills, accountabilities, work environment and ability requirements of a specific job. It also involves determining the relative importance of the duties, responsibilities and physical and emotional skills for a given job. All these factors identify what a job demands and what an employee must possess to perform a job productively. It leads to a Job Description which sets out the purpose, scope, duties and responsibilities of a job. From the job analysis and job description, a Job Specification may be derived, which is a statement of the skills, knowledge and other personal attributes required to carry out the job.

 

Job Design is the next step after job analysis. It is a process of deciding on the content of a job in terms of its duties and responsibilities, on the methods to be used in carrying out the job in terms of techniques, systems and procedures, and on the relationships that should exist between the jobholder and his superiors, subordinates and colleagues.

 

Job Evaluation is a systematic process of determining the relative worth of jobs to establish which jobs should be paid more than others within an organization. It is a method used to describe, analyse, compare and evaluate jobs within a unit, a branch, or an industry on the basis of the work content and the job requirements in order to place them under particular wage or salary grades. It has two basic objectives:

(i) To compare jobs and determine their level within each occupational group; and

(ii) To compare jobs between occupational groups.

Question 58
Examine the following statements on selection and identify the ones which are true and false:(a) Selection is a process of rejection.(b) Multiple Cutoff model is the foundation for setting out selection norms.(c) Kinesics is the interpretation of body motion communication(d) Graphology is study of interpretation of pictures.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a)and(c) are true, and (b) and (d) are false.
  • B.(a), (b) and (c) are true; (d) is false.
  • C.only(a) is true; (b), (c) and (d) are false.
  • D.(b) and (c) are true; (a) and (d) are false.
Correct Answer: (a)and(c) are true, and (b) and (d) are false.

Graphology or grapho analysis is the analysis of the physical characteristics and patterns of handwriting purporting to be able to identify the subject, indicating psychological state at the time of writing, or evaluating personality characteristics. A Polygraph, popularly referred to as a lie detector, measures and records several physiological indices such as blood pressure, pulse, respiration, and skin conductivity while a person is asked and answers a series of questions.

 

Recruitment is positive process and selection is negative process (rejection).

 

Kinesics is the interpretation of body motion communication such as facial expressions and gestures, nonverbal behavior related to movement of any part of the body or the body as a whole

 

When applicants achieve some minimum level of proficiency on all selection dimensions, then Multiple Cutoff Model can be used in which only those candidates who score above the minimum cutoff on all dimensions (tests) are considered. The selection decision is made from that subset of candidates.

 

A variation of the multiple cutoff is referred to as the Multiple Hurdle Model. This decision strategy is sequential in that after candidates go through an initial evaluation stage, the ones who score well are provisionally accepted and are assessed further at each successive stage. The process may continue through several stages (hurdles) before a final decision is made regarding the candidates.

Question 59
Which of the following are the errors, an appraiser is likely to commit during performance appraisal process?(a)Buggywhipeffect(b) Deadlock effect(c) Leniency or Severity effect(d) Horn or Halo effectSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a) and (c)
  • B.(b) and (d)
  • C.(c) and (d)
  • D.(a), (b) and (d)
Correct Answer: (c) and (d)

a) Buggywhip effect: This term is not commonly associated with errors in performance appraisal. It refers to a situation where an industry or business fails to adapt to changing circumstances, similar to the way buggy whip manufacturers became obsolete with the advent of automobiles.

 

(b) Deadlock effect: This term is not directly related to errors in performance appraisal. A deadlock typically refers to a situation where progress is halted because two or more parties cannot come to an agreement.

 

(c) Leniency or Severity effect: This is a common error in performance appraisal. Leniency occurs when the appraiser rates all employees more favorably than their actual performance, while severity occurs when all employees are consistently rated lower than their actual performance. Both leniency and severity can distort the accuracy of performance ratings.

 

(d) Horn or Halo effect: This is another common error in performance appraisal. The halo effect occurs when an appraiser allows one positive trait or performance aspect of an employee to influence the overall evaluation, leading to an overly positive rating. The horn effect is the opposite, where a single negative trait influences the overall evaluation negatively.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) (c) and (d).

Question 60
Which committee was set up by SEBI to review Clause 49 and to suggest measures to improve corporate governance standards?
  • A.Naresh Chandra Committee
  • B.Malhotra Committee
  • C.Narayan Murthy Committee
  • D.NarsimhamCommittee-II
Correct Answer: Narayan Murthy Committee

Narayan Murthy Committee - SEBI had set up a committee in 2003 under the chairmanship of Mr. N. R. Narayana Murthy, to review Clause 49, and suggest measures to improve corporate governance standards. Some of the major recommendations of the committee primarily related to audit committees, audit reports, independent directors, related party transactions, risk management, directorships and director compensation, codes of conduct and financial disclosures.

 

Narasimham Committee – It was established under former RBI Governor M. Narasimham in August 1991 to look into all aspects of the financial system in India. The report of this committee had comprehensive recommendations for financial sector reforms including the banking sector and capital markets.

 

Malhotra Committee - In 1993, the Government set up a committee under the chairmanship of RN Malhotra, former Governor of RBI, to propose recommendations for reforms in the insurance sector. The objective was to complement the reforms initiated in the financial sector. The committee submitted its report in 1994 wherein, among other things, it recommended that the private sector be permitted to enter the insurance industry. They stated that foreign companies should be allowed to enter by floating Indian companies, preferably a joint venture with Indian partner

 

Naresh Chandra Committee - The Department of Corporate Affairs (DCA) had also appointed a Naresh Chandra Committee on Corporate Audit and Governance in 2002 in order to examine various corporate governance issues. It made recommendations in two key aspects of corporate governance: financial and non-financial disclosures: and independent auditing and board oversight of management.

Question 61
Which of the following is not an “off the job” training method?
  • A.Management Games
  • B.Transactional Analysis
  • C.Coaching
  • D.Sensitivity Training
Correct Answer: Coaching

Some of "On the Job" trainings are:

Coaching

Mentoring

Job Rotation

Job Instruction Technique (JIT)

Apprenticeship

 

Some of "Off the Job" trainings are:

Vestibule Training

Sensitivity Training (T-Group)

Transactional Analysis

Classroom Lecture

Programmed Learning or Programmed instruction

Simulation Exercises: (Management Games, Case Study, Role Playing, In Basket Training)

Question 62
Who coined the term collective bargaining?
  • A.Sidney and Beatrice Webb
  • B.Samuel Gompers
  • C.Clark Kerr
  • D.Robert Hoxie
Correct Answer: Sidney and Beatrice Webb

The Collective Bargaining was coined by Sidney and Beatrice Webb, in 1891, in their famous book, "Industrial Democracy".

Question 63
Which of the following is not one of roles performed by Managers, according to HenryMintzberg?
  • A.Decisional
  • B.Informational
  • C.Interpersonal
  • D.Supervisory
Correct Answer: Supervisory

Management expert Professor Henry Mintzberg has argued that a manager’s work can be boiled down to ten common roles. According to Mintzberg, these roles, or expectations for a manager’s behavior, fall into three categories: informational (managing by information), interpersonal (managing through people), and decisional (managing through action).

 

Informational roles are

(1) Monitor -Seek and acquire work-related information

(2) Disseminator- Communicate/ disseminate information to others within the organization

(3) Spokesperson- Communicate/transmit information to outsiders.

 

Interpersonal roles are

(4) Figurehead- Perform social and legal duties, act as symbolic leader

(5) Leader- Direct and motivate subordinates, select and train employees

(6) Liaison- Establish and maintain contacts within and outside the organization.

 

Decisional roles are

(7) Entrepreneur- Identify new ideas and initiate improvement projects

(8) Disturbance Handler- Deals with disputes or problems and takes corrective action

(9) Resource Allocator- Decide where to apply resources

(10) Negotiator- Defends business interests

Question 64
Which of the following statements are true/false?a. Maslow’s Need theory has Five levels.b. TheoryX and Theory Y were first explained by McGregor in his book, “The Human Side of Enterprise”.c. In Vroom’s Expectancy’ theory “Valence” refers to employees’ different expectations and levels of confidence about what they are capable of doing – the belief that effort will lead to first order outcomes.d. Cognitive evaluation theory classifies persons as intrinsically and extrinsically motivated.
  • A.aand d are true, c and b are false.
  • B.a, b and d are true, c is false.
  • C.a, b, c and d are true.
  • D.aand c are true, b and d are false.
Correct Answer: a, b and d are true, c is false.

a. Maslow's Need theory has five levels: True. Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs consists of five levels, arranged in a pyramid from the most basic physiological needs at the bottom to the highest level of self-actualization at the top.

 

b. Theory X and Theory Y were first explained by McGregor in his book, "The Human Side of Enterprise": True. Douglas McGregor introduced Theory X and Theory Y in his book "The Human Side of Enterprise," published in 1960.

 

c. In Vroom's Expectancy theory "Valence" refers to employees' different expectations and levels of confidence about what they are capable of doing – the belief that effort will lead to first order outcomes: False. In Vroom's Expectancy theory, "Valence" refers to the value an individual places on a particular outcome or reward.

 

d. Cognitive evaluation theory classifies persons as intrinsically and extrinsically motivated: True. Cognitive evaluation theory distinguishes between intrinsic motivation (motivation from within, such as personal interest or enjoyment) and extrinsic motivation (motivation from external factors, such as rewards or punishments).

Question 65
The State Bank of India acquired the control of 7 banks (called associate Banks) in the year ________. They were 7 regional banks of former Indian princely states.
  • A.1948
  • B.1949
  • C.1956
  • D.1960
Correct Answer: 1960

The SBI acquired the control of 7 banks (called associate Banks) in 1960. They were seven regional banks of former Indian princely states.

 

Also, the State Bank of Bikaner & Jaipur, State Bank of Hyderabad, State Bank of Mysore, State Bank of Patiala and State Bank of Travancore, and Bharatiya Mahila Bank were merged with State Bank of India with effect from 1 April 2017.

Question 66
The ___________ is a facility under which scheduled commercial banks can borrow additional amount of overnight money from the Reserve Bank by dipping into their Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) portfolio up to a limit at a penal rate of interest. This provides a safety valve against unanticipated liquidity shocks to the banking system.
  • A.Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF)
  • B.Marginal Standing Facility (MSF)
  • C.Reverse Repo Rate
  • D.Repo Rate
Correct Answer: Marginal Standing Facility (MSF)

Marginal Standing Facility (MSF): A facility under which scheduled commercial banks can borrow additional amount of overnight money from the Reserve Bank by dipping into their Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) portfolio up to a limit at a penal rate of interest. This provides a safety valve against unanticipated liquidity shocks to the banking system.

Question 67
The PradhanMantriJanDhanYojana(PMJDY) was launched in 2014 for opening of no-frills accounts. Following are features of PMJDY accounts, EXCEPT:
  • A.The Bank account opened under PMJDY does not require minimum balance.
  • B.There is overdraft facility up toRs5000 after one month.
  • C.FreeRuPaydebit card is also made available.
  • D.There is also inbuiltRs. 1 lakh accident insurance cover and a Life Insurance cover ofRs30,000.
Correct Answer: There is overdraft facility up toRs5000 after one month.

Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana (PMJDY) was launched in 2014 for opening of no-frills accounts. The Bank account opened under PMJDY does not require minimum balance. Further there is overdraft facility up to Rs 5000 after 6 months. Free RuPay debit card is also made available. The Account opening and bank transactions are possible through business correspondent. There is also inbuilt Rs. 1 lakh accident insurance cover and a Life Insurance cover of Rs 30,000.

Question 68
The ____________ means any person engaged in the business of issue management by making arrangements regarding selling, buying or subscribing to securities or acting as manager/ consultant/ advisor or rendering corporate advisory services in relation to such issue management.
  • A.Merchant Banker
  • B.Registrars to an Issue
  • C.Share Transfer Agents
  • D.Underwriters
Correct Answer: Merchant Banker

‘Merchant Banker’ means any person engaged in the business of issue management by making arrangements regarding selling, buying or subscribing to securities or acting as manager/consultant/advisor or rendering corporate advisory services in relation to such issue management. The Merchant Banking firms carry out range of activities that help enterprises mobilize funds, from the capital market.

Question 69
The Head office of SIDBI is in:
  • A.Delhi
  • B.Mumbai
  • C.Hyderabad
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

The Head office of SIDBI is in Lucknow.

Question 70
Which one of the following is not part of governance structure of mutual funds, in India?
  • A.Sponsor
  • B.Trustee
  • C.Asset Management Company
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Since running of a mutual fund involves managing of investors’ money, SEBI prescribes comprehensive set of guidelines in the functioning of a mutual fund through the “SEBI MF regulations 1996”. These regulations stipulate that a mutual fund must be a three-tiered structure consisting of:

1. A Sponsor

2. A Trustee

3. An asset management company (AMC)

 

While the above mentioned play the most important roles in creating and running a fund house, the custodian, registrar and transfer agent (RTA), auditors and the fund accountants play a vital supporting role in aiding the smooth functioning of a mutual fund.

Question 71
Which of the following is not correct?
  • A.The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI), was formed under the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority Act, which came into being in year 1999.
  • B.The members of the IRDAI are appointed by the Central Government.
  • C.The Authority consists of a chairperson, not more than 5 whole-time members and not more than 4 part-time members.
  • D.Every Chairperson and member of IRDAI appointed shall hold office for a term of 6 years. However, Chairperson shall not hold office once he or she attains 65 years while whole time members shall not hold office beyond 62 years.
Correct Answer: Every Chairperson and member of IRDAI appointed shall hold office for a term of 6 years. However, Chairperson shall not hold office once he or she attains 65 years while whole time members shall not hold office beyond 62 years.

Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI)

The IRDAI Act, 1999, established the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (“IRDAI” or “Authority”) as a statutory regulator to regulate and promote the insurance industry in India and to protect the interests of holders of insurance policies. The IRDAI Act also carried out a series of amendments to the Act of 1938 and conferred the powers of the Controller of Insurance on the IRDAI.

 

The members of the IRDAI are appointed by the Central Government from amongst persons of ability, integrity and standing who have knowledge or experience in life insurance, general insurance, actuarial science, finance, economics, law, accountancy, administration etc.

 

The Authority consists of a chairperson, not more than 5 whole-time members and not more than 4 part-time members.

 

 

Every Chairperson and member of IRDAI appointed shall hold office for a term of 5 years. However, Chairperson shall not hold office once he or she attains 65 years while whole time members shall not hold office beyond 62 years.

 

Central Government may remove any member from office if he or she is adjudged insolvent or is physically or mentally incapacitated or has been convicted of an offence involving moral turpitude or has acquired financial or other interests or has abused his position. Chairperson and the whole time members shall not for a period of 2 years from the date of cessation of office in IRDAI, hold office as an employee with Central Government or any State Government or with any company in the insurance sector.

Question 72
The price strategy that prices are low at the beginning stage is called:
  • A.Economy pricing
  • B.Price penetration
  • C.Price skimming
  • D.Premium pricing
Correct Answer: Price penetration

Price penetration is a pricing strategy where the initial price set for a product is relatively low in order to quickly gain market share. The idea is to attract a large number of customers with the low initial price, aiming to penetrate the market deeply. This strategy is often employed for new products or services entering the market.

Question 73
The _________ refers to the aggregating of prospective buyers into groups with common needs and who respond similarly to a marketing action.
  • A.Market targeting
  • B.Market positioning
  • C.Market segmentation
  • D.Market strategy
Correct Answer: Market segmentation

Market segmentation involves dividing a market into distinct groups of buyers who have similar needs and behaviors. These groups are known as segments, and they share common characteristics. The purpose of market segmentation is to better understand and cater to the specific needs of different customer segments. Option (C) "Market segmentation" accurately describes the process of aggregating prospective buyers into groups with common needs and similar responses to marketing actions.

Question 74
Macro marketing environment include:(i) Culture(ii) Politics(iii) Economy(iv) Society(v) TechnologySelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.i, ii, iii and iv
  • B.ii, iii, iv and v
  • C.iii, iv, v and vi
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The overall marketing environment consists of the task environment and the broad environment.

 

The Task environment, also called as Micro Environment, includes the immediate actors involved in producing, distributing, and promoting the offering, including the company, suppliers, distributors, dealers, and the target customers.

 

The Broad environment, also called as Macro Environment, consists of six components: demographic environment, economic environment, natural environment, technological environment, political-legal environment, and social-cultural environment.

Question 75
Four competing philosophies strongly influence the role of marketing and marketing activities within an organization. Which of the following isnota component of market orientation?
  • A.Production Orientation
  • B.Profitability Orientation
  • C.Marketing Orientation
  • D.Societal Orientation
Correct Answer: Profitability Orientation

Four competing philosophies strongly influence the role of marketing and marketing activities within an organization. These philosophies are commonly referred to as:

a) The Production Orientation focuses on internal efficiency to achieve lower prices for consumers. It assumes that price is the critical variable in the purchase decision.

b) A Sales Orientation assumes that buyers resist purchasing items that are not essential and that consumers must be persuaded to buy.

c) The Marketing Orientation is based on an understanding that a sale predominantly depends on the customer's decision to purchase a product and on the customer's perception of the value of that product. Responsiveness to customer wants is the central focus of the marketing orientation.

d) The Societal Orientation holds that the firm should strive to satisfy customer needs and wants while meeting organizational objectives and preserving or enhancing both the individual and society's long-term best interests.

Question 76
Collection of activities for selling products too directly to end user for non-business use is classified as
  • A.Inter-Modeling
  • B.Distribution Operation
  • C.Wholesaling
  • D.Retailing
Correct Answer: Retailing

Retailing includes all the activities involved in selling products or services directly to final consumers for their personal non-business use. Many institutions – manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers – do retailing. But most retailing is done by retailers, businesses whose sales come primarily from retailing.

Question 77
Which of the following isnota characteristic of a Service that reflects the interconnection between the service firm and its customer?
  • A.Intangibility
  • B.Inseparability
  • C.Homogeneity
  • D.Perishability
Correct Answer: Homogeneity

The services have unique characteristics which makes them different from that of goods. The most common characteristics of services are: Intangibility, Inseparability, Perishability and Variability

 

Intangibility: Services are activities performed by the provider, unlike physical products they cannot be seen, tasted, felt, heard or smelt before they are consumed. Since, services are not tangibles, they do not have features that appeal to the customer’s senses.

 

Inseparability: Services are typically produced and consumed simultaneously. In case of physical goods, they are manufactured into products, distributed through multiple resellers, and consumed later. But, in case of services, it cannot be separated from the service provider.

 

Perishability: Services are deeds, performance or act whose consumption take place simultaneously; they tend to perish me the absence of consumption. Hence, services cannot be stored. The services go waste if they are not consumed simultaneously i.e. value of service exists at the point when it is required.

 

Variability: Services are highly variable, as they depend on the service provider, and where and when they are provided. Service marketers face a problem in standardizing their service, as it varies with experienced hand, customer, time and firm.

 

Question 78
From the following set of information, which combination is correct to define the process of perception in order to understand consumerbehavior?(a) Selective Attention(b) Selective Distortion(c) Selective Retention(d) Selective ApprehensionSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Only (a) and (d) are correct
  • B.Only (a), (b) and (d) are correct
  • C.Only (b), (c) and (d) are correct
  • D.Only (a), (b) and (c) are correct
Correct Answer: Only (a), (b) and (c) are correct

Perception is the process by which people select, organize, and interpret information to form a meaningful picture of the world from three perceptual processes (selective attention/ distortion/ retention).

 

Selective Attention is the tendency for people to screen out most of the information to which they are exposed

 

Selective Distortion is the tendency for people to interpret information in a way that will support what they already believe

 

Selective Retention is the tendency to remember good points made about a brand they favor and forget good points about competing brands.

Question 79
Which one of the following refers to “attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand”?
  • A.Points-of-attributes
  • B.Points-of-difference
  • C.Points-of-parity
  • D.Points-of-purchase
Correct Answer: Points-of-difference

Points-of-difference (POD) refer to attributes or benefits that are unique to a brand and are not typically found in competitive brands. These are distinctive characteristics that consumers strongly associate with a particular brand and positively evaluate. Points-of-difference contribute to the brand's competitive advantage by creating a unique and favorable position in the minds of consumers.

Question 80
Which one of the following refers to the use of online and offline promotion techniques to increase the audience of a site?
  • A.Search-engine optimization
  • B.Traffic building campaign
  • C.Search-engine marketing
  • D.Quality score
Correct Answer: Traffic building campaign

Traffic-building campaign is the use of online and offline promotion techniques such as banner advertising, search engine promotion and reciprocal linking to increase the audience of a site (both new and existing customers).

 

Search engine optimization (SEO) is the process of maximizing the number of visitors to a particular website by ensuring that the site appears high on the list of results returned by a search engine.

 

Search engine marketing (SEM) is a form of Internet marketing that involves the promotion of websites by increasing their visibility in search engine results pages (SERPs) primarily through paid advertising. SEM may or may not incorporate search engine optimization (SEO).

 

Quality Score is Google's rating of the quality and relevance of both your keywords and ads. It is used to determine your cost per click (CPC) and multiplied by your maximum bid to determine your ad rank in the ad auction process.

Question 81
_________ is the concept under which a company carefully integrates and coordinates its many communications channels to deliver a clear, consistent, and compelling message about the organization and its products.
  • A.Promotion Mix
  • B.Integrated Product Line
  • C.Integrated Marketing Communications
  • D.Integrated Demand Characteristics
Correct Answer: Integrated Marketing Communications

Integrated Marketing Communications refers to integrating all the methods of brand promotion to promote a particular product or service among target customers. In integrated marketing communication, all aspects of marketing communication work together for increased sales and maximum cost effectiveness.

Question 82
Which of the following does NOT constitute misrepresentation?
  • A.any breach of duty which, without an intent to deceive, gains an advantage to the person committing it
  • B.the positive assertion, in a manner not warranted by the information of the person making it, of that which is not true, though he believes it to be true
  • C.causing, however innocently, a party to an agreement, to make a mistake as to the substance of the thing which is subject of the agreement
  • D.any act fitted to deceive the other party wilfully
Correct Answer: any act fitted to deceive the other party wilfully

Any act fitted to deceive the other party wilfully comes under ‘Fraud’. The term is explained below:

 

Misrepresentation

The term “misrepresentation” is ordinarily used to connote both “innocent misrepresentation” and “dishonest misrepresentation” with intent to deceive and is called fraud.

 

Innocent Misrepresentation

If a person makes a representation believing what he says is true he commits innocent misrepresentation. Thus, any false representation, which is made with an honest belief in its truth is innocent. The effect of innocent misrepresentation is that the party misled by it can avoid the contract, but cannot sue for damages. However, in the following cases, damages are obtainable:

(i) From a promoter or director who makes innocent misrepresentation in a company prospectus inviting the public to subscribe for the shares in the company;

(ii) Against an agent who commits a breach of warranty of authority;

(iii) From a person who (at the Courts discretion) is estopped from denying a statement he has made where he made a positive statement intending that it should be relied upon and the innocent party did rely upon it and thereby suffered damages;

(iv) Negligent representation made by one person to another between whom a confidential relationship, like that of a solicitor and client exists.

 

Wilful Misrepresentation or Fraud

Fraud is an untrue statement made knowingly or without belief in its truth or recklessly, carelessly, whether it be true or false with the intent to deceive. It is immaterial whether the representation takes effect by false statement or with concealment. The party defrauded can avoid the contract and also claim damages.

 

Mere silence as to facts likely to affect the willingness of a person to enter into a contract is not fraud, unless silence is in itself equivalent to speech, or where it is the duty of the person keeping silent to speak as in the cases of contracts uberrimae fidei- (contracts requiring utmost good faith).

Question 83
Caveat Emptor means:
  • A.Buyer must take care
  • B.It is the duty of the seller to make the consumer be aware
  • C.Both buyer and seller must take care
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Buyer must take care

Caveat Emptor means buyer must take care.

 

The Doctrine of Caveat Emptor is explained below:

 

Doctrine of Caveat Emptor

The term “caveat emptor” is a Latin word which means “let the buyer beware”. This principle states that it is for the buyer to satisfy himself that the goods which he is purchasing are of the quality which he requires. If he buys goods for a particular purpose, he must satisfy himself that they are fit for that purpose.

Question 84
Which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
  • A.Once a bearer cheque always a bearer cheque
  • B.An instrument payable to a specified person or to the order of a specified person is an instrument payable to order. Such an instrument cannot be negotiated by endorsement and delivery.
  • C.‘Endorsement’ means and involves the writing of something on the back of an instrument for the purpose of transferring the right, title and interest therein to some other person.
  • D.When the drawee writes across the face of the bill of exchange, the word “accepted” and signs his name underneath he becomes the acceptor of the bill.
Correct Answer: An instrument payable to a specified person or to the order of a specified person is an instrument payable to order. Such an instrument cannot be negotiated by endorsement and delivery.

Statement B is incorrect as an instrument payable to order can be negotiated only by endorsement and delivery.

Question 85
Which of the following combination of statements are incorrect under Companies Act, 2013 with respect to Quorum of the Board Meeting and Shareholders’ Meeting?(i) The quorum for a meeting of the Board of Directors of a company shall be 1/3rdof its total strength or 3 directors, whichever is higher.(ii) The Act lays down only minimum number of directors to form a quorum for with respect to Board Meetings, however the company by its articles can provide for a higher number of quorum.(iii) For Section 8 Companies, the quorum for a meeting of the Board of Directors of a company shall be either 8 members or 25% of its total strength whicheveris less. The quorum shall not be less than 2 members.(iv) For Board Meetings, the quorum shall be present necessarily only at the time of commencement of the Meeting but not necessarily present while transacting business.(v) In case of General Meetings, the quorum shall be 30 members personally present if the number of members as on the date of the meeting exceeds 5000;(vi)inthe case of a private company, 5 members personally present, shall be the quorum for a general meeting of the company.(vii) In case of an adjourned general meeting or of a change of day, time or place of meeting, the company shall give not less than 7 days’ notice to the members either individually or by publishing an advertisement in the newspapers.(viii) In case of General Meeting, if at the adjourned meeting also, a quorum is not present within half-an-hour from the time appointed for holding meeting, the members present shall be the quorum.
  • A.(i), (iv), (vi), (vii)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (v), (viii)
  • C.(i), (iii), (vi), (vii)
  • D.(i), (ii), (vi), (viii)
Correct Answer: (i), (iv), (vi), (vii)

Section 174. Quorum for meetings of Board

The quorum for a company's Board of Directors meeting is set at one-third of its total strength or two directors, whichever is higher. Participation through video conferencing or other audio-visual means is counted for quorum. However, the quorum must not be less than two members. If the number of directors falls below the quorum, continuing directors may act to increase the board's strength or summon a general meeting. When interested directors make up two-thirds of the total strength, the quorum requires at least two directors who are not interested. If a meeting lacks quorum, it automatically adjourns to the same day and time the following week (or the next succeeding day if the initial day is a national holiday), unless the company's articles specify otherwise.

 

Section 103.Quorum for meetings.

Section 103 outlines the quorum requirements for company meetings:

 

1. For public companies:

Five members must be personally present if the membership is up to one thousand.

Fifteen members must be personally present if the membership is more than one thousand but up to five thousand.

Thirty members must be personally present if the membership exceeds five thousand.

For private companies, the quorum is two members personally present.

 

2. If the quorum is not met within half an hour from the scheduled meeting time:

The meeting will adjourn to the same day in the next week at the same time and place, or to a date, time, and place decided by the Board.

If the meeting was called by requisitionists under section 100, it will be cancelled.

Notice for an adjourned meeting or any changes must be given at least three days in advance to the members individually or through newspaper advertisements.

 

3. If, at the adjourned meeting, a quorum is still not present within half an hour from the scheduled time, the members present at that time will constitute the quorum.

Question 86
Which of the following provisions of Companies Act, 2013 are correct with respect to Annual General Meetings?(i) Annual general meetingshould be held oncein each calendar year.(ii) It shall not be necessary for the company to hold any annual general meeting in the year of its incorporation.(iii) The gap between two annual general meetings shall not exceed 18 months.(iv) Annual general meeting of an unlisted company may be held at any place in India if consent is given in writing or by electronic mode by all the members in advance.(v) AGM is to be held within 9 months of the close of relevant financial year.
  • A.(i), (ii), (v)
  • B.(i), (iii), (iv)
  • C.(ii), (iii), (v)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iv)

Only Statement 3 is incorrect. The annual general meeting should be held once in each calendar year.

Question 87
Under the Competition Act, 2002, which of the following statement is incorrect with respect to Accounts and Audit of Competition Commission of India?
  • A.The Commission shall maintain proper accounts and other relevant records and prepare an annual statement of accounts in consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAGI).
  • B.The accounts of the Commission shall be audited by duly appointed practising Chartered Accountant.
  • C.The accounts of the Commission as certified by the CAGI together with the Audit Report thereon shall be forwarded annually to the Central Government which shall cause the same to be laid before each House of Parliament.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: The accounts of the Commission shall be audited by duly appointed practising Chartered Accountant.

Statement B is incorrect as the accounts of the Commission shall be audited by CAGI.

 

The provisions of Competition Act, 2002 with respect to Accounts and Audit are as follows:

(1) The Commission shall maintain proper accounts and other relevant records and prepare an annual statement of accounts in consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAGI).

(2) The accounts of the Commission shall be audited by CAGI at such intervals as may be specified by him and any expenditure incurred in connection with such audit shall be payable by the Commission to the CAGI.

(3) The CAGI shall have the right to demand the production of books, accounts, connected vouchers and other documents and papers and to inspect any of the offices of the Commission.

(4) The accounts of the Commission as certified by the CAGI together with the Audit Report thereon shall be forwarded annually to the Central Government which shall cause the same to be laid before each House of Parliament.

Question 88
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the Information Technology Act, 2000?
  • A.There is provision of the Recognition of foreign Certifying Authorities under the Act.
  • B.“Signature Creation Data” means the private key of the subscriber.
  • C.A Digital Signature Certificate shall not be suspended for a period exceeding 30 days unless the subscriber has been given an opportunity of being heard.
  • D.A Certifying Authority may revoke a Digital Signature Certificate upon the dissolution of the firm or winding up of the company where the subscriber is a firm or a company.
Correct Answer: A Digital Signature Certificate shall not be suspended for a period exceeding 30 days unless the subscriber has been given an opportunity of being heard.

Statement C is incorrect as a Digital Signature Certificate shall not be suspended for a period exceeding 15 days unless the subscriber has been given an opportunity of being heard.

Question 89
