Which of the following statements are correct with respect to ‘appeal provisions’ under the Right to Information Act, 2005?(a) Any person who, aggrieved by a decision of the CPIO/SPIO appeal to First Appellate Authority, but within 45 days.(b) A second appeal against the decision of “First Appellate Authority” can be made to the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, within 60 days.(c) An appeal with the First Appellate Authority shall be disposed of within 30 days of the receipt of the appeal.(d) The decision of the Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, shall be advisory and not binding.
  • A.(a), (b), (c)
  • B.(c) only
  • C.(b) and (c)
  • D.(a) and (b)
Correct Answer: (c) only

Only Statement (c) is correct.

Section 19 of the Right to Information Act, 2005 lays down provisions of Appeal, which are stated below:

 

Any person who, aggrieved by a decision of the CPIO/SPIO appeal to senior officer (called First Appellate Authority), but within 30 days. The officer may admit appeal after 30 days, if there are sufficient reasons.

 

A second appeal against the decision of “First Appellate Authority” can be made to the Central Information Commission or the State Information Commission, but within 90 days. The Commission may accept appeal beyond 90 days, if there are sufficient reasons.

 

An appeal with the First Appellate Authority shall be disposed of within 30 days of the receipt of the appeal or within extended period of 45 days with reasons to be recorded in writing.

 

The decision of the Central Information Commission or State Information Commission, shall be binding.

Question 90
Which of the following does not constitutes ‘infringement’ under the Intellectual Property Rights?
  • A.the trade mark is identical and is used in relation to identical goods or services
  • B.the mark is deceptively similar to the registered trade mark and there is an identity
  • C.similarity of the goods or services covered by the trade mark
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

As all options of the question constitute case for ‘infringement’ under the Intellectual Property Rights, therefor the option D is correct.

 

Infringement of Registered Trade Marks

When a registered trade mark is used by a person who is not entitled to use such a trade mark under the law, it constitutes infringement. This registered trade mark is infringed:

(a) if the mark is identical and is used in respect of similar goods or services; or

(b) the mark is deceptively similar to the registered trade mark and there is an identity; or

(c) similarity of the goods or services covered by the trade mark; or

(d) the trade mark is identical and is used in relation to identical goods or services; and that such use is likely to cause confusion on the part of the public or is likely to be taken to have an association with the registered trade mark.

Question 91
It is mandatory to register under GST for the business whose turnover exceeds
  • A.Rs. 20 Lakhs
  • B.Rs. 40 Lakhs
  • C.Rs. 25 Lakhs
  • D.Rs. 55 Lakhs
Correct Answer: Rs. 40 Lakhs

In the GST Regime, businesses whose turnover exceeds Rs. 40 lakhs* (Rs 10 lakhs for North East and hill states) is required to register as a normal taxable person. This process of registration is called GST registration.

 

For certain businesses, registration under GST is mandatory. If the organization carries on business without registering under GST, it will be an offence under GST and heavy penalties will apply.

*CBIC has notified the increase in threshold turnover from Rs 20 lakhs to Rs 40 lakhs. The notification will come into effect from 1st April 2019.

Question 92
A resident individual will be treated as ____________ during the year if he satisfies both of the following conditions:(1) He is resident in India for at least 2 years out of 10 years immediately preceding the relevant year.(2) His stay in India is for 730 days or more during 7 years immediately preceding the relevant year.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Non-Resident
  • B.Resident and Ordinarily Resident
  • C.Resident but not Ordinary Resident
  • D.Resident only
Correct Answer: Resident and Ordinarily Resident

A resident individual will be treated as resident and ordinarily resident in India during the year if he satisfies both the following conditions:

(1) He is resident in India for at least 2 years out of 10 years immediately preceding the relevant year.

(2) His stay in India is for 730 days or more during 7 years immediately preceding the relevant year.

Question 93
Following information is provided by Mr.Kunalin respect of a property rented by him:Gross annual valueRs. 2,84,000.Municipal taxes for the year paid by the tenant (paid during the year): Rs.10,000.Electricity bill of the property paid by Mr.Kunal(paid during the year) :Rs. 12,000.What will be the Net Annual Value of the property?
  • A.Rs. 2,84,000
  • B.Rs. 2,74,000
  • C.Rs. 2,62,000
  • D.Rs. 2,72,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 2,84,000

The remaining amount left after deducting Municipal taxes (from gross annual value) is called as “Net Annual Value”. In this case, Municipal taxes are paid by the tenant. Hence, Mr. Kunal cannot claim deduction on account of Municipal taxes. Thus, Gross annual value will become Net annual value. In other words, Net annual value will come to Rs. 2,84,000. Thus, option A giving correct amount of net annual value is correct.

Question 94
Income chargeable under the head salaries is computed after making which of the following deductions under Income Tax Act?
  • A.Entertainment Allowance
  • B.Professional Tax
  • C.Standard Deduction
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The income chargeable under the head salaries is computed after making the following deductions under Section 16:

 

Standard deduction: Standard deduction of Rs 40,000 is allowed from salary income for FY 2018-19. This limit has been increased to Rs 50,000 from FY 2019-20.

 

Entertainment Allowance: Entertainment allowance received from employer is first included in gross salary and thereafter, with effect from A.Y.2002-03 a deduction is allowed to government employees (State or Central Government) to the extent of least of following 3 amounts:

(i) Rs.5000

(ii) 20% of basic salary

(iii) Amount of Entertainment Allowance actually received during the year.

 

Professional Tax: Professional tax or tax on employment levied by a State under Article 276 of the Constitution is allowed as a deduction only in the year when it is actually paid. If the professional tax is paid by the employer on behalf of the employee, it is first included in gross salary as a perquisite (since it is an obligation of employee fulfilled by employer) and then the same amount is allowed as deduction on account of professional tax from gross salary.

Question 95
Overall deduction u/s 80C (along with deduction u/s 80CCC &80CCD(1)) allowed is up toRs. _______.
  • A.1,00,000
  • B.1,50,000
  • C.2,00,000
  • D.2,50,000
Correct Answer: 1,50,000

Overall deduction u/s 80C (along with deduction u/s 80CCC & 80CCD(1)) is up to Rs. 1,50,000. Thus, option B is the correct option.

 

These deductions are explained below:

 

Section 80C: The maximum tax exemption limit under Section 80C has been retained as Rs 1.5 Lakh only. The various investment avenues or expenses that can be claimed as tax deductions under section 80C are as below;

- PPF (Public Provident Fund)

- EPF (Employees’ Provident Fund)

- Five-year Bank or Post office Tax saving Deposits

- NSC (National Savings Certificates)

- Kid’s Tuition Fees

- SCSS (Post office Senior Citizen Savings Scheme)

- Principal repayment of Home Loan

- NPS (National Pension System)

- Life Insurance Premium

- Sukanya Samriddhi Account Deposit Scheme

Question 96
Which set of statements is correct under Income Tax Act with respect to international transactions or specified domestic transaction?(i) Penalty will be a sum equal to 2% of the value of each international transaction or specified domestic transaction entered into by the taxpayer.(ii) If any person, being a constituent entity of international group fails to furnish information and documents in respect of international group (as per section 92D), it may be liable to pay penalty ofRs5,00,000.(iii) On demand of Income Tax Authority, the tax payer has to provide such documents within a period of 30 days.(iv) The documents pertaining to such transactions should be maintained for a period of 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year.
  • A.(i) only
  • B.(i), (iii) and (iv)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)

Penalty for failure to keep and maintain information and document etc. in respect of international transaction or specified domestic transaction

Section 92D provides that every person entering into an international transaction or specified domestic transaction shall keep and maintain such information and documents as may be prescribed in this regard under rule 10D. Provided that the person, being a constituent entity of an international group, shall also keep and maintain such information and documents in respect of an international group as may be prescribed. The Income-tax Authority may require the taxpayer to produce these documents. On such demand by the Income-tax Authority, the taxpayer has to provide these documents within a period of 30 days or such extended period as may be allowed by the tax authorities. These documents should be maintained for a period of 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year. The provisions relating to penalty for failure to keep and maintain information and documents in respect of international transaction or specified domestic transaction are given in section 271AA. Penalty under section 271AA is attracted in the case of any of the following failures:

1) If a person fails to keep and maintain information and documents in respect of international transaction or specified domestic transaction as provided in section 92D read with rule 10D.

2) If a person fails to report the international transaction or specified domestic transaction which he is required to do so.

3) If a person maintains or furnishes an incorrect information or document in respect of international transaction or specified domestic transaction.

 

Penalty will be a sum equal to 2% of the value of each international transaction or specified domestic transaction entered into by the taxpayer. If any person, being a constituent entity of international group fails to furnish information and documents in respect of international group (as referred to in Section 92D), it may be liable to pay penalty of Rs 5,00,000.

Question 97
Under Income Tax Act, the basis exemption limit (for the assessment year 2024-25) in case of a resident individual of the age of 80 years or above isRs. ___________.
  • A.Rs. 2,00,000
  • B.Rs. 2,50,000
  • C.Rs. 3,00,000
  • D.Rs. 5,00,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 5,00,000

The basis exemption limit (for the assessment year 2020-21) in case of a resident individual of the age of 80 years or above is Rs. 5,00,000.

Question 98
If the asset is acquired during the previous year and the same is put to use for less than _______ days for the purpose of business or profession of theassesseeduring that year, then the eligible depreciation on such asset which can be claimed by theassesseeduring the previous year will be_______.
  • A.150, 100% of normal depreciation
  • B.150, 50% of normal depreciation
  • C.180, 100% of normal depreciation
  • D.180, 50% of normal depreciation
Correct Answer: 180, 50% of normal depreciation

As per the provisions of section 32, if the asset is acquired during the previous year and the same is put to use for less than 180 days for the purpose of business or profession of the assessee during that year, then the eligible depreciation on such an asset which can be claimed by the assessee during the previous year will be 50% of the normal depreciation. In other words, in the above situation, the assessee is entitled to only 50% of normal depreciation and not to 100% of normal depreciation. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Question 99
Mrs. X has let out one house property @Rs. 62,000 p.m., Municipal ValuationRs. 72,000 p.m., Fair RentRs. 90,000 p.m., Standard rentRs. 1,00,000 p.m., Municipal Tax paidRs. 40,000. The Net Annual Value shall be:
  • A.Rs. 12,00,000
  • B.Rs. 7,44,000
  • C.Rs. 10,80,000
  • D.Rs. 10,40,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 10,40,000

Computation of Income under the Head House Property:

 

Particulars

Amt. (in Rs.)

Calculation of Gross Annual Value

 

Working Note:

 

 

 

(a) Fair Rent (Rs. 90,000 × 12)

10,80,000

 

 

(b) Municipal Value (Rs. 72,000 ×12)

8,64,000

 

 

(c) Actual Rent (Rs. 62,000 × 12)

7,44,000

 

 

(d) Higher of (a) or (b) or (c)

 

10,80,000

 

(e) Standard Rent (Rs. 1,00,000 × 12)

12,00,000

 

 

(f) Actual Rent

7,44,000

 

 

(g) Higher of (e) or (f)

 

12,00,000

 

Gross Annual Value (lower of (d) or (g))

 

 

10,80,000

Less: Municipal Taxes

 

 

40,000

NET ANNUAL VALUE

 

 

10,40,000

 

Question 100
Deduction under section 24(b) in respect of interest in case of let-out property cannot exceed _________.
  • A.There is no such limit
  • B.Rs. 30,000
  • C.Rs. 1,50,000
  • D.Rs. 2,00,000
Correct Answer: There is no such limit

In case of let-out property, interest is deductible without any limit. Thus, option A is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119008

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
Consider the following statements:Statement I:Under the FDI Policy in India, the Equity/FDI cap on e-commerce activities is set at 100% through the automatic route.Statement II:E-commercestartupsand entities should engage only in the Business to Business (B2B) e-commerce and not in the Business to Consumer (B2C) E-commerce.Which of the following options are correct?
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • D.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

Both statements are correct.

 

Under the FDI Policy in India, the Equity/FDI cap on e-commerce activities is set at 100% through the automatic route. However, e-commerce startups and entities should engage only in the Business to Business (B2B) e-commerce and not in the Business to Consumer (B2C) e-commerce.

 

The FDI Policy allows 100% FDI under the automatic route for the marketplace model of e-commerce activities. However, FDI is not permitted for the inventory-based model of e-commerce activities.

 

The marketplace based model of e-commerce means providing an information technology platform by an e-commerce startup or entity on a digital and electronic network, acting as a facilitator between the buyer and the seller.

The inventory-based model of e-commerce means e-commerce activities where the inventory of goods and services is owned by an e-commerce startup or entity and is sold to the consumers directly.

Question 2
Which of the following is NOTone of variables of Micro Environment?
  • A.competitors
  • B.existing customers
  • C.technological factors
  • D.marketing intermediaries
Correct Answer: technological factors

The factors of Macro-environment are economic factors, key issues by sector, political factors, policy factors, social factors, technological factors and economic factors.

 

The factors of Micro-environment are competitors, existing customers, marketing intermediaries, national differences, nature/structure of organization and suppliers.

Question 3
The Balance of Payment (BoP) is a standard double entry accounting record. Which of the following is not correct?
  • A.The purchases of goods and assets by foreign residents from domestic residents are credit transactions.
  • B.A Deficit in the BOP occurs when Total Receipts exceeds Total Payments.
  • C.Because manyBoPentries are estimated, the sum of the current account and the capital account does not always equal zero.
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: A Deficit in the BOP occurs when Total Receipts exceeds Total Payments.

Correct answer is option B.

 

The Balance of Payment (BoP) functions as a double-entry accounting record where each entry represents either a credit or a debit. Here's a breakdown of the options:

 

(A) Correct: Purchases of goods and assets by foreign residents from domestic residents are indeed credit transactions because they represent a source of foreign exchange.

 

(B) Incorrect: A deficit in the BoP actually occurs when Total Payments exceed Total Receipts, not the other way around. A deficit indicates that a country is spending more on imports, investments abroad, or other payments than it is earning through exports, investments in the country, or other receipts.

 

(C) Correct: Many BoP entries are estimated, leading to discrepancies where the sum of the current account and the capital account may not always equal zero. This is due to the inherent complexities and uncertainties in measuring international transactions accurately.

 

(D) This option states "None of above," suggesting that none of the statements are incorrect. However, as discussed above, option (B) is indeed incorrect.

Question 4
Who is credited with the introduction of LPG in India?
  • A.JawaharLal Nehru
  • B.Lal BahadurShastri
  • C.Manmohan Singh
  • D.Indira Gandhi
Correct Answer: Manmohan Singh

Manmohan Singh, who served as the Finance Minister of India from 1991 to 1996, is widely recognized for his pivotal role in spearheading economic reforms in India. These reforms, often referred to as the LPG reforms, aimed to liberalize the Indian economy by reducing government intervention, privatizing state-owned enterprises, and integrating the economy into the global market.

Question 5
In which year, the Foreign Exchange Management Act was introduced?
  • A.1999
  • B.1989
  • C.2002
  • D.1987
Correct Answer: 1999

The Foreign Exchange Management Act (1999) or in short ‘FEMA’ was introduced as a replacement for earlier Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1973 known in short as FERA. FEMA became an act on the 1st day of June, 2000. FEMA was introduced because the FERA didn’t fit in with post-liberalization policies. A significant change that the FEMA brought with it was that it made all offenses regarding foreign exchange civil offenses, as opposed to criminal offenses as dictated by FERA.

 

The main objective behind the Foreign Exchange Management Act (1999) is to consolidate and amend the law relating to foreign exchange with the objective of facilitating external trade and payments. It was also formulated to promote the orderly development and maintenance of foreign exchange market in India.

Question 6
As per provisions of the Companies Act,with effect from April 1, 2014, every company, private limited or public limited, which either has __________, needs to spend at least 2% of its average net profit for the immediately preceding 3 financial years on CSR activities.
  • A.net worth ofRs500 crore or a turnover ofRs1,000 crore or net profit ofRs5 crore
  • B.net worth ofRs1000 crore or a turnover ofRs2,000 crore or net profit ofRs5 crore
  • C.net worth ofRs1000 crore or a turnover ofRs2,000 crore or net profit ofRs50 crore
  • D.net worth ofRs500 crore or a turnover ofRs1,000 crore or net profit ofRs50 crore
Correct Answer: net worth ofRs500 crore or a turnover ofRs1,000 crore or net profit ofRs5 crore

Option A is the correct answer.

 

A company satisfying any of the following criteria during the immediately preceding financial year has to comply with CSR provisions specified under section 135 of the Companies Act, 2013 read with the CSR Rules made thereunder:

i. net worth of rupees five hundred crore or more, or

ii. turnover of rupees one thousand crore or more or

iii. a net profit of rupees five crore or more.

 

The Central Government may give directions to a company or class of companies as it considers necessary to ensure compliance of provisions of this section and such company or class of companies shall be required to comply with such directions.

Question 7
Match the followingList I(i) Custom duty imposed by the importing country in form of a tax imposed on goods being imported.(ii) It is levied on commodities that originate in one country, cross another and are consigned to another.(iii) Duty imposed according to the value of commodities being traded between countries, usually a fixed percentage of the invoice value of the goods.(iv) Combination of specific duty and ad valorem duty on a single product.List II(a) Anti-Dumping duty(b) Transit duties(c) Import tariff/duty(d) Ad Valorem duty(e) Compound duty
  • A.i-c, ii-b, iii-d, iv-e
  • B.i-a, ii-c, iii-d, iv-e
  • C.i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e
  • D.i-e, ii-d, iii-c, iv-b
Correct Answer: i-c, ii-b, iii-d, iv-e

These are all different kinds of Tariff Barriers.

 

Tariff is a custom duty or tax imposed on products that move across borders. It is the most common instrument used for controlling imports and exports:

  • Import tariff/duty: Custom duty imposed by the importing country in the form of a tax imposed on goods being imported.
  • Transit duties: It is levied on commodities that originate in one country, cross another, and are consigned to another.
  • Ad Valorem duty: Duty imposed according to the value of commodities being traded between countries, usually a fixed percentage of the invoice value of the goods.
  • Compound duty: Combination of specific duty and ad valorem duty on a single product.

Anti-Dumping duty: A penalty imposed on suspiciously low-priced imports, aimed at increasing their price to prevent unfair competition.

Question 8
Trade Creation and Trade Diversion terms were used by Chicago SchoolRconomist_________in his 1950 paper "The Customs Union".
  • A.David Ricardo
  • B.Jacob Viner
  • C.Adam Smith
  • D.Heckscher
Correct Answer: Jacob Viner

Trade Creation and Trade Diversion terms were used by 'old' Chicago School economist Jacob Viner in his 1950 paper The Customs Union Issue.

Question 9
Match the items of List-I with the items of List-II and select the correct answer.List – I(i) Capitalist Economy(ii) Socialist Economy(iii) Mixed Economy(iv) Communist EconomyList – II(a) Also called private or market economy; Features: Individual ownership of resources, maximum private gains, free enterprise.(b) Group of administrators run the country insocietiesinterest.(c) Centralised/ centrally planned economy/ Non- market Economy; features: all decisions are taken solely by state, distribution on the basis of need and not affordability.(d) Co-existence of public and private sector; helps to attain directive principles of state policy (DPSP) of constitution.
  • A.i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
  • B.i-c, ii-b, iii-d, iv-a
  • C.i-b, ii-d, iii-c, iv-a
  • D.i-a, ii-c, iii-d, iv-b
Correct Answer: i-a, ii-c, iii-d, iv-b

Types of economic system (theses are organisation satisfying human wants):

 

Capitalist economy – originated from Adam Smith’s – Wealth of Nation. This system adopted Laissez fair policy. Enterprises operate freely with profit motive and the resources are under individual ownership. Economic inequalities, emergence of monopolies and under utilization of resources are the drawbacks of this economic system.

 

Socialist economy – This theory was given by Karl Marx. This can be further divided into two parts: Democratic (all control by government but people have freedom of occupation) and Totalitarian (people are obliged to work under government direction). As all decisions are taken by government so there does not exist any monopoly.

 

Mixed Economy – Co-existence of public and private sectors. Government promote welfare of country and desire to attain balance economic development.

 

Communist Economy - Group of administrators who run the economy in societies interest.

Question 10
Which of the following are the assumptions of Classical View of Theories of International trade?(i) Real sector and monetary changes are independent of each other (neutrality of money).(ii) All the prices (and foreign exchange rates) are inelastic.(iii) The amount of the factors of production is constant and all the factors are fully utilized (full-employment).(iv) Factors of production are mobile within countries but immobile among countries.(v) Level of technology (therefore production functions) is same within a country but may vary among countries.(vi) There are no trade barriers in terms of transportation, knowledge and communication.
  • A.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) only
  • B.(i) (ii) (iii) and (v) only
  • C.(i) (iii) (iv) (v) and (vi) only
  • D.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) and (vi)
Correct Answer: (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v) and (vi)

The Classical View of Theories of International Trade is based on several fundamental assumptions:

 

(i) Real sector and monetary changes are independent of each other (neutrality of money): This assumption suggests that changes in the money supply do not affect real variables such as output, employment, and trade patterns in the long run.

 

(ii) All the prices (and foreign exchange rates) are inelastic: This assumption implies that prices, including foreign exchange rates, do not respond to changes in supply and demand.

 

(iii) The amount of factors of production is constant and all the factors are fully utilized (full-employment): This assumption posits that the economy operates at full employment, meaning all available resources are fully employed in production.

 

(iv) Factors of production are mobile within countries but immobile among countries: This assumption suggests that labor and capital can move freely within a country's borders but face significant barriers to mobility across international borders.

 

(v) Level of technology (therefore production functions) is the same within a country but may vary among countries: This assumption states that technology and production functions are uniform within a country but may differ between countries.

 

(vi) There are no trade barriers in terms of transportation, knowledge, and communication: This assumption implies that trade occurs freely without any hindrances such as tariffs, quotas, or other barriers.

Question 11
Taxpayers with total income of more thanRs. _______ shall furnish the return of income electronically with or without digital signature or by using electronic verification code. However in a case where digital signature is mandatory return is to be mandatorily digital signed.
  • A.25,00,000
  • B.15,00,000
  • C.10,00,000
  • D.5,00,000
Correct Answer: 5,00,000

Taxpayers with total income of more than Rs. 5,00,000 shall furnish the return of income electronically with or without digital signature. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Question 12
Which of the following is not one of methods, through which FDI is routed to India?
  • A.Automatic route without approval
  • B.Government route with FIPB approval
  • C.Government route with approval of concerned ministry
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Government route with FIPB approval

There are two routes by which India gets FDI:

 

1) Automatic route: By this route FDI is allowed without prior approval by Government or Reserve Bank of India.

2) Government route: Prior approval by government is needed via this route. The Foreign Investment Promotion Board, FIPB was the responsible agency to oversee this route till 2017. The FIPB was abolished on May 24, 2017. Now the approval processes are handled by the concerned Ministries/Departments in consultation with the Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion (DIPP), Ministry of Commerce, which will also issue the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for processing of applications.

Question 13
Which of the following institutions is not part of the World Bank community?
  • A.IBRD
  • B.WTO
  • C.IDA
  • D.IFC
Correct Answer: WTO

The WTO or World Trade Organization is not part of the World Bank community.

 

The World Bank Group is comprised of the 5 institutions i.e.

(i) International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD),

(ii) International Development Association (IDA),

(iii) International Finance Corporation (IFC),

(iv) Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)

(v) International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID).

Question 14
Which concept assumes that business shall continue to carry out its operations indefinitely for a long period of time?
  • A.Business entity concept
  • B.Conservatism concept
  • C.Going concern concept
  • D.Consistency concept
Correct Answer: Going concern concept

The Going Concern Concept is a fundamental principle in accounting that assumes a business will continue to operate indefinitely, at least for the foreseeable future. This concept implies that the company will not be liquidated in the near future and will continue its normal operations without any intention or need to sell off its assets or cease its operations.

Question 15
Consider the following.Statement I:In Journal entries, transactions are recorded for thefirst time that is why it is also called ‘Books of original entry’.Statement II:When the transactions entered in journal are recorded in the ledger, it is called posting.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • D.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

Statement I: In journal entries, transactions are recorded for the first time, which is why it is also called ‘Books of original entry.’

 

This statement is correct. The journal is where transactions are initially recorded in chronological order, making it the primary record of business transactions and earning it the name "Books of original entry."

 

Statement II: When the transactions entered in the journal are recorded in the ledger, it is called posting.

This statement is also correct. Posting refers to the process of transferring the information recorded in the journal to the respective accounts in the ledger. It ensures that the ledger reflects the most up-to-date and accurate information about each account's balance.

Question 16
An analysis of percentage financial statement where all the Balance Sheet items are divided by the total assets and all the income statement items are divided by net sales or revenue is known as
  • A.Index Analysis
  • B.Trend Analysis
  • C.Ration Analysis
  • D.Common size Analysis
Correct Answer: Common size Analysis

Common size analysis, also known as vertical analysis, is a financial analysis technique where each line item on a financial statement is expressed as a percentage of a base figure.

 

For Balance Sheet items: Each item is divided by the total assets, resulting in percentages that show the proportion of each asset category to the total assets.

 

For Income Statement items: Each item is divided by net sales or revenue, showing the percentage of each expense or income category relative to the total revenue.

 

Common size analysis helps in comparing financial statements across different time periods or between companies of different sizes. It provides insights into the composition and structure of the financial statements, highlighting trends and identifying areas that may require further investigation.

Question 17
Consider the following:Statement I:Under Fixed Capital Account method, two separate accounts are maintained for each partner (Capital Account and Current Account)Statement II:Under Fixed Capital Account method, the balance of the capital account varies from year to year.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are not correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
  • D.Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.

The correct answer is option (C) Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.

 

Statement I: Under Fixed Capital Account method, two separate accounts are maintained for each partner (Capital Account and Current Account).

 

This statement is correct. In partnership accounting, the Fixed Capital Account method involves maintaining separate accounts for each partner: one for their capital contributions (Capital Account) and another for transactions such as interest on capital, interest on drawings, salary, profit, and loss (Current Account).

 

Statement II: Under Fixed Capital Account method, the balance of the capital account varies from year to year.

 

This statement is not correct. In the Fixed Capital Account method, the balance of the Capital Account remains fixed unless there are changes due to additional contributions, withdrawals, or adjustments. The balance does not vary from year to year as implied in Statement II.

Question 18
Which of the following is NOTa feature of a Company?
  • A.It has Artificial Legal Person
  • B.There is no common Seal
  • C.Its life doesn’t depend on the life of its shareholders, directors, or employees
  • D.A company has a distinct entity and is independent of its members or people controlling it.
Correct Answer: There is no common Seal

The correct answer is option B.

 

The Companies Act 2013 of India defines a company as:

 

“A registered association which is an artificial legal person, having an independent legal entity with perpetual succession, a common seal for its signatures, a common capital comprised of transferable shares, and carrying limited liability.”

 

Features & Characteristics of a Company:

 

Incorporated association: A company comes into existence when it is registered under the Companies Act (or other equivalent act under the law). It must fulfill requirements in terms of documents (MOA, AOA), shareholders, directors, and share capital to be deemed as a legal association.

 

Artificial Legal Person: A company is recognized as an artificial legal person in the eyes of the law. It has the rights to acquire or dispose of property, enter into contracts in its own name, and sue and be sued by others.

 

Separate Legal Entity: A company has a distinct entity and is independent of its members or people controlling it. This means that only the company is responsible for repaying creditors and can be sued for its actions. Individual members cannot be sued for actions performed by the company, and the company is not liable to pay personal debts of the members.

 

Perpetual Existence: A company's existence is not dependent on the life of its shareholders, directors, or employees. While members may change, the company continues to exist indefinitely.

 

Common Seal: A company uses its common seal, bearing the company's name engraved on it, as a substitute for its signature. Any document with the common seal is legally binding on the company.

 

Limited Liability: A company may be limited by guarantee or limited by shares. In a company limited by shares, shareholders' liability is limited to the unpaid value of their shares. In a company limited by guarantee, members' liability is limited to the amount they agreed to contribute to the company's assets in the event of winding up.

Question 19
Which of the following isNOTa type of ResponsibilityCenters?
  • A.CostCenter
  • B.RevenueCenter
  • C.ProfitCenter
  • D.ProcessCenter
Correct Answer: ProcessCenter

Responsibility Center

A responsibility center is an organizational unit headed by a manager, who is responsible for its activities and results. In responsibility accounting, revenues and cost information are collected and reported on by responsibility centers. Following are the main types of responsibility centers for management control:

1) Cost Center

2) Revenue Center

3) Profit Center

4) Investment Center

Question 20
Which of the following isNOTa Technique of InflationAccounting?
  • A.Replacement Cost Accounting
  • B.Current Cost
  • C.Hybrid Technique
  • D.Managerial Accounting
Correct Answer: Managerial Accounting

The correct answer is option (D) Managerial Accounting.

 

Inflation Accounting refers to the methods used to adjust financial statements to account for the effects of inflation. It aims to provide more accurate and meaningful information to users of financial statements during periods of high inflation. The techniques commonly used in inflation accounting include:

 

(A) Replacement Cost Accounting: This technique involves valuing assets and liabilities at their current replacement cost rather than their historical cost. It helps reflect the true economic value of assets and liabilities in an inflationary environment.

 

(B) Current Cost: Similar to replacement cost accounting, current cost accounting values assets and liabilities at their current market prices or costs. This method provides a more accurate reflection of the current value of assets and liabilities compared to historical cost accounting.

 

(C) Hybrid Technique: This technique combines elements of replacement cost accounting and current cost accounting to address the limitations of each method. It may involve using replacement cost for some assets and current cost for others, depending on the nature of the assets and the specific circumstances of the company.

Question 21
What does COBIT mean under System Audit?
  • A.Central Organization for Intelligence and Technologies
  • B.Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies
  • C.Control Objectives for Information and Revenue Technologies
  • D.Control Organization for Information and Technologies
Correct Answer: Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies

The correct answer is option (B) – Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies.

 

COBIT, which stands for Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies, is a framework used in system audits. Developed by the Information Systems Audit and Control Association (ISACA), COBIT provides a structured approach to managing enterprise IT and ensuring its alignment with business goals.

Question 22
Which of the following is not an exception of ‘Law of Demand’?
  • A.Veblen goods
  • B.Giffengoods
  • C.Premium goods
  • D.Exceptions of further price rise in future
Correct Answer: Premium goods

The correct answer is option (C) – Premium goods.

 

The Law of Demand states that, all other factors being equal, as the price of a good or service increases, the quantity demanded for that good or service decreases, and vice versa.

 

Exceptions to the Law of Demand are cases where the typical inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded does not hold. Here's a brief explanation of each option:

 

(A) Veblen goods: Veblen goods are luxury goods that experience an increase in demand as their price rises. This contradicts the Law of Demand because, for most goods, demand decreases as price increases.

 

(B) Giffen goods: Giffen goods are inferior goods for which demand increases as the price increases. This is because the income effect outweighs the substitution effect, leading consumers to buy more of the good despite its higher price.

 

(C) Premium goods: This option is incorrect. "Premium goods" is not a recognized exception to the Law of Demand. Premium goods typically refer to high-quality, high-priced goods that appeal to consumers willing to pay a premium for superior quality or features.

 

(D) Exceptions of further price rise in future: This option is also incorrect. It refers to situations where consumers may anticipate future price increases and therefore increase their demand for a good now to avoid paying higher prices later. However, this behavior still aligns with the Law of Demand, as it involves an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded.

Question 23
Match the followingList – II. Normal ProfitII. Economic profitIII. Accounting profitList – IIa.remaining surplus left after deducting total costs from total revenue.b.net income of the company earned during a particular accounting yearc.least amount of profit needed for its survival.
  • A.i-a, ii-b, iii-c
  • B.i-b, ii-c, iii-a
  • C.i-b, ii-a, iii-c
  • D.i-c, ii-a, iii-b
Correct Answer: i-c, ii-a, iii-b

Different types of profits are distinguished based on their calculation methods and economic implications:

 

Accounting Profit: This is the net income of a company earned during a specific accounting period. It is calculated as Total Revenue minus Total Explicit Costs, which include all direct expenses incurred by the firm.

 

Economic Profit: Economic profit represents the remaining surplus after deducting both explicit and implicit costs from total revenue. Implicit costs are the opportunity costs of using resources that the firm already owns rather than selling them in the market.

 

Normal Profit: Normal profit refers to the minimum amount of profit needed for a firm's survival. It occurs when a firm's total revenue equals its total costs, both explicit and implicit. In other words, normal profit ensures that a business covers all its costs and earns a competitive return on investment.

Question 24
Consider the following.Assertions‘A’: As the proportion of one variable factor in a combination with fixed factor is increased, after a point the marginal product of the factor will diminish.Reason‘R’: Beyond the level of optimum combination of inputs this happens.
  • A.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • B.A is incorrect but R is correct.
  • C.A and R both are correct but R is not right explanation of A.
  • D.A and R both are correct and R is right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: A and R both are correct but R is not right explanation of A.

The Law of Variable Proportion state that as the quantity of one factor is increased, keeping the other factors fixed, the marginal product of that factor will eventually decline. This means that up to the use of a certain amount of variable factor, marginal product of the factor may increase and after a certain stage it starts diminishing. This diminishing stage will occur beyond the optimum combination of inputs. When the variable factor becomes relatively abundant, the marginal product may become negative.

Question 25
Which of the following is/are NOT characteristics of perfect competition market?a. large number of sellersb. small number of buyersc. products are heterogeneousd. no entry and exit barriers
  • A.a & b
  • B.b & c
  • C.only b
  • D.only d
Correct Answer: b & c

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Features of perfect competition are:

1. Large number of firms (sellers)

2. Large number of buyers

3. The product is homogeneous 

4. No barriers to entry or exit 

5. Complete information 

6. Profit maximization

 

In a perfectly competitive market, since there are a large number of buyers and sellers, no particular buyer or seller has any significant impact on the market.

Question 26
Penetration pricing strategy is appropriate when:
  • A.Price elasticity demand in the market is highly elastic
  • B.Price elasticity of demand in the market is uncertain
  • C.Price elasticity of demand in the market is highly elastic
  • D.Income elasticity of demand in the market is negatively elastic
Correct Answer: Price elasticity of demand in the market is highly elastic

Penetration pricing is a pricing strategy where the price of a product is initially set low to rapidly reach a wide fraction of the market and initiate word of mouth. The strategy works on the expectation that customers will switch to the new brand because of the lower price. It is a suitable pricing strategy for the markets where price elasticity of demand is highly elastic.

Question 27
Match the following:List – Ia. Increasing marginal opportunity costb. Ratio of price of two goodsc. Diminishing marginal rate of substitutiond. Constant MU of moneyList – II1. Cardinal utility analysis2. Indifference curve3. Budget line4. Production possibility curve
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1
  • C.a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2
  • D.a-3, b-4, c-2, d-1
Correct Answer: a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

Option B is the correct answer.

 

a) Indifference Curve, IC- Indifference cure is the curve which shows the combination of two goods which provides same level of satisfaction to the consumer. Slope of the IC is marginal rate of substitution. Generally, IC is convex to origin due to diminishing marginal rate of substitution.

 

b) Budget Line- It’s a line which show the combination of two goods which a buyer can buy with his given income. Slope of the budget line is the ratio of the prices of the two commodities, i.e. Px/Py.

 

c) Production Possibility Curve- It’s a curve which shows the combination of two goods which a producer can produce with the given resources and technology. Marginal opportunity cost (MOC) is the slope of the PPC. PPC is concave to origin due to increasing MOC.

 

d) The Cardinal Utility Approach - Provides an explanation of consumer’s demand for a product and derives the law of demand, which establishes an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded of a product. Assumptions are:

1) Rationality

2) Limited Resources (Money)

3) Maximize Satisfaction

4) Utility is cardinally Measurable

5) Diminishing Marginal Utility

6) Marginal Utility of Money is Constant

7) Utility is Additive

Question 28
Consider the following statements:Statement I:Business Economics is a science.Statement II:Business Economics is Interdisciplinary in nature.
  • A.Statement I is Correct and Statement II is Incorrect.
  • B.Statement II is Correct and Statement I is Incorrect.
  • C.Statement I and II both are correct.
  • D.Statement I and II both are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Statement I and II both are correct.

Business Economics is a Science: Science is a systematized body of knowledge which establishes cause and effect relationships. Business Economics integrates the tools of decision sciences such as Mathematics, Statistics and Econometrics with Economic Theory to arrive at appropriate strategies for achieving the goals of the business enterprises. It follows scientific methods and empirically tests the validity of the results.

 

Interdisciplinary in nature: Business Economics is interdisciplinary in nature as it incorporates tools from other disciplines such as Mathematics, Operations Research, Management Theory, Accounting, Marketing, Finance, Statistics and Econometrics.

Question 29
Normally the demand curve slopes_____________.
  • A.Upward
  • B.Downward
  • C.Horizontal
  • D.Vertical
Correct Answer: Downward

The demand curve is a graphical representation of the relationship between the price of a good or service and the quantity demanded for a given period of time. It is due to this law of demand that demand curve slopes downward to the right. When price fall the quantity demanded of a commodity rises and vice versa, other things remaining the same.

Question 30
Who propounded the concept of Consumer’s Surplus?
  • A.Leon Walrus
  • B.CarlMenger
  • C.Alfred Marshall
  • D.J R Hicks
Correct Answer: Alfred Marshall

The concept of consumer’s surplus was propounded by Alfred Marshall. He defined the concept of consumer’s surplus as the “excess of the price which a consumer would be willing to pay rather than go without a thing over that which he actually does pay”, is called consumer’s surplus.”

 

Thus consumer’s surplus = what a consumer is ready to pay – what he actually pays.

Question 31
Short- Run average cost curves are also known as________.
  • A.Plant Curves
  • B.Tree Curves
  • C.U-Shape Curve
  • D.Envelope Curve
Correct Answer: Plant Curves

The Short-run Average Cost curves (SACs) are also called ‘plant curves’. In the short run, the firm can be operating on any short run average cost curve, given the size of the plant. Suppose that there are only three plants which are technically possible. Given the size of the plant, the firm will be increasing or decreasing its output by changing the amount of the variable inputs. But in the long run, the firm chooses among the three possible sizes of plants as depicted by short run average curves (SAC1, SAC2, and SAC3).

Question 32
Which of the following is/are the types of Production Function?
  • A.Leontief
  • B.Constant elasticity substitution
  • C.Cobb-Douglas
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

The correct answer is option (D) – All of the Above.

 

Production functions describe the relationship between inputs and outputs in the production process. Different types of production functions capture various relationships between inputs, such as labor and capital, and the resulting output. Here's an explanation of each type mentioned:

 

Leontief Production Function: This type of production function assumes fixed proportions of inputs with no substitutability between them. In a Leontief production function, inputs are used in a fixed ratio, and there is no possibility of substituting one input for another. An example would be the relationship between tires and batteries in automobile production, where the two inputs are used together in a fixed proportion.

 

Constant Elasticity of Substitution (CES) Production Function: In this type of production function, inputs are considered perfect substitutes. The CES production function shows a constant rate of change in output in response to changes in input. It allows for the substitution of one input for another at a constant rate. For example, natural gas and fuel oil can be considered close substitutes in energy production.

 

Cobb-Douglas Production Function: The Cobb-Douglas production function allows for the substitution of one input for another, but to a limited extent. It demonstrates diminishing returns to scale, meaning that as one input is increased while holding others constant, and the additional output generated decreases over time. An example would be the substitution of capital for labor in production processes, where increasing the amount of capital relative to labor eventually leads to diminishing returns.

 

These types of production functions provide insights into the nature of production processes and how inputs are combined to produce output.

Question 33
Which of the following is /are the objective(s) of financial management?
  • A.Profit maximization
  • B.Wealth maximization
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Objectives of financial management may be broadly divided into two parts:

 

Profit maximization: Main aim of any kind of economic activity is earning profit. Profit is used to measure the efficiency of the business. Profit maximization is also the traditional and narrow approach, which aims at, maximizes the profit of the concern by any means.

 

Wealth maximization: Wealth maximization is one of the modern approaches, which involves latest innovations and improvements in the field of the business concern. The term wealth means shareholder wealth or the wealth of the persons those who are involved in the business concern. Wealth maximization is also known as value maximization or net present worth maximization. Wealth maximization is superior to the profit maximization because the main aim of the business concern under this concept is to improve the value (earning per share) or wealth of all the shareholders and not just increase profits.

Question 34
Which one of the following is NOTa short term debt that can be sold in money market?
  • A.Treasury bills
  • B.Certificate of deposit
  • C.Commercial paper
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The Money Market is where financial instruments with high liquidity and very short maturities are traded. It is used by participants as a means for borrowing and lending in the short term, with maturities that usually range from overnight to just under a year.


Important money market instruments include: Eurodollar deposits, Negotiable certificates of deposit (CD), Bankers' acceptances, U.S. treasury bills, Commercial paper, Municipal notes, Federal funds and Repurchase agreements (repos).

 

The most common money market instruments in India are: Treasury bills, Certificate of deposits, Commercial papers, Repurchase agreements and Banker's acceptance.

Question 35
Match the items of list-II with the items of list-I and select the correct matching.List-I(a) Liquidity risk(b) Financial risk(c) Exchange risk(d) Default riskList-II(i) Refers to the chance that the firm will be unable to recover its dues from its debtors.(ii) Refers to the possibility of adverse effect on firm’s assets, liabilities and income due to movement of interest rates.(iii) Refers to the firm’s inability to pay its dues towards creditors.(iv) Refers to the inability of the firm to meet its financial obligations on time owing to non-availability of ready cash.
  • A.i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
  • B.i-a, iii-b, iv-c, ii-d
  • C.iv-a, iii-b, ii-c,i-d
  • D.iv-a, iii-b,i-c, ii-d
Correct Answer: iv-a, iii-b, ii-c,i-d

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Types of risk:

 

Business or Liquidity Risk: business risk is also known as liquidity risk. It is so, since it emanates (originates) from the sale and purchase of securities affected by business cycles, technological changes, etc.

 

Financial Risk: It arises due to change in the capital structure of the organization. The capital structure mainly comprises of three ways by which funds are sourced for the projects.

 

Foreign-exchange risk: when investing in foreign countries you must consider the fact that currency exchange rates can change the price of the asset as well. Foreign-exchange risk applies to all financial instruments that are in a currency other than your domestic currency. As an example, if you are a resident of America and invest in some Canadian stock in Canadian dollars, even if the share value appreciates, you may lose money if the Canadian dollar depreciates in relation to the American dollar.

Credit or default risk: credit risk is the risk that a company or individual will be unable to pay the contractual interest or principal on its debt obligations.

Question 36
According to the CAPM model, the cost of equity,Keis represented by:(Where Rmindicates market rate of return,Rfindicates risk free rate of return andβindicates Beta.)
  • A.Ke=RfRm-Rfxβ
  • B.Ke=Rf+Rm-Rfxβ
  • C.Ke=Rf+Rm+Rfxβ
  • D.Ke=Rf-Rm-Rfxβ
Correct Answer: Ke=Rf+Rm-Rfxβ

The capital asset pricing model (CAPM) is a model that describes the relationship between systematic risk and expected return for assets. The CAPM Model says that the expected return of a security or a portfolio equals the rate on a risk-free security plus a risk premium. If this expected return does not meet or beat the required return, then the investment should not be undertaken. The security market line plots the results of the CAPM for all different risks (betas).

Question 37
Match the correct option for each of the following approaches of capital structure theories:List-IA. The net income approachB. The net operating income approachC. The Modigliani & Miller proposition – ID. The pecking order theoryList-IIi. The market value of the firm is not affected by changes in the capital structureii. Declining weighted-average cost of capitaliii. The firms prefer to rely on internal accruals followed by debt finance and external financeiv. The value of the firm depends on the earnings and risk of its assets rather than the way the assets have been financed.
  • A.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
  • B.a-iv, b-ii, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii

The correct answer is option C.

 

Net Income Approach:

The net income approach, proposed by Durand, asserts that changes in the capital structure influence the firm's overall cost of capital and total value. It assumes no corporate taxes and that debt is cheaper than equity due to tax deductibility. Therefore, increasing debt can lower the overall cost of capital and increase the firm's value.

 

Net Operating Income Approach:

This approach suggests that the value of a firm is unaffected by changes in its capital structure. It maintains that increasing leverage also increases risk, leading to higher expected returns for equity shareholders. The overall capitalization rate remains constant regardless of leverage levels.

 

Modigliani & Miller Proposition – I:

Modigliani and Miller's proposition, in a perfect capital market without taxes, states that a firm's market value is not influenced by its capital structure. It emphasizes that the value of a firm depends on the earnings and risk of its assets, rather than how those assets are financed.

 

Pecking Order Theory:

The pecking order theory suggests that firms prioritize financing sources based on asymmetric information. They prefer internal funds first, then debt, and lastly equity. Equity issuance is considered less favorable because it may signal to investors that the firm is overvalued, leading to a lower valuation of new equity shares.

Question 38
Which of the following project appraisal method is/are NOTbased on time value of money?(a) Payback method(b) Net Present Value method(c) Internal Rate of Return method(d) Accounting Rate of Return
  • A.Only a
  • B.a and d
  • C.a and b
  • D.b and c
Correct Answer: a and d

The correct answer is option (B) – a and d.

 

The project appraisal methods that are not based on the time value of money are the Payback method and the Accounting Rate of Return.

 

a. Payback Method: The Payback method calculates the time it takes for a project to recoup its initial investment. It does not consider the time value of money, as it focuses solely on the time it takes to recover the initial investment, ignoring the timing and value of cash flows beyond the payback period.

 

d. Accounting Rate of Return (ARR): The Accounting Rate of Return method determines the average accounting profit earned from an investment over its lifespan, typically expressed as a percentage of the initial investment. It does not consider the time value of money, as it relies on accounting profits rather than discounted cash flows.

Question 39
The Economic Order Quantity for Inventory Management, was replicated to Cash Management. The optimal cash 'C' can be calculated as follows:
  • A.C =2XannualcashrequirementXfixedcostpertranscationopportunitycostofholdingcash
  • B.C =annualcashrequirementXfixedcostpertranscationopportunitycostofholdingcash
  • C.C =2XdailycashrequirementXfixedcostpertranscationopportunitycostofholdingcash
  • D.C =dailycashrequirementXfixedcostpertranscationopportunitycostofholdingcash
Correct Answer: C =2XannualcashrequirementXfixedcostpertranscationopportunitycostofholdingcash

The Economic Order Quantity (EOQ) model, commonly used in inventory management, helps determine the optimal order quantity that minimizes total inventory costs. Similarly, in cash management, the optimal cash balance 'C' can be calculated using a similar formula.

 

The formula for calculating the optimal cash balance 'C' is:

C = 2  X annual cash requirement X  fixed cost per transcation opportunity cost of holding cash 

 

Here's what each component of the formula represents:

 

Annual cash requirement: The total cash needed for operations over a year.

Fixed cost per transaction: The cost incurred for each cash transaction, such as withdrawal or deposit.

Opportunity cost of holding cash: The cost associated with holding cash, such as the potential return that could be earned if the cash were invested elsewhere.

 

The formula calculates the optimal cash balance by balancing the costs of holding cash (opportunity cost) with the costs of cash transactions (fixed cost per transaction). By minimizing the total cost, the organization can efficiently manage its cash flow.

Question 40
The degree to which the value of future cash transactions can be affected by exchange rate fluctuations is referred to as:
  • A.Economic exposure
  • B.Transaction exposure
  • C.Translation exposure
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Transaction exposure

Foreign exchange exposure can be classified into three broad categories:

 

Transaction exposure: transaction exposure is the risk of loss from a change in exchange rates during the course of a business transaction. This exposure is derived from changes in foreign exchange rates between the dates when a transaction is booked and when it is settled.

 

The basic rules for transaction exposure are:

Importing goods. When a business is importing goods and its home currency weakens, the firm incurs a loss. If the home currency strengthens, it experiences a gain.

Exporting goods. When a business is exporting goods and its home currency weakens, the firm experiences a gain. If the home currency strengthens, it incurs a loss.

When an organization does not want to run the risk of incurring a loss related to transaction exposure, it can adopt a hedging strategy, where it enters into a forward rate agreement, thereby locking in the current exchange rate.

Question 41
The process of arbitrage, applied to foreign exchange and international money markets, takes 3 common forms, which are listed below, EXCEPT:
  • A.Locational arbitrage
  • B.Triangular arbitrage
  • C.Direct arbitrage
  • D.Covered interest arbitrage
Correct Answer: Direct arbitrage

Arbitrage can be loosely defined as capitalizing on a discrepancy in quoted prices by making a riskless profit. In many cases, the strategy does not require an investment of funds to be tied up for a length of time and does not involve any risk. The type of arbitrage discussed here is primarily international in scope; it is applied to foreign exchange and international money markets and takes three common forms: (a) Locational arbitrage (b) Triangular arbitrage (c) Covered interest arbitrage

Question 42
Which one of the following is not one of measures of central tendency?
  • A.Arithmetic Average
  • B.Standard Deviation
  • C.Median
  • D.Mode
Correct Answer: Standard Deviation

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Following are the measures of average or central tendency:

(i) Arithmetic Average or Arithmetic Mean or Simple Mean

(ii) Median

(iii) Mode

(iv) Geometric mean and Harmonic mean

(v) Quartiles, Deciles and Percentile

 

Following are measures of Dispersion:

(i) Range

(ii) Mean Deviation

(iii) Standard Deviation

Question 43
Match the items of List - I with those of List - II and choose the correct code:List - I(a) The probability of two events occurring together or in succession(b) The probability of occurring one event given that another event has occurred(c) The probability of occurrence of a single event(d) The probability revised in the light of additional informationList - II(i) MarginalProbability(ii) Posterior Probability(iii) SubjectiveProbability(iv) JointProbability(v) ConditionalProbability
  • A.a-iv, b-v, c-i, d-iii
  • B.a-v, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-v, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • D.a-iv, b-v, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-v, c-i, d-ii

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Conditional Probability: Probability of an event or outcome based on the occurrence of a previous event or outcome. Conditional probability is calculated by multiplying the probability of the preceding event by the updated probability of the succeeding event.

 

Joint Probability: A joint probability is a statistical measure where the likelihood of two events occurring together and at the same point in time are calculated. Joint probability is the probability of event Y occurring at the same time event X occurs.

 

Posterior Probability: The revised probability of an event occurring after taking into consideration new information. Posterior probability is normally calculated by updating the prior probability by using Bayes' theorem. In statistical terms, the posterior probability is the probability of event A occurring given that event B has occurred.

 

Unconditional Probability (marginal probability): The probability that an event will occur, not contingent on any prior or related results. An unconditional probability is the independent chance that a single outcome results from a sample of possible outcomes. To find the unconditional probability of an event, sum the outcomes of the event and divide by the total number of possible outcomes.

 

Subjective probability: Subjective probability is a probability derived from an individual's personal judgment about whether a specific outcome is likely to occur. It contains no formal calculations and only reflects the subject's opinions and past experience.

Question 44
The assumptions of BinomialProbability distribution are listed below. Which of the following is not correct?
  • A.The experiment consists of N repeated trials. Each trial can result in just two possible outcomes. We call one of these outcomes a success and the other, a failure.
  • B.The probability of success, denoted by p, is the same on every trial.
  • C.The trials are independent; that is, the outcome on one trial does not affect the outcome on other trials.
  • D.None of Above
Correct Answer: None of Above

Binomial Distribution is discrete probability distribution. Any uncertain situation or experiment that is marked by the following properties is known as binomial probability distribution:

1. The experiment consists of N repeated trials.

2. Each trial can result in just two possible outcomes. We call one of these outcomes a success and the other, a failure.

3. The probability of success, denoted by p, is the same on every trial.

4. The trials are independent; that is, the outcome on one trial does not affect the outcome on other trials.

 

If properties 2, 3, and 4 are present, we say the trials are generated by a Bernoulli process. If, in addition, property 1 is present, we say we have a Binomial experiment.

Question 45
Arrange the following steps of research in correct order.1. Identify the Problem2. Define Terms and Concepts3. Review the Literature4. Collect Data5. Clarify the Problem6. Define the Population7. Develop the Instrumentation Plan8.Analyzethe DataSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.1, 2, 4, 3, 7, 6, 5, 8
  • B.1, 2, 4, 7, 5, 3, 6, 8
  • C.1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • D.1, 3, 5, 2, 6, 7, 4, 8
Correct Answer: 1, 3, 5, 2, 6, 7, 4, 8

There are 8 steps of a research process:

Step 1: Identify the Problem: The first step in the process is to identify a problem or develop a research question.

Step 2: Review the Literature: Now that the problem has been identified, the researcher must learn more about the topic under investigation. To do this, the researcher must review the literature related to the research problem.

Step 3: Clarify the Problem: Many times the initial problem identified in the first step of the process is too large or broad in scope. In step 3 of the process, the researcher clarifies the problem and narrows the scope of the study.

Step 4: Define Terms and Concepts: Terms and concepts are words or phrases used in the purpose statement of the study or the description of the study. These items need to be specifically defined as they apply to the study.

Step 5: Define the Population: Research projects can focus on a specific group of people, facilities, park development, employee evaluations, programs, financial status, marketing efforts, or the integration of technology into the operations.

Step 6: Develop the Instrumentation Plan: The plan for the study is referred to as the instrumentation plan. The instrumentation plan serves as the road map for the entire study, specifying who will participate in the study; how, when, and where data will be collected; and the content of the program.

Step 7: Collect Data: Once the instrumentation plan is completed, the actual study begins with the collection of data. The collection of data is a critical step in providing the information needed to answer the research question.

Step 8: Analyze the Data: The researcher finally has data to analyze so that the research question can be answered. Finally the report is written.

Question 46
Which of the following options is NOTa type of non-sampling error?
  • A.Enumerator’s bias in recording
  • B.Random Sampling fluctuations
  • C.Recording incorrect data
  • D.Errors in data processing
Correct Answer: Random Sampling fluctuations

All options except option B is a type of a non-sampling error. A non- sampling errors are systematic biases that may not be a function of the sample chosen. Sampling fluctuations that are random in nature are a type of sampling error.

Question 47
Which of the following is a type of non-probability sampling?
  • A.Cluster sampling
  • B.Stratified sampling
  • C.Systematic sampling
  • D.Snowball sampling
Correct Answer: Snowball sampling

Snowball sampling is a type of non-probability sampling method where existing study subjects recruit future subjects from among their acquaintances. It is often used in cases where the population of interest is hard to locate or access directly, such as marginalized or hidden populations.

 

In snowball sampling:

  • The initial participants are chosen based on convenience or accessibility.
  • These participants then refer other potential participants, who in turn refer more participants, creating a chain or "snowball" effect.

The sample size grows as more participants are added to the study through referrals.

Question 48
Which of the following is true about the ‘Chi-square’ test statistic?1. Its value can never be negative2. It can be used as a parametric and non-parametric test3. The results from Chi-square test statistic and F-test statistic are identical.4. It has a mean of 0 and variance 1
  • A.Option 1, 4
  • B.Only option 1
  • C.Option 1, 2
  • D.Only option 3
Correct Answer: Option 1, 2

Let us consider the expression of Chi-Square test statistic –

χ2=∑Oi-Ei2Ei.

Since all values are positive in numerator and denominator, Chi-square test statistic will never be negative. However, it can be zero. Also, it is used as a parametric and non-parametric test.
It doesn’t have a mean of 0 and variance – Recall that was the case with standard normal distribution. Also, the results from Chi-square test statistic and F-test statistic cannot identical since both are used for a different purpose.

Question 49
The p-value of a test statistic is 0.08. Based on this information, what can we say about the rejecting null hypothesis (Ho):
  • A.Hocan be rejected at 10% level of significanceonly
  • B.Hocan be rejected at 10% and 15% level of significance
  • C.Hocan be rejected at 5%only
  • D.Hocan be rejected at 5% and 10% level of significance
Correct Answer: Hocan be rejected at 10% and 15% level of significance

The rule of thumb is that if p-value is less than level of significance then we reject the null hypothesis. Thus, we can reject Ho at both 10% and 15% level of significance. But, it cannot be rejected at 5%.

Question 50
Which of the following statements is/are true in case of a simple linear regression model?1. R-square represents the percentage variation in dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable2. The correlation coefficient cannot be calculated using R-square3. There is no difference between Coefficient of determination and correlation coefficient.4. The slope coefficient is interpreted as the change in dependent variable when the independent variable changes by 1 unit.
  • A.1, 2 are true
  • B.1, 2, 3 are true
  • C.1, 4 are true
  • D.Only 1 is true
Correct Answer: 1, 4 are true

Statement 1 is definition of R square. Hence it's true.

 

Statement 2 is FALSE. In simple linear regression, correlation coefficient can be calculated using R-square. Correlation coefficient =R Square. This is however not true in multiple linear regression.

 

Statement 3 is FALSE. Correlation coefficient simply tells us about the strength of linear relationship between two variables. Coefficient of determination (or, R-square) tells us the percentage variation in dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression model.

Statement 4 is true as it is the definition of marginal effect of the independent variable.

Question 51
The Spearman rank-correlation coefficient ranges from:
  • A.0 to 1
  • B.-1 to +1
  • C.Any value
  • D.Always positive (excluding zero)
Correct Answer: -1 to +1

The Spearman rank-correlation coefficient ranges from -1.0 to +1.0 and its interpretation is similar to the Pearson product moment correlation coefficient for quantitative data. The Spearman rank-correlation coefficient provides the same value that is obtained by using the Pearson product moment correlation coefficient procedure with the rank-ordered data.

 

In both cases, a rank-correlation coefficient near +1.0 indicates a strong positive association between the ranks for the two variables, while a rank-correlation coefficient near -1.0 indicates a strong negative association between the ranks for the two variables. A rank-correlation coefficient of 0 indicates no association between the ranks for the two variables.

Question 52
Who defined5functions, or elements of Management as Planning, Organizing, Commanding, Coordinating, and Controlling?
  • A.Henri Fayol
  • B.Mintzberg
  • C.M P Follett
  • D.Warren Haynes
Correct Answer: Henri Fayol

Henri Fayol was the first person to identify elements or functions of management in his classic 1916 book 'Administration Industrielleet Generale'. Fayol was the managing director of a large French coal-mining firm and based his book largely on his experiences as a practitioner of management. Fayol defined five functions, or elements of management: Planning, Organizing, Commanding, Coordinating, and Controlling. Fayol argued that these functions were universal, in the sense that all managers performed them in the course of their jobs, whether the managers worked in business, military, government, religious, or philanthropic undertakings.

Question 53
Which of the following is not one of 5 stages of progression of Conflict?
  • A.Latent Conflict
  • B.Felt Conflict
  • C.Perceived Conflict
  • D.None of Above
Correct Answer: None of Above

There are 5 stages in a conflict:

 

(i) Latent Conflict: The first stage of conflict is latent conflict in which the factors that could become a cause of potential conflict exist. These are drive for autonomy, divergence of goals, role conflict and the competition for scarce resources.

 

(ii) Perceived conflict: Sometimes a conflict arises even if no latent conflict is present. In this stage one party perceived the others to be likely to thwart or frustrate his or her goals. The case, in which conflict is perceived when no latent conflict arises, is used to result from the parties misunderstanding each other’s true position.


(iii) Felt Conflict: Felt conflict is the stage when the conflict is not only perceived but actually felt and cognized.

 

(iv) Manifest Conflict: Manifest conflict is the stage when the two parties engage in behavior which evokes response from each other. The most obvious of these responses are open aggression, apathy, sabotage, withdrawal and perfect obedience to rules.

 

(v) Conflict Aftermath: The aftermath of a conflict may have positive or negative repercussion for the organization depending upon the how conflict is resolved. If the conflict is genuinely resolved to the satisfaction of all participants, the basis for more cooperative relationship may be laid or the participants in their drive for a more ordered relationship may focus on latent conflicts not previously perceived and dealt with. On the other hand, if the conflict is merely suppressed but not resolved, the latent conditions of conflict may be aggravated and explode in a more serious from until they are rectified. This conflict episode is called conflict aftermath.

Question 54
Arrange the following manpower procedure in the correct sequence:(i) Estimating Manpower Requirements(ii) Selection(iii) Recruitment(iv) Performance Appraisal(v) Orientation
  • A.(i), (iii), (ii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii), (v), (iv)
  • C.(i), (iii), (ii), (v), (iv)
  • D.(ii), (iii), (i), (v), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (ii), (v), (iv)

The correct sequence is option (C) – (i), (iii), (ii), (v), (iv).

 

Estimating Manpower Requirements: This involves assessing the organization's manpower needs by considering factors such as the type and number of employees required. Workload and workforce analyses help determine the optimal staffing levels.

 

Recruitment: The process of searching for and attracting potential employees through various sources, evaluating these sources, and inviting applications for vacant positions.

 

Selection: Involves choosing the most suitable candidates for the job through preliminary screening, tests, interviews, reference checks, and other evaluation methods.

 

Placement and Orientation: Placement involves assigning selected employees to suitable positions based on their skills and abilities, while orientation familiarizes them with the organization, its policies, procedures, and their roles.

 

Performance Appraisal: Assessing employees' job performance to identify strengths, weaknesses, and areas for improvement. This evaluation helps in providing feedback, training, and making decisions regarding promotions or other actions.

Question 55
Which is a system designed to achieve organizational effectiveness by steering each employees'behaviortowards the organization's mission by using a combination of goal setting, planning & evaluation activities?
  • A.Behaviour basedModeling
  • B.Management Accounting
  • C.Management by Objectives
  • D.Behaviour Observation method
Correct Answer: Management by Objectives

Management by objectives (MBO) is a process of defining objectives within an organization so that management and employees agree to the objectives and understand what they need to do in the organization in order to achieve them. The term "management by objectives" was first popularized by Peter Drucker in his 1954 book 'The Practice of Management'.

Question 56
The concept of Human relations was developed by:
  • A.Robert Owen
  • B.F W Taylor
  • C.Elton Mayo
  • D.Max Weber
Correct Answer: Elton Mayo

Elton Mayo is considered the founder of the Human Relations Theory.

 

Elton Mayo and his assistants, including Fritz Roetlishberger, conducted research into changing working conditions at Hawthorne plants.

 

They experimented with light, duration of breaks and working hours. A group of women were exposed to either more or less light. It turned out that, regardless of the amount and duration of lighting, this had a positive effect on their performances. The same was true for rest periods; shorter or longer breaks both led to an increase in labour productivity.

 

The conclusion drawn from the Hawthorne research was that giving attention to employees resulted in improved performances.

Question 57
Which of the following is not an “on the job” training method?
  • A.Job Instruction Technique
  • B.Job Rotation
  • C.Coaching
  • D.Vestibule Training
Correct Answer: Vestibule Training

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The List of "On the Job" trainings is:

  • Coaching
  • Mentoring
  • Job Rotation
  • Job Instruction Technique (JIT)
  • Apprenticeship
