The list of "Off the Job" trainings is:

  • Vestibule Training
  • Sensitivity Training (T-Group)
  • Transactional Analysis
  • Classroom Lecture
  • Programmed Learning or Programmed instruction
  • Simulation Exercises: (Management Games, Case Study, Role Playing, In Basket Training)
Question 58
Which of the following is NOTa type of Personality Assessment Test?
  • A.Myers–Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI)
  • B.Bloomberg Aptitude Test
  • C.Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI)
  • D.Thematic Apperception Test
Correct Answer: Bloomberg Aptitude Test

The Bloomberg Aptitude Test (BAT) falls under the category of Aptitude Tests, which measure an individual's capacity to learn specific skills or perform certain jobs with appropriate training. Aptitude tests can assess general mental ability or intelligence, as well as specific aptitudes like mechanical or clerical skills. Other examples of aptitude tests include the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB) and psychomotor tests, which evaluate manual dexterity and motor abilities. Therefore, option (B) is not a type of Personality Assessment Test.

Question 59
What of the following is not one of four psychological sub-processes in ethical action given by James Rest?
  • A.Moral sensitivity
  • B.Moral judgement
  • C.Moral focus
  • D.Moral thinking
Correct Answer: Moral thinking

Moral Development Theory of James Rest

James Rest's studies center directly on moral development in the context of formal education. The four component model suggests various inner psychological processes, which together give way to observable behavior.

 

1. Moral Sensitivity: The first component of the process starts with a recognition that a moral problem or opportunity exists.

 

2. Moral Judgment: The second component of the model is moral judgment. It involves the individual making a judgment concerning which course of action is morally right and which course of action is morally wrong.

 

3. Moral Focus (Moral Intention): The third component of the model is moral focus. This one is also known as moral intention which involves the individual prioritizing choices in response to a given situation.

 

4. Moral Character: The final component of the model is moral character. This component involves executing and implementing a morally-based course of action. During this stage, individuals carry out their intentions by keeping the goals and outcomes of their chosen course of action in mind.

Question 60
Departmentalization is:a. structuring work to accomplish organizational goalsb. visual display of organization structurec. grouping of jobs on some basisd. arranging jobs in a hierarchy
  • A.a and b only
  • B.b and c only
  • C.aonly
  • D.c only
Correct Answer: c only

Departmentalization is the process of grouping the activities (tasks) to be performed into an organisation's unit to accomplish some common purpose. Departmentalization is therefore, the creating of a number of subunits, usually called department. The method or methods used to divide the work of the entire organisation should reflect the grouping that would contribute to the attainment of the organisational objectives and the goals of individual units.

 

The five types of departmentalization are: functional, product, customer, geographical and process.

(1) Functional: Groups of employees based on work performed (e.g. engineering, accounting, information systems, human resources).

(2) Product: Groups of employees based on major product areas in the corporation (e.g. women’s footwear, men’s footwear, and apparel and accessories).

(3) Customer: Groups of employees based on customer’s problem and needs (e.g. wholesale, retail, government).

(4) Geographic: Groups of employees based on location served (e.g. North, South, Midwest, East).

(5) Process: Groups of employees based on the basis of work or customers flow (e.g. testing, payment).

Question 61
In Transactional Analysis, if the response is by the same ego state as through which the message was received, the transaction is called
  • A.Crossed Transaction
  • B.Complementary Transaction
  • C.Ulterior Transaction
  • D.Feed-forward Transaction
Correct Answer: Complementary Transaction

Within ego states of Transaction Analysis, there are three different types of transaction: complementary, crossed, and ulterior

 

Complementary Transactions A complementary transaction occurs when the sender of the message gets the intended response from the receiver. For example, an employee makes a mistake and, wanting some sympathy, apologizes to the boss .Employee ­ `I just dropped the thing when I was almost done. Now I have to do it all over again. 'Supervisor ­ `It happens to all of us; don't worry about it.'

 

Crossed transactions occur when the sender of the message does not get the expected response from the receiver. Returning to our first example: Employee ­ `I just dropped the thing when I was almost done. Now I have to do it all over again.' Supervisor ­ `you are so clumsy.'

 

Ulterior, or hidden transactions occur when the words seem to be coming from one ago state, but in reality the words or behaviors are coming from another. For example, after a training program, one of the participants came up to a consultant asking advice on an adult ego sate. When the consultant gave advice, the participant twice had quick responses as to why the advice would not work (child rather than adult behavior). The consultant realized that what the participant actually wanted was sympathetic understanding for his situation, not advice. The consultant stopped making suggestions and listened actively, using reflective responses. The consultant changed from the adult to the sympathetic parent ego state in order to have a complimentary transaction

Question 62
Which of the following is not type of Informal Group?
  • A.Friendship Groups
  • B.Interest Groups
  • C.Command Groups
  • D.Reference Group
Correct Answer: Command Groups

Formal groups: Different Types of Formal Groups:

1. Permanent and Temporary Formal Groups.

 

2. Command Group such as sections, department etc.

 

3. Functional Groups are classified according to functions of the members of the groups such as clerks, typists, etc. These groups possess the authority of both command groups and functional groups.

 

Functional groups can again be classified into:

(a) Team group specifies no fixed role to its members.

(b) Task group specifies a fixed job to each of its members.

(c) Technological group is allotted the roles by the management.

 

4. Status Groups involve the members of the same status in the organization.

 

Informal groups, on the other hand, arise spontaneously and serve various social purposes. Here are some types of informal groups:

 

Friendship Groups: These groups form based on shared characteristics like age, ethnicity, or common interests, as members enjoy each other's company.

 

Interest Groups: Comprised of individuals from different organizations united by a shared interest, like university professors organizing seminars on specific topics.

 

Reference Group: Individuals use these groups to evaluate themselves, whether actual or imagined, often consisting of scholars or professionals in the same field.

 

Cliques: Close-knit groups within a larger organization, categorized as vertical (same department), horizontal (similar rank), or mixed (both).

 

Sub-cliques: Groups within cliques that include outsiders.

 

Isolates: Individuals who are not part of any group within the organization.

Question 63
Theodore Newcomb was thepropounderof which of the following theories of Group Formation?
  • A.Propinquity Theory
  • B.Homan’s Theory
  • C.Balance Theory
  • D.Exchange Theory
Correct Answer: Balance Theory

Theories of Group Formation: There are 4 important theories of group formation:

 

1. Propinquity Theory: The most basic theory explaining affiliation is propinquity. This word simply means that individuals affiliate with one another because of spatial or geographical proximity. In an organisation employees who work in the same area of the plant or office or managers with offices close to one another would more probably form into groups than would those who are not physically located together.

 

2. Homan’s Theory: According to George C. Homans, “The more activities persons share, the more numerous will be there interactions and the stronger will be their shared activities and sentiments, and the more sentiments people have for one another, the more will be their shared activities and interactions.”

 

It is a very comprehensive theory and based on activities, interactions and Homan’s theory is based on sentiments. These three elements are directly related to each other.

 

3. Balance Theory: Another very comprehensive theory is a Balance Theory of group formation. This theory as proposed by Theodore Newcomb states that “Persons are attracted to one another on the basis of similar attitudes towards commonly relevant objects and goals. Once a relationship is formed, it strives to maintain a symmetrical balance between the attraction and the common attitudes. If an imbalance occurs, attempts are made to restore the balance. If the balance cannot be restored, the relationship dissolves.”

 

4. Exchange Theory: This theory is based on reward-cost outcomes of interactions. To be attracted towards a group, a person thinks in terms of what he will get in exchange of interaction with group members. A minimum positive level (rewards greater than costs) of an outcome must exist in order for attraction or affiliation to take place. Rewards from interactions gratify needs while costs incur anxiety, frustrations, embarrassment or fatigue. Propinquity, interaction and common attitudes all have roles in the exchange theory.

Question 64
The ___________is used by management, where leaders focus on motivating followers through a system of rewards and punishments. There are two factors which form the basis for this system, Contingent Reward and management-by-exception.
  • A.Transactional leadership
  • B.Transformational leadership
  • C.Laissez-faire leadership
  • D.Democratic leadership
Correct Answer: Transactional leadership

A Transformational leader is a type of person in which the leader is not limited by his or her followers' perception. The main objective is to work to change or transform his or her followers' needs and redirect their thinking. Leaders that follow the transformation style of leading, challenge and inspire their followers with a sense of purpose and excitement.

 

The Transactional style of leadership was first described by Max Weber in 1947 and then later described by Bernard Bass in 1981. Mainly used by management, transactional leaders focus their leadership on motivating followers through a system of rewards and punishments. There are two factors which form the basis for this system, Contingent Reward and management-by-exception.

 

The Laissez-faire leadership style is where all the rights and power to make decisions is fully given to the worker.

 

The Democratic leadership style consists of the leader sharing the decision-making abilities with group members by promoting the interests of the group members and by practicing social equality.

Question 65
The regulation of State Co-operative Banks (StCBs) and District Central Co-operative Banks (DCCBs) vests with the _________. Their supervision is carried out by the _____________.
  • A.Registrar of Cooperative Societies, NABARD
  • B.NABARD, Registrar of Cooperative Societies
  • C.RBI, NABARD
  • D.NABARD, RBI
Correct Answer: RBI, NABARD

Regulation of State Co-operative Banks (StCBs) and District Central Co-operative Banks (DCCBs) is overseen by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). Their supervision, however, falls under the purview of the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD).

 

Rural credit co-operatives play a crucial role in providing affordable credit to farmers, addressing rural indebtedness, and alleviating poverty. The long-term co-operative credit structure comprises State Co-operative Agriculture and Rural Development Banks (SCARDBs) at the apex level and Primary Co-operative Agriculture and Rural Development Banks (PCARDBs) at the district or block level. NABARD regulates these institutions to meet long-term credit needs in agriculture.

 

Conversely, the short-term co-operative credit structure (STCCS) primarily caters to crop and working capital requirements. The pyramid of STCCS operates in a three-tier federal structure within a state. At the apex level is the State Co-operative Bank (StCB), followed by District Central Co-operative Banks (DCCBs) at the district level, and Primary Agricultural Credit Societies (PACS) at the village level.

 

While PACS are regulated by the respective State Registrar of Cooperative Societies, the RBI regulates StCBs and DCCBs, similar to Urban Co-operative Banks (UCBs)

Question 66
Except one choice, following are basic function of RBI. Identify the one.
  • A.It regulates the issue of Bank notes.
  • B.Maintains reserves with a view to securing monetary stability in India,
  • C.Maintain price stability while keeping in mind the objective of growth
  • D.Appointment of CMDs andChairmansof PSU Banks.
Correct Answer: Appointment of CMDs andChairmansof PSU Banks.

Option D is not the function of RBI but is performed by the Bank Board Bureau.

 

The Preamble of the Reserve Bank of India describes its basic functions:

(1) It regulates the issue of Bank notes,

(2) Maintains reserves with a view to securing monetary stability in India.

(3) It operates the currency and credit system of the country to its advantage.

(4) It has a modern monetary policy framework to meet the challenge of an increasingly complex economy.

(5) It maintain price stability while keeping in mind the objective of growth.

Question 67
Some of the committees, which contributed to Banking Sector reforms, are given below.List I(i)NachiketMore Committee(ii) P JNayakCommittee(iii)UrjitPatel Committee(iv) Rattan PWatalCommitteeList II(a) Governance of Boards of Bank in India- 2014(b) For comprehensive financial services for small businesses and low-income households- 2013(c) To examine the current monetary policy framework- 2014(d) To boost digital payment system in India - 2016
  • A.(i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)
  • B.(i)-(a), (ii)-(b), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)
  • C.(i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(d), (iv)-(c)
  • D.(i)-(c), (ii)-(b), (iii)-(a), (iv)-(d)
Correct Answer: (i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)

Two expert Committees were set up under the chairmanship of M. Narasimham for reforms in the Banking Sector. The First Committee submitted its report in 1991 and Second in 1998. These recommendations not only helped unleash the potential of banking in India, they are also recognized as a factor towards minimizing the impact of global financial crisis starting in 2007.

 

Some of other committees, which contributed to Banking Sector reforms, are:

1. Nachiket More Committee- For comprehensive financial services for small businesses and low-income households- 2013

2. P J Nayak Committee- Governance of Boards of Bank in India- 2014

3. Urjit Patel Committee - To examine the current monetary policy framework- 2014

4. Rattan P Watal Committee - To boost digital payment system in India - 2016

Question 68
Call/Notice/Term Money refers to lending/borrowing of funds on uncollateralized basis among scheduled commercial banks. The lending/borrowing is for ___ day(s) in case of Term Money, for ____________ day(s) in case of Notice Money and for _________ day(s) in case of Call Money
  • A.1, 7, 14
  • B.1, 2 to 14, more than 14
  • C.2 to 14, 1, more than 14
  • D.More than 14, 2 to 14, 1
Correct Answer: More than 14, 2 to 14, 1

Call/Notice/Term Money refers to lending/borrowing of funds on uncollateralized basis among scheduled commercial banks, cooperative banks and the PDs. The lending/borrowing is for one day in case of Call Money, while it is for a period between 2 days to 14 days in case of Notice Money. The Call/Notice Money transactions take place either on NDSCall, a screen–based, negotiated, quote-driven electronic trading system managed by the Clearing Corporation of India (CCIL), or over the counter (OTC).

 

The Term Money means borrowing and lending of funds for a period of more than 14 days.

Question 69
As per the PFRDA circular of 2023, NPS subscribers can select a maximum of _______ pension fund managers for different asset classes.
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 3

Option B is the correct answer.

 

In November 2023, the Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority (PFRDA) issued a circular stating that now National Pension System (NPS) investors can choose different pension fund managers for different asset classes. According to PFRDA’s latest circular, NPS subscribers can select a maximum of three pension fund managers for different asset classes. An individual is allowed to invest in different asset classes, i.e., equity, (E), government bonds (G), corporate bonds (c) and alternate asset class (A). Previously, this option to choose multiple pension fund managers was not available. Once the pension fund manager was selected, the money invested in the NPS in all the asset classes would be handled by that pension fund manager.

 

In layman's terms, an NPS investor can now select a top-performing fund manager in each asset class. For instance, a subscriber can choose the HDFC Pension Fund Manager for equities, the SBI Pension Fund Manager for government securities, Kotak Pension Fund Manager for corporate bonds.

Question 70
A Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) as defined in the RBI Act, 1934 is permitted to be engaged in the following activities, under the "Principal Business criteria":(a) Lending or financing(b) Agriculture operations(c) Industrial activity(d) Acquisition of shares / stocks / bonds/ debentures/securities issued by Government or local authority(e) Leasing & hire-purchase
  • A.(a), (b), (e)
  • B.(a), (d), (e)
  • C.(a), (b), (d), (e)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (d), (e)

A Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) as defined in the RBI Act, 1934 is a Company registered under the Companies Act and engaged in the business of:

  • Lending or financing
  • Acquisition of shares / stocks / bonds/ debentures/securities issued by Government or local authority
  • Leasing & hire-purchase
  • Insurance business
  • Chit business
  • Collection of monies
  • Acceptance of deposits

 

but does NOT include any company which carries on its principal business in:

  • Agriculture operations,
  • Industrial activity
  • Purchase or sale of any goods (other than securities)
  • Providing any services and
  • Sale / purchase / construction of immovable property.

 

Only those NBFCs that satisfy the 'Principal Business criteria' defined by the RBI will get themselves registered with the RBI and these entities will be regulated and supervised by RBI. Financial activity as “principal business” is when a company's financial assets constitute more than 50 per cent of the total assets and income from financial assets constitute more than 50 per cent of the gross income. A company, which fulfils both these criteria, will be registered as NBFC by the RBI.

Question 71
These Prepaid Instruments PPIs are issued only by banks (approved by RBI) and are used at any merchant for purchase of goods and services, including financial services, remittance facilities, etc. Cash withdrawal at ATMs / Points of Sale (PoS) terminals / Business Correspondents (BCs) are also allowed through such PPIs.
  • A.Closed System PPIs
  • B.Semi-Closed System PPIs
  • C.Open System PPIs
  • D.Semi-Open System PPIs
Correct Answer: Open System PPIs

Prepaid Instruments (PPIs)

PPIs are instruments that facilitate purchase of goods and services, including financial services, remittance facilities, etc., against the value stored on such instruments. PPIs that can be issued in the country are classified under three types viz. (i) Closed System PPIs, (ii) Semi-closed System PPIs, and (iii) Open System PPIs.

 

Closed System PPIs: These PPIs are issued by an entity for facilitating the purchase of goods and services from that entity only and do not permit cash withdrawal.

 

Semi-closed System PPIs: These PPIs are issued by banks (approved by RBI) and non-banks (authorized by RBI) for purchase of goods and services, including financial services, remittance facilities, etc., at a group of clearly identified merchant locations / establishments which have a specific contract with the issuer (or contract through a payment aggregator / payment gateway) to accept the PPIs as payment instruments. These instruments do not permit cash withdrawal, irrespective of whether they are issued by banks or non-banks.

 

Open System PPIs: These PPIs are issued only by banks (approved by RBI) and are used at any merchant for purchase of goods and services, including financial services, remittance facilities, etc. Cash withdrawal at ATMs / Points of Sale (PoS) terminals / Business Correspondents (BCs) are also allowed through such PPIs.

 

The PPIs may be issued as cards, wallets, and any such form / instrument which can be used to access the PPI and to use the amount therein. PPIs in the form of paper vouchers are no longer be issued.

Question 72
Which of the following is not one of major components of marketing mix?
  • A.Product
  • B.Price
  • C.Plan
  • D.Place
Correct Answer: Plan

The Marketing mix is the set of marketing tools that the firm uses to pursue its marketing objectives in the target market. As shown in figure, McCarthy classified these tools into four broad groups that he called the “four Ps of marketing”: Product, Price, Place, and Promotion. For marketing of services, three additional P’s have been identified, People, Process and Physical evidence.

Question 73
Firm uses any existing brand to introduce in market as a new product, brand is classified as
  • A.Brand Extension
  • B.Sub-Brand
  • C.Parent Brand
  • D.Product Extension
Correct Answer: Brand Extension

Brand Extensions: A company may use its existing brand name to launch new products in other categories. If a car dealer enters into car insurance business, it will be brand extension. An associated risk is brand dilution, which occurs when consumers no longer associate a brand with a specific product or highly similar products.

Question 74
Arrange the stages of Product Life Cycle in correct order:(i) Introduction(ii) Growth(iii) Stability(iv) Maturity(v) Decline(vi) Expansion
  • A.i, ii, iii and iv
  • B.ii, iii, iv and v
  • C.i, ii, iv and v
  • D.i, ii, iv and vi
Correct Answer: i, ii, iv and v

The correct order of the stages in the Product Life Cycle is as follows:

 

(i) Introduction: This is the stage where the product is launched into the market for the first time. It involves creating awareness among consumers and initial sales are typically slow.

 

(ii) Growth: In this stage, the product begins to gain acceptance in the market, leading to a rapid increase in sales. Profitability also starts to improve as production volumes increase and marketing efforts become more effective.

 

(iv) Maturity: At this stage, the product reaches its peak level of sales and market saturation. Competition intensifies, and companies may focus on product differentiation or cost reduction strategies to maintain market share.

 

(v) Decline: In the decline stage, sales start to decrease due to factors such as changing consumer preferences, technological advancements, or the introduction of newer products. Companies may choose to discontinue the product or invest minimally in its promotion.

 

The correct sequence, therefore, is (C) i, ii, iv, and v.

Question 75
According to the _________ Model of Consumer behaviour, there are 3 levels of decision making, namely extensive problem solving, limited problem solving and habitual problem solving.
  • A.Nicosia
  • B.EngelKollatBlackwell
  • C.HowardSheth
  • D.Keller
Correct Answer: HowardSheth

The Howard Sheth Model of Consumer Behavior outlines three levels of decision making: extensive problem solving, limited problem solving, and habitual problem solving. At the first level, known as extensive problem solving, consumers lack information and preferences for brands, leading them to seek information about various options before making a purchase. Limited problem solving, the second level, occurs when consumers have some knowledge but still require comparative brand information to establish a preference. Finally, habitual response behavior characterizes the third level, where consumers possess sufficient knowledge to differentiate between brands and have already decided on a particular product.

Question 76
Marketing segmentations division of market into separate homogeneous group of customer on the basis of(i) Geographical variables(ii) Demographic factors(iii) Psychographic factors(iv) Behavioural basis
  • A.i, ii and iii
  • B.i, ii, and iv
  • C.ii, iii and iv
  • D.All of these
Correct Answer: All of these

A market can be segmented on the basis of the following variables:

1. Geographic Segmentation: The characteristics of customers often differ across nations, states, regions cities or neighborhoods. The marketer can decide to operate in one or a few or all the geographic areas, but pay attention to differences in geographic needs and preferences.

2. Demographic Segmentation: Variables such as age, sex, family size, income, occupation, education, religion, race and nationality are widely used for market segmentation.

3. Psychological Variables: Personality, life style, social class, value, etc. can also be used for market segmentation. For example, some products like pens, watches, cosmetics and briefcases are designed differently for common men and status seekers.

4. Behavioural Segmentation: Buyers are divided into groups on the basis of their knowledge, attitude, use or response to a product.

Question 77
Pricing strategy, in which an organization sells multiple variants of same product at different prices, is called
  • A.Optional Pricing
  • B.Product Line Pricing
  • C.Competitive Pricing
  • D.Captive Pricing
Correct Answer: Product Line Pricing

Product Line Pricing: Since firms usually develop product lines rather than single products, product line pricing plays a decisive role in product mix pricing strategies. For example, when you look at a car brand such as Audi, you will see a relation between the different series and their prices. The entry model, the Audi A1, does cost you less than the top-range car A8.

Question 78
Which of the following is not one of reasons of the Channel Conflict in Integrated Channel Management?
  • A.Technological Changes
  • B.Goal Incompatibility
  • C.Role Ambiguity
  • D.Differences in Perceptions of the Market
Correct Answer: Technological Changes

Reasons for channel conflict in integrated channel management stem from various factors, but technological changes are not one of them.

 

Goal Incompatibility: Conflict often arises due to differing goals between manufacturers and wholesalers. Manufacturers may prioritize long-term market share and profit maximization, while wholesalers focus on sales maximization and immediate profit.

 

Role Ambiguity: Conflict can occur when roles within the channel are unclear or ambiguous, leading to misunderstandings and disagreements.

 

Differences in Perceptions of the Market: Varied perceptions of the market and economy can create conflict between manufacturers and middlemen. For example, manufacturers may see opportunities in expanding product lines or territories, while existing dealers may view these changes as threats to their control over the market.

Question 79
You have just taken a new position in an organization and you are learning about the job functions of your new colleagues. You observe that your marketing manager is heavily involved in the process of building and maintaining profitable customer relationships. Your marketing manager frequently speaks about the need to deliver superior customer value and satisfaction. Your manager is concerned with which one of the following?
  • A.The Societal Marketing Concept
  • B.Donor Marketing
  • C.Database Marketing
  • D.Customer Relationship Management
Correct Answer: Customer Relationship Management

Customer Relationship Management (CRM) implies building stronger relationships with customers. CRM’s aim is to produce high customer equity, which is the total of the discounted lifetime values of all of the firm’s customers. The CRM is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer touch points to maximize customer loyalty.

 

The drivers of CRM include:

  • Value equity (sub-drivers are quality, price, and convenience),
  • Brand equity (sub-drivers are customer brand awareness, customer attitude, customer perception of brand ethics),
  • Relationship equity (sub-drivers are loyalty programs, special recognition and treatment programs, community and knowledge building programs).
Question 80
The _________ is an advertising strategy that focuses on low-cost unconventional marketing tactics that yield maximum results. The original term was coined by Jay Conrad Levinson in his 1984 book.
  • A.Right-Time Marketing
  • B.Demand Chain
  • C.Services Marketing
  • D.Guerrilla Marketing
Correct Answer: Guerrilla Marketing

Guerrilla Marketing is a marketing tactic in which a company uses surprise and/or unconventional interactions in order to promote a product or service. Guerrilla marketing is different from traditional marketing in that it often relies on personal interaction, has a smaller budget, and focuses on smaller groups of promoters that are responsible for getting the word out in a particular location rather than through widespread media campaigns.

Question 81
“The manufacturer reminds the channel partner to carry out their activities in accordance with the contract they have entered into at the time they became the channel partners”, refers to which one of the following channel power?
  • A.Referent power
  • B.Coercive power
  • C.Legitimate power
  • D.Reward power
Correct Answer: Legitimate power

Legitimate Power: Here the manufacturer reminds the channel partner to carry out their activities in accordance with the contract they have entered into at the time they became the channel partners. The manufacturer may find it convenient to keep a check on the channel partners in terms of their signed agreement, but the partners may feel humiliated for the continuous reminder for their code of conduct.

Question 82
X transfers possession or custody of the farmland to his son, S. S shall pay rent or a lease fee in return. S only receives custody and control of the property, but X still owns it. X is thus responsible for paying the property taxes and is liable for what happens on the land. This kind of contract or arrangement is called:
  • A.Guarantee
  • B.Bailment
  • C.Pledge
  • D.Indemnity
Correct Answer: Bailment

Contract of Bailment:

Bailment refers to a transaction where one person delivers goods to another for a specific purpose, with an agreement that they will be returned or disposed of as instructed once the purpose is fulfilled. The person delivering the goods is the bailor, while the recipient is the bailee.

 

Bailment involves the voluntary delivery of goods for a temporary purpose, with the understanding that they will be returned to the bailor. Ownership of the goods remains with the bailor, with the bailee having only possession. Delivery of goods can be actual or constructive, such as handing over the key to a warehouse, which signifies delivery of goods stored within.

Question 83
Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the points of distinction between Sale and Agreement to Sell?
  • A.In sale, the seller can sue the buyer for the price of the goods whereas in agreement to sell, the aggrieved party can sue for damages only and not for the price, unless the price was payable at a stated date.
  • B.In sale, a subsequent loss or destruction of the goods is the liability of the buyer, whereas Such loss or destruction is the liability of the seller.
  • C.Sale creates Jus in rem, whereas creates Jus inpersonam.
  • D.Sale is an executory contract, whereas Agreement to Sell is an executed contract.
Correct Answer: Sale is an executory contract, whereas Agreement to Sell is an executed contract.

Sale is an executed contract i.e. contract for which consideration has been paid, whereas Agreement to Sell is an executory contract i.e. contract for which consideration is to be paid at a future date.

Question 84
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to Negotiable Instruments Act. 1881?
  • A.The holder of the instrument is presumed to be the owner of the property contained in it.
  • B.Negotiable instruments are not freely transferable.
  • C.A holder in due course gets the instrument free from all defects of title of any previous holder.
  • D.Negotiability involves two elements namely, transferability free from equities and transferability by delivery or endorsement.
Correct Answer: Negotiable instruments are not freely transferable.

The term “negotiable instrument” means a document transferable from one person to another. However, the Act has not defined the term. It merely says that “A negotiable instrument” means a promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque payable either to order or to bearer.

 

According to this definition the following are the conditions of negotiability:

(i) The instrument should be freely transferable. An instrument cannot be negotiable unless it is such and in such state that the true owner could transfer by simple delivery or endorsement and delivery.

(ii) The person who takes it for value and in good faith is not affected by the defect in the title of the transferor.

(iii) Such a person can sue upon the instrument in his own name.

Question 85
Under the provisions of Companies Act, 2013, which companies are exempted to add “Ltd.” or “Pvt.Ltd.” at the end of their name?
  • A.Banking Companies
  • B.Insurance Companies
  • C.Government Companies
  • D.Association not for profits
Correct Answer: Association not for profits

Association not for profits are exempted to add “Ltd.” or “Pvt. Ltd.” at the end of their name.

Question 86
Select which is the characteristic feature Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)among the following statements.
  • A.It is not mandatory for an LLP to prepare a statement of accounts and solvency every year and file with the Registrar.
  • B.It is mandatory for a LLP to have a common seal.
  • C.No partner is responsible for any other partner’s misconduct.
  • D.An LLP cannot be wound up by the order of Tribunal.
Correct Answer: No partner is responsible for any other partner’s misconduct.

Statement C is correct. In an LLP, no partner is responsible for any other partner’s misconduct.

 

LLP is a corporate business vehicle that enables professional expertise and entrepreneurial initiative to combine and operate in flexible, innovative and efficient manner, providing benefits of limited liability while allowing its members the flexibility for organizing their internal structure as a partnership.

 

There must be at least two designated partners in every LLP of whom one shall be resident in India. There is no maximum limit on the partners in LLP.

Question 87
In vertical agreements, which of the following agreements in respect of production, supply, distribution, storage, sale or price of, or trade in goods or provision of services shall be a void agreement?
  • A.Agreement requiring a purchaser of goods, as a condition of such purchase, to purchase some other goods.
  • B.Agreement which restricts, or is likely to restrict, by any method the persons or classes of persons to whom goods are sold or from whom goods are bought.
  • C.Agreement restricting in any manner the purchaser in the course of his trade from acquiring or otherwise dealing in any goods other than those of the seller or any other person.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Under the Competition Act, 2002, in vertical agreements, any agreement amongst enterprises or persons at different stages or levels of the production chain in different markets, in respect of production, supply, distribution, storage, sale or price of, or trade in goods or provision of services shall be a void agreement if it causes or is likely to cause an appreciable adverse effect on competition in India including:

(a) tie-in arrangement - includes any agreement requiring a purchaser of goods, as a condition of such purchase, to purchase some other goods;

(b) exclusive supply agreement - includes any agreement restricting in any manner the purchaser in the course of his trade from acquiring or otherwise dealing in any goods other than those of the seller or any other person;

(c) exclusive distribution agreement- includes any agreement to limit, restrict or withhold the output or supply of any goods or allocate any area or market for the disposal or sale of the goods;

(d) refusal to deal - includes any agreement which restricts, or is likely to restrict, by any method the persons or classes of persons to whom goods are sold or from whom goods are bought;

(e) resale price maintenance - includes any agreement to sell goods on condition that the prices to be charged on the resale by the purchaser shall be the prices stipulated by the seller unless it is clearly stated that prices lower than those prices may be charged.

Question 88
Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to Cyber Appellate Tribunal under Information and Technology Act, 2002?
  • A.A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Chairperson of the Cyber Appellate Tribunal unless he is qualified to be a Judge of a Supreme Court.
  • B.A person shall not be appointed as a Member, unless he has held the post of Additional Secretary for a period of not less than 1 year or Joint Secretary for a period of not less than 7 years.
  • C.Any person aggrieved by any decision or order of the Cyber Appellate Tribunal could file an appeal to the High Court within 60 days from the date of communication of the decision or order of the Cyber Appellate Tribunal.
  • D.The Chairperson or Member shall hold office for a term of 5 years or until he attains the age of 65 years, whichever is earlier.
Correct Answer: A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Chairperson of the Cyber Appellate Tribunal unless he is qualified to be a Judge of a Supreme Court.

Statement A is incorrect as a person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Chairperson of the Cyber Appellate Tribunal unless he is qualified to be a Judge of a High Court.

Question 89
Whenwas the Right to Information Actcame into force?
  • A.October 2005
  • B.December 2005
  • C.April 2005
  • D.June 2005
Correct Answer: October 2005

The Right to Information (RTI) Act was passed by Parliament on 15 June 2005 and came into force on 12 October 2005 to provide for the setting out the practical regime of right to information for citizens to secure access to information under the control of public authorities, in order to promote transparency and accountability in the working of every public authority.

Question 90
For each of the following intellectual property examples, match the area of IP law that would be most appropriate for their protection.List I(a) A company wishes to ensure that no one else can use their logo(b) A singer wishes to assign the rights to reproduce a video she has made of her concert(c) A new way to process milk so that there is no fat in any cheese made from it(d) A company decides to use a logo that has the same shape as its competitor but with a differentcolorList II(i) Patent(ii) Trade Mark(iii) Industrial Design(iv) Copy Right
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

The correct matching of the intellectual property examples with the area of IP law for their protection is as follows:

 

(a) A company wishes to ensure that no one else can use their logo - Trade Mark (ii)

(b) A singer wishes to assign the rights to reproduce a video she has made of her concert - Copy Right (iv)

(c) A new way to process milk so that there is no fat in any cheese made from it - Patent (i)

(d) A company decides to use a logo that has the same shape as its competitor but with a different color - Industrial Design (iii)

 

So, the correct option is (D) (ii) (iv) (i) (iii).

Question 91
GST was first mooted in which year and by whichCommittee?
  • A.2001, byUrjitPatel Committee
  • B.2003; byKelkarTask Force
  • C.2007, byUdayKotak Committee
  • D.2010, by P JNaikCommittee
Correct Answer: 2003; byKelkarTask Force

Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax. GST was first mooted in the year 2003 by Kelkar Task Force on indirect taxes, who had suggested subsuming various central and state indirect taxes into one indirect tax. To implement this vision, an Empowered Committee known as Kelkar committee of State Finance Ministers was created and tasked with the responsibility of ironing out the differences and taking this monumental reform forward.

Question 92
Income of the previous year is not taxable in the subsequent assessment year for which combination of the following?I. Income of non-resident from shippingII. Income of casual natureIII. Income of bodies formed for short durationIV. Income of a person trying to alienate his assets
  • A.I, II, III
  • B.II, III, IV
  • C.I, II, IV
  • D.I, III, IV
Correct Answer: I, III, IV

Income earned during a previous year is typically taxed in the subsequent assessment year. However, there are exceptions to this rule. These exceptions include:

 

I. Income from Shipping Business of Non-Residents (Sec. 172): Seven and a half percent (7.5%) of the total freight, including demurrage charge and handling charge, earned at Indian ports by the owner, charter, or any other person on their behalf, is deemed to be taxable income.

 

II. Persons Leaving India (Sec. 174): If it appears to the Assessing Officer that an individual may leave India and has no present intention of returning, the total income of such individual up to the probable date of departure from India is assessed to income tax in that assessment year.

 

III. Persons Transferring Property to Avoid Tax or Persons Trying to Alienate their Assets with a View to Avoid Tax (Sec. 175): The total income of such persons up to the date when the Assessing Officer commences proceedings against them is chargeable to tax in that assessment year.

 

IV. Income of Discontinued Business or Profession (Sec. 176): In cases of discontinued businesses or professions, the income from the expiry of the previous year for that assessment year up to the date of discontinuance may be assessed in that assessment year at the discretion of the Assessing Officer.

 

V. Assessment of Association of Person or Body of Individuals or Artificial Juridical Person Formed for a Particular Event or Purpose (Sec.174 A): When it appears to the assessing officer that any association of persons, body of individuals, or artificial juridical person formed or established for a particular event or purpose is likely to be dissolved in the assessment year in which it was formed or immediately after, the total income of such entity for the period from the expiry of the previous year for that assessment year up to the date of its dissolution is chargeable to tax in that assessment year.

Question 93
Select the combination of exempted incomes from income given below under the Income Tax Act, 1961?(i) Amount received as educational scholarship.(ii) Compensation received at the time of Retrenchment to the extent ofRs. 5,00,000.(iii) Interest and remuneration received by the Partner from the firm/ LLP.(iv) Interest credited to Statutory Provident fund in the hands of the employee.(v) Interest Income received by person of Indian origin, who is a non-resident on notified savings certificates issued before 1stJune 2002 by the Central Government.(vi) Gratuity received by Government employee.
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (v), (vi)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v), (vi)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iv), (v), (vi)

All are exempted incomes from those mentioned in the question except (iii) above.

(i) Any amount received as educational scholarship (i.e., scholarship to meet the cost of education is exempt from tax in the hands of recipient).

 

(ii) As per section 10(10B), compensation received at the time of retrenchment is exempt from tax to the extent of lower of the following:

  • An amount calculated in accordance with the provisions of section 25F(b) of the Industrial Dispute Act, 1947; or
  • Maximum amount specified by the Central Government (Rs. 5,00,000);
  • Actual amount received.

 

(iii) As per section 10(2A), share of profit received by a partner from a firm is exempt from tax in the hands of the partner. Further, share of profit received by a partner of LLP from the LLP will be exempt from tax in the hands of such partner. This exemption is limited only to share of profit and does not apply to interest on capital and remuneration received by the partner from the firm/LLP.

 

(iv) Statutory Provident Fund is set up under the provisions of Provident Fund Act, 1925 and is maintained by Government and Semi-Government organisations, local authorities, railways, universities and recognised educational institutions.

 

Taxability as per the Income Tax Act, 1961:

  • Employer’s contribution to provident fund – Exempt
  • Deduction under Section 80C – Available for employee’s own contribution
  • Interest credited to provident fund – Exempt
  • Payment at retirement or termination of service – Exempt

 

(v) As per section 10(4B), in the case of an individual, being a citizen of India or a person of Indian origin, who is a non-resident, any income by way of interest on notified savings certificates (subscribed in convertible foreign exchange) issued before the 1st day of June, 2002 by the Central Government is exempt from tax.

 

(vi) Section 10(10)(i) grants exemption to gratuity received by Government employee (i.e., Central Government or State Government or local authority).

Question 94
Mr. Raja purchased a residential house in April, 2014 and sold the same on 25th April, 2019 forRs. 8,40,000. Capital gain arising on sale of house amounted toRs. 1,00,000. Out of the sale proceeds of old house, he purchased another residential house forRs. 80,000. This house was purchased in May, 2019. What will be the amount of exemption under section 54 which can be claimed by Mr. Raja?
  • A.Rs. 80,000
  • B.Rs. 1,00,000
  • C.Rs. 20,000
  • D.Nil
Correct Answer: Rs. 80,000

Exemption under section 54 can be claimed in respect of capital gains arising on transfer of capital asset, being long-term residential house property. Exemption under section 54 will be lower of the following:

(a) Amount of capital gains arising on transfer of residential house; or

(b) Amount invested in purchase/construction of new residential house property

 

Considering the above provisions, the exemption in this case will be lower of the following amount:

(a) Amount of capital gain, i.e., Rs. 1,00,000.

(b) Amount of investment in new house, i.e., Rs. 80,000

 

Thus, exemption will be Rs. 80,000. Taxable capital gain will come to Rs. 20,000 (Rs. 1,00,000 less exemption under section 54 of Rs. 80,000).

Question 95
Identify the combination of incorrect statements from the following with respect to inter head adjustment of losses.(i) Before making inter-head adjustment, the taxpayer has to first make intra-head adjustment.(ii) Loss from business and profession can be set off against income chargeable to tax under the head “Salaries”.(iii) Non-speculative business loss can be set off against income from speculative business.(iv) Loss from the business of owning and maintaining race horses can be set off against any other income.(v) Loss from the business of owning and maintaining race horses cannot be set off against any other income.(vi) Any loss can be set off against income from winnings from lotteries, crossword puzzles, race including horse race, card game, and any other game of any sort or from gambling or betting of any form or nature.
  • A.(i), (iii), (v)
  • B.(i), (iv), (vi)
  • C.(ii), (v), (vi)
  • D.(ii), (iv), (vi)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iv), (vi)

Statements (i), (iii), and (v) are accurate, while statements (ii), (iv), and (vi) are inaccurate. The Act outlines certain restrictions to consider before proceeding with inter-head adjustment:

  • Before conducting inter-head adjustment, the taxpayer must first address intra-head adjustment.
  • Loss from speculative business cannot offset any other income. However, non-speculative business loss can offset income from speculative business.
  • Losses under the "Capital gains" head cannot be offset against income from other heads.
  • No loss can offset income from lotteries, crossword puzzles, races (including horse races), card games, gambling, or betting.
  • Loss from the business of owning and maintaining racehorses cannot offset any other income.
  • Loss from businesses specified under section 35AD cannot offset any other income. (Section 35AD applies to specified businesses like establishing a cold chain facility, operating warehousing for agricultural produce, developing housing projects, etc.)
  • Loss from business and profession cannot offset income taxed under the "Salaries" head.
  • From the assessment year 2018-19, loss under the "House property" head can only be set off against other income up to Rs. 2,00,000 for any assessment year.

However, unabsorbed losses can be carried forward for set-off in subsequent years as per the provisions of section 71B.

Question 96
Dividend received from an Indian company which has suffered dividend distribution tax is exempt from tax under section__________.
  • A.10(32)
  • B.10(33)
  • C.10(34)
  • D.10(38)
Correct Answer: 10(34)

Dividend received from an Indian company which has suffered dividend distribution tax is exempt from tax under section 10(34). However, as per section 115BBDA, in the case of a "specified assessee" dividend shall be chargeable to tax at the rate of 10% if aggregate amount of dividend received from a domestic company during the year exceeds Rs. 10,00,000.

 

"Specified Assessee" means a person other than,—

(i) a domestic company; or

(ii) a fund or institution or trust or any university or other educational institution or any hospital or other medical institution referred to in sub-clause (iv) or sub-clause (v) or sub-clause (vi) or sub-clause (via) of clause (23C) of section 10; or

(iii) a trust or institution registered under section 12A or section 12AA.

 

Thus, option C is the correct option.

Question 97
Mr. Raja received a rent ofRs. 1,84,000in respect of letting out of residential building and rent ofRs. 52,200 in respect of providing other amenities like lift services and firefighting facilities during the previous year 2012-13. Hence, rent ofRs. 1,84,000is taxable under the head___________ and rent ofRs. 52,200 is taxable under the head __________.
  • A.House property, Profits and gains of business or profession
  • B.House property, House property
  • C.Income from other sources, Income from other sources
  • D.House property, Income from other sources
Correct Answer: House property, Income from other sources

As per section 56(2), if building is let out along with certain amenities like lift services, air-conditioning, firefighting facilities, etc., then rental income of building is taxable under the head “Income from house property” and rental income of such amenities is taxable under the head “Income from other sources”. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Question 98
Identify the incorrect statement from the following with respect to decision whether to own an asset or obtain an asset on Lease:
  • A.If the expenditure is deductible as revenue expenditure, then cost of financing such expenditure is reduced to the extent of tax saved.
  • B.If the asset is purchased, the interest on capital borrowed to finance investment in plant and machinery can be claimed as deduction.
  • C.If asset is obtained on lease, deduction cannot be claimed in respect of lease rentals and lease management.
  • D.Both B and C are incorrect.
Correct Answer: If asset is obtained on lease, deduction cannot be claimed in respect of lease rentals and lease management.

If asset is obtained on lease, deduction can be claimed in respect of lease rentals and lease management. The related provisions under the Income Tax Act are as follows:

 

Own or Lease an Asset - With the concept of leasing gaining immense popularity in recent times, any business management is faced with the choice to purchase assets or to go in for leasing the asset. One must resolve this issue on economic consideration taking into account the different tax shield effects. If asset is purchased, the assessee can claim depreciation. Besides, interest on capital borrowed to finance investment in plant and machinery can also be claimed as deduction. If, however, asset is obtained on lease, deduction can be claimed in respect of lease rentals and lease management.

 

Repairs, replace, renewal or renovation of assets – The main tax consideration which one has to keep in mind is whether expenditure on repair, replace or renewal is deductible as revenue expenditure under section 30, 31, or 37(1). If the expenditure is deductible as revenue expenditure under these sections, then cost of financing such expenditure is reduced to the extent of tax saved. For instance, if tax rate is 30% and a renewal expenditure of Rs 1,00,000 is allowed as deduction under section 30, 31 or 37(1), then effective out of pocket expenditure is Rs 70,000 (i.e., Rs 1,00,0000 minus 30% of Rs 1,00,000). On the other hand, if such expenditure is not allowed as deduction, then it may be capitalised and, on the amount, so capitalised depreciation is available if certain conditions are satisfied.

Question 99
Find the combination of statements on types of business losses which are allowed under Profits and Gains of Business and Profession.(i) Loss on account of embezzlement by an employee(ii) Loss by the failure of a bank in which money is deposited(iii) Loss on account of robbery or theft in the course of business(iv) Loss incurred in the closing down of a business.(v) Loss incurred due to damage, destruction, etc., of capital assets.(vi) Loss caused on account of fluctuation in exchange rate(vii) Loss due to the sale of securities held as investments(viii) Loss of stock-in-trade by fire or other natural calamities
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(iii), (iv), (v), (vi), (viii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (vi), (viii)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vii)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (vi), (viii)

Business Loss Allowed under Income Tax

The following types of business loss are considered to be incidental to the business and are deductible under the Income Tax Act.

(i) Loss on account of embezzlement by an employee is allowed as a deduction in the year in which such embezzlement is discovered.

(ii) Loss of stock-in-trade by fire or other natural calamities or due to the negligence of employees is deductible.

(iii) Loss on account of robbery or theft provided it is in the course of business and incidental to the trade is deductible.

(iv) Loss caused on account of fluctuation in exchange rate at the time of remitting the money for purchase of raw material is deductible.

(v) Loss caused due to non-recovery of advances made in the course of business, providing it is a trading loss is deductible under the Income Tax Act.

(vi) Loss caused due to a breach of contract for delivery of goods by either party is deductible.

(vii) Loss of raw material or finished goods in transit is tax deductible.

(viii) Loss caused by forfeiture of security deposits given at the time of submission of tenders is deductible.

(ix) Loss by the failure of a bank in which money is deposited is tax deductible.

(x) Any loss incurred due to non-recovery of advance given to salvage the capital, if it is in the revenue field, is an admissible deduction.

Question 100
As per section 207 of the Income Tax Act, ____________ not having any income from business or profession is not liable to pay advance tax.
  • A.A resident individual who is of the age of below 60 years
  • B.A resident HUF
  • C.A non-resident individual
  • D.A resident senior citizen (i.e., an individual of the age of 60 years or above)
Correct Answer: A resident senior citizen (i.e., an individual of the age of 60 years or above)

As per section 207, a resident senior citizen (i.e., an individual of the age of 60 years or above) not having any income from business or profession is not liable to pay advance tax. Thus, option D is the correct option.

Quiz Attempts 91-100 of 849
